abstract: Enfans de Troupe of the French Army
snippet: Enfans de Troupe of the French Army
lead_paragraph: -- The Belgian journals publish the following curious story: A widow lady, named TILMANNE, recently died at Charleroi, and the family of the deceased were three days back assembled at her residence for the purpose of hearing the will read. The Juge de Paix and a notary had arrived, when suddenly the Canon Raoul, cure of the town, who had not been invited, suddenly entered the room. "You are no doubt surprised to see me here, gentlemen," he said. "We are," replied several voices. "Well, reassure yourselves; I have not come to put forward any claim, but simply to make restitution." He then handed to the Juge de Paix a small packet carefully tied up, which, on being opened, was found to contain gold and bank-notes to the amount of 210,000 francs. "This has been intrusted, to me," pursued the cure. "In consequence of an avowal made at the confessional. I do not know the amount, nor do I wish for a receipt." The respected ecclesiastic saluted the company and withdrew.

abstract: Cars and Goods Delivery
snippet: Cars and Goods Delivery
lead_paragraph: -- It is doubtless due to an excessive amiability that the more wealthy City Railway Corporations have been in the habit of extending to a class of tradespeople and housekeepers the privilege of stowing away, under and around the seats in the cars, any conceivable amount of outward or homeward bound stuffs. The privilege is probably just in principle, as well as amiable in intent: but is it not possible that with the dog-days all but in sight, and the rushing stream of City travel day by day swelling in volume, the green grocery and general carrying system in combination with the passenger traffic, may be carried to excess? Immediate contact with a huge pile of superannuated Hebrew clothing stock is not desirable at any time: it is most undesirable in overheated and overcrowded cars. The same may be said of packages of partially dried codfish; of suspicious joints of half-cured pork, and of those promiscuous packages which, in the hands of that sad female "help," lately from the other side of the water, are continually dropping loose in fragmentary bits, to the grief of their possessor, and the discomfort of her fellow-travelers. Nor are the stoppages occasioned by the transfer of the goods, in and out, always so convenient to those with whom time is an element to be taken into account. One may overlook the delays caused by accommodating some overburdened waif, whose very look tells you that he can afford no more than a picayune for the transportation of himself and his entire real and personal estate from one end of the island to the other. But is it possible to be equally complaisant towards that stalwart tailor from the suburbs, who is foisted into the car, actually staggering under a load of military uniforms -- sufficient perhaps to clothe half a company -- and all to be liberally paid for on the instant of delivery?

abstract: Admiral Porter's Account of
snippet: Admiral Porter's Account of
lead_paragraph: in the interesting official report of his late operations up the Red River, gives some details of a curious and horrible affair of which we learned by telegraph. It was a fight between one of his iron-clad vessels and a large body of rebels -- the latter a part of the force which had just gained success over Gen. BANKS. He tells how, flushed with victory, or under the excitement of liquor, they appeared suddenly upon the right bank, and fearlessly opened fire on the Osage, (iron-clad,) she being hard aground at the time, with 2,000 muskets, while the Osage quickly returned a destructive fire upon "these poor deluded wretches," as Admiral PORTER properly calls them. In desperation they strove to capture the gunboat; and force after force seemed to be brought up to the edge of the bank, where they confronted the guns of the iron vessel only to be mowed down by grapeshot and canister. We are told that this drunken and maddened mass of men were led on by their officers, and that their hootings and actions baffled description. In the meantime another gunboat, the Lexington, came up to take part in the fight, and opened a cross fire upon the rebels, which finally decided this curious affair of a fight between infantry and gunboats. The rebels were now mowed down by canister, and finally retreated in as quick haste as they had come to the attack, leaving the space of a mile covered with dead and wounded, and knapsacks. The affair lasted nearly two hours before the rebels fled.

abstract: -- By the new Internal Revenue Bill matches are to be taxed one cent per box. This will be a productive source of revenue without doubt, and will be paid in sums so small that the burden will hardly be felt. To give our readers an idea of the magnitude of the business of match-making, we will give a few statistics of one of the manufacturers of this indispensable article: Mr. CARLETON, of Boston, has three factories, in which he consumes twenty cords of wood and five hundred pounds of brimstone per day. He employs two hundred girls and a number of men, (girls cannot make matches without the cooperation of men.) and on his business alone the Government will receive a revenue of $1,440 per day. At present he is selling his matches at one-third of a cent per box or bunch, so that the tax will amount to three hundred per cent. more than the cost of the article to retailers. There are many other large manufacturers of matches in Massachusetts and New-England, and many others still in other parts of the country. -- National Republican, April 28.

abstract: Paris Constitutionnel and other Papers on New Mexican Empire
snippet: Paris Constitutionnel and other Papers on New Mexican Empire
lead_paragraph: Every one is well aware to what a condition, anarchy, under the form of a Republic, had reduced Mexico. Both France and Europe knew only too well the deplorable state, as far as concerns both her material and moral interests, into which that unfortunate country had fallen, in consequence of the ephemeral and spoliating Governments, scarcely recognized at home and despised abroad. What is less known is that Mexico, already despoiled of half her territory, was the sure and speedy conquest of the United States. The word conquest, however, is too noble; for Mexico was put up to the highest bidder. If the disgraceful contract had been realized, the consequences of it would have seen incalculable, the Latin races would have received a check from which they would with difficulty have recovered. The principles of civilization, which constitute our moral influence in the world, would have been deeply interfered with; that is the idea which the Emperor NAPOLEON III, expressed with extraordinary energy in his letter to the Commander-in-Chief of the French expedition. Mexico, by the re-establishment of the Monarchy, returns into her traditional path, and again finds the true conditions of order and of prosperity, without sacrificing anything of her independence. What a noble mission for the young Prince who accepts it so boldly, and comprehends it so well. France will thus have once more merited well from civilization. Once more short sighted, politicians will have been in the wrong and thanks to the great prudence which presides over our destinies, and to that perseverance which triumphs over obstacles and marches forward to its object with admirable calmness, this regeneration of Mexico which is being prepared will be one of the noblest pages of our civilizing mission in the world.

abstract: Sketch of
snippet: Sketch of
lead_paragraph: I met Gen. DUFF GREEN, the old Washington editor and printer, whom everybody knows, or has heard tell of, at Richmond, in the Fall of 1862. He was then at open war with Mr. Secretary MEMMINGER, and was ready to "buttonhole" any one from the private to the President, who could stand the "bore" of his famous scheme for the development of the South; the perpetual regulation of the treasury and the continuation of the war. But these little things were mere incidents in the General's plans. The great inducement and centre of attraction were the golden promises the scheme presented, and the immense fortunes it held forth to those who were lucky enough to obtain shares in the enterprise.

abstract: The Maori War Resumed
snippet: The Maori War Resumed
lead_paragraph: The war against the Maories is not yet ended, despite the sanguine anticipations to the contrary, which were generally entertained by the Australians after the capture of Rangarirl. Though the natives suffered severely on that occasion, they were not so utterly prostrated as the colonists imagined, and when popular clamor constrained Sir GEORGE GREY to abandon his policy of mercy, and to demand absolute submission on the part of the vanquished, they preferred renewing the contest in conjunction with their former allies, rather than accept such a condition; and so to the number of 3,000 or 4,000, they are now intrenched in a formidable position, where they have constructed a series of strongholds, each fortified with earthworks and stockades, while the ground on all sides is honeycombed with a network of rifle-pits. There, at latest accounts, the native warriors awaited the attack of Gen. CAMERON with as much confidence as if they had never been beaten. The position is one of great strength, and will be stiffly defended, but should the gunboats get within range of the works what possible chance can the Maories have?
headline: {'main': 'The New-Zealand War Again.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The New-Zealand War Again.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The merchants of New-York will be gratified to know that the new Health Officer has commenced his duties in a manner which commends him to their confidence.
lead_paragraph: The merchants of New-York will be gratified to know that the new Health Officer has commenced his duties in a manner which commends him to their confidence. Freedom of all well persons arriving in infected vessels from the restraints of Quarantine; the immediate removal of all sick persons from infected vessels to airy hospitals, and the speedy disinfection and release of all vessels and goods subject to Quarantine are the special purposes of a well-conductedestablishment of this kind. The Health Officer is making arrangements, as far as practicable, in the absence of appropriate warehouses and hospitals, for the perfection of these special objects of Quarantine.

abstract: In the United States Commissioner's office, before Commissioner OSBORN, LEMUEL KINNEY was brought up and discharged. Prisoner was arrested some weeks ago charged with having in his possession a quantity of counterfeit Postal Currency. Without going into the facts, the Commissioner was compelled to discharge him, as the law of July, 1862, had not made it a penal offence to be in possession of spurious Postal Currency. On examination, this serious defect in the law authorizing the issue of Postal Currency is found to exist.
lead_paragraph: In the United States Commissioner's office, before Commissioner OSBORN, LEMUEL KINNEY was brought up and discharged. abstract: London Times, >amp;c., on
snippet: London Times, >amp;c., on
lead_paragraph: -- In another column we give copious extracts from our files of English journals, together with translations of notable passages from our French files, to illustrate the popular feeling abroad regarding the progress of events in Mexico. The supercilious, insulting tone in which reference is made to the disability of our Government to interfere at present with the erection of a monarchy upon the ruins of the Mexican Republic might, and perhaps would, excite our indignation, were it not for the ludicrous perplexity in which both the English and French journalists appear to be regarding what has actually been accomplished by NAPOLEON, and the fears which seem to haunt them unless the would-be Emperor may not after all find his path to the Mexican capital strewn with roses. The London Times, for instance, speaks of the historical significance of the fact that a republic has been superseded by a monarchy in America, and in the next breath congratulates the world that NAPOLEON has instituted a Government where anarchy -- no government at all -- existed. La France announce that the French troops will be withdrawn from the scene of their conquests immediately upon the arrival of the Emperor MAXIMILIAN, and by a curious coincidence its prophecy seems to be anticipated simultaneously with its utterance, for we have a rumor that the French have already left the City of Mexico. If events continue to progress at this rate, the Emperor in embryo will not only want a blessing from the Pope to insure the throne to his posterity; -- he will need one none the less to make secure his own occupation of it.

abstract: Gold Mining in
snippet: Gold Mining in
lead_paragraph: The regulations affecting the privileges of mining in the newly-discovered gold-bearing districts of Lower Canada were issued by the Crown Lands Department on Saturday last, and as the capital of American citizens has already been invested to a considerable extent in the Chaudiere and St. Francis Divisions, where operations were commenced several months ago, it is well to see what the claims of the Crown amount to, and what are the governmental restrictions on mining enterprise.

abstract: Among the attractions of the late Metropolitan Fair, so successful in its results, and so honorable to the ladies who devoted themselves through long weeks of toil and anxiety to its work, this department deserves to be especially mentioned. Besides contributing largely to the receipts of the general treasury, it bad a moral influence in reminding us in the midst of the startling extravagance of the day, of the frugal habits of the early fathers of this City. It was at once gratifying and surprising to see how old and young, from day to day, repeated their visits to the apartments to partake of the primitive fare administered by the ladies in attendance, and to view the simple, articles household use from which have sprung the more costly, and familiar decorations of our modern parlors and dining-rooms. Thus while the great object of Christian charity was promoted, it bound in stronger ties of kindred and patriotism, the descendants of the early fathers of the City, and taught them a lesson in this season of sacrifice to the country which, it may be hoped, will not pass unheeded.
lead_paragraph: Among the attractions of the late Metropolitan Fair, so successful in its results, and so honorable to the ladies who devoted themselves through long weeks of toil and anxiety to its work, this department deserves to be especially mentioned. abstract: -- There is a great deal of bold, out-spoken secessionism among the workmen in the armory. In some of the shops it is a common thing to hear the remark that the North has no business to be fighting the South -- the South is in the right and ought to win. With regard to the battle pending in Virginia and numerous battles now matters of history but then expected, employes of the Government in this city have been heard to say that they "hoped to G -- d the North would get whipped." An inspector said a day or two ago that "BANKS got pretty well used up in that Red River business and he was d -- d glad of it," and another not long ago dropped the remark that he "would a d -- d sight rather see LEE's army in Washington than GRANT's in Richmond." This is not "Democracy," or any mild type of Copperheadism, but plain, blank treason that ought not to be tolerated for a day. And it would not be tolerated from any man who said it openly on the street, yet it is comparatively common on the Government grounds and in the Government shops, and from men in Government employ. It would be reported to the officers of the armory in many cases, if the loyal men who hear it daily were not afraid of losing their own positions thereby. The commandant of the armory owes it, not only to the country but to himself, to make a thorough investigation of these facts and order the immediate discharge of men against whom this treason can be proven. -- Springfield Republican.

abstract: The Europa arrived at Halifax yesterday morning after a stormy passage. She brings European dates as late as the 17th ult. via Queenstown.
lead_paragraph: The Europa arrived at Halifax yesterday morning after a stormy passage. She brings European dates as late as the 17th ult. via Queenstown. The pirate Florida had found refuge in a Spanish port, her application for a supply of coal at a Portuguese port having been refused. The paternity of the famous Laird iron-clads is said to have been acknowledged by the Pasha of Egypt, who, a correspondent of the London Times asserts, states that he ordered their construction. The source whence this story comes, and the fact that his Egyptian Highness has been so tardy in acknowledging his connection with these notorious craft, may lead some to doubt the authenticity of this little romance. GARIBALDI continued to be "all the rage" in London. He had a magnificent reception at the Crystal Palace on the 15th ult., when several flags were presented to him. The Emperor MAXIMILIAN and the Empress left Miramar on April 14, and were expected to reach Rome on the 19th, whence they would depart the succeeding day for Mexico. The conference upon the Danish question was to hold its first session in London on April 20, ("no postponement on account of the weather,") and the German Diet was to be represented. Meanwhile, the Prussians are steadily pushing the siege of Duppel. Breadstuffs and provisions were dull and declining. Console closed 91 3/8@91 5/8 for money.

abstract: The steamers Yazoo, Columbia and Merrimac, bringing advices from New-Orleans to April 24, arrived at this port yesterday. That part of the military news which is apparently the most important, seems to be only the echo of that already received via Cairo.
lead_paragraph: The steamers Yazoo, Columbia and Merrimac, bringing advices from New-Orleans to April 24, arrived at this port yesterday. That part of the military news which is apparently the most important, seems to be only the echo of that already received via Cairo. It is to the effect that the rebels exhibited a disposition to attack Gen. BANKS in his strongly fortified position on the Red River, and that the skirmishing which was in progress might at any time grow into a battle. The rumor regarding the occupation of Shreveport by. Gen. STEELE, has one addition -- that he was throwing up fortifications. If he is actually at that place or in its immediate vicinity, it is difficult to understand why the rebels do not attempt to dispose of him before, troubling themselves regarding the forces under Gen. BANKS, which are not likely to be able to resume the offensive for some days, according to the latest accounts. A call for a meeting to appoint delegates to a Union State Convention which shall send delegates to the National Convention, appears in the New-Orleans papers. The Constitutional Convention was trying to reach the more important business which it had assembled to perform.

abstract: Shakespeare Tercentenary Workmen's Meeting in Hyde Park Prohibited
snippet: Shakespeare Tercentenary Workmen's Meeting in Hyde Park Prohibited
lead_paragraph: The operatives of England are the creators of the wealth of England. Without their industry she could not pay the interest of her enormous debt, could not meet the current expenses of her Government, could not maintain her present proud position among the nations. Without the support of their strong arms, her resources, her power, her prestige, would vanish as the morning mist. Yet, how are those indefatigable toilers requited for the services they render? Why, by denying them the rights of citizens and of human nature, and by manifesting, on every possible occasion, her distrust of them. Here is a case illustrative of England's mode of dealing with her moiling millions. An intelligent body of the London operatives, having resolved to celebrate SHAKESPEARE's tercentenary by marching in procession to Green Park, and there planting a young oak in honor of the great dramatist, took the liberty of sending a deputation to Downing-street, to ask permission of Mr. COWPER, Chief Commissioner of Woods and Forests, to proceed through Hyde Park to their destination. Their object had no connection whatever with politics; they merely meant to make a public demonstration of their reverence for literature, to plant in the earth the sapling, which, in its upward and outward growth for centuries, should symbolize the increasing fame of the matchless bard, and then to return home the way they came.

abstract: Much interest has been felt in the bookselling world of London on the contemplated intention of Mr. HENRY G. BOHN to retire from business. It is about thirty years since he commenced in the same locality that he still occupies in York-street, Covent Garden in the old book branch of the profession.
lead_paragraph: -- Much interest has been felt in the bookselling world of London on the contemplated intention of Mr. HENRY G. BOHN to retire from business. It is about thirty years since he commenced -- in the same locality that he still occupies in York-street, Covent Garden -- in the old book branch of the profession. A few years placed him indisputably at the head of this department, when the accidental purchase of what are called the "remainders," or unsold portions of the octavo editions of EVELYN's and PEPY's Diaries, gave a new direction to his energies, and while still continuing the old book business, he became the largest purchaser of these remainders of editions of recent books that was ever seen in England. His skill in adding to the attraction of the books that thus came into his hands (which seemed to start into new life under his auspices,) and the activity with which he sought out all over the world, in Australia, Canada, India, the United States, &c., new channels for the disposal of them, gave him such success that the trade grew jealous of his achievements, and became indisposed to see him monopolize the market, and consequently were less liberal in their terms and less anxious to sell to him. The result of this was that, in self-defence, he became a manufacturer of books himself, and the world-renowned series of "Bohn's Libraries" will give evidenec to the latest times of his tact, enterprise, and literary taste. There is scarcely a volume of the whole set -- nearly six hundred in number -- but what is indebted to his supervision for much of its merits, while several have been edited or translated exclusively by Mr. BOHN. The sale of the series has been very large, both in England and America, and shows no signs of falling off; though in the United States the absence of an international copyright law has allowed much infringement on the publisher's equitable rights in his own property, by which he has been a large loser. Pending negotiations for the transfer of this entire property of the "Libraries," in one lot, for a sum, in our present currency,equal to nearly half a million of dollars, will probably soon be concluded, and will be followed by a more gradual withdrawal from the other branches of his business. Mr. BOHN is now in his sixty-seventh year, but few young men are capable of supporting the labors, intellectual and commercial, that he has constantly endured. He is not of a temperament to be idle for a moment, and in whatever he may turn to, when removed from business pursuits, he will doubtless make his mark as effectually as he has done in the literary publishing trade of England.

abstract: -- A meeting of underwriters was held at the office of the City Fire insurance Company, yesterday, to act upon the claims of Colt's Fire Arms Company, under policies held by them at the time of the great fire. Nothing was done further than to partially examine the statements of the company, and it may take several days to arrive at a final result. Mr. R.G. MARTIN, who represents the interest of all the New-York companies that are losers, EDWARD FREEMAN, President of the Springfield Company, and Mr. DEWOLF, of the American office, Providence, were present. The Hartford offices have referred the whole matter of settlement, so far as they are concerned, to the Adjustment Committee of their Board of Underwriters. The committee consists of C.B. BOWERS, President of the City; JOSEPH H. SPRAGUE, President of the Charter Oak; and HENRY KELLOGG, President of the Phoenix. -- Hartford Courant, April 24.

abstract: Enquirer, >amp;c., on Grant's Campaign
snippet: Enquirer, >amp;c., on Grant's Campaign
lead_paragraph: -- Some of the rebels in Richmond have got the terrible idea into their heads that, notwithstanding all the preparation and concentration that is going on in Virginia -- notwithstanding the demonstrations on the Peninsula, on the Rappahannock, and on the Rapidan -- notwithstanding the renewal of the cry of "On to Richmond," Lieut.-Gen. GRANT is, after all, not going to open his Summer campaign in Virginia at all. They fancy that all the preparation in Virginia is but a blind to cover up some dangerous design of GRANT elsewhere, and that, as he dumbfounded the rebels by his operations at Vicksburgh last year at this time, and as again at Chattanooga, last November, he dumbfounded BRAGG and all rebeldom -- so it is possible he may now be preparing for their benefit some operation of which they have as little idea as they had of his last two. Who can tell, to use the flatulent language of a late Richmond Enquirer, but that "all preparations for an advance against JOHNSTON may be made in the West just as secretly as they have been openly conducted in the East, and within a few hours the railroads transport GRANT and his headquarters from the "field" in the East to the "field" in the West, and he sweep down upon JOHNSTON while the public in Virginia are straining their eyes to see his advance, or their ears to hear the distant thunders of his approach." This is certainly an appalling line of speculation the Jeff. Davis organ falls into, but we leave it to Gen. GRANT himself to convey the information whether or not the speculations are correct.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. WILSON introduced a resolution, which was referred to the Military Committee, that any officer whose resignation of a commission was accepted, shall not be entitled to hold or exercise command until again appointed by the President, with consent of the Senate. Mr. SUMNER introduced a bill providing for a Board of Examination to ascertain the merits and capacity of all applicants for civil service under the Government, except those appointed by the President. The House bill for relief of settlers on land claims in California was called up and discussed. The bill granting lands for a railroad in Minnesota, as amended by the House, was passed. The amendment of the Finance Committee to the Tax Bill taxing banks was passed.

abstract: MUTINY ON BOARD A BRITISH BARK ONE OF THE MUTINEERS KILLED. The British bark Campanero, Capt. JAMES A. DUBEL, from Palermo, arrived at this port yesterday, with several of the crew in irons, they having mutinied. The names of the mutineers are Theodore Stolp, William Denink, Henry Killing,
lead_paragraph: -- The British bark Campanero, Capt. JAMES A. DUBEL, from Palermo, arrived at this port yesterday, with several of the crew in irons, they having mutinied. The names of the mutineers are Theodore Stolp, William Denink, Henry Killing, John Braken and Otto Krall. From the statement of Capt. DUBEL, it appear, that the prisoners and a sailor named FERDINAND FREDERICK mutinied on the 18th of March last, and after threatening the captain's life, and also that of the second mate, they refused to obey orders from their superior officers. Soon after, an assault was made on the captain, and he was. thrown to the deck of his vessel by the mutineers. The second mate interfered to save his own life, and in the struggle FREDERICK was shot by the mate, and died two hours after, from the effects of the wounds, STOLP was also shot in the arm, but the injuries are not serious. On the arrival of the bark in port, she was boarded by Officer HARVEY, of the Harbor Police, who arrested the refractory sailors and took them before Justice HOGAN, at the Tombs, who committed them for trial.

abstract: Secession in Switerland and U. S. Compared; De Peyster, Gen. J. W. Secession in Switzerland and U. S. Compared
snippet: Secession in Switerland and U. S. Compared; De Peyster, Gen. J. W. Secession in Switzerland and U. S. Compared
lead_paragraph: Those who are fond of drawing instruction from historical parallels, or who seek for political guidance by examining the analogies of different States, may consult, with no little interest at the present time, a comprehensive and learned monogram, by Gen. J. WATTS DEPEYSTER, of New-York, entitled "Secession in Switzerland and in the United States Compared." The author does not absolutely confine himself to an analysis of the secession malady which seems almost to be of an endemic character in the Swiss Republic, since it has existed there for more than three hundred years -- but makes discursive references to the three European Republics, Holland, Venice and Genoa, destroyed by the first NAPOLEON; and taking the first named for a text, reads his fellow-countrymen a solemn and pointed admonition on the danger of mistaking the heat of party spirit for the zeal of patriotism, and of seeking for national riches as the end, and not as the means, of national greatness. Along with this admonitory reflection, Gen. DE PEYSTER draws from the fate which followed the admission of foreign interference by the United Provinces, a practical lesson to illustrate the necessity, the imperious necessity, of maintaining the doctrine of MONROE inviolate, "as an antidote to the poison of foreign intervention in the affairs of this, our continent." He reasons, too, and reasons well, that the failure of former republics and the occasional license or sporadic excesses of liberal institutions should neither discourage nor disgust thinking men. And quoting the famous passage of MACAULAY on Liberty, he pointedly reminds us of the Fairy of Ariosto: "Those who injured her during the period of her disguise, when she bore a loathsome aspect, were forever excluded from participation in the blessings which she bestowed, but to those who, in spite of her loathsome aspect, pitied and protected her, she afterward revealed herself in the beautiful and celestial form which was natural to her, accompanied their steps, granted all their wishes, filled their houses with wealth, made them happy in love, and victorious in war. Such is the spirit of liberty. * * Woe to those who in disgust shall venture to crush her! And happy those who having dared to receive her in her degraded shape, shall at length be rewarded by her in the time of her beauty and her glory."
headline: {'main': 'Secession Historical Parallels.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Secession Historical Parallels.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We hear every day accounts from Tennessee, of GRIERSON having captured parties of FORREST's men, If they are true, and there is no reason to doubt them, he must have in his hands by this time nearly two hundred,...
lead_paragraph: We hear every day accounts from Tennessee, of GRIERSON having captured parties of FORREST's men, If they are true, and there is no reason to doubt them, he must have in his hands by this time nearly two hundred, if not more. It will not, or certainly ought not to be difficult for an active and vigilant officer such as he is to pick up three hundred and sixty of them, considering that they are all given to drink, and that as they are mostly occupied in plundering, they must scatter and straggle a good deal. Now, if this is the case, does it not furnish a ready solution of our difficulty about retaliation for the Fort Pillow affair? It would certainly be very hard for us either to counsel or to witness the execution in cold blood of this number of Confederate prisoners who have had no share in this bloody deed. The butchery of a large number of men for a crime of which, though technically answerable for it, they are not really guilty, is something which no Christian man at the North likes to face, if it can possibly be avoided. We have not got down to the Confederate level yet, and have no love of bloodshed for its own sake. But we doubt very much if there is anybody amongst us, or in any part of the civilized world, who would not hear with intense satisfaction that three hundred and sixty of FORREST's butchers had been strung up as fast as they were caught. They are the very men who have done the deed, and the only men who, if simple justice was always attainable, ought to be made to suffer for it. We are satisfied, therefore, that if Col. GRIERSON will hang on the nearest tree every prisoner who falls into his hands, who shall be proved to have belonged to FORREST's gang, he will relieve the Government from great embarrassment, set a valuable and striking example, and give satisfaction to the Northern public.

abstract: In the Senate, Saturday, Mr. WILSON, introduced a resolution, which was referred to the Military Committee, that any officer whose resignation of a commission was accepted, shall not be entitled to hold or exercise com  mand until again appointed by the President, with consent of the Senate.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, Saturday, Mr. WILSON, introduced a resolution, which was referred to the Military Committee, that any officer whose resignation of a commission was accepted, shall not be entitled to hold or exercise command until again appointed by the President, with consent of the Senate. Mr. SUMNER introduced a bill providing for a Board of Examination to ascertain the merits and capacity of all applicants for civil service under the Government, except those appointed by the President. The House bill for relief of settlers on land claims in California was called up and discussed. The bill granting lands for a railroad in Minnesota, as amended by the House, was passed. The amendment of the Finance Committee to the Tax Bill taxing banks was passed.

abstract: If there is to be another battle in Louisiana, we hope the Government has by this time forwarded instructions to Gen. BANKS to try the plan of fighting the enemy with his whole army at once, and of trying to be the stronger...
lead_paragraph: If there is to be another battle in Louisiana, we hope the Government has by this time forwarded instructions to Gen. BANKS to try the plan of fighting the enemy with his whole army at once, and of trying to be the stronger at the point of attack. A great many of our Generals have, so far, as we remarked the other day, regarded this idea with great disfavor, influenced, we believe, by the example of the Greeks at Marathon and Thermopylae, who are reported to have fought and conquered with vastly inferior forces. As civilians, we of course offer an opinion on a point of this kind with a good deal of diffidence, but the plan of attacking the enemy with superior numbers, or of letting him severely alone until he can be attacked in this way, has in modern times been tried on several occasions with much success; and from this it would seem that there really must be something in it. Then, it is now satisfactorily proved that the Confederates are "evil beasts," and positively will not let themselves be thrashed by half their numbers -- the United States Constitution to the contrary notwithstanding. They began the display of their stiffneckedness on the Peninsula, where they resolutely and wickedly refused to be conquered by detachments detailed from Little MAC's army for that purpose. Their malevolence to ward Gen. BANKS seems equally strong. The manner in which they precipitated their whole force on each of his divisions as it came up, following their refusal to lay down their arms to Gen. A.L. LEE's cavalry, was a stupendous example of malignity. A man named BONAPARTE, who cut some figure in the wars following the French Revolution, was in the habit of so arranging matters that he might fling his whole army on one point of the enemy's line, and he on several occasions did them a good deal of damage in this way, and achieved some reputation among his co-temporaries. We, therefore, respectfully suggest that Gen. BANKS be requested to try this device at Grand Ecore, if it be not too late. We think it extremely doubtful whether the Confederates can be conquered by "raids" much before the year 1900, and we fear by that time people at the North would begin to show symptoms of dissatisfaction with the slow progress of the war. Gen. GRANT is evidently resolved on trying our plan, and, if LEE beats him, he will have the satisfaction of destroying an immense army at one fell blow.

abstract: Dispatches from the Army of the Potomac furnish the usual stories relative to the fabulous strength which LEE is massing in front of Gen. GRANT. His infantry is reported by deserters to number eighty thousand, and his cavalry twenty-two thousand, all mounted, of course, on well-fed steeds, with ten days' rations issued every week for an advance which don't take place. The town of Madison Court-house has been burned by our troops.

abstract: It seems to be pretty well settled that the letters produced in the House of Representatives some days since by Gen. GARFIELD, purporting to have been written by J.S. DAVIS and D.R. ECKLES, of Indiana, were actually forgeries.
lead_paragraph: It seems to be pretty well settled that the letters produced in the House of Representatives some days since by Gen. GARFIELD, purporting to have been written by J.S. DAVIS and D.R. ECKLES, of Indiana, were actually forgeries. The Indianapolis Sentinel states that they were written at the desk in the office of a hotel in that city, and that they were fabricated for the spy RANKIN in the hopes that they might protect him in case he fell into rebel hands. The last time RANKIN's friends heard from him was three days before the battle of Chicamauga, when he was at BRAGG's headquarters, and they now suppose him to be dead.

abstract: A SOLDIER ROBBED. FREDERICK ECKK, a soldier recently returned from the war, took lodgings  at No. 109 Greenwich-street, and while asleep in his room, on Saturday night, he was robbed by CHARLES...
lead_paragraph: A SOLDIER ROBBED. -- FREDERICK ECKK, a soldier recently returned from the war, took lodgings at No. 109 Greenwich-street, and while asleep in his room, on Saturday night, he was robbed by CHARLES BRINKMAN, who entered the apartment and rifled his pocket of the sum of $450. The theft was discovered soon afterward,and BRINKMAN being suspected, he was arrested by Officer FINKE, of the Twenty-seventh Precinct. On searching his person $350 of the stolen money was found. The accused confessed the theft, and Justice HOGAN committed him to the Tombs for trial.

abstract: Movements in Tennessee
snippet: Movements in Tennessee
lead_paragraph: The opinion is universal, both in the North and in the South, that this month of May will be a month of great battles. It was almost impossible, this year, to commence operations earlier. It was impossible for the army in Tennessee to advance, for the simple reason that until within the last few weeks, there was no accumulation of supplies at Chattanooga; and without a very large accumulation, a forward movement was not only impracticable, but if it had been successfully made, we could not have held the new positions we might have won. By this time, we have a considerable stock of supplies at Chattanooga. Our army there, too, has greatly increased in magnitude by the return of the veteran regiments, who went back much enlarged after their furlough. Its objective point is generally believed to be Atlanta, a position second only to Richmond in importance, and, in a strategic point of view, in its bearings upon the whole Southern Confederacy, of still higher value than the rebel capital. Its commanding importance was argued very frequently by military men last Fall and Winter; and though we have heard but little of it lately, its importance has not diminished a whit. Some of the Richmond rebels have lately given expression to the opinion that the Summer campaign will really begin in the West, from Chattanooga, and though this is a subject about which we know nothing, we must confess that the reasons the rebels give for their opinion are not bad. Beside the drawback we have mentioned to an advance on this line, another great impediment has just been removed. We refer to the column in East Tennessee under LONGSTREET, which is now withdrawn to Virginia. As long as LONGSTREET held Bull's Gap with a large force, the advance of our main army under SHERMAN was perilous. The rebels might have fallen upon Knoxville, might have got upon SHERMAN's communications or in his rear, or might have struck into Kentucky, and by one or other of these movements compelled a retrograde movement on the part of SHERMAN before he had consummated his campaign. That danger is now out of the way for the time being; and if our forces seize and properly fortify Bull's Gap, we can secure East Tennessee and guard Kentucky with a small body of troops.

abstract: The Europa arrived at Halifax yesterday morning after a stormy passage. She brings European dates as late as the 17th ult, via Queenstown. The pirate Florida had found refuge in a Spanish port, her application for a supply of coal at a Portuguese port having been refused.
lead_paragraph: The Europa arrived at Halifax yesterday morning after a stormy passage. She brings European dates as late as the 17th ult, via Queenstown. The pirate Florida had found refuge in a Spanish port, her application for a supply of coal at a Portuguese port having been refused. The paternity of the famous Laird iron clads is said to have been acknowledged by the Pasha of Egypt, who, a correspondent of the London Times asserts, states that he ordered their construction. The source whence this story comes, and the fact that his Egyptian Highness has been so tardy in acknowledging his connection with these notorious craft, may lead some to doubt the authenticity of this little romance. GARIBALDI continued to be "all the rage" in London. He had a magnificent reception at the Crystal Palace on the 15th ult., when several flags were presented to him. The Emperor MAXIMILIAN and the Empress left Miramar on April 14, and were expected to reach Rome on the 19th, whence they would depart the succeeding day for Mexico. The conference upon the Danish question was to hold its first session in London on April 20, and the German Diet was to be represented. Meanwhile, the Prussians are steadily pushing the siege of Duppel. Breadstuffs and provisions were dull and declining. Consols closed closed 91 3/8@91 5/8 for money.

abstract: Rossiter's Picture, Eve in the Garden
snippet: Rossiter's Picture, Eve in the Garden
lead_paragraph: Mr. MARETZEK has come to the conclusion that a Spring season of Italian opera is impossible. The public seemed to be ready for it, and the subscribers presented themselves in encouraging numbers. It was owing to these facts, perhaps that a few German chorus-singers supposed that the right time had arrived for anew exaction, and therefore "struck." They were followed, we believe, by some members of the orchestra, and so Mr. MARETZEK found himself in a dilemma. Either he had to acknowledge a new principle in management, namely, paying for rehearsals as well as performances, or to postpone the season. The latter was the judicious course, and Mr. MARETZEK adopted it. Hence we shall have no more opera until October next. By that time the impresario will have arranged the matter -- not, perhaps, to the satisfaction of the disaffected, but judiciously, so far as the public is concerned. The time has certainly come for combating the pretensions of the mechanics of the orchestra and chorus. A decent operatic entertainment will otherwise be impossible. At the present moment they hold, or fancy they hold, the manager completely in their power. He has to accede to their monstrous demands, or be left in the lurch. The latter alternative is rather difficult with a man like Mr. MARETZEK, but he has acceded to their demands too often and too cheerfully, which has encouraged them to make the present trouble. Musicians are, we admit, scarce, but it is possible to add to their number, and this is the only, plan by which the monopoly can be broken down. Who will undertake the task of importing a few dozen fiddlers, and half a hundred decent chorus-singers?

abstract: DEDICATION OF A NEW CHURCH. The new and splendid edifice recently erected in Elm-place, near Fulton-avenue, was dedicated to Divine worship yesterday. It is known as the Elm-place Congregational Church, under the pastoral charge of...
lead_paragraph: DEDICATION OF A NEW CHURCH. -- The new and splendid edifice recently erected in Elm-place, near Fulton-avenue, was dedicated to Divine worship yesterday. It is known as the Elm-place Congregational Church, under the pastoral charge of Rev. WM.A. BARTLETT. The congregation have for some years past occupied the building known as the Tabernacle, on Fulton-avenue. The services in the morning opened with a voluntary on the organ, and the reading of a portion of the Scriptures. After singing the 551st hymn, the Pastor announced that to-day the pews were free, but that to-morrow (Monday) and Tuesday evenings the choice seats would be rented to the highest bidder. A collection was then taken up for furnishing the church, when the dedicatory sermon was preached by Rev. Dr. R.D. HITCHCOCK, who took for his text the 22d and 1st clause of the 23d verses, 1st chapter of the Ephesians: -- "And nath put all things under His feet and gave Him to be the Head over all things to the Church, which is His body," in which he treated of the church as the revelations of God and as the organ and instrument of His will.

abstract: Ferries between Up and Down Town Suggested; Disease and Sanitary Neglect
snippet: Ferries between Up and Down Town Suggested; Disease and Sanitary Neglect
lead_paragraph: It has come to be recognized as a natural law of society that the sins and evils of one class are visited upon other classes. If the rich be extravagant or corrupt in morals, the poor are injured by their influence. If the poor live in unhealthy physical conditions, their diseases pass over to those who have every comfort.

abstract: We understand that a movement is on foot among the ladies of this City to diminish somewhat the drain of gold from the country, by agreeing among themselves not to use any of the expensive fabrics imported from abroad, which enter so largely just now into the consumption of the country. They propose to confine themselves, so far as possible, to the use of home fabrics, while the war lasts. Such a movement among the ladies, if it becomes at all general, will do good in many ways. It will relieve their husbands from paying a good many very heavy bills. It will thus keep gold, not only within the country, but within their private purses. And it will tend to build up and encourage the manufacture here at home, of a great many articles which are now imported. Few persons probably are aware of the extent to which the manufacture of a great many things supposed to come exclusively from abroad, is already carried on here at home. This can and will be very much enlarged by such action as the ladies propose to take. We are told that already a great many of the silk fabrics sold here as of foreign importation, are actually made in Connecticut, and so far as quality is concerned, nobody could tell the difference.

abstract: -- The Emperor of the French has addressed a note to his Minister of Finance upon the "happy solution of the Mexican question." The closing sentence of the note, which is supposed to have a general bearing upon the prospects in Europe, has produced a tremendous sensation, as will be seen by our foreign letters. This important sentence reads thus: "This measure, together with the hopes of peace, which every day becomes more certain, will contribute, I trust, to the development of prosperity." As NAPOLEON is thought to be the master of Europe, and to have the power of controlling, to a great extent, the issues of peace or war, his words have almost as great weight as the march of his legions. It has been widely feared that this would be a Summer of general war in Europe, as the complications there are so many, so wide and so deep. But the Emperor says that peace becomes every day more certain. Perhaps he means it, but his words have not always been capable of a straightforward interpretation.

abstract: EXPERIENCES OF A PIANO-FORTE MANUFACTURER IN THE SOUTH. Mr. POISSON, formerly welknown as a manufacturer of piano-fortes, has returned to this City, after a residence of several years in North Carolina, and advertises tn another column his intention to resume his old business at No. 478 Broadway.
lead_paragraph: EXPERIENCES OF A PIANO-FORTE MANUFACTURER IN THE SOUTH. -- Mr. POISSON, formerly welknown as a manufacturer of piano-fortes, has returned to this City, after a residence of several years in North Carolina, and advertises tn another column his intention to resume his old business at No. 478 Broadway. Mr. POISSON escaped from JEFF. DAVIS' dominions several weeks ago, and brings with him some relics and reminiscences of his experiences while there. He wears a dilapidated pair of boots, the mere footing of which cost him over three hundred dollars. To offset this, however, and to show that although the rebels are fit for "treason, stratagem and spoils" they still have some "music in their souls," he states that he received fifty dollars apiece for tuning pianos, and that the market price of inferior instruments at the time he left the South was three thousand dollars -- in rebel currency, of course.

lead_paragraph: On last Saturday the Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments closed the assessment rolls of the real and personal estate of the County for 1864 to public inspection, and henceforth applications for reductions or other alterations of assessments must be made to the Board of Supervisors. abstract: The Springfield Republican Publishes a private letter from an officer, written at Grand Ecore, La. shortly after Gen. BANKS' battles. The writer says: ...
lead_paragraph: The Springfield Republican Publishes a private letter from an officer, written at Grand Ecore, La. shortly after Gen. BANKS' battles. The writer says: [???] Gen. BANKS was advancing with the confidence that he had only to advance, and advanced faster than the rebels retreated. Seeing our exposed position, they brought on an engagement near Mansfield, which resulted in the loss of all the train and artillery which were irregularly distributed in the train. The attack was so sudden that all were panic-stricken; the horses were cut from the wagons, and artillery and infantry precipitately fled to the rear. Then the cavalry became engaged, but only for a moment, when they abandoned their horses and fled. Then the Thirteenth Army Corps was ordered up, a brigade at a time. Thus this corps was fearfully routed, losing some sixteen or eighteen hundred men, and those who did escape, were forced to abandon their arms. Had it not been for the plunder in the captured train, this entire corps would have been taken prisoners, one brigade at a time. I have talked with many of the Thirteenth Corps who were taken prisoners, and escaped while the rebels were plundering the train. The Thirteenth is now almost without arms. It was commanded by Gen. RANSOM and four brigade commanders. Gen. RANSOM was wounded by a ball passing through his leg above the knee, and three of the brigade commanders were killed. The remaining one, Col. RAYMEN, is now in command of the corps. Gen. BANKS is universally condemned by officers and men. The few rebel prisoners we have are very jubilant, and say, "Well, Gen. BANKS has been the best commissary we have ever had in this department, since he has been in command. We could not get anything from BUTLER." The next morning after the second day's fight, our exhausted and slightly wounded men, who were too much worn out to get off the field that night, on waking up and finding no one about made up their minds that our army had advanced and so went forward. After going two or three miles, they came upon our captured train and many other wagons. This confused them, but on they went, and after they had passed the train and were within a short distance of Pleasant Hill, they were fired upon by rebel pickets. They then knew their condition and retraced their steps. Thus both armies were running from each other. We lost from twenty to thirty pieces of artillery and some five thousand men in killed, wounded and missing. The army gives Gen. A.J. SMITH great credit for his conduct, and say if it had not been for him all would have been lost. The army seem to be expecting an attack; they have been in line of battle to-day."

abstract: The Emperor had addressed the following letter, dated April 15, to M. FOULD, Minister of Finance: "The happy solution of the Mexican affair creates in me a desire to see the country profit by the first repayment of the expenses of the war, by diminishing taxes. Be good enough to see if it be not possible to effect the immediate suppression of the second decime registration fee, only preserving of the general law prepared by the Council of State those arrangements which may be strictly necessary for balancing the budget. This measure, together with the hopes or peace, which every day becomes more certain, will contribute, I trust, to the development of prosperity."

abstract: In the Senate yesterday very little business of importance was transacted. The bill regulating the foreign and coasting trade was passed, and the Internal Tax bill was received from the House, referred, and ordered printed.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday very little business of importance was transacted. The bill regulating the foreign and coasting trade was passed, and the Internal Tax bill was received from the House, referred, and ordered printed. Likewise the Army Appropriation bill. A message was received from the President, inclosing a letter from Gov. NYE, of Nevada, giving information relative to the rejection of the State Constitution by the people of that territory. The National Currency Bill was taken up, but no material progress made therein. The joint resolution to appropriate $25,000,000 to pay the expenses of the hundred day troops was taken up, and after a long discussion was put upon its passage, but as no quorum voted, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: The steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool, April 20, via Queeastown, April 21, arrived at this port yesterday evening, bringing four days' later news.
lead_paragraph: The steamship City of Washington, from Liverpool, April 20, via Queeastown, April 21, arrived at this port yesterday evening, bringing four days' later news. At a late hour last night the Belgian was also telegraphed from Port au Basque, with dates to the 22d, one day still later. The news is of an important character. The Prussians had finally reduced and captured Duppel -- the Danish loss being 400 officers, 2,600 men and 90 guns. The Danes threatened to take the Island of Alsen, and the Allies had already sent forces into the Province of Jutland to occupy it, and lay siege to Fredericia. The Conference met in London, informally, on the 20th, but adjourned until the 25th. The Emperor of the French had created much excitement in financial circles by a brief letter to M. FOULD, his Minister of Finance, in which he announces the encouraging prospect for peace in Europe, and congratulates the nation that the early reimbursement of the Mexican War expenses enables him to recommend a decrease in the tax budget. This news produced a panic in the funds. GARIBALDI had suddenly concluded to shorten his visit to England, and would embark for Caprera again on the 22d, though great efforts were making to induce him to remain longer. It was given out that his health was affected, but it was strongly suspected that this departure was because of official intimations, though Lord PALMERSTON, for the British, and the Paris Moniteur, for the French, disclaimed everything of the kind. The Emperor and Empress of Mexico had visited the Pope, and would leave for Mexico on the 20th of April. Other news unimportant.

abstract: This celebrated trotting stallion died quite unexpectedly, at four o'clock on Sunday, at JOHN J. SNEDIKER'S, adjacent to the Union Course. Long Island his death being caused by rupture. Patchen was about fourteen years old.
lead_paragraph: This celebrated trotting stallion died quite unexpectedly, at four o'clock on Sunday, at JOHN J. SNEDIKER'S, adjacent to the Union Course. Long Island his death being caused by rupture. Patchen was about fourteen years old. He was sired by Cassius M. Clay, his dam being a mare owned by Mr. GEORGE M. PATCHEN, of Brooklyn, by importted Trustee; hence the name he bore. The stallion was in training at the time of his decease, (under DAN PFIFER,) although he had no immediate engagements on hand. As a trotter he was scarcely inferior to any that has appeared on the trotting turf; and it was as much as its queen "Flora Temple" could do, with her indomitable speed and courage, to obtain the best of him in their several contests. Patchen possessed great size, power, and, substantial solidity, and when put to it had a fine slashing style of going. He will prove a great loss to the trotting turf, as well as his owner. (Mr. WALTERMIRE,) who it is reported, only recently refused $22,000 for him.

abstract: Speech on Prasecution of the War
snippet: Speech on Prasecution of the War
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a speech by Senator DOOLITTLE, of Wisconsin, on the paramount importance of avoiding, in the discussions of the day, everything not essential to the prosecution of the war, and which can divide Union men or weaken the active loyalty of the people of the loyal States. It was made upon a proposition brought forward by Senator WILKINSON, of Minnesota, to give negroes the right of suffrage in the Territory of Montana. As there has never been but one negro in that territory, and as he either died or left it some time since, the question had no very great practical importance; but it was pressed by Senator WILKINSON and some of his colleagues with as much zeal as if the fate of the Union, or their own reelection, depended exclusively on the result. Senator DOOLITTLE declined to discuss the question whether negroes should be allowed to vote in Montana -- because it was not of the slightest practical consequence, just now, whether they are or not, and because, furthermore, the discussion is very likely to do harm to the cause of the Union by dividing those who are struggling for its preservation. And the object of his speech is to press upon loyal men everywhere the absolute necessity of union and harmony, and of waiving controversies and discussions which threaten to disturb them.
headline: {'main': 'A Plea for Union Among Union Men.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Plea for Union Among Union Men.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: PHILADELPHIA ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Mr. FRY'S opera of "Notre Dame of Paris" will be pro  duced at this establishment to-morrow night. It in augurates a series of performance in aid of the ...
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Mr. FRY's opera of "Notre Dame of Paris" will be pro duced at this establishment to-morrow night. It in augurates a series of performance in aid of the Sanitary Fair, which will commence at the same time. Our musical efforts for the cause were dismal failures, arising from the inefficiency of the people who had them in charge. In Philadelphia, a large and liberal plan will it is hoped, afford a better result. Mr. FRY's opera is a new work, and will be played for the first time. There was once a prospect that it would be played here in Italian, but difficulties occurred which rendered it impossible. Mr. FRY has contribute the work to the Sanitary Fair, and the Commissioners have wisely concluded to produce it. The artists engaged for the performance are Mme. BORCHARD, Mrs. JENNY KEMPTON Mr., WM. CASTLE, Mr. J.C. CAMPBELL and Mr. EDWD, SECUIN. The orchestra and chorus will be, of unusual proportions, numbering, in fact, upward of two hundred performers. In addition to this, a grand corps de ballet has been engaged, new scenery painted, new dresses manufactured, &c. The event is one of the most interesting that has occurred in our musical history for many years, and is in fact of so much importance, that nearly all the leading journals of the Metropolis send representatives to the initial performance.

abstract: The Fall of Duppel
snippet: The Fall of Duppel
lead_paragraph: fortress of Duppel, the siege of which by the Prussian troops began is February last, has fallen into the hands of the besiegers. The Danish garrison of twenty-six hundred men, with ninety guns, have fallen into the hands of the Prussians, and the Prussian loss in the assault is set down at six hundred privates and sixty officers. The bombardment of this stronghold has been going on steadily since its investment, without very great loss of life. The Prussians made two assaults upon the works, and the Danish troops made several brave sorties upon the enemy's lines. The fall of the place, under the circumstances of the siege, was inevitable; but it was supposed that the Danes would evacuate it at the last moment, and cross the Sound on their pontoons to the island of Alsen. The assault of the Prussians doubtless prevented this. The Allies have now only to take Alsen to make themselves masters of the whole of Schleswig; and we have a dispatch that this has been effected, but its authenticity is doubtful.

abstract: Garibaldi's Visit to England and His Advised Departure
snippet: Garibaldi's Visit to England and His Advised Departure
lead_paragraph: -- The visit of GARIBALDI to England and his abrupt determination to return to Italy, are among the notable episodes of the times. There is no instance in which the appearance of a public personage in Great Britain, native or foreign, has produced deeper or more universal enthusiasm. Even the loyal demonstrations made on great occasions in honor of Her Majesty, have been surpassed by that in honor of this poor foreigner. The aristocracy vied with the populace, and men of the highest official station were proud to welcome the red-shirted Revolutionist. Suddenly, after being but a few days in England, and before he had proceeded beyond the precincts of London upon his grand tour, his departure from the country was announced.

lead_paragraph: About 3 o'clock yesterday morning a fire occurred at the junction of Doyer-street and Chathamsquare. The fire was first discovered in the apartments of JOHN SULLIVAN, on the third floor of premises No. 210 Chatham-square. Five persons perished in the flames, viz.: WM. HENNING, aged 23 years; MARY HENNING, aged 25 years; WM. HENNING, Jr., aged 4 years; MARY HENNING, aged 2 years, and CHAS. HENNING, aged 15 months.

abstract: The investigation in this case was concluded before Coroner NORRIS last night. Three witnesses were examined. Mr. JAMES MONTGOMERY, who claims to be the original inventor of the Martin boiler, testified to that fact, and detailed all the circumstances connected therewith. Mr. WM. A. LIGHTHALL testified that the explosion of the boiler of the Chenango was the result of superheated steam., Mr. DANIEL E. MARTIN, the patentee of the boiler, was recalled, to explain certain facts in relation to his testimony previously given. The Coroner then announced that he would charge the jury this morning at 10 o'clock, and a verdict may therefore be expected this evening.

abstract: Intelligence from Helena, Ark., to the 24th is as follows: On April 21, 400 men, under MICHAEL McCONN and Capt. MEATYARD, crossed into Mississippi, to break up the forces under Capt. LANDERS.
lead_paragraph: Intelligence from Helena, Ark., to the 24th is as follows: On April 21, 400 men, under MICHAEL McCONN and Capt. MEATYARD, crossed into Mississippi, to break up the forces under Capt. LANDERS. After accomplishing this, they recrossed into Arkansas and captured six of FORREST's guerrillas, who were in the State, viz.: Lieut. Thomas C. Casteel, Lieut. Fealty, Capt. Aamdey, Thomas Quarlus, Thomas Stoneman, and Capt. Wild. These, with Col. Josey, Capt. Wacherly and Lieut. John Thompson were taken a few weeks ago. The guerrillas in Arkansas are without officers. Gen. BUFORD has captured and sent North 450 prisoners within the last few months.

abstract: Both Boards of the Common Council met at 2 o'clock P.M. yesterday. Both Boards adopted resolutions appropriately noticing the death of Commodors PORTER, authorizing the Committee on National Affairs to take charge of his remains, lay them in state in the Governor's Room, and that the members of both Boards would attend the funeral in a body on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Both Boards of the Common Council met at 2 o'clock P.M. yesterday. Both Boards adopted resolutions appropriately noticing the death of Commodors PORTER, authorizing the Committee on National Affairs to take charge of his remains, lay them in state in the Governor's Room, and that the members of both Boards would attend the funeral in a body on Wednesday. In the Board of Aldermen, a new Relief Fund ordinance, providing for a further issue of bonds to the amount of $500,000, and extending the benefits to the families of persons whose enlistment in the navy is allowed upon our quota, was presented and laid over. A petition from the Sanitary Commission to erect temporary quarters on the Battery for the sick, wounded and discharged soldiers arriving here en route to hospitals and to their homes, was referred to the Committee on Lands and Places. A resolution by Mr. MCKNIGHT, that the Comptroller secure the Union-square Sanitary Fair building, at a cost not to exceed $2,000, for the use of colored troops as temporary barracks and hospital, elicited some equivocal but humorous remarks, and was referred. A resolution to increase the pay of all corporation laborers to $2 per day, and to date back to Jan. 1, was adopted. The board concurred in ordering the publication of 9,000 copies of the Manual for 1864. The resolution to do away with the office of Inspector of City Railroads was concurred in after some remarks by Mr. RYERS. He said the office failed to benefit the people, because the incumbents of it had always made it a sinecure. The present incumbent was a State Senator, (CHRISTIAN B. WOODRUFF,) which was a powerful reason, to some, why the office should not be abolished; but the day was past when the position of Senator was one of high honor, for it was not uncommon of them to seek and accept sinecure offices, worth from $600 to $1,500 per year. In the Board of Councilmen, a resolution by Mr. OPDYKE, directing the Corporation Counsel to further test the title to the Fort Gansevoort property by a suit to eject the present holder of it, and directing the Mayor, Comptroller, and Clerk of the Common Council not to issue bonds to Mr. TAYLOR, for the purchase of it, until further directed by the Common Council, was referred. Both boards adjourned to 2 o'clock P.M. tomorrow.

abstract: Mercantile Library Assoc. and its Usefulness
snippet: Mercantile Library Assoc. and its Usefulness
lead_paragraph: The great value of this institution to the young men of New-York engaged in mercantile pursuits, in elevating their morals, purifying their tastes, and enlarging their acquaintance with literature and ideas, has been felt and seen for too many years to be now a subject of doubt. Thousands of our leading business men have, in other days, enjoyed its benefits, and the fruits of those benefits they still retain and will for life retain. It has at present over forty-five hundred members, about four thousand of whom, are young, clerks. The library is large, and is constantly being enlarged. The expenses are necessarily heavy, and the demands of the times compel their continual growth. It should be placed on the basis upon which it can act most advantageously and independently, from which it can enlarge its value and its privileges, and render itself attractive to the entire community of mercantile young men.
headline: {'main': 'The Mercantile Library Association.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Mercantile Library Association.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Gold Incomes (Dividends) for the People
snippet: Gold Incomes (Dividends) for the People
lead_paragraph: There was a refreshing sight for the holders of the Public Debt at the Treasury Office in Wall-street yesterday. The holders of the 5-20's were present in force. They were notified fifteen days ago that the Gold was ready and waiting to pay their First of May interest; but hundreds of them waited until yesterday before presenting their coupons. This Loan constitutes about two-thirds the present Funded, Gold-bearing stocks of the United States. The May and November payments are the most important of the year. The immediate instalment is $14,250,000 in Gold. Large as this sounds, we may add that the Customs Revenue, specifically pledged for the Gold interest on the Funded Debt, amounted to over fourteen millions in the month of April alone, at the port of New-York. The previous accumulation of Gold in the Treasury from the same source was double this sum. For the fiscal year the Customs will more than double the Gold interest upon the entire Funded Debt. This Debt, exclusive of the new 10-40 years 5 per cent. Loan, is $768,000,000. The present interest-charge in Gold upon this amount is $47,735,000. This will be reduced next year to $46,000,000 by the conversion of the 7.30 per cent. into the 6 per cent. stocks. It will be reduced after the war to $41,000,000, by the reduction of the 5-20 years 6 per cent. into a 5 per cent. stock; if not $10,000,000, by its reduction into a 4 per cent. stock.

abstract: COUNCIL -- APPOINTMENTS. -- The Jersey City Common Council met last night and organized by reelecting Alderman WM. CLARKS, President, and GEORGE CASEDY, City Clerk. The following-named gentlemen were then elected to fill various offices: City Marshal, Nathaniel Ellis; Corporation Attorney, Richard D. McClellan; City Treasurer, Peter D. Vroom; Collector of City Revenue, John B. Height; Comptroller, J.B. Hardenbergh; Street Commissioner, John D. Nolan; Overseer of the Poor, Wm. Whitley; City Weigher and Measurer, Joseph McMannus; Sealer of Weights and Measures, William H. Smith; Superintendent of Ferries and Wharves, Joseph H. Rommels; Inspector and Measurer of Lumber, Peter Gordon; City Physicians, Dr. Edward Olcott, Jr., and Dr. Theodore F. Morris; Members of the Board of education, David Gould, John H. Lyon, Thomas T. Lacy, Christopher D. Mills, Francis Robinson, and Andrew Clancey. Alderman Patrick Jordon was temporarily appointed to act as Chief of Police until an election takes place to fill the vacancy occasioned by the death of Chief of Police Reily. An unsuccessful attempt was made to elect a City Printer. JOHN H. LYON of the Daily Standard, and WM. DAVIDSON of the Chronicle, were nominated, and six ballots were had, resulting in a tie on the last, and further balloting was dispensed with.

abstract: Railroad Corporations and their Influence
snippet: Railroad Corporations and their Influence
lead_paragraph: Mr. MARSH, our Minister at Turin, in his interesting work on Man and Nature, which has just been published, makes some remarks on the social and political influence of the great corporations by which so many of the industrial enterprizes of our day are carried on, which have just now a good deal of appositeness. He says:

abstract: The Paris Temps, of the 21st, says: "A singular error committed by the Moniteur this morning, shows that the official journal can lay no more claims to infalibility than the common run of newspapers. The Moniteur declares that the mails from NewYork bring 'no news which merits attention.' But we read in the American dispatches of the Times...
lead_paragraph: The Paris Temps, of the 21st, says: "A singular error committed by the Moniteur this morning, shows that the official journal can lay no more claims to infalibility than the common run of newspapers. The Moniteur declares that the mails from NewYork bring 'no news which merits attention.' But we read in the American dispatches of the Times that the Chamber of Representatives at Washington unimously voted, on the 4th of April, a resolution, proposed by Mr. WINTER DAVIS, to the effect that the United States can never recognize or tolerate a monarchy in Mexico. The Independence Belge gives the same news, with a variation, according to which the Congress has simply protested against a monarchy established with the assistance of a European Power. Whichever may be right, we can only believe in an inadvertance of the Moniteur. It cannot have wished to suppress news, which is by no means unexpected, and the importance of which must not moreover be exaggerated. The Chamber of Representatives at Washington is not the American Government. The President is much more independent of Parliament than the Queen of England. The resolution we are announcing is not so much an act as an indication. We may, besides, be certain that the United States will leave Mexico tranquil while the civil war is unfinished. As to the eventualities which may arise after the reestablishment of the Union, the Emperor MAXIMILIAN would have been very imprudent had he not already thought of them; and as he has accepted the Crown, we must conclude that he considers himself prepared to brave the hostility of the United States."

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Scotia at this port yesterday, we have two days's later news from Europe, her advices being down to April 24. The Garibaldi excitement in England has culminated in an outburst of indignation from the common people, at what they allege to be an...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Scotia at this port yesterday, we have two days's later news from Europe, her advices being down to April 24. The Garibaldi excitement in England has culminated in an outburst of indignation from the common people, at what they allege to be an attempt on the part of the nobility to drive GARIBALDI from England because of political influences. The letter of our London correspondent sets forth very clearly the reasons why GARIBALDI's presence in England just now should prove uncomfortable to the Government. Grave and dignified peers were out in cards to the effect that it was certainly the General's health which had so summarily shortened his visit, and Mr. GLADSTONE had announced in the House of Commons that the Government had no connection whatever with the cause of his sudden departure. GARIBALDI would sail for Caprera April 25, in the Duke of SUTHERLAND's yacht. The Conference had not yet done anything, owing to the absence of some of the German representatives, and stood adjourned to the 20th. The French press had received the news of the American resolution on the Mexican question, in various degrees of temper. The Government organs first ignored it, but when compelled to allude to it, affected to treat it as of no moment. The Liberal organs, however, commented freely on it, and pointed to it as an ugly feature for the French Government to contemplate when it guarantees French protection for Mexico for six years. MAXIMILIAN had sailed from Rome, with the blessing of the Pope. There was nothing new in the situation in Denmark. The King of Prussia was visiting his army, and congratulating the troops that stormed the works of Duppel. Preparations were making for pushing into Jutland.

abstract: An adjourned meeting of the Commercial Brokers was held at the Produce Exchange yesterday, Mr. E. HAYDOCK WHITE in the chair, and Mr. CHARLES TAYLOR officiating as Secretary. The attendance was very slim, owing, doubtless, to the fact that no public announcement had been made that such a meeting would be held. The chairman explained briefly that the committee, which had been sent to Washington to look after the interests of the commercial brokers, had made an informal report, to the effect that they had been assured that the new Tax Bill was not designed to injure any class in particular, and that the provision relating to commercial brokers had been so modified that they would have only to pay $20 a year each for a license. It appeared, however, to the committee, as it did to the chairman of the meeting, that there was a direct conflict between the clause relating to produce brokers and that relating to commercial brokers. The committee held -- and they were given to understand that such was the meaning of the authors of the new tax bill -- that brokers in floor, grain and provisions were as strictly commercial brokers as any other merchandise brokers, and that, under the pertinent clause of the new tax bill, they will have to pay only the annual license fee of $20 each, in addition to the tax on income. According to the wording of the clause of the new tax bill, immediately preceding, that just mentioned, however, all brokers in agricultural or farm products (such as flour, grain, &c., really are) are classed as produce brokers, and as such will be required to pay a tax of $10 on all annual sales under $10,000, and of $1 on every additional $1,000. Accepting this as the true interpretation of the clause, then the brokers doing business at the Produce Exchange would be subject to this tax, which the committee and the chairman of the meeting considered unjust and invidious. The brokers of the Produce Exchange were as truly commercial as brokers in sugar, coffee, metals, oils, or any other kind of merchandise, and should be taxed only as it was contemplated by the new bill to tax those who were specially mentioned as commercial brokers.

abstract: GARIBALDI has been driven from England. I told you so I said there would be trouble soon, and there is a precious row about it. I am sorry to write slang. My tendencies, as you know by long observa  tion, are to a style severely classic, but the red-shirted democracy is boiling up just now, and one may be excused for writing like a sans-culotte or a costermonger.
