abstract: and Prices
snippet: and Prices
lead_paragraph: The Railway inflation is arrested. The Mining bubble has been pricked. The gambling operations in Wall and William streets have been cut down to the ordinary business of the regular Stock Exchange Board. These ways to sudden fortune have been made harder and dearer than of late. Their lines are not so pleasant. Calmer counsels must return not only in this quarter, but to the Produce Exchange and to the Grocery and Dry Goods interests, in which, we are sorry to say, the spirit of inordinate speculation is (or has been for the last few months) as rife as in Stock circles. They are now met, so far as Foreign merchandise is concerned, with an increased Tariff, adding one-half to the previous rates of duty. They expect, of course, to mark up their goods accordingly. It will not be their fault if speculation is not kept up and advanced on this pretext. But it will be the fault of household consumers if they succeed. The speculators in Grain and Flour and Provisions, on the Produce Exchange and the leading markets of the West, who, under the pretext of an inflated currency, have forestalled in a large measure the regular export demand, besides inflating prices to home consumers, are met by the opening of the Canals and by reduced Money facilities for accomplishing these quick fortunes out of the prime necessities of life. They will doubtless persevere, because Gold keeps up. They may possibly succeed, but it will be the fault of household consumers if they do. In like manner the great Coal Corporations, who have recklessly advanced the price of labor upon themselves, because they could pay it by forcing up the price of coal upon the community, will no doubt persevere in their speculations, if only to keep good an extravagant market for their shares; but even here, household consumers may hold a salutary check, and the steam lines and steam ferries work on light stocks throughout the Summer and Fall months.

abstract: Leaning vs. Standish; Freight and Demurrage
snippet: Leaning vs. Standish; Freight and Demurrage
lead_paragraph: Matthew Leaning vs. William Standish. -- This was a libel for freight and demurrage. The libelant was master of the barge Anthracite. The coal was shipped at Swatara Colliery, to be delivered at NewYork, "unto Hiram Tocht or his assigns, he or they paying freight at $2.70 per ton, and demurrage at the rate of $10 per day for any detention over three days after notice of arrival has been given to the consignee." The libelant at New-Brunswick received instructions to deliver his coal to the respondent at the foot of Delancey-street. On the 18th of December the arrival of the vessel was reported, and on the 24th of December the libelant signed a receipt for "$25 of Hiram Tocht, on account of the freight." The vessel was not able to get to a berth for several days. The respondent's clerk testified that after the barge had arrived, he told the libelant the respondent would take the coal at the foot of Stanton-street, where there was a berth; but this the libelant denied. He finally got a berth at the foot of Delancey-street, and after that there was no delay in receiving the coal. The libelant claimed to recover the freight and demurrage for ten days. The respondent did not contest the freight, but denied his liability to pay demurrage.

abstract: Luke vs. Tug Eleanor, >amp;c.; Collision at Anchor
snippet: Luke vs. Tug Eleanor, >amp;c.; Collision at Anchor
lead_paragraph: Hannah M. Lake vs. The Steamtug Eleanor and the Canal-boat Beach. -- This was a libel filed by the owner of the sloop Lady of the Lake, to recover the damages occasioned to her by being run into by the canal-boat while in tow of the steam-tug, on May 27, 1863. The sloop was lying at anchor in the East River, about opposite Pier No. 27, toward the Brooklyn side of the river, but near the middle. The canal-boat was lying at the end of Pier No. 27, East River, and was taken in tow by the tug to tow her to the foot of Thirty-sixth-street, East River. The tide was strong flood. The tow was started from about Pier No. 27. on a line straight across the river, several yards ahead of the bows of the sloop.

abstract: ROAD. -- A laboring man, name unknown, was run over and instantly killed, last evening, by car No. 105, of the Third-avenue line. It appears that the man had some trouble with the driver of the car, JOHN FORSYTH, who pushed or threw him off the car, which ran over and instantly killed him. The police of the Eighteenth Precinct arrested the driver and took him to the station-house. The body of deceased was conveyed to the Bellevue Dead-house. He was dressed in a brown sack, gray knit jacket, brown Kossuth hat, and heavy shoes. He had brown hair, and was about forty years of age.

abstract: McKibben vs. Steamship C. Vanderbilt; Collision in a Fog
snippet: McKibben vs. Steamship C. Vanderbilt; Collision in a Fog
lead_paragraph: Robert H. McKibben vs. The Steamer C. Vanderbilt. -- This was a libel for collision filed by the owner of the canal boat Canisteo, which, with her lading, was sunk by a collision with the steamboat on the morning of May 16, 1863. The canal-boat was coming down the river from Troy in tow of the tug O.C. Hubbard, which had two barges attached on each side, and the Vanderbilt was bound up the river to Troy. The collision occurred about a mile below the steamer's landing place, and opposite the arsenal on the Westside of the river. Thirteen witnesses were examined in court in the case, with the usual differences of statement as to estimates of the speed of the vessels, their position and signals. There was a dense fog at the time, so that vessels were discoverable, only a few yards off. The river was swollen several feet beyond its ordinary volume, by which the channel was much enlarged.

abstract: We are enabled to give from the German papers some particulars of the fall of Duppel, in anticipation of the reports from the correspondent of the London papers. We learn from the Cologne Gazette that the Danish Gen. GERLACH was ill at the time, and that the command was entrusted to Gen. STEINMANN. At the Cabinet Council which met at Copenhagen, on Friday, 15th, it was discussed whether Duppel should be abandoned or holden. Bishop MONRAD, the Danish Premier, was for holding it. It is stated that the Danish army numbered 26,000 men, including, probably, the men brought from Fredericia. A fearful cannonade from the Prussian guns began at 11 on Sunday night, and lasted till 10 on Monday morning; and it was during this time that the preparations for a storming were made. Early on the 18th, Marshal WRANGEL set out from Gravensteins, the Prussian headquarters, for Dybbol, accompanied by a large number of officers and surgeons. All was in activity. After the capture of the redoubts and the tete-de-pont already described, the fortress of Sonderborg appeared in the foreground. There were five forts behind each other which had rendered the Prussians powerless at sea. Three of them were captured. A telegram received in Hamburg on the morning of the 19th, states that the number of killed and wounded was 3,000, and required immediate assistance. This number, no doubt, included the Danes who were put hors du combat. In Rendsburg, as in Flensburg and Hamburg, news was received, by telegraph and universally believed that the Prussians had got possession of Alsen.

abstract: -- An investigation was commenced before Coroner RANNEY yesterday, at the sixth Ward Station-house, with the view of ascertaining, if possible, the cause that led to the terrible calamity at the corner of Chatham-square and Degor-street, on Monday last. A large number of witnesses have been summoned to attend and give evidence in the case -- two only were examined. JOHN SULLIVAN, who occupied the apartments in which the fire broke out, testified at length, but he seemed to be entirely ignorant as to the origin of the conflagration. His testimony threw no light on the question which the officials are investigating. NANCY SULLIVAN, a girl, 14 years of age, daughter of the witness above-named, testified to being awake at 3 o'clock in the morning, while her father and mother were down stairs engaged in emptying tubs of water, which were used by SULLIVAN in his business as a carrier and dresser of leather. When this witness was awakened, she found the room in which she was sleeping filled with smoke. She, like her father, knew nothing as to the origin of the fire. The further investigation is adjourned until 11 o'clock this morning.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. Mr. EDWIN BOOTH commenced a short season of performances here last night. The house was, of course, crowded. It is gratifying to know that it is always so when this fine artist performs. The seats were all filled, and filled with that peculiarly calm, contemplative, intellectual...
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- Mr. EDWIN BOOTH commenced a short season of performances here last night. The house was, of course, crowded. It is gratifying to know that it is always so when this fine artist performs. The seats were all filled, and filled with that peculiarly calm, contemplative, intellectual audience that Mr. BOOTH invariably summons to his assistance when he delineates a Shakespearean character -- an audience which we may here add is totally different to any congregation of inanities that a sensation play can or ever will command. The play was "Hamlet," in which Mr. BOOTH is without an equal. It is impossible to witness his fine impersonation of the Prince without perceiving at once how thoroughly the nature as well as the intellect of Mr. BOOTH has yielded to and absorbed the conspicuous manifestations and reticent meanings of this most difficult role. There is no impassable gulf between the settled melancholy of the first act and the unsettled tribulation of the last. They both exhibit a mental condition, acute and sensitive, yet kindly and easily overwhelmed. We know of no actor who presents this temperament with so tender a fidelity, and, in fact, have never seen it preserved intact except by Mr. BOOTH. It is clearly revealed in his grand scene with the ghost, and remains in a shattered and increasingly pathetic form to the end. The fault with most artists is that they elaborate certain conspicuous portions of their parts, and ascend so many mountains of rhetoric that they have naturally to descend to swampy flats of common-place, and so become either exhaustive or dreary. Mr. BOOTH avoids these extremes, and treads the steady elevations of poetry with the conscious calmness of the mountain guide, who sees all that is sublime, yet knows how to avoid that which is fatal.

abstract: Adams, Hon. C. F., Speech at Atlantic Telegraph Dinner; Bright, John, Speech on American Affairs, at Atlantic Telegraph Dinner
snippet: Adams, Hon. C. F., Speech at Atlantic Telegraph Dinner; Bright, John, Speech on American Affairs, at Atlantic Telegraph Dinner
lead_paragraph: The promoters of the Atlantic Telegraph Company dined together on the 15th, at the Palace hotel, London, Mr. CYRUS W. FIELD in the chair. There were also present, the American Minister, Lord JOHN HAY, Mr. BRIGHT, M.P., Capt. SHEARARD OSBORNE, &c. The American Minister, in replying to the toast of his health, said: I think that the best way to keep England and the United States in harmony, is to establish the Atlantic Telegraph, which will be one of the most memorable events in history, for everything that tends to bring the two nations closer together will have the effect, I am sure, of perpetuating harmony between them. From the little observation I have made since I came here, one thing has struck me more than anything else, and that is the existence of prejudices on both sides of the Atlantic which require for their removal only a little more familiarity between the two peoples. I have seen statements made in public prints here with respect to the acts of my country which I know they would not have believed if they had had any opportunity of knowing the truth from personal experience. [Hear, hear.] So, likewise, on the other side of the Atlantic, there are newspapers which have made statements with respect to Great Britain which would not have been made if the writers had known what the British people really are, and what are their real feelings. [Cheers.] Mr. FIELD, in proposing the health of Mr. BRIGHT, said he hoped the honorable gentleman would soon visited the United States, where he would be sure of receiving a welcome such as no man living ever received.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Supervisors yesterday, an ordinance sent in by the Comptroller, authorizing him to issue bonds pursuant to recent laws, was adopted. The issue will consist of six per cent, twenty-year bonds, to be entitled, "Soldiers' Substitute Bounty Fund Bonds,"  $2,000,000; "Riot Damages Redemption Bonds," $1,000,000; and "Soldiers' Substitute and Relief...
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Supervisors yesterday, an ordinance sent in by the Comptroller, authorizing him to issue bonds pursuant to recent laws, was adopted. The issue will consist of six per cent, twenty-year bonds, to be entitled, "Soldiers' Substitute Bounty Fund Bonds," $2,000,000; "Riot Damages Redemption Bonds," $1,000,000; and "Soldiers' Substitute and Relief Redemption Bonds," $946,700; all to redeem temporary bonds heretofore issued, and which are payable respectively on the 1st of June, 1st of August and 1st of September ensuing. The Comptroller also sent in a copy of the County Tax Law, with an ordinance making the appropriations as specified therein, which were referred to the Committee on Annual Taxes. The report of the Commissioners of Charities and Correction for the first quarter of 1864 was submitted. The number of persons received in the various institutions under their charge during that period was 14,221; during the quarter there were 5,350 cases of sickness, 783 persons died, and at the close of March 6, 36 persons remained in their charge. The compensation of the legal adviser of the board (the Corporation Counsel) was fixed at $2,000 for the year -- the usual amount -- but the sum is required to be named yearly. A resolution complimentary to Mr. BLUNT, for his services on the Recruiting Committee, was unanimously adopted. Mr. STEWART called attention to erroneous statements of current expenditures contained in a circular issued by the "Citizens' Association," and moved the appointment of a committee to report the expenditures on current account of each year for several past years. The motion was carried, and Messrs. STEWART and PURDY were appointed. Alderman LONG was appointed Commissioner of "McComb's Dam," or "Central Bridge," (over Harlem River,) vice JAMES C. WILLETT, deceased. Adjourned to next Tuesday, at 3 o'clock P.M.

abstract: Rebel Ship-building in England
snippet: Rebel Ship-building in England
lead_paragraph: The cases of the vessels building in England for the rebels seem to be in abeyance just at present. The former case of the Alexandra, which was watched with so much interest on both sides of the Atlantic, came to an ignominious end, resulting only in the determination that the Government officials had made a mistake in the merest point of practice. The judgment in the case, however, resulted as favorably for the builders of the vessel as if it had been decided upon the vital questions which the case was at one time thought to involve. What further proceedings, if any, will be taken about the vessel, we can hardly conjecture. We saw the statement sometime since that the English Government had notified the builders that they were ready to deliver them the vessel. But we find an editorial in the London Law Times which says, though not vouching for the fact, that as soon as the decision of the House of Lords was rendered, "the Solicitor to the Treasury rushed to the office and filed another information against her -- the object of this hot haste being, of course, to prevent her escape;" and the editor says:

abstract: The news from the Red River is very conflicting. The steamer Matanzas, from New-Orleans April 26, arrived at this port yesterday, but brought no particulars of the retreat of Gen.
lead_paragraph: The news from the Red River is very conflicting. The steamer Matanzas, from New-Orleans April 26, arrived at this port yesterday, but brought no particulars of the retreat of Gen. BANKS from Grand Ecore to Alexandria, although such news was current in the city when the steamer left. Dispatches via Cairo bring news from Alexandria to the 24th, and represent Gen. BANKS and his force there at that time. It is further reported that the rebels attacked him on his retreat, and were beaten with a loss of one thousand men and nine pieces of artillery. The gunboats were reported safe, all rumors to the contrary notwithstanding. Per contra, regarding the retreat of Gen. BANKS, a letter from Admiral PORTER, received in Washington, dated the 17th, makes no mention of any such intention on the part of Gen. BANKS. The Admiral also reports the results of an expedition up the Washita River as far as Munroe, which captured three thousand bales of rebel cotton, brought away eight hundred negroes and destroyed much rebel property. The expedition was under Lieut.-Commander FOSTER, and was particularly successful.

abstract: Pennsylvania Reserves in Gen. Meade's Army; Fessenden, Brig.-Gen.; Killed in battle
snippet: Pennsylvania Reserves in Gen. Meade's Army; Fessenden, Brig.-Gen.; Killed in battle
lead_paragraph: Justice and strength are the main requisites in the governance of an army. Personal freedom of action or volition on the part of the individual soldier is out of the question. The order, issued by Gen. MEADE, on Monday, displays both the requisites alluded to. There are some three thousand men of the Pennsylvania Reserves about whose term of service there is a difference of reckoning of a couple of months; and some of them, it seems, have refused to do duty on the ground that their term has expired. Gen. MEADE explicitly announces to these mutineers that their conduct, will be punished with death without trial, unless they return to duty; and hereafter any soldier who refuses to do duty on a similar plea will instantly be shot without any form of trial whatever. He desires that the soldiers of the army generally should appeal to the War Department in such cases; but says he has no further word or warning for those who, at a time like the present, choose to defy authority.
headline: {'main': 'A STRONG ORDER.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A STRONG ORDER.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- This is the last of the great fairs to be given in aid of the Sanitary Commission. We trust our citizens, who are never wearied in well-doing, will give it their generous aid. New-York owes much to St. Louis, which, by its trade, is one of the great feeders to the wealth of this Metropolis. No city in the loyal States has suffered so much from the war. Contributions in aid of this fair, if in money, may be made to Mr. JOHN P. YELVERTON, President of the Bank of North America; or, if in goods, they should be sent to PROTH & FOX, No. 20 Cliff-street. Whatever is done should be done at once, for it is to be opened on the 17th inst.

abstract: Credit of and Army Movements
snippet: Credit of and Army Movements
lead_paragraph: We observe no want of reasonable confidence among the loyal masses in the pending army movements, East or West. There is some anxiety on the subject, of course, and, perhaps, some impatience. The first is pardonable -- the last, simply unreasonable. The same impatience is shown toward the Government on other points of administration, but chiefly confined, as far as we can see, to the great cities, like New-York. Gold is said to be too high, as it certainly is, and this is attributed, not to the speculations of indifferent foreigners and Southern sympathizers in our midst; not to the effect of the mischievous and unprincipled predictions of a portion of the Opposition press; not to the croaking of a certain class of politicians who would delight to see the National Currency reduced to worthlessness, as Confederate paper, and the Government to repudiation, if they could thereby breakdown the Administration and seize the reins and patronage themselves, but to "the policy of Mr. CHASE" and the redundancy of his Greenbacks.

abstract: Both Boards of the Common council met yesterday. A communication was read in each board from City Inspector BOOLE, calling attention to the fat-boiling establishments in West Thirty-ninth-street and vicinity, which he declares are not only nuisances, but are fraught with danger to the public health.
lead_paragraph: Both Boards of the Common council met yesterday. A communication was read in each board from City Inspector BOOLE, calling attention to the fat-boiling establishments in West Thirty-ninth-street and vicinity, which he declares are not only nuisances, but are fraught with danger to the public health. He proposes to banish them from the City limits, and as he has done all in his power for their abatement, that the Common Council request the Mayor to convene the Board of Health, who have the fullest power to remedy such evils. Both boards adopted a resolution embodying such a request to the Mayor. The Aldermen took up the City Tax Law and appropriation ordinance, as previously received from the Comptroller, and referred them to their Finance Committee, to report in half an hour, for which length of time a recess was immediately taken. On reassembling, the committee reported the ordinance, with the special appropriations originated at Albany, with the exception of $15,000 for the Society for the Protection of Destitute Catholic Children, reduced each to $5 -- the Common Council having no power to increase, but it has always been conceded the right to reduce appropriations. With this difference, and the striking out of the words "by contract" whenever they occur, the items in the City Tax Law were passed. The report of the committee, necessarily short, is published in the official proceedings. It contains the reasons for the changes voted. The Councilmen received the ordinance and laid it over under the rule. They also laid over the resolution to increase the pay of Corporation laborers to $2 per day, and concurred in the resolution for a joint special committee to report upon the subject of selling franchises of omnibus routes at auction. The Aldermen adopted resolutions, previously reported by a special committee, requesting the Central Park Commissioners to remove obstructions from a certain plot of ground in the Central Park, and directing the Street Commissioner to prepare it for a division parade-ground. The doubtful legality of this movement was pointed out by Messrs. HARDY and JEREMIAH; but Mr. MCMAHON said Gen. SANDFORD would "take the responsibility," if the Common Council would open the way for him, and Mr. JONES said that, under the new feature of law introduced into the City Tax Law for 1864, making the Common Council trustees of the public property of the City, they had the right to take this action -- at any rate, it would be well to know what their rights in the matter are. The Aldermen adjourned to Monday, and the Councilmen to Friday next, at 2 o'clock P.M.

abstract: Hundred-day in Western States
snippet: Hundred-day in Western States
lead_paragraph: We have not heretofore praised the policy which has on several occasions been adopted, of spasmodically calling for immense bodies of troops for very short periods of service. But the prompt popular responses to all such calls are always remarkable. The response of the Western States to the recent order for 85,000 hundred day men is the most remarkable of them all. The quota of Ohio under that call was 30,000; but the moment the order was promulgated throughout the State, telegrams began to pour into the Capital from all quarters, offering companies and regiments (already organized) of the National Guard, until on Monday last the number of 35,000 men had been offered for the public service. Indiana, IIlinois and other Western States will be about as prompt as Ohio.

abstract: The previous trots, inaugurating the opening of the season over this track, have exicted considerable attention, less on account of the intrinsic value of the purses which were contended for than for the entry of several green horses, new to the trotting turf of Long Island.
lead_paragraph: The previous trots, inaugurating the opening of the season over this track, have exicted considerable attention, less on account of the intrinsic value of the purses which were contended for than for the entry of several green horses, new to the trotting turf of Long Island. It will be remembered that in his first trot on this track, so high were the anticipapations of the cognoscenti concerning the gelding Gen. Grant, that 3 to 1 was freely laid on his winning. His ignoble defeat is also a recorded fact. Stonewall Jackson proved himself so good a horse in this trot and the one which ensued -- in which he again defeated the General with ridiculous ease, owing to the extreme nervousness of the latter, and the utter inability of his driver to get him down into a fair and square trot -- that a repetition of the same results in the trot of yesterday was deemed a foregone conclusien. There are, however, no certainties in racing or trotting, even under the most favorable circumstances of public performances, and they are materially reduced when one has something remarkably good -- which has done so much in private -- and kept so entirely "shady" as to lead to the belief that both owner and trainer knew what they were about, and the thorough value of the stock they possessed -- the confidence being enhanced by the knowledge that the animal in question was in the reliable hands of Hiram Woodruff, who, although he has driven many bad horses, always drives to win -- and the public are thoroughly acquainted with that fact.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. LANE, OF Kansas,  introduced a bill instructing the Military Committee to inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill to pay for property taken during the war, excluding slave property.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. LANE, of Kansas, introduced a bill instructing the Military Committee to inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill to pay for property taken during the war, excluding slave property. Mr. HALE introduced a bill providing for a board of competent persons to examine the claims of contractors for certain [???]re classes of gunboats who assert that they losing money on their contracts inconsequence of enhanced prices. The report of the Conference Committee on the bill establishing a Bureau of Military Justice was not agreed to. The question of what shall constitute a quorum in the Senate was discussed at length, and Mr. SHERMAN's resolution finally adopted. It provides that a quorum of the Senate consists of a majority of the Senators duly chosen; that if a majority of the Presidential electors vote for one person, he is the President; that if the election of President devolves upon the House of Representatives and the votes of a majority of the States represented in the House be cast for one person, he is the President.

abstract: National Academy of Design, Exhibition
snippet: National Academy of Design, Exhibition
lead_paragraph: There are 369 numbers in the thirty-ninth annual catalogue of the National Academy of Design -- many of them representing works of art. All things considered, the show, in point of numbers, is creditable. Artists have been exposed to many and various temptations during the past year. Their pictures have been so often exhibited that this particular exhibition has, to a great extent, lost its savor. Lastly, all -- who could -- have availed themselves of the superior popularity of the Metropolitan Fair. The demand for pictures, too, has been so great that they have not accumulated in the studios. Hence many of our most popular artists -- having sold out or being engaged in the pleasing business of advertising themselves up town -- are not represented in the present collection. On the other hand, there is a powerful delegation from that numerous class that brings more industry than talent to bear in the matter of painting, and whom we should rejoice to see prospering in any other avocation than this. We hear that many pictures were excluded -- notably an important work by Mr. NEHLIG. This is remarkable, considering the number of canvases -- not pictures -- that have been admitted. Among the names that we should have liked to see in the present catalogue are CHURCH, KENSETT, GIGNOUX, LEUTZE, JAMES HART, CASILEAR, EASTMAN JOHNSON, INNES, &c., &c. These and other well-known artists are unrepresented.

abstract: Turner vs. Segur. Persons and Property, Foreign Embassadors
snippet: Turner vs. Segur. Persons and Property, Foreign Embassadors
lead_paragraph: Turner vs. Segur. -- The defendant made a motion to have an attachment vacated. The attachment issued upon a judgment for $2,000, and defendant was a non-resident. In suppport of the motion defendant showed by the affidavits of Mr. Cushing and others that he was the Minister Plenipotentiary of the State of San Salvador accredited to the United States, and that he had received a passport from Secretary Seward, securing to him all the privileges and immunities of foreign ministers. In reply the plaintiff showed that defendant had been imprisoned in Fort Lafayette for alleged treasonable practices, and his commission had been revoked. Defendant's counsel admitted that Mr. Segurihad been imprisoned, but contended that the passport given by Mr. Seward condoned for all past offences, and restored him to all his former rights and privileges, among which is exemption from arrest. Decision reserved.

snippet: The Movement of
lead_paragraph: Lieut.-Gen. GRANT has spoken the word, and the long-anticipated "forward march" of our great armies has begun. On the first secular day of the current month, the soldiers struck their tents by the Rapidan, and probably also by the Tennessee; and, with rifle and knapsack, with the enthusiasm of volunteers and the stern spirit of veterans, advanced to the struggle with the rebellion.

abstract: Our naval reporter yesterday visited the vessels-of-war in course of construction at Greenpoint. They are silently and surely approaching completion. Within three or four months nearly all of them will be cleared of the yards and afloat. Stopping at the yard of the New-York Iron Ship-yard of Mr. J. J.S. UNDERHILL, we found the Modoc approaching the likeness of her beautiful model.
lead_paragraph: Our naval reporter yesterday visited the vessels-of-war in course of construction at Greenpoint. They are silently and surely approaching completion. Within three or four months nearly all of them will be cleared of the yards and afloat. Stopping at the yard of the New-York Iron Ship-yard of Mr. J. J.S. UNDERHILL, we found the Modoc approaching the likeness of her beautiful model. She is one of the light-draft monitors, 225 feet long, 45 feet wide and 9 feet deep. One peculiar feature in her form is that her deck is rounded, being 21 inches higher at the crown than at the edge of the deck; and thus, when the vessel is submerged, nothing but the round hump will be visible of the entire hull. This is to remedy an objection in vessels of the same class where the edge or the vessel is visible, and the ball forces its way and rips up the whole length of the deck plates. The water-tight compartments run the whole length of the vessel on each side, bulkheaded off 20 feet, so as to make separate compartments, and are filled to lower the vessel, or emptied to raise her, by engines. This vessel like all light-draft monitors, is intended for steam and inlet navigation. She will be ready for active service in September, at which time she will also be launched, being fitted out complete on the stocks. Another improvement in this vessel is the steering apparatus being double, so that when the one above the turret in the pilot-house becomes disabled, the one forward of the turret and under the deck can be used with equal facility, Mr. UNDERHILL is using his best energies in making this vessel one of the best of her class. She is constructed of the best material, four feet of white pine on each side forms the backing for the armor, which is three inches thick. The bow forms a ram; it goes three feet below the top of the deck and is as sharp as a knife. The deck will be covered with two thicknesses of half-inch iron plates, under which is the oak timber, fifteen inches thick, nearly all of which is laid. There will be one revolving turret in the centre of the vessel, with two guns.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is publishedTHIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic  letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week. The "SEMI-WEEKLY RECORD," or news summary -- being a careful synopsis and digest of the news of the day, both rebellion and general -- is alone worth double the subscription price to the paper, as it preserves in a condensed and conveniently classified form all news on interest, and must prove valuable as a record to all time.

abstract: After having labored ineffectually to defer as far as was in our power the critical moment when the attention of the people must inevitably be fixed upon the selection of a candidate for the chief magistracy of the country; after having interrogated our conscience and consulted our duty as citizens, obeying at once the sentiment of a mature conviction and a profound affection for the common country, we feel ourselves impelled, on our own responsibility, to declare to the people that the time has come for all independent men, jealous of their liberties and of the national greatness, to confer together and unite to resist the swelling invasion of an open, shameless and unrestrained patronage which threatens to engulf under its destructive wave the rights of the people, the liberty and dignity of the nation.

abstract: The steamship Ocean Queen, from Aspinwall, April 26, arrived at this port yesterday. The Government of Nicaragua had concluded a contract with Capt. PRIM to build an Interoceanic Railroad. Advices from Lima state that the question between Peru and Spain had reached an alarming stage.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Ocean Queen, from Aspinwall, April 26, arrived at this port yesterday. The Government of Nicaragua had concluded a contract with Capt. PRIM to build an Interoceanic Railroad. Advices from Lima state that the question between Peru and Spain had reached an alarming stage. The Spanish Minister, having been refused a recognition, sent an ultimatum to the Peruvian Government, which was returned unopened, and he left the country in a steamer. Report said a Peruvian war-steamer went after him, but returned without finding him, The people of Peru speak of the probability of the Spanish squadron taking possession of the Chincha Islands and of the Peruvian navy. The project of a railroad across the Andes in Chili has lost none of its interest there. The report of the Surveying Engineer says there are no serious, obstacles to be encountered.

abstract: It will be seen by the following act of the Legislature, just passed, that it is a penal offence to induce, or attempt to persuade or induce, any person to leave this State to enlist in another State. The punishment for violating this law is imprisonment, and a fine not exceeding $1,000. Our Police and public authorities should look to the violators of this law, and see that our citizens are not seduced into other States to fill their quotas while our own is deficient.

abstract: PHILADELPHIA ACADEMY OF MUSIC PRODUCTION OF MR. FRY'S NEW OPERA, NOTRE DAME OF PARIS. In accordance with extensive announcement, and after an amount of preparation that has rarely been bestowed on any wort of art, Mr. FRY'S opera of "Notre Dame of Paris" was produced at the Philadelphia Academy on Wednesday evening.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- PRODUCTION OF MR. FRY's NEW OPERA, NOTRE DAME OF PARIS. -- In accordance with extensive announcement, and after an amount of preparation that has rarely been bestowed on any wort of art, Mr. FRY's opera of "Notre Dame of Paris" was produced at the Philadelphia Academy on Wednesday evening. The fact that it can be produced is therefore established. There never could have been any real doubt on the subject, but one of our best managers had to return the manuscript, because some of his unamiable company declared that it contained impossibilities, and hence we refer to it. The Sanitary Commissioners, whose fair is shortly to commence, accepted the work as an offering to the cause, and brought it out as the leading feature of their musical programme, being assisted in that labor by the members of Mr. FRY's own family, who, it is understood, contributed liberally to the expences of the undertaking. May the tree thus planted bear good fruits in the future.

abstract: THE ALLEGED MURDEROUS CONSPIRACY IN CHAMBERS-STREET PROCEEDINGS TO DISMISS THE COMPLAINT. The case of JOHN D. LEWIS, the Chambersstreet merchant, who, it was alleged, had entered into a conspiracy a short time since to murder JOHN H. ANDERSON, merchant, doing business at No. 87 Chambers-street, came up yesterday before Justice SHANDLEY, at the ESSEX Market Police Court.
lead_paragraph: THE ALLEGED MURDEROUS CONSPIRACY IN CHAMBERS-STREET -- PROCEEDINGS TO DISMISS THE COMPLAINT. -- The case of JOHN D. LEWIS, the Chambers-street merchant, who, it was alleged, had entered into a conspiracy a short time since to murder JOHN H. ANDERSON, merchant, doing business at No. 87 Chambers-street, came up yesterday before Justice SHANDLEY, at the ESSEX Market Police Court. It will be remembered that, according to the affidavits already published, it was charged that LEWIS employed JOHN MCCARTY, JEREMIAH GALVIN and Ex-Policeman JOSEPH ACKERMAN, to inflict bodily harm on ANDERSON. The difficulty between LEWIS and ANDERSON had been of long standing, and a bitter enmity existed between them. CHAUNCEY SHAFFER, one of the counsel for Mr. LEWIS made a motion to dismiss the complaint on the ground of the insufficiency of the testimony. Counsel contended, in an argument of great length and force, that nothing had been proven against LEWIS to warrant his being held; that, in fact, he was not a party to the conspiracy. CHAS. S. SPENCER replied to these remarks, and strongly opposed the motion to dismiss the complaint. The magistrate took the papers, and gave notice that he would make his decision in a day or two. Meantime MCCARTY and ACKERMAN are held as witnesses.

abstract: Reticence of
snippet: Reticence of
lead_paragraph: According to an Eastern story, a prince of Persia once asked a philosopher of his court what he required to render him perfect. The sage replied with more sincerity than flattery, "The art of silence." The prince was a weak man, or he would have had no need to be told this. The keeping great counsels, when made, always goes with the ability to make them. First-rate capacity never babbles. It is always self-contained. That sort of intellectual fibre which engenders great conceptions is sure to be strong enough to keep them back until their hour come. That sort of will, too, which alone is equal to the highest mastery is sure, first of all, to master itself. It is your loose natures that carry loose tongues -- your pretenders that are the least reticent. "My hand of iron was not at the extremity of my arm; it was immediately connected with my head," said BONAPARTE. He kept his plans to himself. He confided nothing. He was at no man's mercy. It was thus that he was never betrayed, never surprised. It was thus that he a thousand times struck his enemies with the suddenness of a thunderbolt.
headline: {'main': "General Grant's Reticence Its Grand Promise.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "General Grant's Reticence Its Grand Promise.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: Pablo de Arieta vs. John Morrissey. -- This action is brought to recover $23,000, lost by the plaintiff in the faro saloons of the defendant in this City and in Saratoga -- $9,000 in Saratoga, in September, 1863, and $14,000 in this City soon after. Motion was made to have the complaint made more definite and certain by setting out the items. That motion was denied, and appeal taken by defendant; and motion was now made for an extension of time to answer until after the decision on the appeal. Motion granted.

abstract: An inquest was held yesterday on the body of BRIDGET HYNES, an Irish domestic aged 18 years, who committed suicide at No. 167 West Thirteenth-street: The deed was effected by means of a dose of arsenic, which, from all the testimony in the case it seems she deliberately administered to herself for the purpose of self-destruction. Dr. BOUTON made a post-mortem examination when he found a quantity of arsenic in the stomach of deceased. No cause has been assigned for the commission of the act.

abstract: The news from the several armies of the Union this morning will be read with intense interest. Though we have yet no announcement of actual collison, there is the utmost assurance for stating and believing that the great armies under Gens. SHERMAN, MEADE and BUTLER are all well in motion, and but a few days can elapse are we have stirring news.
lead_paragraph: The news from the several armies of the Union this morning will be read with intense interest. Though we have yet no announcement of actual collison, there is the utmost assurance for stating and believing that the great armies under Gens. SHERMAN, MEADE and BUTLER are all well in motion, and but a few days can elapse are we have stirring news. The Army of the Potomac has again successfully crossed the Rapidan, but the enemy was not found in force. The impression prevailed that LEE was falling back on Richmond. Gen. GRANT telegraphed on Wednesday that forty-eight hours would decide where he would have his battle. That time is up to-day. Gen. BUTLER's army embarked on transports on Tuesday and Wednesday, and were to be accompanied by a fleet of monitors and gunboats. That column expects warm work. The news from Gen. SHERMAN is, that he was to move on Monday, or very soon thereafter, in three grand columns, into Northern Alabama and Georgia.

A postponement of a day or so may hare taken place, but we shall soon have stirring news from the West also. Gen. SHERMAN's army is very large, and under efficient organization and discipline.

lead_paragraph: We have been waiting for the verdict of the Coroner's jury in the case of the Chenango before making the inquest the subject of comment; but no verdict seems to be forthcoming. What is the cause of the delay we are not aware: probably the jury cannot agree as to the cause of the explosion. But there were some facts developed by the trial which deserve public attention, whatever verdict the jury may decide to render.

abstract: Women's Movement on Dress Economy; the Call for the
snippet: Women's Movement on Dress Economy; the Call for the
lead_paragraph: We published yesterday the constitution and the address of the new society in Washington among the ladies, for the promotion of economy in the purchase of foreign imports. This is undoubtedly a movement most wise and patriotic. It will produce a marked impression through the whole country. There are some points, both in the rhetoric and the political economy of the address which we might find fault with. But in view of the noble and self-sacrificing objects of the association, these things are not to be considered. Still, it would be well for other ladies, who are forming similar associations, to remember that the limited exports of gold per se, is not an evil in a country which produces gold, any more than the export of petroleum. But without going into the necessities of the influence of gold on our currency and on exchange, the grand and simple fact remains, patent to all -- that a nation is made up of individuals and cannot expend its surplus on luxuries and at the same time carry on a war, any more than an individual. We can possibly have only so much means to waste or destroy, and if we consume them all in one way, we cannot in another.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a bill was introduced to provide additional safeguards against smuggling, by the appointment of additional Inspectors of Revenue. The bill to establish mail steam service to Brazil was reported and discussed at length, but no action taken. A bill was reported to enable the people of Nevada to form a State Government, by holding an election for the adoption of a Constitution. The National Currency Bill was taken up, and the Senate considered it at length, but no conclusion reached when the Senate adjourned.

abstract: About daylight yesterday morning an attempt was made to set fire to the office of the Provost-Marshal of the Seventh District, Capt. WAGNER, at No. 63 Third-avenue. The incendiary bored a hole through the ceiling of the third floor from the adjoining premises. He then saturated the floor with burning-fluid, and applied a match. Fortunately, the flames were discovered in time by the officer on duty, who promptly extinguished them. Fire-Marshal BAKER is making an investigation of the case. No arrest had been made at a late hour last night.

abstract: Yesterday Comptroller BRENNAN appointed GEORGE H. PURSER, (Dem.,) JONATHAN, W. ALLEN, (Rep.,) and CHRISTIAN B. WOODRUFF, (Dem.) Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments, in place of the present board, whose term of office expired on last Monday. Mr. ALLEN is reappointed from the old board, who had been in office ten years, five of which were a continuance authorized by a special act of the Legislature. The two Commissioners who go out of office are JOSIAH W. BROWN, (Dem.,) and AMOR J. WILLIAMSON, (Rep., editor of the Dispatch.) Mr. WOODRUFF is one of our State Senators, and until the other day, and since last Summer, held the office of Inspector of Railroads, at a salary of $2,500 per year, an office for the abolishment of which Mayor GUNTHER has but just signed a resolution passed by the Common Council. Mr. WOODRUFF resigned this position just about the time the Mayor signed it out of existence. The salary of each Commissioner of Taxes and Assessments is $3.500 per year. The old board got a special bill through the Legislature to keep them in office five years more, but they failed to induce Gov. SEYMOUR to approve it. Yesterday afternoon, at 1 o'clock, the new board demanded possession of the books, papers, &c. The demand was refused by the old board, and the case went into court. The old board claim that the law continuing them in office, which is somewhat ambiguous in respect to appointment of successors, does not give the Comptroller the power to appoint.

abstract: Anabella Patterson, by her Guardian, vs. James Harrington. -- This was an action for $6,000 damages for injuries received by reason of being run over by a butcher's wagon belonging to defendant, and driven by one of his servants, counsel for the plaintiff contending that the accident occurred through the negligence of defendant's servant, the driver of the cart. Defendant's counsel maintained that it was the result of negligence on the part of the lady. His Honor charged the jury that the plaintiff was entitled to recover if it appeared from the evidence that she had used due care, and that the defendant's driver had been careless. The jury, after being out fifteen minutes, returned with a verdict for the plaintiff for $3,000 damages.

abstract: Grant's New Campaign against Richmond
snippet: Grant's New Campaign against Richmond
lead_paragraph: The news that BEAUREGARD is at Petersburgh with 30,000 men, indicates clearly enough that the Confederate armies are going to battle for their capital. We have had the same rumors at the opening of this campaign that we have had at the opening of every preceding campaign that the rebels were about to abandon Richmond, and that their armies would retreat somewhere south of the James River, if not to North Carolina. Those who believed this have always heretofore been disappointed, and it is altogether unlikely that the event will take place now. It is as necessary for the rebels to hold Richmond as it is for us to take it; and they will never leave it unless overthrown in the field, or unless some masterly strategic movement on the part of GRANT renders the holding of it absolutely impossible. It cannot as yet be told what will be the effect of this apparition of BEAUREGARD upon the movements of BUTLER's army. Its purpose is, of course, to neutralize that army, and from Petersburgh BEAUREGARD can operate quickly against BUTLER whether the latter attempt an advance upon Richmond by the south side of the James, or by the Peninsula. His appearance at this moment, and at that point, is certainly a shrewd thing. We have telegraphic news that BUTLER has reached and occupied City Point, at the mouth of the Appomattox, and only ten miles from BEUREGARD's position at Petersburgh, so that an opportunity is presented for an immediate collision.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. Mr. EDWIN BOOTH will appear here to-night in his great character of "Richard the Third." The success of this gentleman during the week bas been almost without a parallel; and it has been universally remarked by press and public that he has never been seen to such advantage.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- Mr. EDWIN BOOTH will appear here to-night in his great character of "Richard the Third." The success of this gentleman during the week bas been almost without a parallel; and it has been universally remarked by press and public that he has never been seen to such advantage. His extraordinary performance of "Hamlet" had to be repeated last night in consequence of the demands at the box office. We doubt if the modern stage has ever seen anything to equal it.

abstract: The news from the Armies in Virginia is of a highly interesting character. The most important part of it, however, is the announcement of Gen. BUTLER'S successful landing at City Point, Va., and the report of the occupation of Petersburgh by the rebel General BEAUREGARD, with 30,000 men.
lead_paragraph: The news from the Armies in Virginia is of a highly interesting character. The most important part of it, however, is the announcement of Gen. BUTLER'S successful landing at City Point, Va., and the report of the occupation of Petersburgh by the rebel General BEAUREGARD, with 30,000 men. Petersburgh is only ten miles from City Point. The news from the Army of the Potomac is to the effect that it has advanced far enough south of the Rapidan to emerge from "The Wilderness," the dense forest in which the battle of Chancellorsville was fought, and that LEE is undoubtedly falling back to Richmond. In a skirmish at Thoroughfare Gap on Thursday, a rebel Lieutenant was killed, who had upon his person an order from Gen. LEE, calling upon the cavalry forces, in Northern Virginia, to fall back and join him.

abstract: Mr. Lewis Exonerated
snippet: Mr. Lewis Exonerated
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon Justice SHANDLEY, of the Essex Market Police Court, rendered a decision on the motion to discharge Mr. JOHN D. LEWIS, a merchant doing business at the corner of Chambers and Church streets, from arrest. The motion was granted, and LEWIS was released from the heavy bonds under which he was placed about two weeks ago. In rendering his decision, the Magistrate said: "After a careful examination of the affidavits in the case, I am of opinion that the evidence is insufficient to warrant me in holding Mr. JOHN D. LEWIS to answer upon the charge against him. Although the defendant, JOSEPH ACKERMAN; has confessed his guilt, he cannot, under the law, criminate anybody but himself. I deemed that the ends of justice would be promoted by using MCCARTY and GALVIN as witnesses."

abstract: Speculators at Work
snippet: Speculators at Work
lead_paragraph: -- THE SPECULATORS AT WORK. -- It is all well to charge the high and rapidly increasing prices of everything to the inflation of the currency. But a great deal of this increase is due to the direct combinations of speculators, who take advantage of the public notions on this subject to keep supplies out of market until they can force prices to a very high figure.

abstract: a lad 14 years of age, born in Germany, came to this City when he was about two years of age. Soon after his arrival here he was taken sick and lost his hearing. By degrees he became first deaf and then dumb. For nearly ten years he was a mute, unable to hear the loudest voice or articulate a word. About one year ago he was placed by his parents in the hands of Dr. LIGHTHILL, who has so far succeeded in restoring to him his lost powers of hearing and utterance, that he can converse with those who speak to him distinctly and deliberately. During the past four or five months he has been under the tuition of Mr. BENNECKE, and has made considerable progress in reading and arithmetic. -- N.Y. Tribune.

abstract: Brady's Photographs of Sanitary Fair Committees
snippet: Brady's Photographs of Sanitary Fair Committees
lead_paragraph: OF THE SANITARY FAIR. -- That the kindly influences of the New-York Sanitary Fair, the pleasant and beneficial grasping of hands that took place there, should not die out, it is desirable that every souvenir of that great undertaking should be preserved, and its aim and triumph commemorated in all ways possible. The public has, to a great extent, taken the matter in its own hands. All who visited the Fair left it with some remembrances of its useful existence. Every day we see in the streets a strange horse-shoe device attached to the button-holes or enthusiastic citizens, and it is impossible to visit a home, be it in the western avenues or the eastern purlieus of the City, without observing in the place of honor some prized purchase made in the great caravansaries of charity. But better than these, if less substantial to the soldier, were the genial friendships that were cemented in the common cause. These, if they do not otherwise appeal to the public, show us at least now heartily the rich work when the poor need their services. The labor and self-sacrifice that were involved in the management of the fair will probably never be made known. It was almost incredible. We have heard it stated that some of the young lady volunteers were absolutely killed by the unaccustomed fatigue imposed upon them, and by the necessity it involved of breathing for many hours an atmosphere which a visitor could barely endure during a hasty scamper through the various buldings.

abstract: Wounded Soldiers, forethought for
snippet: Wounded Soldiers, forethought for
lead_paragraph: It can have escaped no one's memory that on the occasion of nearly every great battle since the war commenced, one of the first appeals to public feeling and sympathy has taken the shape of an urgent request for supplies of material for bandages for the wounded. It was so at the close of all the great engagements from Shiloh to Antietam. Admitting the vast improvements effected in every detail of the army hospital arrangements within the last two years, and assuming that the supplementary labors of the Sanitary Commission have aided greatly as auxiliaries of the surgical department of the army, it would be well not to forget that at no period of the war have there been such gigantic operations as the present simultaneously in progress. Of the three-quarters of a million men that compose the national army, it is no excessive estimate to reckon that a half million will be either in the very blaze and shock of battle, or marching thither-ward with eager and impatient step, before the few remaining hours of the week have elapsed. For the contingencies of battles in which a host so enormous will be engaged, it is no disparagement to the forethought, judgment and ability, either of the Medical Department or the Sanitary Commission, to suggest that even further volunteer effort may possibly be needed. Whether the pending campaigns shall take the shape of open contests in the field, or of prolonged sieges in front of Richmond in the East and Atlanta in the West, it would be childish to disguise the certainty of bloodier work in prospect than has yet marked the progress of the conflict.

abstract: The vessels-of-war now being built at Jersey City are progressing finely. There are about 400 hands constantly employed on the iron-clads Manhattan, Mahopac, and the iron double-ender, Mohongo, at the yard of the Messrs. SECOR. The Manhattan is already launched, turret up, gun carriages being lowered, and about 200 hands are busy upon her decks
lead_paragraph: The vessels-of-war now being built at Jersey City are progressing finely. There are about 400 hands constantly employed on the iron-clads Manhattan, Mahopac, and the iron double-ender, Mohongo, at the yard of the Messrs. SECOR. The Manhattan is already launched, turret up, gun carriages being lowered, and about 200 hands are busy upon her decks and interior, working from sunrise till dark to get her ready for active service. Steam will be got up to-day to try her engines and boilers; the guns will be set by Friday, and between that time and the 15th, having made her trial trip, she will go to the Navy-yard to be put in commission. The Mahopac and Mohongo are on the stocks. The Mahopac will be launched at full moon, the 21st, when the tide will be very high. She will be ready for launching next week. The Mohongo will be launched about the 1st of June. The following are the dimensions of the vessels: The Mahopac, 235 feet long, 42 feet wide and 14 feet deep; the Manhattan the same; the Mohongo is 255 feet long, 35 feet beam and 14 feet deep. The ram on the Mahopac is 12 feet long and sharp as a knife. She is a counterpart of the Manhattan, with one exception. Capt. ERICSSON has applied an invention in this craft which will be of inestimable value in saving life. It is a sounding-well -- the leadsman standing inside of the turret and dropping his line through a hole in the bottom of the vessel, and thus attaining the same end as when the leadsman has his person exposed, in approaching an enemy's fortification, to ascertain the exact depth of water. The deck of the vessel is fastened from the outside, and the armor is put on top of that, making a solid mass of iron and wood together. The iron armor is nine inches thick, with the usual wood backing. The turret is finished, and will be put on her when launched. She will be ready to go in commission in about eight weeks from the time she is launched. The engines, forty-eight-inch cylinder by eleven inch stroke, are in, and ready to receive the copper pipes and connections.

abstract: Headley, J. T. Chaplains and Clergy of the Revolution; Vaux, Gilbert. Villa and Cottage Designs
snippet: Headley, J. T. Chaplains and Clergy of the Revolution; Vaux, Gilbert. Villa and Cottage Designs
lead_paragraph: We believe that the statistics of publication place Mr. HEADLEY, beyond all controversy, in the proud position of the most popular author of America the writer whose works have been most largely bought and most widely circulated among his countrymen during the present century, which, of course, is as much as to say, of any or of all time past. This popularity has not been aided, as often happens, by the reflex wave of European criticism. Half a million volumes of Mr. HEADLEY's books have found a market here, though scarcely one of his works has been honored with foreign critical approval. They have Struck a chord that finds its response in the breasts and heads of the American people, and their author may well be proud of the audience he commands and sways at will. Less vividly attractive in subject than his military historical biographies, "The Clergy of the Revolution" yields to none of the author's writings in solid and substantial interest, while it enjoys the advantage over most of them afforded by a subject new, fresh and attractive not only in itself, but by association with the great series of events intimately connected with, and growing out of it. If the war of the American Revolution is honorably distinguished in many importan respects from other contests, for the gravity, the earnestness, the sobriety of feeling, which marked its progress through the most startling vicissitudes of sunshine and gloom, the difference is largely to be attributed, especially in New-England, to the pulpit and the clerical element, there a recognized power in the State, whose aid was formally and earnestly invoked to sanctify the people's cause. The remembrance of CROMWELL and his Ironsides, equally prompt for spiritual or bodily combat, was not totally extinct in those days, nor even of GUSTAVUS ADOLPHUS, the Protestant Lion of the North, in whose, armies "the drums best to prayers, morning and evening, as regularly as for parade." If examples were needed, these were sufficient to show that praying never hindered fighting in a good cause. Mindful of this truth, Mr. HEADLEY. has taken pains in this work to record the deeds of those faithful teachers who feared not to follow where their doctrines led, and were never found wanting in the hour of difficulty or danger. To give to these men the place they ought to occupy in the history of the Revolution is his object, coupled, indeed, with the view of directing the minds of the generation now rising into manhood, not only to the importance of religious influences, but to the great source of all national blessings, without which battle-fields and strong legions are in vain.

abstract: We publish this morning a list of the members of a British association, established to promote the destruction of the United States. We don't give it as any novel development, inasmuch as it has for some time figured as an advertisement, not only in the Manchester Guardian, from which we transfer it, but in several of the English papers. It has never before been presented to American readers, and it is well that Americans should have the palpable evidence before them of the atrocious means employed in England to overthrow their Government.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen met yesterday. The only business transacted was to consider and pass upon the general appropriation ordinance, which had been received from the Board of Aldermen on Wednesday. It was finally concurred in by a large vote, without amendment.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen met yesterday. The only business transacted was to consider and pass upon the general appropriation ordinance, which had been received from the Board of Aldermen on Wednesday. It was finally concurred in by a large vote, without amendment. Mr. OPDYKE endeavored to get in a clause reducing all salaries ten per cent., and Mr. JACQUES spoke at length against the propriety of adopting the ordinance at all, because the Legislature had assumed their prerogatives and provided for the expenditure of all the items named in the City Tax Law, if the Common Council neglected to make the appropriations. As adopted the ordinance obeys the Tax Law in respect to special appropriations, with two or three exceptions, only by making the amount of each $5. The items of the ordinance foot up $5,117,259 02, or $621,158 less than the aggregate of the items contained in the City Tax Law, which foot up $5,738,417 02. The Board adjourned to Monday, at 2 o'clock P.M.

abstract: Speculation,>amp;c.,--the Duty of the Hour
snippet: Speculation,>amp;c.,--the Duty of the Hour
lead_paragraph: Let our good people only persevere in the work of economy, and of repressing inordinate speculation, of which the preliminary signs are auspicious, and they will assuredly command more time and give more money to the great energies of the War. They will every way increase their earnestness in its support. They will be better prepared for the always uncertain contingencies of battle. The struggle must go on, in any immediate event, until the rebellion is put down. The Richmond paper may be right, speaking for its own side, in assuming that this is to be the last year of the War. It is wrong, as it has been before, in assuming that our side will give up if defeated in the coming struggle. There has been too much loyal blood and treasure expended in reclaiming one-half the territory originally in revolt, and in our attempts upon Richmond and Charleston, to leave the work half finished. It is not possible to do so, short of the self-destruction of the Government. Our armies may be repeatedly baffled, as they were on the Potomac last Spring and in the gloomy Summer of 1862. But the work, will go on. To this determination the popular mind is fully made up. There is no probability of its reversal, come what may, of the Spring campaign. And this being so, our loyal masses at home are imperiously called upon, by the claims of our gallant armies in the field, and the necessities of a heavily burthened Treasury, to give their best time and thoughts and means to the prosecution of the War.

abstract: Ware, John, M. D., of Boston
snippet: Ware, John, M. D., of Boston
lead_paragraph: Dr. JOHN WARE died suddenly at his residence, in Boston, on Friday, April 29, at the age of 68 years He was the son of Rev. HENRY and MARY (CLARKE) WARE, and was born in Hingham, Massachusetts, 19th December, 1795. His father was, for several years, minister in Hingham, and was afterward Hollis Professor of Theology in Cambridge. His mother was daughter of Rev. JONAS CLARKE, of Lexington, and grand-daughter of Rev. THOMAS HANCOCK, who was grandfather of the celebrated JOHN HANCOCK. He graduated with high honors at Harvard College in 1813. Immediately after leaving college he began the study of medicine, and received his degree of M.D. in 1816, when he began the practice of his profession in Duxbury, but in 1817 he removed to Boston, where he resided the remainder of his life. He soon acquired an extensive practice, and attained to the highest rank in professional skill. In 1832 he was appointed Professor of the Theory and Practice of Medicine in the Medical Department of Harvard College, and held this office until 1858. He published various medical lectures and discourses, essays on "Croup," on "Delirium Tremens," and on "Haemoptysis;" a volume on the "Philosophy of Natural History," and a "Memoir of Henry Ware, Jr." (Boston, 1846.)

abstract: John Anderson vs. The Mayor, Aldermen and Commonalty of the City of New-York. -- This was one of the riot claims against the City. The premises No. 22 Rector-street, occupied by the plaintiff, were attacked by the mob on the 14th of July last, and the plaintiff's stock and furniture were destroyed or carried away. Counsel for the Corporation contended that plaintiff could only recover for that portion of the property that was actually destroyed by the mob on the premises, and not for that portion stolen or taken away. Plaintiff's counsel maintained that he was entitled to the whole amount of actual loss to him, viz., $211.

abstract: The ease with which the green horse Dexter defeated Stonewall Jackson, Lady Collins and Gen. Grant, at the Fashion track, on the occasion of his first public appearance on Wednesday, naturally excited much curiosity in connection with his second innings at the Union yesterday; notwithstanding which, the attendance was confined to a few leading trotting men, owing to the apparent obliviousness of Messrs. SHAW & WHITE, the proprietors of the track, who do not seem to consider it worth their while to append to their advertisement the hour at which the last train starts for the course in time to witness the trot, or in fact any other information necessary for the uninitiated. That ante-divulian specimen of railroad creation, the Jamaica line -- which, in parenthesis, we venture to suggest should be entombed "lock, stock and bottle" in its old closed-up tunnel under Atlantic-street, as a medlaeval institution so far behind the age that the sooner it is put out of sight the better -- undertook in its effete wisdom to alter the time of its cars from 1:45 to 1 o'clock in consequence, we presume, that as the days are lengthening that the public should be compelled to "hurry up" and plant their feet on the sacred soil of Long Island an hour or two earlier than necessary either for business or pleasure. The result was that numbers who depended on the old time-table found to their disgust that the train had gone three-quarters of an hour previously, and there was no other until 3 P.M. whereupon they summarily returned to New-York, and the proprietors of the track lost just the amount of gate money that there were disappointed individuals, and had themselves only to blame.

The result was that numbers who depended on the old time-table found to their disgust that the train had gone three-quarters of an hour previously, and there was no other until 3 P.M. whereupon they summarily returned to New-York, and the proprietors of the track lost just the amount of gate money that there were disappointed individuals, and had themselves only to blame.

abstract: BASE BALL NEWS. Ninth annual opening day of the Enterprise Club of Bedford, L.I. This veteran club having, through the kindness of Messrs. WEED  DECKER, secured the famous Capitoline Ball Grounds for their use on their regular practice days, which will be Wednesday and Saturday afternoons of each week during the ensulting season, will commence play at 2 o'clock P.M., this day.
lead_paragraph: BASE BALL NEWS. -- Ninth annual opening day of the Enterprise Club of Bedford, L.I. This veteran club having, through the kindness of Messrs. WEED & DECKER, secured the famous Capitoline Ball Grounds for their use on their regular practice days, which will be Wednesday and Saturday afternoons of each week during the ensulting season, will commence play at 2 o'clock P.M., this day. It is hoped that such members of the press as can find leisure to attend, all members of clubs belonging to the Base Ball Convention, and the public generally will honor the occasion with their presence. Messrs. WEED & DECKER having already earned a meritorious reputation among the skating community, are entitled to additional praise for their efforts to advance and stimulate another of our healthful out-door sports, and one, too, which is purely and solely American in its character. The Fulton-avenue cars at Fulton ferry afford a direct means of transportation.

abstract: the French Plan; Cooperative Societies in France
snippet: the French Plan; Cooperative Societies in France
lead_paragraph: Nearly all fair-minded persons who have investigated the subject, agree now that French socialism brought forth from its fanciful theories, one great economical fact which is of immense importance to the well-being of the working classes: the existence and the utility of "Cooperative Societies." A recent writer in the London Spectator has given a most valuable account of such of these associations as have survived the fall of Socialism, among the workingmen of Paris.

abstract: The popular reception of GARIBALDI in London struck the most blase circles of English society with a new sensation. More than 600,000 persons poured out into the streets of the great metropolis, without the military or scarce the police to restrain, of all classes from the costermonger to the members of Parliament, to welcome the Italian Revolutionist. There was no martial procession or civic ceremony, but incessant waving of hats and handkerchiefs, and "huzzas which shook the houses," and a throng so vast and so much in earnest as apparently to give even the most critical of the public that thrill of sympathy which an immense multitude in excitement always produces. It was observed that all this grand ovation from every class of a city, the most given up in the world to material pursuits, was toward a man who "probably had not a hundred pounds at his bankers;" who was not titled or noble born; who had been defeated in a revolution, and who could not now benefit or profit any living Englishman. To conservative England he must have represented the very spirit of Red Republicanism which had been disturbing Europe for nearly twenty years. To successful and prejudiced England he was only a poor "foreigner," lame from a foolish outbreak against his own Government, without power or followers. And yet all England rose to do him honor; the City of London stopped in its immense and busy life to greet him; the Prince of Wales called on him; the nobility and gentlemen, the mechanics and factory workmen, all paid him their own mark of respect.
lead_paragraph: The popular reception of GARIBALDI in London struck the most blase circles of English society with a new sensation. abstract: -- The Singapore correspondent of the Messager du Midi gives the following information relative to the Japanese Embassy, just arrived at Marseilles: "In 1862 the ambassadors of the Talcoon in Paris had very skillfully demanded that Japan should not be constrained to open all her ports to foreigners so long as there was any cause to fear that security in the interior could not be relied on. They offered every possible facility to commerce at Nagasaki and other points, but at none of those that had been wished for. The Frence Government accepted the demand, but on condition that Japan should reduce the duties on French wines and other articles of Paris manufacture. On returning to Yeddo, and after twenty months' hesitation, that is to say, after having acquired the conviction that nothing could be done by force against the foreigners, a decision was come to, to yield on the question of the tariffs, in order to demand in their turn the fulfillment of the promises made at Paris. They hastened to the French Minister to offer him to take up the customs' question. A discussion took place, and in the end they yielded, as they said, out of sympathy to France. The following is the official circular of the Charge d'Affaires, which explains what was done: 'The undersigned Minister Plenipotentiary and Charge d'Affaires at Japan has the honor to inform the French merchants that the Japanese Government has just come to a decision, conformably to the engagements stipulated at Paris by the Ambassadors of the Talcoon, in October, 1862, relative to the reduction in the duties on French wines and articles of Paris manufacture. That reduction will take place in the following proportions: Wines and liquids to 5 per cent., instead of 35 per cent., and Paris articles to 5 per cent. and 6 per cent., according to classes, instead of 20 per cent. The present measure is to come into force for Yokohama on the 8th of February, and for the other ports on the 8th of March.' "

abstract: FIVE MEN DROWNED FOUR OF THEM UNKNOWN. An unknown man, about forty years of age, five feet seven inches in height, stout built, with long, dark hair and whiskers, was found floating in the water at the foot of Thirty-fourth-street, East River, Deceased was dressed in a block coat and pants, brown vest, gray woolen stockings and laced shoes. Coroner COLLIN held an inquest on the body....The
lead_paragraph: FIVE MEN DROWNED -- FOUR OF THEM UNKNOWN. -- An unknown man, about forty years of age, five feet seven inches in height, stout built, with long, dark hair and whiskers, was found floating in the water at the foot of Thirty-fourth-street, East River, Deceased was dressed in a block coat and pants, brown vest, gray woolen stockings and laced shoes. Coroner COLLIN held an inquest on the body....The same Coroner held an inquest on the body of an unknown man found in the water at the foot of Thirty-seventh-street, East River. Inasmuch as there were no marks of violence on the body, a verdict of death from drowning was rendered. Deceased was about 35 years of age, five feet eight inches in height; was dressed in black pants, blue flannel shirt, and army shoes. He had a leather strap about his body....Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest on the body of an unknown man found in the water at the foot of Beach-street. N.R. Deceased was about five feet seven inches in height; dark hair and goatee. His dress consisted of a white muslin shirt and a dark coat, pants and vest. The body had been in the water several weeks....Another unknown man was found in the water at the foot of One Hundred and Eighteenth-street, E.R. The body had been in the water but a few hours. He was five feet six inches in height, had straight brown hair and hazel eyes. Deceased, who was obviously an Irish laborer, had on when found, corduroy pants and around his waist a leather strap....Coroner COLLIN held an inquest on the body of THOMAS SYMS, a porter, employed recently at No. 8 Beaver-street, who was drowned at the foot of Whitehall-street, in consequence of accidentally falling overboard while intoxicated.
