abstract: -At six out 6 o'clock last evening, an altercation arose between PATRICK O'SHEA and WM. HAMMELL, in CLARK's liquor-store. No. 45 Henry-street, which resulted in O'SHEA being so seriously stabbed in the abdomen that it is feared the injuries will prove fatal. It appears the parties were friends, and had been drinking together in the liquor-store, when a wrestling match was proposed and accepted. In the wrestle HAMMEL was thrown, which so incensed him that he drew a knife and attacked O'SHEA, stabbing him so severely in the abdomen that the intestines of the wounded man protruded. He was taken to the New-York Hospitals, where the surgeon in attendance gave but slight hopes for his recovery. In the excitement of the stabbing, HUMMEL fled, and up to a late hour last night had not been arrested although the Seventh Precinct Police are searching dilligently for him.
lead_paragraph: -At six out 6 o'clock last evening, an altercation arose between PATRICK O'SHEA and WM. HAMMELL, in CLARK's liquor-store. No. 45 Henry-street, which resulted in O'SHEA being so seriously stabbed in the abdomen that it is feared the injuries will prove fatal. It appears the parties were friends, and had been drinking together in the liquor-store, when a wrestling match was proposed and accepted. In the wrestle HAMMEL was thrown, which so incensed him that he drew a knife and attacked O'SHEA, stabbing him so severely in the abdomen that the intestines of the wounded man protruded. He was taken to the New-York Hospitals, where the surgeon in attendance gave but slight hopes for his recovery. In the excitement of the stabbing, HUMMEL fled, and up to a late hour last night had not been arrested although the Seventh Precinct Police are searching dilligently for him.

abstract: The correspondent of the Times, writing from Alexandria, on the 12th ult., says: "I have to correct some inaccuracies in my last letter concerning the commission which has arrived to examine the Viceroy with respect to the ironclads at Liverpool. Mr. FRANCIS is here as government commissioner, Mr. HAMIL as the government lawyer, and Mr. FLETCHER on behalf of M. BRAVARY, for whose account the vessels were said to have been built. From further inquiries I have made, I am led to believe that if SAID PASHA, the late Viceroy, did order any ironclads, he did not do so in England. ISMAIL PASHA has very properly refused to undergo any official examination, as unbefitting his dignity, and also as affording a dangerous precedent, which might be used whenever it was desired to coerce him into granting any claim or measure which he would not otherwise be inclined to yield. Under what circumstances such an annoyance might be used  will suggest itself at once to those who know the chief points now in dispute between this Government and foreigners; and where so much turns on what a preeeding Viceroy did or did not say or do, examining commissioners would force themselves every day on His Highness' patience. I believe the commission will be received by His Excellency SHERIFF PASHA, Minister for Foreign Affairs, who will communicate whatever information this Government can give in this case."

abstract: Battle News and Dealers in Conjecture
snippet: Battle News and Dealers in Conjecture
lead_paragraph: It would be idle to look for a moderate regard to probability in those bulletins which supply the details of battles several days in advance of their occurrence. But one might expect some revision of the system, which, if it did not relieve the utterers of fabricated news from disgrace, might, at least, redeem their operations from the character of absolute and unpardonable folly. So long as the war continues there will not only be a class of vampires found glutting in the life-blood of the country, but there will be professional pimps to cater to their lust. It is part of the national sacrifice to endure this affliction, in addition to the prime evil of the war itself. And what honest men and faithful citizens have to see to is, that they do not unconsciously aggravate the crime of defaming the army and disheartening its leaders by hasty assumptions, by giving to honest hope and steadfast faith the place which can only belong to actions done and duty fulfilled. While we abate no part of our condemnation against those who eagerly anticipate defeat, let us not forget, if we would be wise, that there is error and danger in the opposite extreme, which blazons forth victory in advance of its achievement, and opens the way for disappointment and chagrin by prefiguring impossible exploits and supernatural successes. In the early stages of the conflict it might have been a pardonable weakness to anticipate uninterrupted victory for the national cause, but the lesson has surely been often enough repeated for some men to learn that there is no miraculous interposition to be looked for in this war -- that feeble generalship, immature plans of operation, occasional unsteadiness of nerve in the ranks, beside the thousand accidents of position, of mistaken orders, of climatic changes, have all to be reckoned with sober care in forming any estimate of value as to the fate of a campaign. And, therefore, wise and clear-headed men, however firmly assured of a steady advancement for the cause they sustain, and of ultimate triumph for the right, will discourage whatever appears a hasty assumption of complete success -- content in the conviction that the best has been aimed at in the Council of War, and that the bravest has been done in the field of battle.

abstract: CHARLES SEIDERWITZ was brought before the Commissioner yesterday morning charged with passing a $100 counterfeit greenbank upon ROBERT HERMAN. It appears from the evidence that the prisoner came in hastily to a cigar store No. 549 Broadway where HERMAN was and asked for change for a $100 bill HERMAN immediately gave him two $50 bills with which the accused went out of the store, Subsequent examination, of the bill proved it to be a counterfeit moderately well executed. The prisoner did not deny that he had the bill changed at the cigar store but he claimed that he did not know it to be a counterfeit, he himself having received showed that faith. The testimony of the parties showed that the accused was well known at the cigar store that he resided or did business in the neighborhood; that he had not attempted to run away, and that his character was good. Upon fact of the large denomination of the bill, and that the accused went to a friend and neighboor where he was well known to get it changed, the Commissioner came to the conclusion that there was no proof that accused knew the bill to be spurious, and he must therefore be discharged, Prisoner was accordingly released.

abstract: The New-York Ladies' Educational Union have purchased a beautiful and commodious property in Flushing, L.I., where they have permanently eatablished their institution for the protection and education of the children of our soldiers, both of the army and navy. The building will accommodate three hundred. They have now in charge one hundred and daily applicants are begging, through parents or friends, to be admitted. The ladies are anxious to...
lead_paragraph: The New-York Ladies' Educational Union have purchased a beautiful and commodious property in Flushing, L.I., where they have permanently eatablished their institution for the protection and education of the children of our soldiers, both of the army and navy. The building will accommodate three hundred. They have now in charge one hundred and daily applicants are begging, through parents or friends, to be admitted. The ladies are anxious to relieve the wants of these little ones whose natural protectors have fallen on the battle-field or lie in hospital disabled from wounds, and they appeal to our citizens for assistance. They want contributions of money, of clothing, of provisions of every sort, and so fast as they shall receive the aid required, so fast will they most gladly admit the boys and girls of our patriots, and be unto them both father and mother so for as possible. Send all donations to "Receiving Office," Patriot Orphan Home, No. 14 Bible House, Astor-place, to which place address all communications.

abstract: We have information that up to 7 P.M. of Wednesday evening last no firing was heard in the direction taken by our Army of the Potomac the night before, and we have reason to believe that it was definitely known to Gen. GRANT that LEE had left his former positions before our advance took place. That up to this hour it is not known here by telegraph from Fortress Monroe, that LEE has attacked or confronted Maj.-Gen. "Baldy" SMITH's force, strikes us as embracing substantial proof that GRANT's pursuit commenced very shortly after LEE's movement -- so soon after, as that, if he did move against our troops on the Peninsula, he could hardly open upon them before GRANT can attack his rear. But every succeeding hour of the absence of intelligence of a battle in that quarter strengthens the probability that LEE's movement was simply a retreat to get behind the Richmond fortifications; as by this time GRANT, if not seriously opposed, could have marched to within thirty or forty miles, at most, of the rebel capital, or to within supporting distance of where Gen. SMITH's army must be by this time, unless its advance has been delayed by the appearance of LEE in his front; in which case, GRANT's route to his support would be shorter than if his advance had been unopposed. Twenty-four hours at most must, however, solve all the so interesting questions as to what has happened in that quarter up to this time.

abstract: The Thirty-seventh Regiment N.G.S. N.Y,, were Friday afternoon mustered into the service of the United States for thirty days, by Capt. BARSTOW, United States Army. lead_paragraph: The Thirty-seventh Regiment N.G.S.N.Y,, were Friday afternoon mustered into the service of the United States for thirty days, by Capt. BARSTOW, United States Army. The regiment received their uniforms in the morning, and about 4 o'clock in the afternoon they formed line, and marched down Broadway to the Battery, where they embarked, on their way to Forts Richmond and Tompkins, which they are to garrison.

abstract: The Probable Conference
snippet: The Probable Conference
lead_paragraph: This Conference maybe now sitting in London, but we should not be greatly surprised were it not yet assembled. It was originally to be held on the 12th ultimo, then it was postponed to the 20th, and, when the 20th arrived, and the representative of the German Diet did not make his appearance, it was again postponed to the 25th, the fact being that neither the Austrian nor Prussian Ministers would take part in the proceedings till their colleague was present.

abstract: Wednesday, City Inspector BOOLE suggested to the Common Council, the means by which to rid the City of the pest of fat-boiling establishments. It appears that the ordinances in regard to this class of nuisances, which are treated as being dangerous to the heatlth of the City, extend only to bone-boiling in fact, covering nearly all things in the manufacturing line, that produce stench, which might engender disease, except fat-boiling.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday, City Inspector BOOLE suggested to the Common Council, the means by which to rid the City of the pest of fat-boiling establishments. It appears that the ordinances in regard to this class of nuisances, which are treated as being dangerous to the heatlth of the City, extend only to bone-boiling in fact, covering nearly all things in the manufacturing line, that produce stench, which might engender disease, except fat-boiling. It is this particular kind of nuisance that Mr. BOOLE has called the attention of the Common Council; and he has suggested, as the most effectual method of securing an undoubted power to drive it beyond the limits of the City, that the Board of Health be convened. Promptly conceding the merit of the suggestion, both Boards of the Common Council yesterday adopted a resolution requesting Mayor GUNTHER to convene the Board of Health, whose power in respect to protecting the health of the City is unlimited. Mr. BOOLE says he has done all that lies in his power as City Inspector to abate the evil of fat-boilng in the City, but that his prerogatives have not allowed him to restrict it to any material degree. It now remains with the Mayor to decide whether the reform suggested shall be promptly [???] out for it [???] as though the Common Council desire to go straight ahead, and to aim directly at the abolishment of the evil, else they would not have so quickly responded to the suggestion of the City Inspector.

abstract: -- Some ten of the most eminent lawyers of the City have volunteered their services to the Citizens' Association to protect the interests of the City, and to vigorously prosecute any matters in its government which are considered illegal. The different appropriations will first come under consideration, and be rigidly scrutinized and their legality ascertained. If these be any which have not the authority of law, they will be opposed in the courts, Incessant vigilance as to all departments of the Government will be exercised. The association design continuing its efforts and increasing its influence until the purpose of reform is attained. The different Ward organizations are permanent, and their strength constantly increasing; already, it is believed, the organization holds the balance of power. It is worth while for citizens who have not attended any of the many meetings, to attend and hear some of the facts which have at last aroused taxpayers to decided action. There is nothing exaggerated; plain facts, such as any one can get hold of, are given.

abstract: We hope that those who are just now so anxious to convert a portion of the Central Park into a parade-ground, thoroughly understand what they are talking about. It might be possible to provide a graveled square -- turf would not do -- on which one, two or even three thousand men could drill and manoeuvre in the park, either above or below the reservoir, though we do not see that it could be done without seriously interfering with its utility as a public garden; and this, it must never be forgotten, is the main point. But in providing a parade-ground, it is not simply space for the troops that has to be provided; arrangements have also to be made for the spectators. All military shows call out a large body of lookers-on, composed mainly of decent people, but also to a great extent of vagabonds, and other mischievous or disorderly persons; and this body surrounds the troops in every direction, and cannot be kept within any fixed bounds by any police we are ever likely to have at our command. Many climb trees, trample down grass, break the shrubbery, if there are any such things in the neighborhood, and would certainly in a single Summer convert all that portion of the park in the neighborhood of the parade-ground, into a disgusting arid waste, like the City Hall Park at this moment. More than this, the habit of trespass, of running across the turf, taking short cuts in every direction, and in fact of breaking through all the rules which we have so generally respected, would soon be acquired; and we should see, before long, the magnificent pleasure ground, of which we are all now so proud, reduced to the condition of a ragged and disorderly pasture.
lead_paragraph: We hope that those who are just now so anxious to convert a portion of the Central Park into a parade-ground, thoroughly understand what they are talking about. abstract: Magazines for May
snippet: Magazines for May
lead_paragraph: -- The Atlantic Monthly (Boston, TICKNOR & FIELDS) for May opens with a pleasant paper by BAYARD TAYLOR, a leaf of his late Russian diplomatic experiences, describing a visit to the shrines of pilgrimage consecrated by the usages of the Greek church, in the picturesque but little visited waters of Lake Ladoga. No. 6 of Mr. MITCHELL's "Wet Weather Work" continues his gossip with the old horticultural writers of England, and, except in its too harsh judgment of HORACE WALPOLE, commands the reader's assent to its critical judgments, as the production of one equally at home in handling the spade or the pen of the belle-lettre essayist. The useful and the enteraining are blended in the remaining articles by Miss PENSCOTT, Mrs. H.B. STOWE, Dr. PALFREY and others, but the Atlantic is sadly in need of the continuous interest afforded by that indispensable attraction in modern magazines, a high class serial story, as all who remember "Elsie Venner" will allow. An original poem by ROBERT BROWNING is a thing no American periodical has ever before offered to his readers. "Gold Hair," a Breton legend, has his usual characteristics, but is not free from his customary obscurity. T. BUCHANAN REED and the veteran CHARLES J. SPRAGUE also enrich the poetical department with contributions or merit.

abstract: Curious Cor. with Earl Russell
snippet: Curious Cor. with Earl Russell
lead_paragraph: A late number of the Columbus (Ga.) Times copies from the Mobile Tribune an article consisting, with a few introductory remarks, of a diplomatic correspondence between Earl RUSSELL, Lord LYONS and JEFFERSON DAVIS. The correspondence begins with a communication from Lord LYONS to Mr. DAVIS, introducing part of a dispatch from Earl RUSSELL to Lord LYONS. The dispatch opens with "the formal protest and remonstrance of Her Majesty's Government against the effort of the authorities of the so-called Confederate States to build war-vessels within Her Majesty's dominions, to be employed against the Government of the United States." The dispatch goes on to say that, "after consulting with the law officers of the Crown, Her Majesty's Government has come to the decision that agents of the authorities of the so-called Confederate States have been engaged in building vessels which would be at least partially equipped for war purposes on leaving the ports of this country; that these war-vessels would undoubtedly be used against the United States, a country with which this Government is at peace; that this would be a violation of the neutrality laws of the realm; and that the Government of the United States would have just ground for serious complaint against her Majesty's Government should they permit such an infraction of the amicable relations now subsisting between the two countries," The dispatch proceeds: "No matter what might be the difficulty of proving in a court of law that the parties procuring the building of these vessels are agents for the so-called Confederate States, it is universally understood throughout the world that they are so, and her Majesty's Government are satisfied that Mr. DAVIS would not deny that they are so. Constructed as rams, as these vessels are, they would certainly be in a condition, on leaving port, to inflict the most serious damage on vessels belonging to the United States, as was shown by the destruction of the Cumberland, a United States sloop-of-war, by the ram Merrimac, merely by the latter having run into collision with the Cumberland." "It is clear," argues the dispatch, "that a hundred and twenty gun ship might be equipped for war purposes with any fraction of her armament on board, although she might not be so prompt or so efficient as she would be, if she had the whole of it. A ram would be also equipped for war purposes, although the absence of her ordnance and ammunition might render her less effective than she would be with them." The concluding paragraph of the dispatch is: "Under these circumstances, Her Majesty's Government protest and remonstrate against any further efforts being made on the part of the so-called Confederate States, or the authorities or agents thereof, to build, or cause to be built, or to purchase, or cause to be purchased, any such vessels as those styled rams, or any other vessels, to be used for war purposes against the United States, or against any country with which the United Kingdom is at peace or on terms of amity; and Her Majesty's Government further protest and remonstrate against all further acts in violation of the neutrality laws of the realm."

abstract: Growth of the American Nation
snippet: Growth of the American Nation
lead_paragraph: The other day I saw in one of the worst Copperhead sheets in this country, an extract from the N.Y. Tribune, gloated over as a most precious confession. It think it was precious for the Copperheads and disreputable to Republicans. It was in substance this: That there was a time when Mr. LINCOLN, Gov. MORGAN, and "most of us" were willing the South should separate peaceably, if they would go into convention, and have the thing done orderly! I don't know who "most of us" are; but, I know something of the people, and I know -- that on the hypothesis that such a thing was possible -- the result would have been, that the Republican party would have been utterly dissolved, the Democratic party become a war party, and the country involved in a worse war than it is now. The great body of the people are for war till the National Flag files over every fort of our territory -- and they would have denounced every leader, (whether in a Convention of States, or not,) who was for separation, as they do BURR and DAVIS. But let that pass. Men have a right to their opinions, and especially in the forming stages of public action. I have never happened to agree with the sort of people who thought this world is to be governed by conventions. But I do agree with the great body of people, who set the unity and grandeur of their country above all the considerations of party, and all the artificialties of convention. The American people are national. Since the commonwealth of Israel, no more people are more so. Why? This involves a view of their origin and growth. Mr. HERBERT SPENCER, (who is not so deep a thinker as his admirers suppose,) lays down the principle that a cause produces more than one effect -- homogenity produces heterogenity -- which is illustrated by many obvious facts. But this is only apparent. Unity can never produce anything but unity. The causes which he assumes contain in reality different elements. Applied to nations, agglommeration of different elements may possibly exist in one empire, (as in Rome, Austria, Great Britain.) But what is the consequence? An inevitable tendency of the different elements to fly off. The empire of ALEXANDER flew to pieces. The empire of Rome flew to pieces; and unless great changes are accomplished, that of Austria and Great Britain will do so also. This antagonism of elements may be very much diminished, and almost destroyed, if, instead of being localized, the adverse elements were socially mixed up in one country. If there was no Ireland, but the Irish were mixed up with the English, the case would be very different, and the great English difficulty removed. But where is that difficulty in American nationality? It does not exist. There is, in fact, a remarkable homogeneousness. Prof. STOWE, of Andover, said in some speech, several years since, that he thought the American people would be an improvement on other nations, because their blood would be mixed by the continual immigration of foreigners. But who were those foreigners? In fact, they are the very same people migrating to this country now who were migrating here a century ago. We do not mix blood, in tact. The English and Germans are first cousins. The Irish are different; but, though many have come to this country, they have produced no sensible impression on either the current of blood or the current of thought. The idea that a people are to be improved by mixing blood must be taken with great allowance. Suppose you have the best blood in the world already, how are you to improve it by mixing with inferior blood? Is the mulatto superior to his white father? Can you improve Durham cattle by mixing them with the scallawags which are often seen in the New-York market? I say, then, the American nation is essentially homogeneous in its origin and progress. The Germanic immigration has not changed it in the least, for it is essentially the ancestral race. Taking the era of the peace of 1783 as a stand-point, we find the American nation at that time almost entirely homogeneous, excepting always the blacks, who then numbered but 650,000. From that era to 1860, the nation increased at nearly an average of 34 per cent in each ten years. Of this growth, 26 per cent was wholly the growth of the native American stock. About eight per cent was the increase by immigration. Of this growth by immigration, less than one-half was Irish. We have then this result, that admitting the Irish to be different blood, the whole increase from that source is but slightly more than one-ninth of the annual growth. But this is not the whole. The Irish produce no writers to influence the public mind, and they scatter over the country and intermix, so that, in the third generation -- as can be readily observed in New-York -- they are no longer Irish. They are thoroughly American. Thus we see that no sensible change is going on by intermixture with the white race. That remains, in substance, Anglo-American.

abstract: The Mayor, Comptroller and City Inspector met yesterday, to take action in regard to cleaning streets under the provision therefor in the tax levy. The opinion of the Corporation Counsel in regard to the construction of the clause in the tax levy relating to cleaning the streets was read, approved and ordered on file.
lead_paragraph: The Mayor, Comptroller and City Inspector met yesterday, to take action in regard to cleaning streets under the provision therefor in the tax levy. The opinion of the Corporation Counsel in regard to the construction of the clause in the tax levy relating to cleaning the streets was read, approved and ordered on file. The Mayor was appointed President of the commission. It was, on motion, resolved that the Counsel to the Corporation be requested to prepare forthwith a form of proposals and specifications, to enable the commission to advertise for bids for cleaning the streets of the City. The Comptroller informed the commission that WILLIAM B. ASTOR had stated to him at Albany that there was a person who would clean the streets of the City for $100,000 a year, whereupon it was resolved that the Comptroller be requested to inform Mr. ASTOR of the proposed action of this commission, and request the name of the party referred to by him, with the view of calling his attention to the proposals for cleaning the streets. An adjournment was had until Tuesday next.
headline: {'main': 'The Matter of Cleaning Streets.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Matter of Cleaning Streets.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Up to the hour of going to press, we have received no news from Virginia really later than  that given to the public yesterday afternoon. A battle was begun on Thursday, and probably renewed on Friday. After Gen. GRANT had crossed the Rapidan, it seems he was met by, LEE, with his whole force marching up from his defences on the Gordonsville road.
lead_paragraph: Up to the hour of going to press, we have received no news from Virginia really later than that given to the public yesterday afternoon. A battle was begun on Thursday, and probably renewed on Friday. After Gen. GRANT had crossed the Rapidan, it seems he was met by, LEE, with his whole force marching up from his defences on the Gordonsville road. A partial engagement took place between HANCOCK, who occupied our right, and LONGSTREET, while the former was endeavoring to form a connection with Gen. WARREN, in the centre, who was also slightly engaged. The loss is reported heavy on both sides. Our forces were disposed as follows: SEDGWICK on the right. WARREN in the Centre, HANCOCK on the left, and BURNSIDE in reserve. Much less than one-half of Gen. MEADE's force was engaged on the first day, and the rebel onslaught was repulsed, though made with the evident intention of breaking up our columns in de ail. The locality of the battle-ground is in the densest part of "The Wilderness," a short distance west of the old battle-field of Chancellorsville. Among the casualties reported on our side are Gen. ALEX. HAYS, reported killed and Gen. BARTLETT and Col. GURNEY, severely wounded.

abstract: Grant's Campaign in Virginia
snippet: Grant's Campaign in Virginia
lead_paragraph: That a great battle is going on in Virginia, even if not already concluded, seems to admit of no doubt, but the results are still in abeyance, and the details painfully meagre. Gen. GRANT's sudden passage of the Rapidan was undoubtedly a surprise to LEE; but the latter immediately marched out of his works on Wednesday, and on Thursday he precipitated his columns upon GRANT's veteran host, with an evident design of cutting off or cutting up one of our corps before it could be properly supported. But in this he was foiled. HANCOCK met his old antagonist, LONGSTREET, and held him at bay handsomely until he connected his command with WARREN, and on Thursday evening our troops rested on their arms, a compact, confident army, with the reserves under BURNSIDE, across the Rapidan, and in position for prompt support to the main army. Such heavy cannonading was heard on Friday morning as to leave no doubt but that the battle was renewed on that day. The locality of the battle-ground is in the densest part of that wild tract known as "the Wilderness," and only a short distance from the Chancellorsville battle-ground, even if the conflict does not rage over a portion of that same field.
headline: {'main': 'The Great Battle.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Great Battle.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Chicago Journal publishes an extract from a private letter, dated Nashville, May 1, which says: "This was the day on which the armies at Huntsville and Chattanooga were expected to move. It is reported this morning, however, that the movement has, for some reason, been deferred. There is probably to be a new order in the programme. It has been found out to a certainty that many of the rebel troops in JOHNSTON's army have gone to Richmond. The discovery of this fact may have something to do with the revocation of the order for a forward movement."
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Journal publishes an extract from a private letter, dated Nashville, May 1, which says: "This was the day on which the armies at Huntsville and Chattanooga were expected to move. abstract: Ampere, Jacques Antoine; French author
snippet: Ampere, Jacques Antoine; French author
lead_paragraph: One of the most charming, candid and instructive books ever written on our country was by M. AMPERE, the intimate friend of the late Marquis DE TOCQUEVILLE. In the month of March he died, leaving a distinguished vacancy in the Academie Francaise, JACQUES ANTOINE AMPERE, born at Lyons in 1800, was the son of the celebrated mathematician, ANDRE MARIE AMPERE, who, many years before his son attained manhood, published some remarkable observations and speculations on electro-telegraphy. M. AMPERE fils, early entered upon a literary career and soon rose to a commanding position. It is true that he had great advantages in the warm friendship of CHATEAUBRIAND and BALLANCHES, the latter having introduced him into the first and most spirituelle literary reunion of France, which became so famous under the name of (and also in the mansion of) that beautiful queen of society, Madame DE RECAMIER. Before CHARLES X. fell, young AMPERE became one of the editors of the Giobe and of the Revue Francaise, which was founded by GUIZOT to oppose the last Government of the Bourbons in France.

abstract: The movement to discourage the use of imported goods where native substitutes can be procured, is worthy of encouragement, and this subsititution can be made with much greater case and to a far greater extent than is generelly believed. Indeed, we know of many kinds of homemade goods which are usually sold as foreign, and which are fully equal in quality and finish to anything in the same line that can be imported.
lead_paragraph: The movement to discourage the use of imported goods where native substitutes can be procured, is worthy of encouragement, and this subsititution can be made with much greater case and to a far greater extent than is generelly believed. Indeed, we know of many kinds of homemade goods which are usually sold as foreign, and which are fully equal in quality and finish to anything in the same line that can be imported. If those home-made goods, as such, were in favor with buyers, they could be purchased much cheaper than at present, under their foreign reputation. It has been already stated editorially that many of the silk fabrics sold as foreign are made in Connecticut and New-Jersey, and no consumer could detect any essential difference in quality or finish. If property encouraged, this branch of industry would soon be developed so as to practically gain a monopoly of the home market.

abstract: The news from the armies, this morning, is very gratifying. Success seems realized and promised from all quarters. Gen. GRANT has repulsed LEE in all his attacks, with tremendous loss; Gen. BUTLER is successful on the Peninsula, and has destroyed the railroad between Richmond and Petersburgh; Gen. SHERMAN in the west has occupied Tunnel Hill, outflanked the rebel position at Buzzard's Roost, and JOE JOHNSTON is reported falling back on Atlanta. But for further particulars we refer the reader to the full reports we publish elsewhere.

abstract: -- Yesterday afternoon a quarrel occurred between two waiters at the St. Nicholas Hotel, named THOMAS O'KEEFE and JOHN O'BRIEN. During the affray O'KEEFE drew a knife from his pocket, and stabbed O'BRIEN twice in the left side, immediately below the ribs. The wounds inflicted are considered of a dangerous nature. Officer EDWARD BARBALET, a policeman detailed at the St. Nicholas Hotel, promptly arrested O'KEEFE, and conveyed him to the station-house, and thence to the Jefferson Market Police Court. The officer making the arrest made an affidavit before Justice DOGDE, in which he stated that the wounded man had been conveyed to his residence in a dying condition, and was therefore unable to appear in Court. Coroner WILDEY was notified, and will take the ante-mortem examination. In the meantime O'KEEFE has been committed to prison to await the result of the injuries inflicted by him. The prisoner is about 30 years of age and an Irishman by birth.
lead_paragraph: -- Yesterday afternoon a quarrel occurred between two waiters at the St. Nicholas Hotel, named THOMAS O'KEEFE and JOHN O'BRIEN. During the affray O'KEEFE drew a knife from his pocket, and stabbed O'BRIEN twice in the left side, immediately below the ribs. The wounds inflicted are considered of a dangerous nature. Officer EDWARD BARBALET, a policeman detailed at the St. Nicholas Hotel, promptly arrested O'KEEFE, and conveyed him to the station-house, and thence to the Jefferson Market Police Court. The officer making the arrest made an affidavit before Justice DOGDE, in which he stated that the wounded man had been conveyed to his residence in a dying condition, and was therefore unable to appear in Court. Coroner WILDEY was notified, and will take the ante-mortem examination. In the meantime O'KEEFE has been committed to prison to await the result of the injuries inflicted by him. The prisoner is about 30 years of age and an Irishman by birth.

abstract: Grant's Campaign in Virginia
snippet: Grant's Campaign in Virginia
lead_paragraph: Not in the history of modern scientific war has there been a series of operations at once so colossal and so complex, as those of which our country has been the theatre, and Lieut.-Gen. GRANT the director, in the first week of the month of May, 1864. The Americans have been accused of confounding mere bigness with grandeur; but, though magnitude is a striking characteristic of present events, we think that their conception and inception at least, merit the honor of being also termed grand.

abstract: The Chicago Journal publishes an extract from a private letter, dated Nashville, May 1, which says: "This was the day on which the armies at Huntsville and Chattanooga were expected to move. It is reported this morning, however, that the movement has, for some reason, been deferred. There is probably to be a new order in the programme. It has been found out to a certainty that many of the rebel troops in JOHNSTON's army have gone to Richmond. The discovery of this fact may have something to do with the revocation of the order for a forward movement."

abstract: Brazil Steamship Aid Bill in Senate
snippet: Brazil Steamship Aid Bill in Senate
lead_paragraph: Although the Brazil Steamship Aid Bill passed the Post-office Committee in the Senate on Thursday, there is an apparent hesitancy, natural enough perhaps, to take decisive action on the measure at once. The reasons attributed to the opponents of the measure for delaying action are, we think, of doubtful validity. The objectors, it is said, consider that the claims of steamship lines to run from New-York to European ports, should have precedence in any scheme of subsidies. So, perhaps, in ordinary cases and in ordinary times they ought to have. But let it first be granted that the trade of Brazil warrants the establishment of such an enterprise, and there are more and better reasons for early action than the opposition can give for delay. In the good years before the war we took from $22,000,000 to $25,000,000 worth of Brazilian products annually, and sent to Brazil sometimes between $6,000,000 and $7,000,000 a year -- running almost neck and neck with Great Britain in the race of competition for the trade. That trade was, we may say, the short growth of thirty odd years. Within that period it had grown in the matter of imports almost forty-fold. Nearly ten years ago the merchants of Hamburg thought the trade of sufficient importance to warrant the establishment of postal communication by steam with Rio. And, under a similar stimulus, the commerce of Great Britain with the Empire, has more than doubled in the last seven years.

abstract: The latest news from the army received here is up to seven o'clock yesterday evening, at which time GRANT fully maintained his position. The fighting on Thursday and Friday was very severe, with skirmishing only on Saturday. LEE'S first onset was made upon our left, but failing he then fell upon our centre and finally upon our right, where the hardest contest took place.

abstract: -- The Society held regular meetings on the 14th and 28th ult. The Secretary read letters from Gov. SEYMOUR, of New-York, and from the Governors of Maine, New-Hampshire, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Delaware, Connecticut and West Virginia, inclosing seals of their respective States, with interesting descriptions of same, for which the thanks of the Society were tendered to their Excellencies. Specimens of the cumbrous seals of the English Patent Office, in the time of GEORGE IV., were exhibited, and the Secretary was requested to prepare a paper on the subject of seals, to be read at some future meeting. A member on behalf of Mrs. GIBBS, exhibited a number of interesting coins, which had been sent to the Metropolitan Fair, but as yet remained unsold. They comprised gold, silver and copper, from Japan; "Etagam," "Neboos," etc., the former an uncouth alloy of silver, resembling a sinker, and some German coins, sent by Mr. MURPHY, the United States Consul-General at Frankfort. Among these latter is a very curious and beautiful gold coin, weighing two grains, and scarcely more than an eighth of an inch in diameter, having on one side the "Agnus Del," and on the other the State Arms. Mr. MURPHY says it is very old, and probably the smallest gold coin in the world. It is very perfect, seems unknown to collectors, and is thought to be of great rarity. These, together with some gold of CHARLES I., will be put up for sale at the earliest opportunity. The Curator announced several valuable donations to the library and cabinet. The report of the Special Committee recommending a revision of the Constitution was adopted. Communications from the New-Haven Society and others were read, several members elected, and the society adjourned to the 12th inst.

abstract: A man, supposed to be A.O. BRANCH, was drowned yesterday by falling or jumping into the water at the foot of Beach-street. It appears that deceased was discovered on the pier about 1 o'clock in the morning by the night watchman, who warned him to be careful or he would fall overboard. Shortly afterward he heard a splash in the water, and running to the end of the pier saw deceased and made every exertion to get him out. The man drowned, however, before he could be saved. A verdict of accidental death was rendered.

abstract: THE BUILDING OF IRON-CLADS IN JERSEY CITY. -- The construction of iron-clads at SECOR & CO.'s yard in Jersey City is progressing with all possible dispatch, and in a short time three more of these formidable machines of war will be in readiness to operate against the enemy. About 200 men are employed putting the finishing strokes on the Manhattan which has been launched some time. The turret is up, the gun carriages are being placed in position, and the guns will probably be mounted by Saturday, and, in all probability, this vessel will be put in commission during next week. The Mahopac and Mahonga are still on the stocks, but will undoubtedly be launched some time within three weeks. The Mahonga is 255 feet in length, 25 feet in breadth and 14 feet in depth. The Mahopac is 235 feet long, 42 feet beam and 14 feet deep, and attached to her is a ram 12 feet in length. The Mahonga, which is intended for river and harbor service, will be supplied with eight broadside guns and two rifled swivels. She is furnished with four water-light bulkheads, worked by valves from the deck. These compartments can readily be emplied or filled, by which means the vessel can be raised or lowered in the water.
lead_paragraph: THE BUILDING OF IRON-CLADS IN JERSEY CITY. -- The construction of iron-clads at SECOR & CO.'s yard in Jersey City is progressing with all possible dispatch, and in a short time three more of these formidable machines of war will be in readiness to operate against the enemy. About 200 men are employed putting the finishing strokes on the Manhattan which has been launched some time. The turret is up, the gun carriages are being placed in position, and the guns will probably be mounted by Saturday, and, in all probability, this vessel will be put in commission during next week. The Mahopac and Mahonga are still on the stocks, but will undoubtedly be launched some time within three weeks. The Mahonga is 255 feet in length, 25 feet in breadth and 14 feet in depth. The Mahopac is 235 feet long, 42 feet beam and 14 feet deep, and attached to her is a ram 12 feet in length. The Mahonga, which is intended for river and harbor service, will be supplied with eight broadside guns and two rifled swivels. She is furnished with four water-light bulkheads, worked by valves from the deck. These compartments can readily be emplied or filled, by which means the vessel can be raised or lowered in the water.

abstract: Responsibility of
snippet: Responsibility of
lead_paragraph: A verdict was rendered in our Court of Common Pleas, on Saturday, which establishes, so far as that court is concerned, a principle of marked importance in regard to the liability of Telegraph Companies for the accuracy of their dispatches. It seems that a firm telegraphed to their agents here to sell 500 shares of Southern Michigan stock at the Morning Board, and buy 500 Hudson in the afternoon. The word "Hudson" was omitted in the dispatch, and 500 Southern Michigan were bought. The result was a heavy loss to the parties who had given the order and this loss was directly due to the mistake in the transmission of the dispatch. The result was a verdict in favor of the claimants, thus establishing the principle that Telegraphic Companies are responsible, like other common carriers, for the accuracy with which they transmit the messages intrusted to them. These companies have hitherto claimed exemption from this responsibility, but we see no reason in justice, as we are very glad to find there is none in law, for according it. A blunder like the one which led to this suit may involve very serious losses, and there should certainly be responsibility for it somewhere, not only as a matter of justice, but to prevent their occurrence. If Telegraph Companies find that their errors involve no penalty, they will employ operators of inferior capacity on the ground of economy, and, indeed, the extent to which this is now done is one of the most serious defects of the Telegraph system. It this decision is sustained by the higher courts it will improve that system as well as protect the public.

abstract: The old buildings formerly situated on the notorious lane in the Five Points, called "Cow-Bay," have been removed, and a new structure is being erected as an addition to the House of Industry. The building is to be 50 by 100 feet, two stories in height, the first floor to be used for a chapel and the second for school rooms. The structure will be completed in about six weeks.

abstract: It is often remarked that the best measure of the real meaning of events is to be found in the stock market. The state of the Government funds, for instance, after the announcement of a victory, is a far truer indication of the public judgment than the official bulletins or the articles of journalists. To a certain degree this is true.
lead_paragraph: It is often remarked that the best measure of the real meaning of events is to be found in the stock market. The state of the Government funds, for instance, after the announcement of a victory, is a far truer indication of the public judgment than the official bulletins or the articles of journalists. To a certain degree this is true. The market for securities and exchange is the best possible indication of the public feeling, but not of the wisest public judgment. Capital, in seeking investments, or speculation in trading in them, must of necessity be influenced by fancy and feeling, for these two imponderable elements enter into the very estimates of their value. The stock market is always, and must be, sensitive to every breath of public feeling. There is no place in New-York where the airy sprites of caprice and imagination have such unlimited sway as in Wall and William streets. In such localities, a feeling propagates itself with amazing rapidity, and whether it be fear or hope, the results are constantly far disproportioned to realities. In the long run, of course, the market settles down on a solid estimate of things, but at any particular period its tone may be widely astray from a rational judgment.

abstract: On Friday night last, our pickets on the creek that runs through the marsh on the western side of Morris Island, succeeded in capturing two boats containing sixteen rebels, who had come down from Charleston on a scouting expedition. The capture was made by a party of the Fitty-fourth Massachusetts (colored) Regiment; Capt. HENESSEY, of the Fifty-second Pennsylvania, acting as officer of the picket line at the time.

abstract: New-York Fourth National; Statement of Facts
snippet: New-York Fourth National; Statement of Facts
lead_paragraph: At an adjourned meeting of the shareholders, held May 5, 1864, Mr. CLEVELAND, a partner of Mr. OPDYKE, offered a resolution, prefaced by alleged reasons therefor, absolving Mr. OPDYKE and others, from their promise made to the shareholders, that they would not be reelected as directors of the bank during the present year. This resolution led to a feeling discussion, and was opposed by Messrs. CHITTENDEN and GEORGE D. PHELPS, and others, as impolitic and untrue in its statements. A shareholder, owning one hundred shares, paid for and not hypothecated, moved an amendment striking out all alter the word resolved, in the resolution, and substituting a resolution to the effect that the whole matter involved be referred to the present directors, with power to act as they think the interest of the bank requires, and free from the advice or control of any committee appointed heretofore.
headline: {'main': 'THE FOURTH NATIONAL BANK.; Statement of Facts Regarding the Vote of a Portion of the Shareholders of the Fourth National Bank of New-York, Absolving George Opdyke, Esq., and Others, from their Promise not to be Re-elected Directors of the Bank During the Present Year, by one of the Tellers.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE FOURTH NATIONAL BANK.; Statement of Facts Regarding the Vote of a Portion of the Shareholders of the Fourth National Bank of New-York, Absolving George Opdyke, Esq., and Others, from their Promise not to be Re-elected Directors of the Bank During the Present Year, by one of the Tellers.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The news from Louisiana continues to get worse and worse. Gen. BANKS has given up all thoughts of a forward movement, and seems to be just now occupied mainly in devising means to get back to the Mississippi. He has lost one-third of his army, twenty or thirty guns, perhaps twice as much baggage as the force which defeated him has had in...
lead_paragraph: The news from Louisiana continues to get worse and worse. Gen. BANKS has given up all thoughts of a forward movement, and seems to be just now occupied mainly in devising means to get back to the Mississippi. He has lost one-third of his army, twenty or thirty guns, perhaps twice as much baggage as the force which defeated him has had in its possession for the last year, and $1,000,000 in greenbacks. Nor is this all; it appears by a letter from which we published extracts yesterday, that there are but three feet of water on the shoals at Alexandria, while a large portion of our gunboats and transports are still above. Several of the gunboats have been disabled, and guerrillas swarm along both banks of the Red River from Grand Ecore to Fort de Russey. This is a painful close to an expedition which was to extinguish the rebellion in the whole region west of the Mississippi, and drive KIRBY SMITH, DICK TAYLOR and MAGRUDER into the "illimitable perspective." And it must not be forgotten that while this is going on upon the Red River, the enemy is reappearing along the Mississippi; Vicksburgh and Memphis are both threatened, and the navigation is being again endangered at all points.

abstract: The announcements at the various places of amusement to-night are as follows: At Wallack's Theatre the play of the "Wife," with Mr. LESTER WALLACK as Julian St. Pierre, and Miss JANE COOMBS as Mariana; at the Winter Garden, Mr. EDWIN BOOTH resumes the role that first made him famous, namely -- Richelieu, in the play of that name; at the Olympus Mr. THOMAS BAKER, the musical conductor, takes his benefit, and announces, for the first time here, the two-act drama called the "Chimney Corner," and the farce of "Somebody Else;" at Niblo's Garden, Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS continue their engagement for six nights longer, playing in a variety of their light and laughable pieces. "An Hour in Seville" and "Ireland as it Was" are announced for to-night; at Barnum's Museum, the serio-comic drama of "Belphegor" will be played this afternoon and evening, and Mlle. ERNESTEIN, the pretty and talented danseuse from the Academy of Music, will make her first appearance at that establishment. The illuminated fountain, the giants, dwarfs, &c., still remain.

abstract: Saturday is a decidedly unfashionable day to select for a trot on the Island, as the large majority of the patrons of the trotting turf are compelled by their business pursuits to remain in the City to settle up the affairs of the week; still, the knowledge that a play or pay match was to come off on the Union, in which the game and gallant mare Sally Come Up, who had previously shown so much stoutness and bottom, was to reappear in competition with Rattling Mad, another mare, concerning whose merits the highest anticipations were held, induced many to hurry up their City business, and the result was a far larger, attendance than could have otherwise been expected.
lead_paragraph: Saturday is a decidedly unfashionable day to select for a trot on the Island, as the large majority of the patrons of the trotting turf are compelled by their business pursuits to remain in the City to settle up the affairs of the week; still, the knowledge that a play or pay match was to come off on the Union, in which the game and gallant mare Sally Come Up, who had previously shown so much stoutness and bottom, was to reappear in competition with Rattling Mad, another mare, concerning whose merits the highest anticipations were held, induced many to hurry up their City business, and the result was a far larger, attendance than could have otherwise been expected.

abstract: A NOBLE ACT -- DR. ROWE. -- When we hear of any extraordinary restoration to health or a very skillful operation, we feel as though no praise is too lavish to bestow on the physician effecting it, but when with it is coupled a noble act of charity, words fail to speak in terms sufficiently commendatory. In the City of Brooklyn, at No. 171 Jay-street, live two sisters, one of whom is a widow, the other single. Not being blessed with a plethora of this world's goods, but, on the contrary, less than usually fails to the share of individuals in general, they were solely dependent on their hard earnings for their daily support. This was all very good until ill health, caused from catarrh, overtook the elder, compelling her many days to remain at home from work. Physicians in vain were sought, all trying, but none effecting any good. Soon that most loathsome and insidious disease showed that it had also laid its ruthless hand on the younger sister. As a natural consequence, her constitution began to break down, and now came the time when she also was compelled to cease from work many days. In the meantime the elder sister had grown worse, the disease having settled on her lungs. Like her elder sister, the younger, whose name is Miss CLARK, tried every one and everything in vain. So reduced had her constitution become that many weeks she would not be able to work more than one day during the week. When we consider the state in which the other sister's health was, and that they had no friends or relations to help them, their position could have been anything but enviable. Acquaintances felt confident that neither of them would be very long in this world, it seeming to every one that they must soon die. Physicians had given them up as hopeless.
lead_paragraph: A NOBLE ACT -- DR. abstract: BROOKLYN CITY MORTALITY. -- The total number of deaths in this city last week was 119, from the following diseases, namely: Consumption, 15; inflammation of lungs, 9; convulsions, 8; croup and congestion of the lungs, 6 each; diphtheria, 5; small pox, bronchitis, scarlet fever, debility, inflammation of bowels, marasmus and measles, 3 each; spotted fever, 1; remittent fever, 1; bilious fever, 1; poisoned, 1; diarrhoea, 2; pleurisy, 1, &c., &c. Men, 21; women, 25; boys, 42; girls, 31; under one year of age, 24. Natives of the United States, 92; Ireland, 15; England, 5; Germany, 4; other countries, 3.

abstract: The time has come for the campaign to begin. It is just a year since the sturdy boys "of ours" (the Twenty-first New-Jersey) and the other regiments assigned, flung away their knapsacks, and, with one hurried thought of home, and years compressed in a moment, rushed on through shot and shell till we stood on the impossible heights of Fredericksburgh. The first look around on Marye's Hill showed us the shaft of an imposing monument.
lead_paragraph: From Our Own Correspondent.

abstract: The report of Thursday's battle includes news that Gen. ALEXANDER S. WEBB, commanding a brigade of the Second Division of the Second Army Corps, was among the killed. This is a serious loss to the army and the country. The service had few more capable officers, and none more promising. Gen. WEBB graduated at West Point, we believe, in 1857, nearly at the head of his class. He was soon afterward ordered to Florida, and, after serving in that State for several months, was transferred to West Point, and with great credit filled the chair of an instructor. At the outbreak of the rebellion, he entered into active service at once, and fought as an artillery officer at the first battle of Manassas. Soon afterward, he had command of a volunteer infantry regiment, and in June, 1862, became attached to the staff of Gen. FITZJOHN PORTER, in the capacity of Inspector of the Fifth Army Corps. with the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel. In April, 1863, he was appointed Brigadier-General, on the recommendation of Gen. HOOKER, and was assigned to the command of a brigade in the Second Army Corps. At the battle of Gettysburgh he displayed preeminent gallantry. Not a sing of Brigadier contributed so much, it is safe to say, to that great victory as young WEBB. He was in the very thickest of the fight, handled his men with extraordinary ability and coolness, and escaped death by a miracle, only to meet it among the first in the bloody work of the present year.

abstract: The steamer Arago, at New-York, reports that on Friday, May 6, at 8:30 P.M., the propeller Fanny, with 240 soldiers on board, was run into by the propeller Cumbria, and sunk, in Hampton Roads. It is supposed all on board were saved, but two men were badly injured.

abstract: THE HOME FOR LITTLE WANDERERS. -- The anniversary of the Howard Mission and Home for little Wanderers will take place at the Academy of Music on Tuesday evening the 10th inst. The exercises promise to be very interesting. Addresses will be delivered by eminent speakers. GRAFFULA's Seventh Regiment Band will be present, and several solos, duets, glees and anthems will be given by the children. During the past year 1,326 children have enjoyed the benefits of that institution. Over 30,000 loaves of bread and over 15,000 garments have been distributed among the deserving, and the institution has been very successful. The Board of Managers consist of Messrs. JOSEPH HOXIE, Chairman; Wm. Phelps, Treasurer; Abraham Baldwin, Secretary; H.S. Terbell, A.D. Mathews, H. Sanford.

abstract: RAILROAD. -- BARTHOLONEW CLINTON, a child 4 1/2 years of age, was accidentally run over some days since at Augusta Bridge, by a train of the New-York and Erie Road, and was brought from that place to the New-York Hospital, where he died yesterday. Coroner COLLIN held an inquest in the case, and upon the evidence it was shown that the occurrence was purely accidental. A verdict to that effect was rendered by the jury.
lead_paragraph: RAILROAD. -- BARTHOLONEW CLINTON, a child 4 1/2 years of age, was accidentally run over some days since at Augusta Bridge, by a train of the New-York and Erie Road, and was brought from that place to the New-York Hospital, where he died yesterday. Coroner COLLIN held an inquest in the case, and upon the evidence it was shown that the occurrence was purely accidental. A verdict to that effect was rendered by the jury.

abstract: A telegram from Berlin, of April 26, says: "Yesterday an engagement took place off Rugen Island, between a Prussian gunboat and the Danish iron-clad frigate Tordenskiold. The Danish frigate sailed off, pursued by nine slow-sailing Prussian boats, which failed to overtake her. The Tordenskiold was, however, subsequently overtaken by the Grille and set on fire, but the Danes succeeded in extinguishing the flames. The Minister of Public Worship has sent Privy Councellor STIEHL to Schleswig to inquire into the condition and wants of the school system in that Duchy."
lead_paragraph: A telegram from Berlin, of April 26, says: "Yesterday an engagement took place off Rugen Island, between a Prussian gunboat and the Danish iron-clad frigate Tordenskiold. abstract: Though comparatively an off day, and out of the programme, there was a goodly attendance at the Fashion yesterday, to witness the match for $500, half forfeit, mile heats, best three in five, to wagons, between the two Harlem horses the gray gelding Sam and the bay gelding Billy both celebrated on the road, and both having numerous partisans.
lead_paragraph: Though comparatively an off day, and out of the programme, there was a goodly attendance at the Fashion yesterday, to witness the match for $500, half forfeit, mile heats, best three in five, to wagons, between the two Harlem horses the gray gelding Sam and the bay gelding Billy -- both celebrated on the road, and both having numerous partisans. Prior to the day, and during the morning, quite a considerable amount of money had been invested at evens -- but on the track 50 to 20 was laid on Sam -- and much interest was felt in the result, which promised a well-contested trot, and ended in its being the best that has taken place on the Fashion this season.

abstract: Wadsworth, Gen. James S.; Killed in battle
snippet: Wadsworth, Gen. James S.; Killed in battle
lead_paragraph: The news this morning fully confirms all that was promised yesterday. Gen. GRANT'S victory brightens and looms up in importance as time brings us fuller particulars. The official dispatches from Gens. GRANT and MEADE announce that LEE began his retreat on Friday night, and on Saturday morning he was promptly pursued by our army. Gen. HANCOCK, with the Second Corps, pressing forward and passing through Spottsyl vania Court-house on Sunday morning. On Sunday, at noon, headquarters of the army were twenty miles south of the battle field toward Richmond. Fredericksburgh was occupied by our cavalry at eight o'clock on Saturday evening, and a depot for the wounded will be at once established there. The news from Gen. BUTLER is regarded as favorable. He had a severe engagement on Saturday with BEAUREGARD's troops, in which the latter were driven back, and the railroad destroyed. Among the casualties on our side is Brig.-Gen. JAMES S. WADSWORTH, killed, LEE, in his report of the battle of Thursday, reports four of his Generals killed and wounded, among them LONGSTREET, severely. The news has brought forth from the President a recommendation for thanksgiving and prayer.

abstract: The Retreat of
snippet: The Retreat of
lead_paragraph: The great and salient fact in the intelligence from Virginia this morning, is the confirmation of yesterday's announcement that LEE had retreated from before Lieut.Gen. GRANT. His fight commenced on Friday night, immediately after the drubbing he had received on that day and the preceding. His course seems to have been nearly due South, in the direction of Spottsylvania Court-house and Richmond. On Saturday, the Lieutenant-General promptly gave chase to him, made a march on that day of twenty miles, passed through Spottsylvania Court-house at daylight on Sunday; and there may be truth in the telegram that LEE was forced again to fight on that day, was again repulsed and compelled to continue his retreat. Secretary STANTON, whose dispatches to Gen. DIX have been our most reliable sources of information, sends word under date of yesterday evening, that GRANT is pushing on to Richmond, and that the official belief is that he is achieving a complete victory. The President also sends to the country a modest note of congratulation and calls upon the people to render thanks to the God of Battles.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Hansa, from Southampton April 27, we have two days' later news from Europe. Parliamentary proceedings were unimportant. The Conference met on the 25th, and all the representatives were not present, and nothing was done. The Alexandra would be delivered up to her owners on the 25th. A suspicious war steamer had been seen by the Hamburg bark Orion, on the 13th of March, which spoke her, but gave no information as to who she was. The Alabama was in Table Bay, Indian Ocean, on the 20th March, but had destroyed no more vessels, though she had driven all American shipping from those waters. GARIBALDI had reached Plymouth, April 26, to take his departure. The meeting of workingmen, in London, to protest against the treatment of GARIBALDI, was dispersed by the police. There was nothing new in the Danish war. The first thing demanded in the Conference would be an armistice.

abstract: A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce will be held this day at one o'clock to take some action in regard to the payment in gold of the interest due on the stocks of this State held by foreign creditors. An amount equal to $85,000 in currency is required, of which near one-third has been subscribed by a few patriotic men of this City.

abstract: We are glad to have the news that a monitor has been ordered to the North Carolina coast to attend to that rebel ram which has been cavorting about there for the past fortnight. Its first exploit was in dashing down the Roanoke River, attacking our vessels at its mouth, and assisting in the capture of Plymouth and its garrison. Subsequently it threatened Little Washington, at the mouth of the Tar River, and caused its evacuation. It was next reported to be rushing down in the direction of Newbern, on the Neuse River, and seems to have caused great perturbation there. We had vessels enough in the North Carolina Sound, but none of them dared to give fight to it.
lead_paragraph: We are glad to have the news that a monitor has been ordered to the North Carolina coast to attend to that rebel ram which has been cavorting about there for the past fortnight. abstract: The American Seamen's Friend Society held their thirty-sixth anniversary at Irving Hall last evening. The rain prevented a large attendance, but the friends of the society and the clergy were well represented. WM.A. BOOTH, Esq., President, occupied the chair, and introduced Rev. Dr. COX, who opened the exercises by reading a passage of Scripture, followed by a prayer.
lead_paragraph: The American Seamen's Friend Society held their thirty-sixth anniversary at Irving Hall last evening. Dr. COX, who opened the exercises by reading a passage of Scripture, followed by a prayer.

abstract: We rejoice in the efforts that are being made by our State officers, and by public-spirited capitalists to prevent the stain which the action of the Legislature, in virtually deciding that our foreign creditors, should not be paid their interest in gold, is bringing upon our State credit. It passes understanding how a Legislature of intelligent and honest men could have thus yielded to the wretched sophistry that aimed to show that it was no violation of good faith to pay the foreign creditors in what our laws recognize to be "legal tender."

abstract: Bill on Examinations for Public Offices
snippet: Bill on Examinations for Public Offices
lead_paragraph: Mr. SUMNER has introduced a bill into the Senate, which, owing to the general absorption of the public attention in the great events which are taking place in the field, will probably not attract much notice, but it nevertheless attempts to deal with a matter which is of more importance, we venture to say, to the stability of this Government, than any other one thing except the extinction of the rebellion. It is neither more nor less than a sweeping measure of administrative reform; obliging all candidates for situations in the public service to pass an examination before a board appointed for the purpose; giving them their offices during good behavior, and with promotion through the various grades in the order of seniority, and a retiring pension after a certain term of service.
headline: {'main': "Public Offices and Those Who Fill Them Mr. Sumner's Bill.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Public Offices and Those Who Fill Them Mr. Sumner's Bill.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The draft is ordered to take place in this City to-morrow, (Wednesday,) for the deficiency of our quota under the last call for 200,000 men, which is believed to be less than 700. This number will be distributed pro-rata to the several Congressional districts in the City. It is understood that the draft is to be made on the same day throughout this State. The orders for the draft here were sent on several days ago, and yesterday peremptory orders to make it on Wednesday were received. In consequence of this, the labors of the Supervisors Recruting Committee will close to-day. All the men they enlist to-day however, will be allowed in reduction of the number for which the draft is ordered to be made, The Committee will, submit their report to the Board of Supervisors at the meeting to be held to-day.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday an adverse report was made on the expediency of changing the southern front of the Treasury building. The bill for the erection of a branch mint at Philadelphia was passed. Mr. HOWARD reported a substitute for the Pacific Railroad Bill. The Senate considered the Bank Bill at length, but little or no progress was made. An amendment by Mr. DOOLITTLE, to keep the circulation of the banks within certain bounds, was voted down. Mr. WADE, of Ohio, from the Committee on the Conduct of the War, made a report in reference to the returned prisoners at Baltimore and Annapolis. On his motion, 25,000 copies were ordered to be printed for the use of the Senate. Mr. COLLAMER then read a dispatch from the Secretary of War, announcing a victory by Gen. GRANT, when the Senate adjourned.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday an adverse report was made on the expediency of changing the southern front of the Treasury building. The bill for the erection of a branch mint at Philadelphia was passed. Mr. HOWARD reported a substitute for the Pacific Railroad Bill. The Senate considered the Bank Bill at length, but little or no progress was made. An amendment by Mr. DOOLITTLE, to keep the circulation of the banks within certain bounds, was voted down. Mr. WADE, of Ohio, from the Committee on the Conduct of the War, made a report in reference to the returned prisoners at Baltimore and Annapolis. On his motion, 25,000 copies were ordered to be printed for the use of the Senate. Mr. COLLAMER then read a dispatch from the Secretary of War, announcing a victory by Gen. GRANT, when the Senate adjourned.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamer Louisa Moore at Fortress Monroe, from North Carolina, we learn that the rebel ram Albemarle, which captured Plymouth, is now in full possession of Albemarle Sound Friday last she was seen from Roanoke Island. There is no know knowing what movement she may make to attempt to take Roanoke Island and its black population, Newbern and other important points.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamer Louisa Moore at Fortress Monroe, from North Carolina, we learn that the rebel ram Albemarle, which captured Plymouth, is now in full possession of Albemarle Sound Friday last she was seen from Roanoke Island. abstract: The Hamburg bark Orion arrived at St. Helena March 23, and reports: On March 13, in lat. 34° S., lon. 15° 5′ E., observed a screw-steamer, under sail, with the American ensign flying, and a signal, "Heave to, and I will send a boat on board." The Orion was then hove to, when a boat was lowered from the steamer, and came alongside of us, with eight men, all armed, and an officer in uniform. The ship's papers and log were demanded. The latter being new, the old one was demanded. The boat's crew told my crew that they had 270 men on board; and it was also stated that they were last from Rio Janeiro, but had been seventy days at sea. Also that they were waiting off the Cape for a store-ship, when they were to proceed to China, to take the place of an American frigate in those waters, about which they made inquiries; but when told of the Alabama being in the China waters they appeared to consider it insignificant. He then left us. The vessel is a three-masted schooner, sails very fast, and to all appearance is British-built. The Alabama put into Table Bay, March 20. for coals and other supplies. The total number of ships destroyed and captured in the Indian Seas had been seven: The Amanda, Winged Racer, Contest, Martaban, (or Texan Star,) Senara, Highlauder and Emma Jane, but Capt. SEMMES reckoned the damage indirectly done to the Federal commerce by his cruise in the Indian Seas as equivalent to $15,000.000.

The Orion was then hove to, when a boat was lowered from the steamer, and came alongside of us, with eight men, all armed, and an officer in uniform. The ship's papers and log were demanded. abstract: Wadsworth, Gen., the Death of
snippet: Wadsworth, Gen., the Death of
lead_paragraph: Gen. WADSWORTH's death excites feelings of intense regret everywhere. There has been no instance in this war of a more high-toned surrender of comfort, fortune and life itself to principle, than that afforded in his career. Possessed of enormous wealth, occupying the highest social position attainable in this country, accustomed to a life of ease and personal enjoyment, shunning political position, and content always with discharging worthily the duties of a private citizen, he joined the army when the war broke out, because he believed the cause of the Union to be the highest and noblest in which the sword was ever drawn, and because he could not sit at ease, in his own house, while leaving others to fight the battle of his man liberty and republican government. He sought no official position, asked for no command, but attached himself to the Staff of Gen. MCDOWELL, anxious only to make himself useful and to contribute something to the triumph of the Union cause. At the first battle of Bull Run he had a horse shot under him, and behaved with conspicuous and serviceable gallantry. He discharged all the duties afterwards assigned him, with conscientious care and fidelity, -- devoting himself to the comfort of his men, living himself in the humblest and plainest manner, seeking no promotion, and complaining of nothing but the enforced inactivity which seemed to be wasting life and treasure without result.
headline: {'main': 'General Wadsworth.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'General Wadsworth.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The latest news from Gen. GRANT'S army in Virginia is up to Monday at noon, at which time Gen. GRANT sent a dispatch to Secretary STANTON that the rebels were making a stand at Spottsylvania Court-house, and that, though
lead_paragraph: The latest news from Gen. GRANT's army in Virginia is up to Monday at noon, at which time Gen. GRANT sent a dispatch to Secretary STANTON that the rebels were making a stand at Spottsylvania Court-house, and that, though there had been some hard fighting, no general engagement had been fought. Gen. SEDGWICK was killed in a skirmish by a ball through the head from a sharpshooter. Gen. GRANT wrote that he was replenishing the provisions of his army from the supply train, so he could advance without it. The wounded were being received and cared for at Fredericksburgh.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors met yesterday. A resolution was adopted directing their legal adviser (the Corportion Counsel) to sue the owners of the hulks of sunken vessels which the Pilot
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors met yesterday. A resolution was adopted directing their legal adviser (the Corportion Counsel) to sue the owners of the hulks of sunken vessels which the Pilot Commissioners have raised and removed from the harbor, for the expense of raising and removing. The Committee on Annual Taxes reported the ordinance previously received from the Comptroller and referred to them, making the general county appropriations in conformity with the several sums authorized in the County Tax Law. The ordinance was adopted. The committee set forth in their report that of the $5,854,907 65 appropriated originally by the Board on county account for 1864, $4,889,917 49 is required to be raised by special existing acts, leaving only $964,990 16 which the Board had control over, to which the Legislature have added $223,350, making a total of $1,188,340 16 directed to be raised for 1864 by the County Tax Law. The committee also say that most of the money appropriated by the Board is for the use of independent commissioners, and when added to money raised for these bodies, it is considered that the appropriations for officers' and witnesses' fees, Coroners' fees interest on County debt, &c., are all directed especially by the Legislature to be raised, the Supervisors really control over $250,000 of all these appropriations. The Board adjourned to 3 o'clock P.M. on next Friday.

abstract: -- A young lady died at Washington, a few days since, under circumstances which led to an inquest. After an elaborate inquiry into her history, circumstances, and general relations to everybody and everything, the jury found that she died of pneumonia. One would think that after this verdict, people of ordinary justice and decency would be content to leave to her family and friends what reputation the remorseless investigation of a Coronor's prosecution might have spared her. But it seems not. Quite a number of newspapers are determined to blast her character utterly, before leaving her to rest in her untimely grave. The motive which seems to prompt them aggravates the inhuman baseness of their conduct. They have started with the purpose of fastening the charges of immorality upon certain employees of the Treasury Department, and the verdict of the Coroner's Jury stands in their way. If the poor girl concerned in this matter actually died of pneumonia, the officials in question will not be convicted, in this instance, at least, of the offences charged; and her reputation and the feelings of her friends, it seems, cannot be allowed to stand in the way of achieving that result. This does not strike us as a particularly chivalrous style of carrying on a political warfare -- but it seems to be fashionable in some quarters.
