abstract: Sedgwick, Maj.-Gen. John
snippet: Sedgwick, Maj.-Gen. John
lead_paragraph: The death of this gallant soldier will cause a deep feeling of sorrow throughout the country. His fortunes had been so long allied with the Army of the Potomac, and his career so distinguished for gallantry and efficiency, that "Uncle JOHN," as he was universally known among the troops, was almost an essential to the well-being of that army. He was a native of Connecticut, graduated at West Point high in his class, served with distinction and honor for many years in the regular army, and at the outbreak of the war was, we believe, Colonel of the Fourth Regular Cavalry. He was among the early appointments to the position of Brigadier-General, and commanded a brigade, and subsequently a division, of troops, succeeding Gen. STONE on the upper Potomac, in the Fall and Winter of 1861-2. His command joined the Army of the Potomac when MCCLELLAN moved to the Peninsula, and the division was assigned to the corps of Gen. SAMNER. This division he commanded with distinguished success, up to the battle of Antietam, where he was wounded. Upon his recovery he was again assigned to the Army of the Potomac, and commanded the Ninth Army Corps for a short time, in the winter of 1863, and then succeeded Gen. SMITH in the command of the Sixth Corps, which he exercised with great ability up to the day of his death, participating in the second assault upon Fredericksburgh, the battle of Gettysburgh, the advance upon Mine Run, and the late desperate battle in the Wilderness, only to lose his life at the hands of a murderous sharpshooter, instead of falling, as he would have chosen to fall, in the heat of battle, inspiring his men by a brilliant example. To no one will his death come with deeper sorrow than to his command, who loved him, and the avenging arm of the noble Sixth Corps will strike surer and swifter blows upon the tottering rebellion as they remember the fall of their brave leader.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, there was very little business done of an important character, save the passage of the National Bank Bill in an amended form, which sends it back to the House for concurrence. The bill to prevent smuggling was passed. The bill organizing the veteran volunteer engineers of the Army of the Cumberland was also passed. After an Executive session, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Last night a number of boats proceeded to Aquia -Creek to bring up wounded. A few straggling wounded men have reached Alexandria, having traveled on foot from the Rapidan, have been captured by rebels on the way, and subsequently es
lead_paragraph: Last night a number of boats proceeded to Aquia Creek to bring up wounded. A few straggling wounded men have reached Alexandria, having traveled on foot from the Rapidan, have been captured by rebels on the way, and subsequently escaped. The following additional casualties are reported, belonging to the Third Vermont: Killed -- Capt. Bartlett, Capt. Brigham, Lieut. French, Privates John Sabin, Hodsten, Marsh, McGibbon, Boyd. Wounded -- Corp. McCue, Doyle, Wm. Hughes, Moran, Miles, McCormick, James Lushman, Brick, Lieut. Miller, Bemas, Corp. Lock, Smith, Lt. Bailey, Harris.

abstract: Grant's Advance
snippet: Grant's Advance
lead_paragraph: We suppose there were enthusiastic people who fancied, when GRANT set out in pursuit of LEE last Saturday, that he would closely follow up the rebel, on the doublequick, until he found refuge behind the earthen walls of Richmond. It would have been a very fine thing to do, had it been in mortal power to perform it. But the movements of great hostile armies, whether in retreat or in pursuit, are under conditions very different from those which govern a foot-race. Were GRANT to travel the nearest roads from the Wilderness to the rebel capital, he would have something like seventy miles to pass over; and this space is closely threaded with rivers and streams, which have to be crossed; is well studded with strong works, which can be stiffly defended; and is, moreover, notwithstanding the battles of Thursday and Friday, guarded by a large and desperate army, led by a capable General. LEE, with but a single division, could retard the advance upon Richmond very seriously, and for considerable time, by the simple strategy of standing at advantageous positions, and compelling our army to frequently form line of battle.

abstract: in Social Expenses
snippet: in Social Expenses
lead_paragraph: The movement of the ladies in behalf of economy of expenditure is especially important, in view of the fact that in this country the women determine the scale of living. It is one of the peculiarities of American social life. Why, we need not discuss here, but the women have an overruling influence on society. In all classes, it is the wife or daughter who determines the style of the home and the general rate of expenditure. The men are sufficiently extravagant and waste money enough, but it is not generally in social expenses. The furniture, the dress and ornament of women and children, the number of servants, the style of living -- all those little things which make up a great deal of the expense of a household -- are legislated on and settled by the weaker sex. Now it happens that most of the luxuries and extravagances in this direction are of foreign source, and must be imported. When brought here they do not (the most of them) add anything to the wealth of the country, and they must be paid for, to a considerable extent, in gold.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE. SHERIDAN KNOWLES' "great" play of the "Wife" was given here on Monday evening with fair success. It is not a work to call for any special commendation. The language is roundabout; the sentiments are cheap, and the
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- SHERIDAN KNOWLES' "great" play of the "Wife" was given here on Monday evening with fair success. It is not a work to call for any special commendation. The language is roundabout; the sentiments are cheap, and the style is SHERIDAN KNOWLES'. It would be hard to say less, and impossible to say more. There is, however, a special merit in the matter of construction. The action is quick, and the play, under favorable circumstances, comes to a gratifyingly rapid end.

abstract: Gen. LEE is determined to hold Richmond; Lieut.-Gen. GRANT is determined to take it. LEE defends the approaches to it with great vigor; GRANT overcomes obstacles and steadily advances upon it by his indomitable perseverance. It is a week to-day since
lead_paragraph: Gen. LEE is determined to hold Richmond; Lieut.-Gen. GRANT is determined to take it. LEE defends the approaches to it with great vigor; GRANT overcomes obstacles and steadily advances upon it by his indomitable perseverance. It is a week to-day since GRANT's army reached the further side of the Rapidan. The army has made one-third the distance to its objective point; but we think it has done more than one-third the work required to get there.

abstract: In consequence of some necessary delay on the route the Yankee prisoners captured at Plymouth by Gen. HOKE did not reach here on Monday, as expected. Yesterday evening, however, the first instalment of them arrived -- six hundred and eighty in number. Another lot will pass through to-day, to the number of about two thousand two hundred and forty. The Yankees which passed through yesterday were an impudent set of well-dressed vagabonds, full of insolence and impertinence. Two cars were loaded with officers of various grades, and belonged to the commands as following, and in the numbers annexed. They were in charge of Capt. NICHOLS, Seventeenth South Carolina Infantry, EVANS' brigade. They are as follows:

abstract: We learn from Nantes that the two steamships built in that port for the Confederate States of America, the Shanghai, by M. DUBIGIEN, and the San Francisco, by Messrs. JOLLET ET BABIN, were launched on Saturday last. The launch of the former was effected with complete success in the morning; that of the latter was attempted about the same time, but some impediment occurring, it had to be postponed to the evening, when it was satisfactorily accomplished. Not the slightest mystery, it appears, is observed at Nantes as to the fact of these vessels having been constructed for the Confederates; and it is affirmed there that the French Government, notwithstanding the remonstrances of Mr. DAYTON, the United States Minister at Paris, has no intention whatever of preventing the arming of them. Thus French shipbuilders enjoy a liberty of action which those of England do not possess, and the French Government pays no attention to representations from the North Americans, to the like of which our Government meekly bows. Verily, Old England, in both respects, has fallen from her high estate. The Shanghai and the San Francisco are described as very handsome and powerful vessels, and are so constructed that they will possess great speed. In addition to these, some floating batteries, also for the Confederates, are in course of construction at Nantes, and such progress has been made with them that they can put to sea before long.
lead_paragraph: We learn from Nantes that the two steamships built in that port for the Confederate States of America, the Shanghai, by M. DUBIGIEN, and the San Francisco, by Messrs. Verily, Old England, in both respects, has fallen from her high estate. The Shanghai and the San Francisco are described as very handsome and powerful vessels, and are so constructed that they will possess great speed. abstract: The President and his family have just met with a great affliction in the sudden and violent death of JOSEPH E. DAVIS, second son of the President, about four years old. He felt from the east portico on Saturday afternoon, between three and four o'clock, a distance fully fifteen feet, fracturing his hip and injuringhis head. Mr. DAVIS and his wife were absent from the mansion at the time of the accident, and some minutes must have elapsed before the facts of the accident end the discovery of the condition of the child was made by the servant. The sufferer was taken into the nursery, and a messenger despatched in haste for the President and his lady. Drs. PETICOLAS, CONWAY and GARNETT, the family physician, successively came in and applied their skill without avail. The child was insensible when picked up, and never recovered consciousness, dying in about three-quarters of an hour after being taken up by the servant and carried into the house. The funeral took place yesterday afternoon at 5 o'clock, from St. Paul's Church, the Rev. Dr. MINNEGERODS officiating. The occasion called forth a large throng of sympathizing friends, and the services were of the most affecting character. The interment took place at Hollywood, where the President's family have a vault.

abstract: The latest news received here from Gen GRANT'S army relates to the operations of Monday  and yesterday. The fight on Monday evening was very severe, inflicting a loss on our side of over two thousand men killed and wounded. It was brought on by HANCOCK, who, in his effort to take Spottsylvania Court-house, accomplished the crossing of the River Po under cover of a tremendous artillery fire, and established himself on the south bank.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, May 11.

abstract: Grant's Advance
snippet: Grant's Advance
lead_paragraph: The correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer thus describes Gen. GRANT's appearance during the recent battles: "Lieut.-Gen. GRANT had ridden out to the field first about 11 1/2 o'clock A.M., and taken a general view of the situation, and I may here remark that his appearance was peculiar to what I had seen him on many fields before; but Thursday was the first time I ever saw him, in battle or out, in full uniform. The three stars of his rank adorned his shoulders, and his coat was full dress, and white gloves graced his hands. These may be trivialities; but this man, whose career has been so checkered and so grand, was entering the crisis of his history, and trivialities grow interesting. But there was nothing in his manner to show that he felt the least concerned for the future. Calm and confident he was then, and ever has been, through the varying fortunes of the battle of the Wilderness."

abstract: And his Congress
snippet: And his Congress
lead_paragraph: scarcely possible to conceive a greater contrast than is presented between the Message of JEFFERSON DAVIS to his second Congress, (which we publish elsewhere,) and those exultant addresses in which he was wont formerly to present his case before the world. Of the present document, three-fourths are taken up in fretful lamentation -- first, over the devastation caused by the southward march of the national army, and next, over the hostility of foreign Powers towards the rebel cause. When DAVIS last spoke, he insinuated a difference in the treatment he received at the hands of France and England respectively. Now, however, no such distinction is made; and "foreign Governments," without exception, come in for his bitterest maledictions. Nay more, although he thinks it may be possible hereafter to extend forgiveness to some of his foreign enemies, there are cases which will demand redress when the independence of the South shall have been established. There is a melancholy madness about these assumptions. which almost overtops the villany in which they have their origin.

abstract: Grant's Advance, Martial Nerve of the Armies
snippet: Grant's Advance, Martial Nerve of the Armies
lead_paragraph: The great fact to be derived from the battles of the past week is that, of the two armies, ours will bear the most "punishing" without failing. The contest was mainly one of endurance. Gen. LEE attempted at once his customary tactics, which must now be perfectly familiar to our Generals, of massing and throwing his forces on the exposed portions of our line, trusting to mere weight of numbers to break through, and thus to force back the whole army. It is a very expensive system for the attacking party, but may be worth the loss of men and the wear and tear of vital force in an army. Gen. LEE tried it, with such a corps-commander as he has not now, Stonewall JACKSON, at Gaines' Mill, and produced the effect he desired. Again, in a battle, in which his army was probably more exposed to destruction than it has ever been since -- Chancellorsville -- he tried it with terrible result. It must be remembered that such grand attacks may break and put hors du combat only a comparatively small portion of a large army. At Gaines' Mill, and at Chancellorsville, the Army of the Potomac had men enough remaining, after the successful attacks, to have utterly crushed the enemy.
headline: {'main': 'Martial Nerve--The Two Armies.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Martial Nerve--The Two Armies.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: AND KILLED. -- Col. THOMAS D. DOUBLEDAY, late of a regiment of heavy artillery, New-York Volunteers, and a brother of Maj.-Gen. DOUBLEDAY, of the United States Army, died yesterday at the New-York Hospital, from the effects of injuries received on Tuesday last, by being run over by stage No. 335 of the Seventh-avenue line, at the corner of Broadway and Chambers-street. Mr. WM. H. PHELPS, of No. 134 Maiden-lane, brother-in-law of deceased, testified that he understood deceased was trying to enter a stage going up, when he slipped and fell. At this moment a down-stage was passing, and one wheel of it passed over his chest before he could get out of the way. The jury rendered a verdict of accidental death. Deceased resided on Staten Island. He was forty-eight years of age, and a native of this State.

abstract: The brig Mary, of Barbados, Capt. MARTIN, from Rio Grande, Brazil, March 9, with hides, wool, horns, &c., to master, arrived here Tuesday. April 21, at midnight, lat. 14° 23′ N., lon; 53° 45′ W., was boarded by the rebel steamer Florida -- so reported by the officer who came on board. They supposed us to be the American brig Lark, of Baltimore, Capt. BULLOCK, from Rio Grande for Barbados, with mules. They reported having, three weeks previous, burned the ship Arvon, of Boston, from China for the United States, and part of the crew joined the pirate.

abstract: The Inman steamship City of Manchester, with Liverpool dates to the 27th ult., and Queenstown to the 28th, arrived here yesterday. The London Shipping Gazette states that the two new rebel steamers, Shanghai and San Francisco, have been launched at Nantes. No mystery, it is...
lead_paragraph: The Inman steamship City of Manchester, with Liverpool dates to the 27th ult., and Queenstown to the 28th, arrived here yesterday. The London Shipping Gazette states that the two new rebel steamers, Shanghai and San Francisco, have been launched at Nantes. No mystery, it is said, is made about their destination. Another rebel steamer is reported to be in progross at Bordeaux. The pirate Alabama was at Capetown on the 21st of March. SEMMES states that he destroyed the American ship Emma Jane, bound from Bombay to Rangoon, on the 4th of January. The Alabama has captured nine vessels in eastern seas. GARIBALDI, prior to his embarkation, issued two addresses -- one to the Queen, and one to the people of England. The trial trip of LAIRD's rams is fixed for the 28th of May. The Newmarket race for 2,000 guineas was won by Lord GLASGOW's Gen. Peel -- TEN BROECK's Paris running second.

abstract: Coroner WILDEY yesterday concluded the inquest in the case of PATRICK GANLEY, the conductor on the Second-avenue Railroad, who was killed on Sunday evening last by one of a large gang of rowdy boys who threw a stone and hit him on the left temple. The missile knocked him from the rear platform of the car to the pavement. He was taken up insensible, conveyed to the New-York Hospital, where he died in a few hours after. The testimony in the case is quite voluminous, but, inasmuch as the most important portion of it has been published in the TIMES, we can now only give the results. The jury rendered the following verdict:

abstract: The intelligence from Gen. GRANT'S army in Virginia is up to Tuesday evening at 5 o'clock, at which time he was steadily forcing LEE back, and driving him out of one strong position after another. Gen. HANCOCK'S Corps had crossed the  Po River under a very heavy fire, and established itself in a favorable position on the rebel left.
lead_paragraph: The intelligence from Gen. GRANT's army in Virginia is up to Tuesday evening at 5 o'clock, at which time he was steadily forcing LEE back, and driving him out of one strong position after another. Gen. HANCOCK'S Corps had crossed the Po River under a very heavy fire, and established itself in a favorable position on the rebel left. WARREN had advanced in the centre, and Gen. WRIGHT's Sixth Corps had charged and driven the rebels from their first line of rifle-pits. BURNSIDE was also in a favorable position on our extreme left. The last dispatch represents LEE as falling back to the North Anna River. His army is represented as becoming despondent, and as fighting with less spirit than during the first days of the battle. Rations are undoubtedly scarce with the rebels. Our army is represented as in excellent spirits, well supplied, and sanguine of entire success.

abstract: Speech at Am. Anti-Slavery Soc. Anniversary; Speech at American Anti-Slavery Society Anniversary
snippet: Speech at Am. Anti-Slavery Soc. Anniversary; Speech at American Anti-Slavery Society Anniversary
lead_paragraph: At the Church of the Puritans, Tuesday moreing, this Society celebrated its Thirty-first Anniver sary, WM. LLOYD GARRISON presided. After the opening ceremonies a series of resolutions were offered which were in substance, as follows: That the society recognize in the rebellion the hand of God as a merited chastisement for our great national sin of Chattel Slavery; that Liberty and Slavery must be in perpetual conflict, and that any Government attempting to unite them, must be overthrown; that the measures before Congress for the extinction of Slavery in those portions of the country exempt from the President's Proclamation of Jan. 1, 1863, are wise and patriotic; that honor is due to the Women's Loyal League for their energy in circulating petitions asking Congress to adopt measures for the immediate extinction of Slavery; that it is essential the Constitution shall expressly prohibit Slavery and that the action of the Senate adopting an amendment to that effect, should be sanctioned by the House of Representatives; that the several accusations ever brought against Slavery, as a system, by the Abolltionists, have been fully sustained by the atrocities at Fort Pillow, Port Hudson, Fort Wagner and other places; that the Government is bound to give protection to all fighting under its flag; that the decision of Attorney-General BATES, that no decision can be made, between those who are fighting for their country, and that the same compensation is to be meted out without regard to race or complexion, is just and obligatory.
headline: {'main': "Anniversary of the American Anti-Slavery Society.; TUESDAY'S PROCEEDINGS.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Anniversary of the American Anti-Slavery Society.; TUESDAY'S PROCEEDINGS.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: While it would be presumptous yet to affirm that GRANT will soon conquer his road to Richmond, it is certain that the present campaign will leave one of the great armies terribly worsted.
lead_paragraph: While it would be presumptous yet to affirm that GRANT will soon conquer his road to Richmond, it is certain that the present campaign will leave one of the great armies terribly worsted. The spirit of the two leaders, and of the two armies, will make it impossible for Richmond to be either taken, or not taken, this Summer, without a blow that shall absolutely disable either the one army or the other. Knowing that this blow must fall, we have a right to inquire which side is best prepared to endure it. Would it be alike damaging, or alike fatal, in either case?

abstract: The prize steamship Minnie, Acting Ensign FRANCIS WALLACE, commanding, arrived at this port last night from off Wilmington, having been captured on the 9th inst. in lat. 34, lon. 73, by the United States steam gunboat Connecticut while attempting to run the blockade. She left Wilmington the night previous, and has a cargo of 600 bales cotton, 30 tons tobacco and 12 barrels turpentine, destined for Bermuda. She was built in Glasgow in November, 1863 for a blockade runner. She registers 450 tons, and was owned by the Albion Trading Company of London. The following is a list of the prize officers in charge: Acting Ensign, FRANCIS WALLACE, commanding; Acting Master's Mate, E.P. Blague; Acting Third Assistant Engineers, (in charge,) Wm, McGrath, Chas. H. Lawrence.
lead_paragraph: The prize steamship Minnie, Acting Ensign FRANCIS WALLACE, commanding, arrived at this port last night from off Wilmington, having been captured on the 9th inst. in lat. 34, lon. 73, by the United States steam gunboat Connecticut while attempting to run the blockade. She left Wilmington the night previous, and has a cargo of 600 bales cotton, 30 tons tobacco and 12 barrels turpentine, destined for Bermuda. abstract: Owens, Brig.-Gen. J. J.; Killed in battle; Rice, Brig.-Gen. James C.; Killed in battle; Stevens, Brig.-Gen. Thomas; Killed in battle
snippet: Owens, Brig.-Gen. J. J.; Killed in battle; Rice, Brig.-Gen. James C.; Killed in battle; Stevens, Brig.-Gen. Thomas; Killed in battle
lead_paragraph: Amongst the dead who fell in Tuesday's battle in Virginia was Con. JAMES C. RICE, of this City, one of the bravest, purest, noblest spirits this country has seen -- a man so simple in his ways, so entirely devoted to his country, so fearless and determined in battle, so true and genuine a man and so thoroughly a soldier, that, without family or political influence, and without personal effort, his own merits raised him from the position of private in the Thirty-ninth New-York Regiment to that of one of the most trusted and respected Brigadiers in the Army of the Potomac. He fought in every battle in which that army was engaged, except that of Antietam; he bore the blunt of many terrible conflicts; on many occasions received shots through his clothing, but was never touched in his person till, in the charge which he led on Tuesday, he was shot in the thigh. He died shortly after amputation had been performed -- his last words the request, "Turn me over that I may die with my face to the enemy." In him the country has lost not only a true and brave soldier, but a devoted citizen -- a man who understood the full meaning of liberty -- who was a democrat in the best and truest sense of the word.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. WILSON offered a bill authorizing every railroad in the United States to carry freight, passengers, mails, troops and Government supplies, and receive compensation therefor.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. WILSON offered a bill authorizing every railroad in the United States to carry freight, passengers, mails, troops and Government supplies, and receive compensation therefor. It was resolved that the Secretary of War be directed to furnish the Senate with a list of all general officers in commission at or since the beginning of the present war. The bill altering the charter of the City of Washington so as to allow every male citizen to vote without regard to color, was brought up for argument, after which the Senate adjourned to Monday.

abstract: The twenty-eighth anniversary of the American Temperance Union was held last evening at Irving Hall, Gov. BUCKINGHAM, of Connecticut, presiding. After prayer, the report of the Executive Committee was read, showing the receipts for the year to have bees $7,971 38. The President then delivered the annual address, after which resolutions were passed thanking the President for the assistance he had rendered in protecting the soldier from the intoxicating cup, the Sabbath Schools and Christian Commission for their contributions, and congratulating their brethren in Great Britain on the progress they were making.

abstract: -- Let the whole country send up prayers to Heaven for the protection of the great leader of our army, Lieut.-Gen. GRANT. His great lieutenant has fallen -- SEDGWICK is no more. The heroic WADSWORTH sleeps in death. HAYS, STEVENSON, RICE and OWENS have fought their last fight. Many others of his staunchest Generals, scores upon scores of his Colonels, and hundreds of other invaluable officers, have been killed or put out of the field by wounds. How terrible the thought that some one of the million whizzing bullets may perchance strike the head or heart of Gen. GRANT. God save the Lieutenant-General! God save the Lieutenant-General!
lead_paragraph: -- Let the whole country send up prayers to Heaven for the protection of the great leader of our army, Lieut.-Gen. GRANT. His great lieutenant has fallen -- SEDGWICK is no more. abstract: -- We are now beginning to comprehend the terrible significance of a phrase which has been in very frequent use for a long time -- "the destruction of LEE's army." How little the public realized the full import of the words or of the thing. How little they comprehended the havoc in our own army which the effort must cause. LEE's army was a huge, strong, compact, fierce, ferocious mass. It was energized by hate, hardened by experience, toughened by time, and severely disciplined. It was determined not to be destroyed. Last week, however, we began to try it. A week of fearful battles, and fearful destruction to both sides, is the record. The work is by no means done yet. When it is done, and in other years, we shall begin to realize the magnitude of the bloody labor we undertook.
lead_paragraph: -- We are now beginning to comprehend the terrible significance of a phrase which has been in very frequent use for a long time -- "the destruction of LEE's army." abstract: Admiral Porter's Report
snippet: Admiral Porter's Report
lead_paragraph: The interest which attaches to the late operations -- unfortunate though they were -- on the Red River, will insure for Admiral PORTER's report, which appears in other columns, a general perusal. It will strike most readers, however, that the amount of labor, in the first place, wasted in attempting to recover the steamer Eastport, after her sinking by a torpedo, and the amount of space given in his report to details of the attempted recovery of the vessel, are out of proportion to the importance of the subject. We do not need a column of argument to convince us that such experienced and careful officers as Commander PHELPS and his superior in this ill-starred expedition did everything that was possible, not only to save the Eastport, but also to bring back as many of the smaller fry of vessels as possible. What we are chiefly interested in is to procure additional light on the point of non-cooperation between the naval and land forces, on the apparent absence of any sufficient prearrangement to meet or provide against the obstructions in the river or on its banks, and on the seeming neglect to reckon on a dearth of the water necessary to float such craft as were employed in the expedition. On these points we have some light thrown in this report -- if not exactly all that the public crave for. But we have no explanation intelligible to ordinary readers of naval and military history, of the circumstance that for many days there was no communication between the fleet and the army, or of the fact that the latter was sometimes marching forty miles a day when the Admiral supposed it was marching but twenty. Nor do we see why Admiral PORTER should deem it necessary in this report to deprecate public censure upon the Red River operations, by appealing to Providence not to desert his cause and "permit the fleet to be sacrificed when it has so well performed its part in what should have been a complete success." The public have no desire either to prejudge or to condemn the fleet or its brave Commander. They only seek to find a reasonable cause for unanticipated failure.

abstract: The news which we give this moring will sends a thrill of joy throughout the country. Gen.  GRANT, it seems, renewed the battle on Wednesday, and made good progress during the day, forcing LEE out of his position at Spottsylvania, ...
lead_paragraph: The news which we give this moring will sends a thrill of joy throughout the country. Gen. GRANT, it seems, renewed the battle on Wednesday, and made good progress during the day, forcing LEE out of his position at Spottsylvania, and capturing many prisoners, though of this day's operations, the details are very meager. But yesterday morning Gen. HANCOCK, leading his whole corps, with the most sublime valor, made a terrific charge upon the rebels under A.P. HILL, and put them to ignominious route, bearing off as trophies of their gallant action one Major-General, two Brigadier-Generals, over three thousand prisoners and twelve pieces of artillery. This occurred five miles below Spottsylvania Court-house, and indicates that LEE was in full retreat.

abstract: DON JOSE AUGUSTINE ARGUILLES, Governor of a Cuban Province, to whom the Governor-General confided this duty of releasing a cargo of 300 Africans, sold the negroes, pocketed the avails, together with funds in his possession beloning to his Government, and "skedaddled." Learning that he embarked for New-York, the Governor-General dispatched an agent to Washington. The Spanish Minister applied to the State Department for authority to arrest and remand the runaway Governor. This duty was devolved upon Marshal MURRAY, who found the gentleman at the St. Nicholas Hotel, where he was arrested early yesterday morning. At one o'clock the Marshal took his prisoner on board a small steamer and proceeded to Sandy Hook, where he remained until the regular steamer for Havana came out, and then transferred him. The recusant Governor is therefore on his way back to Havana. Counsel were employed yesterday, but their efforts for a release were unsuccessful. To-day the counsel went before the Grand Jury with a complaint against the Marshal, whose action was authorized by our Government, upon a requisition of the Spanish Minister.
lead_paragraph: DON JOSE AUGUSTINE ARGUILLES, Governor of a Cuban Province, to whom the Governor-General confided this duty of releasing a cargo of 300 Africans, sold the negroes, pocketed the avails, together with funds in his possession beloning to his Government, and "skedaddled." abstract: The Evacuation of Frederics
snippet: The Evacuation of Frederics
lead_paragraph: -- There is probably less significance, in a military point of view, than at first sight appears in the report, which comes to us this morning by the Africa, that the stronghold of Fredericia, had been evacuated by the Danes. The place, it is true, has a traditional interest from its successful resistance of hostile attacks in repeated sieges. In the present case, its capacity for defence does not seem to have been put to the test; the Danes probably considering it not only a hopeless task to make another stand within intrenched works after the surrender of the Dannewerke and the fort of Duppel, but an equally needless and unprofitable waste of strength, in view of the conference negotiations in London. After their losses at Duppel, their present fighting force in the field is probably under 30,000. But were it twice as much, no friendly counselor would advise Denmark to prolong the unequal contest, after having taken her seat in the conference. Upon her allied enemies must henceforth rest the responsibility of causing needless bloodshed, if the invasion should be prosecuted beyond the Provincial frontier. Unless the international council in London is to be a mockery alike of reason and of right, the intervening delegates of the three great neutral Powers will see to it, that at this point -- if no formal armistice shall be proclaimed -- at least a truce shall practically be called, while the preliminaries of the proposed arbitration are under consideration.

abstract: The forty-eighth anniversary of this society was held at Irving Hall yesterday morning. The annual business meeting was held at 9 o'clock at the Bible House. The old Board of Managers were elected without opposition. The exercises at Irving Hall were opened with prayer by Bishop JANES. The President of the society, JAMES LENNOX, Esq., delivered the opening address. He congratulated the society on their prosperous condition, and gave some details in regard to the work performed during the past year. The Treasurer's and Managers' reports were read to the meeting, and a series of resolutions were presented and unanimously adopted. Hon. REVERDY JOHNSON, Rev. WILLIAM L. THORNTON, of London, Rev. BYRON SUNDERLAND, Rev. LACHLAN TAYLOR and others delivered addresses, when the meeting adjourned.

abstract: -- A singular contretemps (to call it by no stronger name) in the Garibaldi demonstrations, is seen in the report that the same day -- the 23d of April -- on which the working people of Naples were passing a series of resolutions expressive of their gratitude for the reception the Liberator had met in England -- a meeting of workingmen, held in London, to protest against the quasi-compulsory departure of the General, was violently broken up by the Metropolitan Police -- a body under Government control.

abstract: Ullman vs. Congregation B'Nai Israel--Desecration of a Grave
snippet: Ullman vs. Congregation B'Nai Israel--Desecration of a Grave
lead_paragraph: Solomon Ullman vs. The Congregation B'Nai Israel, -- The plaintiff in this case is a Jew, and was formerly a member of the above congregation. The plaintiff alleges that the defendants are a religious corporation or society, and that they have a burying-ground in which all the members of the congregation are shareholders, and have a plot. In 1862 Joseph Ullman, the father of plaintiff, was a member of this society, and had a right in this burying ground. In September, 1863, plaintiff's father died, and was buried in the burying-ground of the congregation, on the plot owned by him. After such burial, plaintiff caused to be erected over his grave a plain marble slab, of the value of $50, and plaintiff alleges that in October, 1863, the defendants, by their agents or servants entered the graveyard, removed the tombstone over his father's grave, taking it away and converting it to their own use. Plaintiff claims $500 damages for the value of the stone and for the desecration of his father's grave.

abstract: -- We have never in the course of the war, nor on the occurrence of any of its great battles, known such a deep and solemn feeling to pervade the community as that which has been dominant for the last few days, and especially yesterday. The public realized the greatness, the importance and the costliness of the struggle between our old Army of the Potomac and the army of LEE. They realized the carnage and felt the irreparable losses. The feeling was not one merely sensational, nor of mere excitement. It was profound and appreciative. Admiration of the deathless valor of our brave soldiers, and gratitude for their devotion was also universal.
lead_paragraph: -- We have never in the course of the war, nor on the occurrence of any of its great battles, known such a deep and solemn feeling to pervade the community as that which has been dominant for the last few days, and especially yesterday. abstract: Unwilling to remain on the defensive, Gen. GRANT, on Thursday night, ordered a general attack along the whole line for 5 o'clock the next morning. BURNSIDE, who had been hitherto in reserve was ordered in, and HANCOCK, who, as was realized had a severe part to perform, was strengthened by four divisions, taken from the Fifth and Sixth Corps, so that he now commanded nearly one-half the army.
lead_paragraph: Unwilling to remain on the defensive, Gen. GRANT, on Thursday night, ordered a general attack along the whole line for 5 o'clock the next morning. BURNSIDE, who had been hitherto in reserve was ordered in, and HANCOCK, who, as was realized had a severe part to perform, was strengthened by four divisions, taken from the Fifth and Sixth Corps, so that he now commanded nearly one-half the army.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen held quite a lengthy sitting yesterday, and dispatched considerable business. The Mayor sent in message, stating that  he had signed the appropriation ordinance for 1864, as adopted by the Common Council, because of the wants of the numerous claiments upon ...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen held quite a lengthy sitting yesterday, and dispatched considerable business. The Mayor sent in message, stating that he had signed the appropriation ordinance for 1864, as adopted by the Common Council, because of the wants of the numerous claiments upon the City Treasury, but expressing his belief, that while the Common Council had an undoubted right to decrease appropriations authorized by the Legislature, still the cutting off of such items as the appropriation for an Inebriate Asylum, for the Blind Mechanics' Association, and for judgments which have been already obtained against the City, and which it is bound in honor to pay, was injudicious. After some opposition, the message was received and ordered to be printed in the minutes. The Mayor also transmitted the resolution of the commissioners of Health, recommending that the ordinance prohibiting bone-boiling establishments within the City limits be amended to include fat-boiling establishments. The message was referred to the Committee on Board of Health. The Comptroller was directed to furnish the House of the Refuge 3,000 loads of manure. A resolution was adopted directing the Comptroller to set apart rooms in the Police Court-house on fifty-seventh-street, for the use of the Seventh District Justice's Court, now located in Eighty-sixth-street. The Comptroller reported that for the fortnight ending April 30, 13,498 families, comprising 34,099 persons, were relieved from the Volunteer Family Aid Fund, at an expense of $61,174. The fund was then overdrawn $82,810 90. The resolution adopted by the Aldermen, setting apart a portion of the Central Park for a division parade ground for the military, was discussed. The board refused to call upon the Central Park Commissioners for information on the subject, or to ask the opinion of the Corporation Counsel as to the powers of the Common Council in the premises, and finally refused to concur with the Aldermen in adopting the resolution. The paper was laid over. The board reconsidered its former resolution to meet but twice a month, and agreed to meet hereafter twice a week, as usual.

abstract: The steamship Africa, with Liverpool dates to the 30th ult., and Queenstown dates to the 1st inst., arrived at Halifax on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Africa, with Liverpool dates to the 30th ult., and Queenstown dates to the 1st inst., arrived at Halifax on Wednesday night. A party test vote had been taken in the House of Commons on the question of detaining the rebel prize Tuscaloosa, at the Cape. The Government were sustained by a majority of thirty-four. Lord DERBY brought up the subject of LAIRD's rams in the House of Lords -- defending the builders. The commission which went to Egypt to procure evidence of their intended destination for the Viceroy's service, was to be back on the 7th of May. The Danish Conference had temporarily suspended its sittings. The Atlantic cable is being manufactured at the rate of ten nautical miles a day. The Duke of Newcastle is again seriously ill. Lord PALMERSTON is also confined to his house. The news of BANKS' reverses had caused an advance of 2 1/2 per cent. in the rebel loan. At the Frankfort Shakespeare Tercentennary, some high words passed between the English and German guests. The American Consul acted the part of peacemaker.

abstract: Grant's Advance--What will Come of it; Grant's Advance--The Work to be done
snippet: Grant's Advance--What will Come of it; Grant's Advance--The Work to be done
lead_paragraph: There are many people, as is shown by the continued high price of gold, who are disappointed and made doubtful by the slowness of GRANT'S advance, the obstinacy of LEE's resistance, and the magnitude of our losses. This is due mainly to the fact that there still lingers in the public mind much of the old delusion about the importance of capturing certain places. We have so long cherished the belief that the existance of the Confederacy depended on the possession of certain towns, that no amount of practical experience of its falsity seems sufficient to rid us of it. We have gone on flattering ourselves for three years that if we took New-Orleans, or took Charleston, or Vicksburgh, or took Richmond and reoccupied this and that point, "the back of the rebelion would be broken." The latest illustration of this craze was Gen. BANKS' march on Shreveport. There is very little doubt that he flattered himself that, when Shreveport fell, the Confederacy would shake to its centre.

abstract: -- By the Africa we have the intelligence that the Tory party made the case of the Tuscaloosa rebel prize (detained at the Cape by orders from the Home Government) the occasion of testing their strength in the House of Commons. The result was a very notable defeat, considering how nearly balanced parties have been for the last two years. In a House of over 400 members the Government majority was 34. A simultaneous attack was made on Earl RUSSELL in the House of Lords by Lord DERBY, in connection with the Laird rams; but there the question was not put to the vote.
lead_paragraph: -- By the Africa we have the intelligence that the Tory party made the case of the Tuscaloosa rebel prize (detained at the Cape by orders from the Home Government) the occasion of testing their strength in the House of Commons. abstract: RELIEF OF THE RUPTURED AND CRIPPLED.  The New-York Society for the relief of the ruptured and crippled, held their first annual meeting, at the Bible-House, Tuesday evening, May 10, when Mr. R ...
lead_paragraph: RELIEF OF THE RUPTURED AND CRIPPLED. -- The New-York Society for the relief of the ruptured and crippled, held their first annual meeting, at the Bible-House, Tuesday evening, May 10, when Mr. R.M. MARTLEY, Corresponding Secretary, read a very able report, being a review of their labors for the year; and was followed by Dr. JAMES KNIGHT, the physician and surgeon of the institution, who read a very full report of the great and good work that has been done for the indigent ruptured and crippled. There has been treated in the Institution during the year, 828 patients, 4 1/2 per cent being under 14 years old. Many of them being paralytic, and unable to walk, have been restored to the use of their limbs; also several laboring under hip disease and white swelling. Cases of club-feet have been made perfect in form, and many cases of weakness peculiar to women, and extraordinary cases of rupture relieved. After the reading of the reports an election was held for officers and a Board of Managers, when JOHN C. GREEN was elected President, and James Lenox, John David Wolfe, R.B. Miniurn, Stewart Brown, and A.R. Wetmore, Vice Presidents; Jonathan Sturges, Treasurer; R.M. Hartley. Corresponding Secretary and Joseph B. Collins, Recording Secretary.

abstract: The remains of the brave and lamented SEDGWICK, which lay in state yesterday at the City Hall, were visited by a great number of citizens, who de  sired to pay a last tribute of respect to one, whose death, though so untimely, was the fitting close of an heroic life.
lead_paragraph: The remains of the brave and lamented SEDGWICK, which lay in state yesterday at the City Hall, were visited by a great number of citizens, who de sired to pay a last tribute of respect to one, whose death, though so untimely, was the fitting close of an heroic life. He was dressed in his uniform, just as he fell when struck by that fatal bullet. His coffin was draped with the national flag, and was appropriately decorated with wreaths and bouquets, in which were entwined forget-me-nots and lilies of the valley. The martial face of the departed hero, bronzed by exposure to the fierce blaze of battle, wore in death a calm and serene aspect, marred only by the wound in the left cheek -- nay, not marred, for that sad token of his stern and high fidelity unto death to the cause of his country and of liberty, was a nobler decoration than was ever the star or cross bestowed by royalty for success in war. The remains will be taken this morning to Cornwall, Conn., when they will be consigned to their last resting place.

abstract: A match of some interest to the owners of the two horses engaged and the friends of either party, came off at the "fashion" yesterday.
lead_paragraph: A match of some interest to the owners of the two horses engaged and the friends of either party, came off at the "fashion" yesterday. It was somewhat unfortunate that this match was set down on the same day as a previously announced trot at the "Union," hence the attendance was more select than numerous. The gelding Discount, one of the contestants, had been previously well-known in trotting circles under the soubriquet of Andy Mulligan, and had done his two miles in 5:32; whilst his oppponent, Morgan Jones, who had been unnamed until the day previously, was comparatively a green horse.

abstract: -- The anniversary of this institution took place at the Academy of Music last Tuesday evening, a very large audience being in attendance. Rev. Dr. BURLINGAME presided and made the opening address. Rev. Mr. VAN METER read the annual report, showing that about 1,300 children had, during the year, been provided for. The exercises consisted of addresses by Rev. Dr. DE WITT TALLMAGE, of Philadelphia, Rev. Dr. ANDERSON and Rev. MATTHEW HALE SMITH, interspersed with songs, duets, glees, &c., by the children of the institution, of whom nearly one hundred occupied seats upon the stage. A large collection for the benefit of the Mission was taken up during the evening.

abstract: Grant's First and Last "Propositions"
snippet: Grant's First and Last "Propositions"
lead_paragraph: At the opening of Gen. GRANT's military career at Fort Donelson, he sent a proposition to Gen. BUCKNER, who had requested a cessation of hostilities after two days' fighting, in these words: "I propose to move immediately upon your works." We have had but few other propositions from him till now, when he makes another, after six days' fighting: "I propose," says he, "to fight it out on this line, if it takes all Summer." Both of these proposals are very cool, but terribly determined.

abstract: The United States vs. Tyrrell, Bunns, Reilly and Steers, Charged with Enticing a Soldier to Desert. -- The accused were brought up for examination this morning, before the Commissioner, charged with enticing a soldier belonging to the Tenth United States Infantry to desert from his regiment and procure the extra bounty. After the examination of Capt. Erhardt, the Provost-Marshal for the First District, and two of his detectives, in regard to certain admissions and confessions alleged to have been made on a preliminary examination by the accused, and the Government failing to produce the complainant, the accused were discharged.

abstract: The New-York Observer, of the 12th inst., contains a letter from its correspondent at Larnaca, in the Island of Cyprus, (Turkish dominions,) describing a most remarkable lusus naturae recently discovered there. It is nothing less than a woman with horns growing out of her head. She has one large horn on the side of her head of the size and consistency of an ordinary ram's horn; besides, three or four cornicles on other parts of the head. The writer states that he has seen her, and that she has been visited by nearly all the Consuls and Europeans in that place, some of whom are making an effort to secure her for exhibition.
lead_paragraph: The New-York Observer, of the 12th inst., contains a letter from its correspondent at Larnaca, in the Island of Cyprus, (Turkish dominions,) describing a most remarkable lusus naturae recently discovered there. It is nothing less than a woman with horns growing out of her head. She has one large horn on the side of her head of the size and consistency of an ordinary ram's horn; besides, three or four cornicles on other parts of the head. The writer states that he has seen her, and that she has been visited by nearly all the Consuls and Europeans in that place, some of whom are making an effort to secure her for exhibition.

abstract: It was, therefore, difficult on Friday night to say whether the enemy would resume the attack or retire. In case of the former alternative, a new and stronger line, considerably contracted, was selected on Friday evening. The attack, however, was not resumed in the morning, and reconnoissances and skirmishes made during the day along the whole line, though developing on the part of the enemy a strong skirmish line, left little doubt that the main portion of his army was retiring.

abstract: CAPTURE OF A BURGLAR. -- Yesterday afternoon a burglar, just coming out of No. 8 Clinton-street, was detected by Sheriff MCNAMEE and Mr. OWEN HANOVAN, who gave chase, and on attempting to arrest the fellow he turned round and fired five shots from a revolver. None of them took effect. The parties continued to pursue him, and finally secured him in Furman-street. He had stolen the revolver and some money from the house he entered. The accused was given into the hands of Detective FROST, and locked up. He refused to give his name.

abstract: This iron-clad ram (the largest vessel of the kind in the world) will probably be ready for launching about the middle of next month.
lead_paragraph: This iron-clad ram (the largest vessel of the kind in the world) will probably be ready for launching about the middle of next month. The armor on the casemates has been laid on and the "beak," the extreme end of the prow, has been successfully cast and will be put in position during the week. There are at present over five hundred men engaged in the construction of the vessel and her machinery. The delay in the work on the Dunderberg, which has been nearly two years on the stocks, was occasioned by the difficulty of completing her machinery, owing to the crowded state of the different iron works under contract with the Government. This was not the fault of any of the parties concerned in the building of the ram; but was the result of the necessities of the Navy Department. It was thought at Washington that all necessary repairs to those vessels we have already afloat should first be attended to, before the work on the iron-clads should be progressed with.

abstract: Yesterday a trot came off on the Union Course, Long Island, for the proprietor's purse and stake of $175, mile heats, best three in five, to wagons.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday a trot came off on the Union Course, Long Island, for the proprietor's purse and stake of $175, mile heats, best three in five, to wagons. The attendance, owing to the threatening appearance of the weather, which betokened rain, was not large, although nearly all the frequenters of the trotting track were present. There were five entries for the race, but only two, HIRAM WOODRUFF's b.g. Dexter, and JOHN DOTY's bay mare, came on the track to trot for the race. Dexter's previous performances on this track and the Fashion, having won all his engagements, naturally gave him the call in the betting, $20 to $8 being the current quotations in the betting market. Very little however was done, for nothing was known of the mare's capabilities. She is a big slashing daughter of GEORGE N. PATCHEN out of a last Jersey mare, and stands 15 hands 3 inches. Her style of going is very like her sire's, and she will assuredly be heard of again to advantage when she gets fairly into trotting condition.
headline: {'main': 'The Turf.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Turf.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We regret to say that the hopes inspired by Capt. SCHUYLER'S dispatch, received yesterday, that Gen. WADSWORTH, though wounded and a prisoner, might still be living, are dissipated by later accounts. Gen. E. JOHNSON, who was cap- ...
lead_paragraph: We regret to say that the hopes inspired by Capt. SCHUYLER'S dispatch, received yesterday, that Gen. WADSWORTH, though wounded and a prisoner, might still be living, are dissipated by later accounts. Gen. E. JOHNSON, who was captured by HANCOCK, though he did not know the fact personally, had very little doubt of his death, and our correspondent, Mr. SWINTON, was told by a rebel Captain, who was taken prisoner, that he assisted in his burial and took from his body his official papers. There is very little doubt, we presume, that his wound was fatal.

abstract: The valuable collection of paintings belonging to GOUPIL & Co. will be submitted to the hammer this evening, at the old Dusseldorf Gallery, No. 548 Broadway. It contains some neat cabinet specimens of the best known artists of the European and American schools, and a few large gallery pictures of decided importance, such as MULLER's "Secret Interrogatory of Marie Antoinette," and VANDERLYN's "Ariadne." There are many charming little gems, notably, a "Standard Bearer," by MEISSONIER, which is the second work by the artist ever offered at auction in America, and making only the fourth picture by him in the country. There are good examples by Ed. Frere, Schlesinger, Verboeckhoven, Toulmouche, Trayer, Coutourier, Lemmens, Williams, Bonheur. And among our own artists we notice the names of Durand, Kensett Church, Bierstadt, Gignowx; Casilear, Gifford, Eastman Johnson, McEntee, James and Wm. Hart Hennessy, Whittredge, &c., &c. There are in all 192 pictures, and as moat of them are of neat and reasonable proportions, the purchaser will have an unusual range of selection. The sale is by Messrs. H.H. LEEDS and MINER, and commences to-night at 7 1/2 o'clock.

abstract: A meeting is to be held to-morrow (Sunday) evening at the Academy of Music in aid of the Christian Commission, for the special purpose of enabling that excellent and effective organization to prosecute, with a degree of energy and success proportioned to the greatness of the emergency, the work of relieving the sufferings of the sick and wounded soldiers of the army.
lead_paragraph: A meeting is to be held to-morrow (Sunday) evening at the Academy of Music in aid of the Christian Commission, for the special purpose of enabling that excellent and effective organization to prosecute, with a degree of energy and success proportioned to the greatness of the emergency, the work of relieving the sufferings of the sick and wounded soldiers of the army. No one needs to be told that the demand for such aid just now is enormous, and no efforts can be too great or too prompt. The battles now in progress in Virginia, have already thrown thousands upon thousands of wounded upon the hands of the Government, and their numbers must inevitably be largely increased before the campaign is closed. The Christian Commission works in perfect harmony with the Sanitary Commission, and through both these channels the benevolence and charity of the country finds practical expression.

abstract: -- According to the usage of the Established Church of Scotland, there is but one sacramental fast -- or at most two -- in the year, and the manner in which the day was observed on its last recurrence (on the 21st ult.,) is described with unconscious humor in the Scotsman newspaper. The editor says that as the day was unusually fine, cheap excursion trains were the order to and from the capital -- supplemented by "itinerant exhibitions, shows, shooting galleries, picnics, dances a d rows." From any other source such a statement might be fairly considered slanderous.

abstract: The U.S. steamer Queen, Capt. TARR, Norfolk 40 hours, arrived yesterday morning. On the 13th, 20 miles north of Cape Henry, saw an English bark with signal of distress flying. Went to her. abstract: The Anniversary Exhibition of the New-York Institution for the Blind, was given at Irving Hall last evening. The exercises by the pupils of the ...
lead_paragraph: The Anniversary Exhibition of the New-York Institution for the Blind, was given at Irving Hall last evening. The exercises by the pupils of the Asylum, in this City, under direction of the Rev. Mr. PEET, Superintendent of the Institution, were received with mingled wonder and delight, by an audience thoroughly appreciative and sympathetic. The sadness of the spectacle of a school of young unfortunates, deprived forever of the advantages of sight, would of course incline those present to look most charitably upon all failures in the performers, but there were no failures to overlook or cover up with the mantle of kindness: not a single error or mistake on the part of pupils or teachers, marred the pleasure of the evening, and pity changed to wonder at the accomplishments of these young lads and misses, taught only by the sense of feeling.
headline: {'main': 'The Anniversaries.; ANNUAL EXHIBITION OF THE NEW-YORK INSTITUTION FOR THE BLIND.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Anniversaries.; ANNUAL EXHIBITION OF THE NEW-YORK INSTITUTION FOR THE BLIND.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: IMPORTANT SANITARY MOVEMENT. The City Inspector has ordered a Sanitary survey of the City, which cannot fail to result in a great benefit to a large portion of its population.
lead_paragraph: IMPORTANT SANITARY MOVEMENT. -- The City Inspector has ordered a Sanitary survey of the City, which cannot fail to result in a great benefit to a large portion of its population. The subordinate officers of his department are engaged in ascertaining the street and number of each house, with the name of the owner and occupant, the size of the lot, material of the house, its safety as a residence, the means of escape in case of fire, &c. The size of the house, the number of stairways, divisions of the apartments, height of the ceiling, width of halls and stairways, are to be ascertained with the utmost particularity. A careful census of the cellar population is also to be made, and the condition of every basement and cellar occupied as a dwelling will be reported. The facts thus ascertained will be laid before the Common Council, together with such suggestions as may be considered necessary. The fat-boiling establishments in the Twentieth and Twenty-second Wards are, according to the orders of the Commissioners of Health, to be renovated or removed, and the slaughter-house system will be reformed. The prospects of the Sanitary Government of the City are better than for years before.

abstract: The present campaign against Richmond will probably be a series of most stubborn and bloody battles, across every ravine and stream and river between Spottsylvania Court House and the rebel capital.
lead_paragraph: The present campaign against Richmond will probably be a series of most stubborn and bloody battles, across every ravine and stream and river between Spottsylvania Court House and the rebel capital. The country is a most difficult one, intersected with streams, on whose high banks artillery and riflemen can have the strongest positions. Still, by far the most arduous part of the way is already passed, now that the "Wilderness" is in the rear of our army, and probably the most stubborn fighting is over. The Southern army is not one for disaster and continued retreat; the conscripts will fall away; the officers will lose heart; and supplies, wih perhaps ammunition, may fail. LEE himself must see that he could never again have such a position for attack as he had on the outskirts of the "Wilderness," and he probably even now fights for existence. If any of the roads behind him are cut by our cavalry -- as is the case -- he is in a most perilous position for supplying his men. Still, all his difficulties might be overcome, and he retreat in good-order toward North Carolina, whither it would be impossible for us to follow, except by arranging a new campaign, with a new base at Weldon.

abstract: Maj.-Gen. McDOWELL has been appointed to the command of the Military Department of the Pacific. He will leave for California by an early steamer. The country has no more loyal citizen ...
lead_paragraph: Maj.-Gen. MCDOWELL has been appointed to the command of the Military Department of the Pacific. He will leave for California by an early steamer. The country has no more loyal citizen and no more accomplished soldier than he: and it is not at all unlikely that in the rapid progress of events he may find in what seems now the comparatively unimportant region of California, a field for the full exercise of his abilities. The complications to which the Mexican question may possibly give rise will be only less in magnitude than those growing out of the rebellion; and in case of war with any European Power our Pacific possession will be the main prize of the contest.

abstract: The remains of Gen. J.C. RICE Will receive the last tribute of gratitude and respect from our community to-morrow afternoon, at 2  o'clock, at the Church on Madison-square, of which he died a member. Rev. Dr. ADAMS will make the address on the occasion. The military will be represented among ...
lead_paragraph: The remains of Gen. J.C. RICE Will receive the last tribute of gratitude and respect from our community to-morrow afternoon, at 2 o'clock, at the Church on Madison-square, of which he died a member. Rev. Dr. ADAMS will make the address on the occasion. The military will be represented among the pall-bearers, as will also the legal profession, Gen. RICE having been in the practice or the law in this City at the time of the breaking out of the rebellion. The country mourns the loss of this gallant soldier, in common with our City and his own family. His remains will be taken to the house of his mother in Washington for interment.

abstract: Between nine and ten thousand prisoners arrived at Beile Plain to-day. They will be brought here to-morrow. Roads between Fredericksburgh and Battlefield are thronged with captured graybacks on their way to the rear. We have captured thus far nearly fifteen thousand prisoners. The rebel dead and wounded cover the country for miles. The dead are unburied.

lead_paragraph: A mass meeting was held last evening at the Cooper Institute under the auspices of the Lincoln Central Campaign Club, in opposition to the postponement of the Republican National Convention, and in favor of the renomination of ABRAHAM LINCOLN to the Presidency. The large hall was crowded to its utmost capacity with an intelligent and enthusiastic audience, comprising many ladies. A band was in attendance, which discoursed national airs occasionally during the meeting.

abstract: -- But few works on surgery contain a more interesting or remarkable case than the following: MATTHEW PHENIX, Co. B, Eighty-sixth New-York Volunteers, was wounded, by a spent ball, in the left eye, at Mine Run, on the 27th day of November, 1863. He was brought to the Baptist Church hospital, in this City, on the 4th day of December, 1863, where his wound was probed by Dr. C.P. BIGELOW, surgeon in charge, who failed to discover the locality of the ball. He remained in the hospital some time, experiencing occasional pain, but all the time his general health was improving. The wound was frequently probed by Dr. BIGELOW, but without any better result than at the first trial. About the first of March last, his general health being very good, he was granted a furlough for forty days. At the expiration of that time he returned, and soon began to complain quite frequently of severe pain form his wound. The wound was again probed, and some pieces of dead bone taken from his eye and the roof of his mouth. On Saturday last, in examining the wound again with a probe, Dr. BIGELOW discovered the locality of the ball, which seemed to be resting immediately over the pallet of the mouth or throat. Inserting his ball forceps, he found he could not grasp it, and, after repeated efforts, he concluded to wait until Sunday morning, when it was his intention to separate the bone on each side of the eye, by which means it was thought the ball could be easily taken out. Early on Sunday morning a messenger aroused the Doctor, and informed him that PHENIX was choking to death. He at once repaired to the hospital, where he found the patient in the condition stated. He soon discovered that the ball had been moved from its original bed a little lower down, and unless immediately removed must produce suffocation. He inserted his forceps and extracted it without the least difficulty, giving instant relief to his patient. The ball was a grape shot (iron,) one and a half inches in diameter, and about four inches in circumference, and weighs but a fraction less than hall a pound. To any one but a surgeon this story would seem somewhat miraculous, but truth sometimes is even stranger than fiction. PHENIX is still at the above hospital, and from all appearances the carrying of a cannon ball in his head for five months has but slightly impaired his health, and got shortened his days in the least. -- Alexandria Sentinel, May [???].

On Saturday last, in examining the wound again with a probe, Dr. BIGELOW discovered the locality of the ball, which seemed to be resting immediately over the pallet of the mouth or throat. Inserting his ball forceps, he found he could not grasp it, and, after repeated efforts, he concluded to wait until Sunday morning, when it was his intention to separate the bone on each side of the eye, by which means it was thought the ball could be easily taken out. Early on Sunday morning a messenger aroused the Doctor, and informed him that PHENIX was choking to death. He at once repaired to the hospital, where he found the patient in the condition stated. He soon discovered that the ball had been moved from its original bed a little lower down, and unless immediately removed must produce suffocation. He inserted his forceps and extracted it without the least difficulty, giving instant relief to his patient. The ball was a grape shot (iron,) one and a half inches in diameter, and about four inches in circumference, and weighs but a fraction less than hall a pound. To any one but a surgeon this story would seem somewhat miraculous, but truth sometimes is even stranger than fiction. PHENIX is still at the above hospital, and from all appearances the carrying of a cannon ball in his head for five months has but slightly impaired his health, and got shortened his days in the least. -- Alexandria Sentinel, May [???].

abstract: Grant's Advance--"Lee's Army"
snippet: Grant's Advance--"Lee's Army"
lead_paragraph: The terrible series of battles which, during the last ten days, have tried the mettle of our army, and the remarkable succession of victorious bulletins which have thrilled the nerves of the nation, seem to be reaching their consummation. The great army of the rebellion, which has held its ground against the power of the United States for three long years, which has fought more great battles than any army that has existed in the world for the last half century, which has twice crossed to this side of the Potomac, and four times driven back mighty armies led by four Generals in succession -- the veteran army of ROBERT E. LEE is breaking up. Or rather, it is being defeated, demolished, crushed and annihilated by the courage of our soldiers and the masterly generalship of their Commander.

abstract: The body of Gen. SEDGWICK was removed at 7 o'clock yesterday morning from its temporary resting place at the City Hall, and conveyed to the depot of the New-Haven Railroad, attended by the Sons of Connecticut and a detachment of the Eighth Regiment, Col. VARIAN. The pall-bearers were Gov. Bucking- ...
lead_paragraph: The body of Gen. SEDGWICK was removed at 7 o'clock yesterday morning from its temporary resting place at the City Hall, and conveyed to the depot of the New-Haven Railroad, attended by the Sons of Connecticut and a detachment of the Eighth Regiment, Col. VARIAN. The pall-bearers were Gov. Buckingham, R.H. McCurdy, P.M. Wetmore, E.P. Cowles O.J. Hodge, Charles Gould, Waldo Hutchings, E.N. Horsford, John Allen and David B. Booth. The funeral will take place to-morrow at Cornwall, Connecticut. There will be no military or civic display, when the remains of the lamented hero are laid beside his kindred. Imposing ceremonies would have been, perhaps, nnsultable at this crisis, but the sorrow and gratitude of the people will follow the dead soldier to his grave, which henceforth will be a consecrated place to every lover of his country.

abstract: Grant's Advance
snippet: Grant's Advance
lead_paragraph: The brilliant news announced yesterday morning that LEE'S rebel army had received a staggering, if not a crushing blow, is officially confirmed this morning by dispatches from Gen. GRANT himself up to Friday morning, at 8 o'clock, at which time LEE was in full retreat either for Richmond or for another strong position. Our troops were at once sent in pursuit, and soon came up with the rebel rear guard. Gen. GRANT would pursue vigorously, though his army was greatly fatigued. The captures of the glorious battle of Thursday, when HANCOCK so gallantly stormed the rebel right, are set down at from thirty to forty guns and from four to six thousand prisoners. One Major-General. EDWARD JOHNSON, and two Brigadiers -- a brother of JOHNSON and GEORGE H. STUART, of Maryland -- are among the captured officers. Our losses had been very heavy, but no computation could be made with any degree of correctness. A dispatch was read in the army on Thursday, announcing that Gen. SIGEL had destroyed the railroad between Lynchburgh and Charlottesville, forty miles below the latter place.

abstract: French Alliance--What it Costs England
snippet: French Alliance--What it Costs England
lead_paragraph: Unless the alliance of France has become indispensable to the very existence of England, her rulers are paying a rather exorbitant price for it. The arrangement of the differences between the Danes and the Germans may be an extremely important matter, but if British statesmen cannot accomplish it without French aid, and if French aid cannot be obtained save on terms incompatible with British honor and interests, would it not be better for England's Ministers to decline altogether the acceptance of NAPOLEON'S conditions, and to leave Danes and Germans to settle their differences themselves? There can be no more convincing proof of the high tribute which the British Government have to pay for the French Emperor's good will, than the fact that they are ashamed to acknowledge it. Such an admission, on their part, is not necessary, since their deeds proclaim more expressively than could words the disgraceful nature of the contract. There was a time when England respected the laws of hospitality, and the rights of her people -- when the exile was secure within her borders, and thought and speech were free as air. But now these things would almost seem to be changed. To conciliate an imperious ally, if all the evidence does not deceive us, the reigning Ministry of England have recently stooped to drive from her shores, by ungenerous pressure, a man whom they had just received as an honored guest; and still more recently, through anxiety to please this upstart arbiter of European destinies, they have ventured to perpetrate an outrage of deeper dye.
headline: {'main': 'What the French Alliance Costs England.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'What the French Alliance Costs England.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Renan, M. Ernest. Studies of Religion, History and Criticism
snippet: Renan, M. Ernest. Studies of Religion, History and Criticism
lead_paragraph: M. RENAN's name has, for the last two or three rears, been more widely bruited abroad than that of any other modern writer of continental Europe. Circumstances, independently of his actual merits, have cooperated with them to bring him prominently before the general public and the class who do not usually trouble themselves with linguistic and archaeological discussions. Persecution has operated in his favor with all inhabitants of free countries, and by stimulating curiosity as to his opinions, has increased the number of his readers and widened the circle of his influence. He is known to lie under the Papal anathema, and to be the object of the most bitter and rancorous attacks of its ministers, in numbers exceeding the capacity of the most patient bibliographers to keep count of. While thus exposed as a mark or target for the hostility of every private champion of orthodoxy, the same subtle power that inspires their assaults has been working in high places, and, through the Imperial Government of France, causes the sudden suspension of his official functions as Professor in the College of France, merely for the exercise of a customary freedom of investigation distasteful in its results to the ecclesiastical mind. This arbitrary state of suspension still continues, and the enforced leisure it affords him has been turned to account by M. RENAN, for the composition of the works already alluded to, that are now exercising a startling effect on the more cultivated portions of the nations composing (to make use of a fashionable term) "the Latin race."

abstract: Grant's Advance
snippet: Grant's Advance
lead_paragraph: In three separate bulletins, admirable for their brevity and distinctness, the Secretary of War sums up the whole of the news from the armies East and West, which had reached the Department up to yesterday afternoon. The dispatches from Gen. GRANT come up to Friday evening at 6 o'clock. During that day the advance of HANCOCK developed the fact that the rebel army had fallen back four miles. There was no engagement during Friday, and the department has no intelligence of any general officer having been killed in the terrible engagement of Thursday. Some definite idea of the losses inflicted on the rebels may be gathered from the additional fact, stated in Mr. STANTON's first dispatch, that over 7,000 prisoners, including 400 officers, with Major-Gen. JOHNSON, and Brig.-Gen. STEWART, had arrived at Belle Plain.

abstract: The retrospect which Gen. MEADE has taken of the eight days and nights of battle which commenced at early dawn on the 5th of May, was not, we trust, needed opportune and most becoming as that retrospect isto remind a grateful community of the great and important part which the CommandingGeneral has borne in this series of victories.
lead_paragraph: The retrospect which Gen. MEADE has taken of the eight days and nights of battle which commenced at early dawn on the 5th of May, was not, we trust, needed -- opportune and most becoming as that retrospect is -- to remind a grateful community of the great and important part which the CommandingGeneral has borne in this series of victories. The nation, it may be safely reckoned, will not readily forget, either, the noble and unpretentious service of Gen. MEADE at a time when the army which he now commands had been put on the defensive by an insolent and all but victorious enemy. The modest victor of Gettysburgh may fairly feel, as he quietly expresses it, authorized to address his army in terms of congratulation, and the nation will echo his words when he says: "Your heroic, noble endurance of fatigue and privation will ever be memorable. Let us return thanks to God for the mercy thus shown us, and ask earnestly for its continuance."

abstract: AN EXAMPLE. -- It is not often that we look for much enlightenment in the proceedings of the Provincial Legislature at Quebec. But two nights ago, they did something in the way of taxation not unworthy of notice. There is a million or more of a deficit in their treasury, and half the amount can be raised in a few months by an excise on spirits. This the House of Assembly unanimously agreed to in a conference of an hour or more; and the telegraph was immediately put in use by the Government to order all the inland revenue officers to make the levy next morning, by 9 o'clock.

abstract: Letter to his Brother, J. E.
