abstract: Railroads and Cruelty to Animals
snippet: Railroads and Cruelty to Animals
lead_paragraph: There is ample room in New-York for the labors of a society for the prevention of cruelty to animals. Not infrequently crippled, diseased, and worn-out horses may be seen lashed into service altogether above their strength, by unfeeling drivers, or dragged in the last stage of life, bruised and bleeding, to the side of the public street, to gasp out in needless pain their little remaining breath. One can understand how a class of reckless, greedy, unfeeling cartmen may thus use the faithful brutes that have earned their masters' meat and drink, for there is a class of human beings with whom cruelty to the brute creation seems to be as elaborately cultivated as if it were one of the fine arts. But we may well express astonishment that the same indifference to brute suffering which tempts men to abuse and treat unmercifully the most useful and noble of all domestic animals, should be found to have possession of many whose moral attributes are otherwise acknowledged. Let us leave out of account the crowds of thoughtless, reckless lads who club for a holiday ride, and who may always be met with on Sunday on some suburban road making the most of their carriage experience for the day by a steady pounding of the unconscious brute that drags them along -- regardless alike of his ability or willingness to make a reasonable pace. The owners of the animals thus abused are more to blame than the brainless pleasure-seekers, who are incapable probably by their very constitution of knowing either what cruelty really means, or what treatment is reasonable and just toward a horse or any other living animal. The people we speak of want sensibility, and in too many cases it is with them a native and constitutional want which partakes of the nature of total depravity, and for which there is probably no earthly remedy.
headline: {'main': 'The City Railroads and Cruelty to Animals.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The City Railroads and Cruelty to Animals.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The London Conference on Dano-German War
snippet: The London Conference on Dano-German War
lead_paragraph: The oft-postponed conference for the settlement of the Dano-German imbroglio held its first session in London on the 25th ult. But the representatives of the interested Powers might as well not have assembled, for it is said they were unable to agree on a basis of action, and no business was done.

abstract: Yesterday intelligence was received of the death of Brig.-Gen. FESSENDEN, who fell at the head of his command while leading it into the battle of Cane River, in Louisiana. Gen. FESSENDEN was at an early period of the war appointed a Captain in the regular service. At the battle of Shiloh he was very severely wounded. Shortly after his recovery he was transferred to the command of a Maine regiment. When the regiment was mustered out at the expiration of its term of service, he was appointed Colonel of a veteran regiment, and ordered to joints Gen. BANKS in Louisiana. He was afterward appointed a Brigadier-General, and fell while gloriously leading his brigade into battle. He was but 27 years age of age, and was married about a year ago.

abstract: Attack and Defence, Capt. Selwyn on
snippet: Attack and Defence, Capt. Selwyn on
lead_paragraph: This is the title of an article published in a late number of the Journal of the Royal United Service Institute, over the signature of Capt. SELWYN, R. N., and comprising the substance of a paper read by him. This institution; under the special patronage of the Queen, and composed of the most practical and scientific men of the United Kingdom, gives careful attention to all new views upon the great topics of the day which come within their jurisdiction. Upon the subject of the paper read by Capt. SELWYN much debate ensued; and as no question connected with carrying on the war in which we are now engaged has excited more attention than this, we deem it worth while to give some space to the remarks of Capt. SELWYN and the comments thereon. What with the Alabama, Georgia and Florida on the one hand, and a countless host of invisible blockade-runners on the other, the Chief of the Navy Department has his mental energies very severely tasked in these matters, and any hints that may be of service will doubtless be appreciated. Capt. SELWYN contends that

abstract: PHOTOGRAPHY AND THE FAIR. -- We have already made mention of the splendid photographic views of the various departments of the Metropolitan Fair, made by Mr. BRADY, the well-known photographic artist. But he is by no means alone in this display of artistic enterprise and skill. Messrs. GURNEY & SON are publishing stereoscopic views of the fair, comprising a series of 54 different views. They are also engaged upon a group of the Executive Committee, which will soon be on exhibition at their rooms in Broadway. Messrs. GURNEY & SON made very valuable donations of portraits and other works of art to the fair --  among which was a full length portrait of Mayor GUNTHER, valued at $579.

abstract: IMPORTED LUXURIES, AND HOW TO DIMINISH THEIR CONSUMPTION. -- A public meeting will be held to-morrow, (Monday,) at 1 o'clock, at the Cooper Union. It is called by the ladies of the Metropolitan Fair. A notice of it and its object is to be found in another column. Mr. CHAS. KING, President of Columbia College, will preside, and addresses will be made by Prof. HITCHCOCK, Dr. F. VINTON, JAMES T. BRADY, Esq., W.E. DODGE, Esq., and other distinguished citizens. A full attendance is especially urged, as the subject to be considered -- some means for diminishing the use of imported luxuries -- is of great importance at this time of our country's trial.

abstract: On Saturday night last a young man named WILLIAM DENBROOK, a barkeeper employed at the Sheepshead Bay Hotel, committed suicide by cutting his throat with a razor. The deceased had long been afflicted with the dropsy, and latterly had swollen to an unusual size, which compelled him to take to his bed. Becoming despondent, he resolved to end his existence, which he did during the temporary absence of a man who was attending upon him. The deceased was 26 years of age, a native of Bremen, and unmarried. The Coroner was notified to hold an inquest.

abstract: ONE OF THE OLDEST FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES IN AMERICA. -- This old Manhattaner was incorporated in 1821. Its capital has been increased from $250,000 to $500,000. Its surplus, added to this, gives a total of $750,000 assets. Rightly, did its directors resolve, by a unanimous vote, when the increase in capital was made, to increase that capital to $1,000,000, at the earliest possible opportunity, for not only is the Manhattan thoroughly grounded, it is thoroughly well managed. The names of ROBERT B. MINTURN, MOSES TAYLOR, EDWIN D. MORGAN, RUFUS L. LORD, PETER COOPER, SIDNEY MASON, HENRY BAYLIS, and other leading merchants, appear on its list of Directors -- sure guarantees of stability and good government. We cannot, therefore, speak too strongly in praise of this old and solid corporation. -- Boston Post

abstract: The business of recruiting in this, County progresses slowly, the number of men raised now averaging only about fifty per day. The whole number to be raised at this date, however, to complete the...
lead_paragraph: The business of recruiting in this, County progresses slowly, the number of men raised now averaging only about fifty per day. The whole number to be raised at this date, however, to complete the quota is less than 1,000, and would be less than 100, if Government would credit the County with the two and one year naval men, the same as three year army recruits, as it was understood they would do.

abstract: -Beinforcements  are on the march for GRANT, across the Potomac, Rappahannock and Po. Two things make it possible for GRANT to command these reinforcements at this moment: firstly, he
lead_paragraph: -- Reinforcements are on the march for GRANT, across the Potomac, Rappahannock and Po. Two things make it possible for GRANT to command these reinforcements at this moment: firstly, he controls all the soldiers in the United States, and can move them at his pleasure; secondly, the prompt response of the hundred days' men in the West enables him to draw to his side the veterans at outposts and garrisons, and fill their places with these militiamen. At this moment many legions of hardy and veteran fighters from the West are with him; and not a few of those who campaigned on the Mississippi with GRANT, and under him laid siege to Vicksburgh, will now campaign with him in old Virginia, and we hope will soon be able to lay siege to old Richmond.

abstract: -One of our Paris cor  respondents, in a letter published yesterday, thinks that the "new-fledged Emperor of Mexico is Very likely to die of funk before be sets
lead_paragraph: -- One of our Paris correspondents, in a letter published yesterday, thinks that the "new-fledged Emperor of Mexico is Very likely to die of funk before he gets near Vera Cruz at all." He adds that "he is a poor, weedy, delicate specimen of humanity, without any physical or moral constitution worth a groat; and it was precisely because of his want of energy and habitual indolence that the Emperor NAPOLEON selected him for a tool." If this is true, the Emperor NAPOLEON has been overrated. If he supposes that such a tool will answer his purposes in Mexico, he will find himself greatly mistaken. As M. DROUYN DE LHUYS told Mr. DAYTON, the wires by which any puppet in Mexico is to be managed will be "too long to work" easily and well; and something more than a shadow will be required at this end to make things go smoothly. Before two years are over the advocates of a monarchy in Mexico will need something more than such a tool as MAXIMILIAN is described to be, for effectual service. However, if the Emperor NAPOLEON is content, we have no special reason to be dissatisfied.

abstract: the, and Forgery of Official Documents
snippet: the, and Forgery of Official Documents
lead_paragraph: -- We published yesterday, a letter from Lord LYONS to Earl RUSSELL, in regard to the pretended report of the rebel Secretary of the Navy, published some months since. Lord LYONS, in that dispatch, dated March 22, says that Mr. SEWARD had informed him that he had discovered this document to be a forgery. Mr. SEWARD had made inquiries in regard to it when first published, and had been satisfied that it was genuine. But recently he had been informed by the gentleman who concocted it, and who had noticed with some dismay the importance attached to it, that he had written it originally "as a jeu d'esprit, and that partly the amusement which it had afforded to see every one taken in by it, and partly the notion that it was injuring the Confederate cause, had prevented an earlier avowal of its truth." The name of the author is not disclosed.

abstract: About 9 o'clock last evening, a fire broke out in the extensive piano manufactory owned by Mr. J. LINDSTADT, No. 70 Water-street, and resulted in the destruction of the interior, with contents consisting of a number of pianos, and a large amount of prepared material for their manufacture. The building is of brick, and four stories in height. It was formerly occupied as a distillery by Mr. BENSON. The amount of loss could not be correctly estimated, but will, doubtless, reach from $15,000 to $20,000. It is not known, how the fire originated.

abstract: We reported yesterday the averment of a gentlemen that he had seen Gen. SIGEL at Cumberland last Saturday, and that he was not thinking of a movement. We are glad to say that this assertion is totally unfounded. We have been visited to-day by a gentleman connected with Gen. SIGEL's army, who contradicts our informant's statement in toto. This person was unusually cautious in giving his information, but we were enabled to glean from him that SIGEL had not been in Cumberland for over two weeks; that he left Martinsburgh Tuesday, two weeks ago, and went as far as Winchester, where his command was encamped until last Monday, when tents were struck and SIGEL went "upon the war path." We know in the direction then traveled, but conclude it was up the valley, toward Staunton. We fear that but little help in the way of cooperation with GRANT must be expected from SIGEL. His force was not near so, large as generally supposed -- not more than a third, and we presume his business will be more to provide against a rebel countermove by way of Shenandoah, rather than any offensive operation. Should he find the cost clear, however, he may surprise all one of these find days, by dropping into Charlottesville or Gordonsville, or may be into Lynchburgh. He must be now somewhere in the neighborhood of Staunton.

His force was not near so, large as generally supposed -- not more than a third, and we presume his business will be more to provide against a rebel countermove by way of Shenandoah, rather than any offensive operation. abstract: About 9 o'clock on Saturday night a fire broke out in the four-story brick building, Nos. 68 and 70 Water-street, formerly known as BENSON's distillery, but now occupied by Mr. J.E.L. LINSTADT as a piano-forte manufactory. The fire is supposed to have originated in the drying-room on the first floor, and extended thence through the entire building. The Fire Department was promptly on hand, and succeeded in suppressing the flames, but not before everything inside had been either destroyed or greatly damaged. One finished piano, near the door and ready for transportation, was saved; but sixty more, in various stages of completion, were destroyed. The loss on stock is about $15,000, upon which there is an insurance of $10,000 in several New-York and Brooklyn offices. The workmen lost, their tools, amounting to several hundred dollars in value. The adjoining cracker bakery of HANKS & Co. was damaged by water to the extent of about $300. In proceeding to the fire two engines were damaged by running against some obstacles, and one tender was completely wrecked. A railroad car on Main-street was run into and damaged. No person was injured.

abstract: The following brief extracts from reports made by various officers and agents of the Sanitary Commission, will give the public some idea of the magnitude of the work of benevolence now being carried on in the vicinity of every battlefield throughout the country by this truly admi-...
lead_paragraph: The following brief extracts from reports made by various officers and agents of the Sanitary Commission, will give the public some idea of the magnitude of the work of benevolence now being carried on in the vicinity of every battlefield throughout the country by this truly admirable institution. It should not be forgotton, however, that the labors of the commission are subordinate and only auxiliary to the vaster and more perfectly organized system of the Medical Department of the army, with which it works in complete accord. Col. JOSEPH K. BARNES, Medical Inspector of the army, and at present Acting Surgeon-General, gives to the commission and its agents all the facilities within his power; and from the Quartermaster's Department valuable aid is oftentimes received. These extracts, brief and hurried as they are, give a good answer to those cavilers who ask "What does the Sanitary Commission do with all its money?" -- said cavilers, probably, never having given the commission a dollar, and not being aware that its treasury has received altogether, since the commencement of the war, somewhat less than one million, five hundred thousand dollars in money from all sources -- the proceeds of the New-York Sanitary Fair not yet being turned over to it. It should be borne in mind that just the same labors described in these extracts are going on at Belle Plain and Fredericksburgh, are being carried on in every section of the country occupied by our armies, from Washington to the Rio Grande, and from Fortress Monroe to the Rocky Mountains.
headline: {'main': 'THE SANITARY COMMISSION.; Its Labors During the Last Fortnight. abstract: THERE MEN FOUND DROWNED. Coroner WILDNY yesterday held as inquestion the body of JAS. WELCH, a native of Ireland, aged 40 years, who was found drowned at the feet of Beach-street, North
lead_paragraph: THERE MEN FOUND DROWNED. -- Coroner WILDEY yesterday held as inquestion the body of JAS. WELCH, a native of Ireland, aged 40 years, who was found drowned at the feet of Beach-street, North River. He had been in the water about three weeks ....The same Coroner held an inquest at the foot of Whitehall-street on the body of DANIEL BRESLEHAN, a native of Ireland, aged 35 years, who was found floating in the water. Deceased had been missing about two weeks. He left a wife and five children, residing in Brooklyn. A verdict of death from drowring was rendered ...An unknown man was found in the water at Pier No. 14 East River yesterday. Deceased was about 25 years of age, five feet five inches in height, and very slim built. He had dark hair, was dressed in black coat and vest, blue check shirt and blue cloth pants, one shoe and sock. The body had been in the water about three weeks. Coroner WILDEY held an inquest on the body, and a verdict of death from drowning was rendered.

abstract: AT WASHINGTON. -- The wounded soldiers are arriving in Washington in such large numbers as to render it impossible for the surgeons now on duty there to give them the attention and care they need. Twenty volunteer surgeons are therefore wanted immediately. They will be accepted without the usual examination it recommended by well-known medical men. Pay, $100 per month. The Medical Director, U.S.A., No. 125 Bleecker-street, will receive applications, and give all necessary information.

abstract: In the early part of the rebellion a good deal of fault was found with the policy of the Government in assigning nearly all the high commands to graduates of West Point.
lead_paragraph: In the early part of the rebellion a good deal of fault was found with the policy of the Government in assigning nearly all the high commands to graduates of West Point. It was maintained that the crushing of the rebellion did not depend so much upon science as upon promptitude and energy; and the slow progress made was, with considerable plausibility, attributed to the precise and stiff habits of mind that are so apt to be superinduced by book training. It became a sort of popular demand that some, at least, of the leaders should be taken fresh from the people, and should be allowed to operate with all the popular fire and energy. Thus, PATTERSON, BANKS, BUTLER, FREMONT, SICKLES, MCCOOK, LEWIS WALLACE, MCCLERNAND, PRENTISS, SHIELDS, CARL SCHURZ, and other civilians of less note, were made Major-Generals. It is curious to note the result of that popular delusion. Not a civilian, of whom so much was then hoped, fulfilled expectations; and many of them are responsible for some serious damage to the cause.

abstract: -TWO OFFENDERS ARRESTED. -- On the afternoon of the 8th inst. a party of Germans became involved in a quarrel in Avenue A. During the fight stones, clubs, brickbats and other missiles were freely used. Several of the combatants were badly injured during the combat, and among the number was FREDERICK BROSHERT. He was struck on the head with a stone, alleged to have been thrown by JOHN SITER, residing at No. 449 East Sixteenth-street. A section of policemen from the Seventeenth Precinct arrested the delinquents and took them before the Police Court, where they were fined $5 each, and required to find bail to keep the peace. BROSHERT went home, grew rapidly worse, and on Saturday night last he died from the effects of his wounds. Shortly before his death the Coroner was notified to take his ante-mortem examination, but upon his arrival there, the wounded man was found to be insensible. Coroner WILDEY, therefore, took the deposition of FRANK BLANK, a brother-in-law of the deceased. SITER, and a man named LEWIS GANT, have been arrested, and are held to await the result of the Coroner's inquest, which will be held to-day. Deceased was a native of Germany, aged 24 years, and resided at No. 77 Avenue A. He has left a wife and two or three children.

abstract: In six distinct bulletins, admirable for their brevity and distinctness, the Secretary of War sums up the whole of the news from the armies East and West, which had reached the Depart-...
lead_paragraph: In six distinct bulletins, admirable for their brevity and distinctness, the Secretary of War sums up the whole of the news from the armies East and West, which had reached the Department up to Sunday morning. The dispatches from Gen. GRANT come up to Saturday morning at 6 1/2 o'clock. During that day the advance of HANCOCK developed the fact that the rebel army had fallen back four miles. There was no engagement during Friday, and the department has no intelligence of any general officer having been killed in the terrible engagement of Thursday. During Friday night an important manoeuvre was made in sending the Fifth and Sixth Corps to our left, and an attack was to have been made at daylight, but no sound of battle was heard during Saturday at either Belle Plain or Fredericksburgh, and it is therefore supposed that LEE had retreated still further. The movement and attack, had they been successful, would have placed our army is LEE's rear, and compelled his retreat upon Lynchburgh instead of Richmond. Some definite idea of the losses inflicted on the rebels may be gathered from the additional fact, stated in Mr. STANTON's first dispatch, that over 7,000 prisoners, including 400 officers, with Maj.-Gen. JOHNSON and Brig.-Gen. STUART, had arrived at Belle Plain.

abstract: The long-promised play of "Bel Demonio" will be produced at Niblo's Garden to-night. It has been very carefully prepared, and the manager confidently expects for it an indorsement of the prodigious success that has attended its many performances in
lead_paragraph: The long-promised play of "Bel Demonio" will be produced at Niblo's Garden to-night. It has been very carefully prepared, and the manager confidently expects for it an indorsement of the prodigious success that has attended its many performances in London. The cast includes some of the best members of Mr. WHEATLEY's company. Mlle. VESTVALI makes her rentree as the hero Angelo, and Miss ROSE EYTINGE plays the part of Lena, the heroine. New scenery and dresses have been prepared for the work, and we may safely predict that it will be presented in a liberal and effective manner.

abstract: And the War
snippet: And the War
lead_paragraph: It was quite fashionable two or three weeks ago for the Copperhead press to sneer at the idea that President LINCOLN would permit any decisive fighting to be done until the Presidential nomination had been made. His chances, they assumed, depended on the prolongation of the war; and although scarcely willing to impute openly to him the infamously selfish design of sacrificing the country to his personal ambition, they were not ashamed to imply that he was governed by such a motive.

abstract: We publish this morning  the important intelligence from our Panama correspondent, that on the 14th of April Admiral PINZON, commanding the Spanish fleet on the coast of Peru, and DON EUSADIO SALAZAR, Her Catholic Majesty's Special Commissioner to Peru, formally and without any warning, took possession of the Chincha Guano Islands, and raised the Catholic flag in the name of the Queen.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning the important intelligence from our Panama correspondent, that on the 14th of April Admiral PINZON, commanding the Spanish fleet on the coast of Peru, and DON EUSADIO SALAZAR, Her Catholic Majesty's Special Commissioner to Peru, formally and without any warning, took possession of the Chincha Guano Islands, and raised the Catholic flag in the name of the Queen. The most singular part of the proceedings is that not only have the Islands, which are a great source of revenue to the Peruvian Government, been seized as a guarantee for the redress sought by Spain for certain grievances, alleged to have been suffered by Spanish citizens of Peru, but the Spanish Admiral, in his abrupt announcement of the seizure, states that he has also retained, as hostages, several officers of the Peruvian Navy, who are to be held answerable for any insult offered to Spanish subjects. One of the immediate difficulties, which preceded this summary action, appears to have arisen from the circumstance, that the Government of Peru refused to enter into negotiations with a Spanish official bearing the title of "Commissioner," which is the rank and designation in Spain of a Colonial Agent of the Home Government. As Peru has never been recognized by Spain as an independent State, it was probably deemed unnecessary to deal with the country on terms different from a colony. But the Peruvians refused to see the matter in this light, and the high-handed act of Admiral PINZON intervened, leaving this question of national dignity unsettled.

abstract: Women's Anti-Luxury Meeting in New-York
snippet: Women's Anti-Luxury Meeting in New-York
lead_paragraph: In response to a call, issued by the ladies of the Executive Committee of the Metropolitan Fair, a very large meeting was held yesterday afternoon at Cooper Union for the purpose of calling the attention of women to the injury inflcted upon the country in this crisis by the extravagant purchase of imported luxuries, and to suggest the propriety of abstaining from such luxuries until the present crisis is past. On motion of PETER COOPER, Esq., President KING was elected Chairman of the meeting. On taking the Chair Dr. KING remarked that it had seldom been his good fortune to preside over a meeting called together to promote so good a cause. It has been called to discuss a point which has always been supposed to be very dear to the female heart-dress. Yet it has always been said that women dress to please the men; and when we of the sterner sex ask them for the sake of the Union to appear in a simple dress, becoming to an American women at this crisis, they will appear more lovely in our eyes than if they were decked in all the splendor of royalty.

abstract: Both Boards of the Common Council were in session yesterday. The Aldermen referred to the Committee on Markets a lengthy but important communication from the City Inspector, renewing and urging his proposition to banish slaughterhouses from the City, and erect abattoirs in the suburbs, and the draft of an ordinance from the same officer, to prohibit the keeping of offal by butchers longer than one day, was laid over.
lead_paragraph: Both Boards of the Common Council were in session yesterday. The Aldermen referred to the Committee on Markets a lengthy but important communication from the City Inspector, renewing and urging his proposition to banish slaughter-houses from the City, and erect abattoirs in the suburbs, and the draft of an ordinance from the same officer, to prohibit the keeping of offal by butchers longer than one day, was laid over. The Comptroller reported that there remained on the 9th instant, a balance of nearly $21,041 10 in the Relief Fund, $573,105 35 having been disbursed from it since the 1st of last January. The Aldermen passed a new audinance authorizing a further loan, (No. 9,) of $500,000 for this fund, and the Councilmen laid it over under the rule, to be passed on Thursday. The Mayor returned to the Aldermen the resolution to donate the old Colored Orphan Asylum site in aid of the erection of a new asylum, and purchase of a new site, for the insertion of provisions, by the advice of the Corporation Counsel; securing the specific application of the proceeds of sale of the ground, and that the sale shall be by auction, and in lots. The Mayor vetoed the resolution to procure badges, etc., for members of the Common Council, because it is vague in character, and no appropriation accompanies it. He also returned to the Councilmen the resolution requesting him to convene the Board of Health, with his declination, from the belief that the Commissioners of Health have power to abolish fat-melting and like nuisances. The Councilmen adopted a resolution to send a joint special committee to the recent battle-fields of Virginia, to look after the wounded of New-York City regiments, adminster to their comfort, and recover bodies of the chief officers. The Aldermen first amended it by a provision that the committee pay their own expenses, and then referred it. The Councilmen took up, but immediately recommitted, the report and resolutions to take land in Central Park for a division parade ground. The Aldermen adjourned to Monday, and the Councilmen to Thursday next, at 2 o'clock P.M.

abstract: Laird's Steam-rams, Earls Derby and Russell's Speeches
snippet: Laird's Steam-rams, Earls Derby and Russell's Speeches
lead_paragraph: We surrender a large space this morning to a Secession speech in the English House of Lords from the Earl of Derby, and to a sensible and conclusive reply from Lord JOHN RUSSELL. Both are of marked interest and importance. They will produce, on both sides the ocean, effects which will be felt for many years. Lord DERBY is the leader of the Tory party of England -- rich, aristocratic, eloquent, ambitious and unscrupulous. His speed shows very clearly that he is quite willing to involve Great Britain in war for the sake of displacing the present Ministry; for he can scarcely doubt that the departure of those rams from an English port to prey upon American commerce would be regarded and treated by the United States as an act of war. Party spirit in this country often leads public men to rash extremes, but it very seldom happens that any party is willing to involve the nation in war in the hope of achieving a party victory.

abstract: His Warning on Confiscating Slaves, and the World on his Retirement from before Richmond
snippet: His Warning on Confiscating Slaves, and the World on his Retirement from before Richmond
lead_paragraph: The TIMES is mistaken in its history in saying that Gen. MCCLELLAN "got away" from Richmond, leaving the rebels "safe, sound and triumphant." He was peremptorily ordered away from the immediate neighborhood of that city by the President and Gen. HALLECK, against his earnest entreaties. His solemn official warning, when at Harrison's Landing, of the perils which would come upon the country if his army was recalled, are not forgotten by the people, though the TIMES finds it convenient to ignore them in the interest of its candidate for the Presidency. -- World.

abstract: By the Inman steamer City of London and the Cunard steamer Hecla, which arrived here yesterday, we have European news to the 5th inst., and by the Hibernian at Father Point, dates to the 6th. The rebel privateer Georgia is at Liverpool...
lead_paragraph: By the Inman steamer City of London and the Cunard steamer Hecla, which arrived here yesterday, we have European news to the 5th inst., and by the Hibernian at Father Point, dates to the 6th. The rebel privateer Georgia is at Liverpool, where, according to some reports, she is to be dismantled, as she is found to be unfit for the service required of her. Some questions were put in Parliament to the Under Foreign. Secretary relating to the MALLORY forgery, and the sending of a British agent to the Davis Government at Richmond, via Havana -- the agent being refused admission to the rebel States. On the latter point Mr. LAYARD said an agent had been sent as stated; but he was not permitted to pass the blockade. The repudiation of the interest on the New-York State bonds is severely commented on in the London press. The lose of the steamship City of New-York is attributed to the default of Capt. KENNEDY, whose certificate is suspended for eight months. The story is revived that the Great Eastern has been purchased for the French Government. The Pope has delivered an allocution at Rome against the Russian persecution of the Catholic Church. Prince ALFRED, of England, is in Berlin, on a visit to his sister, the Crown Princess. The Danish Conference reassembled on the 4th inst., but adjourned to the 9th without having transacted any business. It was considered that it had come to an untimely end. The death of MEYERBEER, the great German composer, is announced. He was 70 years of age.

abstract: The British prize steamship Greyhound, Acting Ensign S.W. HARDINGE commanding, arrived here yesterday morning, in 18 hours from Fortress Monroe. She was captured on the 10th inst., in lat. 34, long. 70, by the United States gunbont Connecticut. She was from Wilmington, bound to Bermuda, and has a cargo of 850 bales of cotton, 35 tons tobacco, 25 bbls. turpentine. Is a screw steamer, 7 months old, 280 tons British register, and her engines are 200 horse power.

abstract: Major-Gen. Dix, New-York:  We have dispatches from Gen. GRANT to 8 o'clock this morning. He states that offensive operations have been necessarily suspended until the roads become passable; that the army is in the best  of spirits, and feels the fullest confidence in success. The two armies are now concentrated on the main road from Fredericksburgh to Richmond.

abstract: A New Call for Cleveland Convention
snippet: A New Call for Cleveland Convention
lead_paragraph: -- We published a few days ago the call of a small body of radicals for a convention at Cleveland, to "counsel together concerning the approaching Presidential election." A supplementary call has now been issued by other parties, in which they avow more explicitly the object of the convention and their motives for calling it. They call the convention to "recommend the nomination of JOHN C. FREMONT for the Presidency, and to assist in organizing for his election," and their motives for so doing are thus set forth:

abstract: Our official advices from the Army of the Potomac are to yesterday morning. There had been no renewal of the great struggle. LEE'S army was still near its last battle-field, apparently awaiting for another onset.
lead_paragraph: Our official advices from the Army of the Potomac are to yesterday morning. There had been no renewal of the great struggle. LEE's army was still near its last battle-field, apparently awaiting for another onset. We imagine it will not have to wait long. If any man wishes to know why Lieut.-Gen. GRANT has not during the last two or three days continued his work of executing the rebels, we advise that man to join the ranks of the army, and engage in an eight days' life and death battle, and he will then find himself answered.

abstract: The Britis Channel fleet which had gone from Portland to the Downs still remained at the latter place on the 3d inst., although rumors had been current that they were under orders for the Baltic. It is stated that all officers had been ordered to join their vessels in the Downs forthwith. Lord CLARENCE PAGET stated in the House of Commons, on the 2d inst., that the fleet was ready to proceed to any part of the world at twenty-four hours' notice.

abstract: -- On the eve of the great battle of the Wilderness, we drew attention to the possible wants of those who were sure to be wounded in the struggle. The fears then expressed, that the casualties (from the vast magnitude of the conflict) would be found to be unprecedented, have been realized. The Sanitary Commission, which has done, and is now doing its utmost as an auxiliary of the Medical Department -- having 150 active agents administering relief in the various camps and buildings where the wounded are lying -- makes a statement to the public, which, we feel assured, will meet a prompt and practical response: The latest report of the Commission says: "The number of wounded is so large that even the ample resources of the Commission will not be sufficient to meet the continued demand." To this bare announcement it is unnecessary to add a word to a generous public.
lead_paragraph: -- On the eve of the great battle of the Wilderness, we drew attention to the possible wants of those who were sure to be wounded in the struggle. The Sanitary Commission, which has done, and is now doing its utmost as an auxiliary of the Medical Department -- having 150 active agents administering relief in the various camps and buildings where the wounded are lying -- makes a statement to the public, which, we feel assured, will meet a prompt and practical response: The latest report of the Commission says: "The number of wounded is so large that even the ample resources of the Commission will not be sufficient to meet the continued demand." To this bare announcement it is unnecessary to add a word to a generous public.

abstract: Surgeon W.J. McDERMOTT, of the Sixty-sixth Regiment New-York Volunteers, who arrived in this City yesterday from Fredericksburgh, gives some interesting particulars concerning the recovery of Gen. WADSWORTH'S body, and the removal of a large number of our wounded from the rebel lines, after the first great battle in the Wilderness.
lead_paragraph: Surgeon W.J. MCDERMOTT, of the Sixty-sixth Regiment New-York Volunteers, who arrived in this City yesterday from Fredericksburgh, gives some interesting particulars concerning the recovery of Gen. WADSWORTH'S body, and the removal of a large number of our wounded from the rebel lines, after the first great battle in the Wilderness. He states that pursuant to an order issued by Gen. HANCOCK before the fight, several Surgeons were detailed to remain with the wounded, in the event of its becoming necessary to leave them behind. After the fight, and on the morning of the eighth instant, this order was complied with, in consequence of Gen. GRANT's ordering Gen. HANCOCK to move his division to the left. This manoeuvre resulted in twelve hundred of our wounded being left in an improvised hospital in the Wilderness, at the Stephen's House, near the plank road running from Fredericksburgh, and within the enemy's lines. On the 9th instant, a portion of Gens. ROSSES and GORDON's rebel cavalry under command of Capt. BORDEN, First Regiment North Carolina, took possession of twelve hundred of our wounded at this hospital, besides a large number of their own, which had fallen into our hands after the first day's battle. The rebels, immediately after taking possession of the hospital, removed six ambulances filled with their wounded to their hospital near LONGSTREET's headquarters. Dr. BROCK, of Richmond, superintended the removal of the rebel wounded, and extended such courtesies to our surgeons as the circumstances would allow. Surgeons GEORGE L. POTTER, One Hundred and forty-fifth Pennsylvania; _____ KILSEY, Sixty-fourth New York; W.J. MCDERMOTT, Sixty-sixth New-York and W. O'MAHEE, Sixty-ninth New-York, were immediately paroled. Capt. CAMPBELL and Lieut. SAVAGE, One Hundred and eighty-third Pennsylvania, were also released on parole. On the 12th inst., while our paroled officers were still within the enemy's lines a flag of truce, accompanied by wagons for our wounded, under command of Capt. WRIGHT, of the Fifty-seventh New-York, acting Provost-Marshal of Fredericksburgh arrived at the hospital. An interview was had between Capt. WRIGHT and the rebel Capt. BORDEN, who consented to the removal of our wounded. In the conversation between these two officers, Capt. BORDEN informed Capt. WRIGHT where Gen. WADSWORTH's body was buried, describing exactly the place of interment. He stated that it was near LONGSTREET's general hospital, on the Fredericksburgh plank road, about five miles distant from the first day's fight; that a man, by the name of STRIKER, whom Gen. WADSWORTH had befriended in Washington since the beginning of the war, asked, permission of Gen. LEE to bury the body, which was granted, and by order of Gen. LEE a coffin was made of doors, in which the body was placed. Our paroled officers accompanied a train of our wounded to Fredericksburgh. On the 13th inst. a flag of truce, under Capt. MIDDLETON, of the Fifty-seventh New-York, returned to the hospital in the Wilderness for the balance of our wounded left in the enemy's hands. Capt. MIDDLETON, guided by the information received from the rebel Capt. BORDEN, proceeded with a wagon to make search for the body. On the 14th he had found the place of interment, encountering but few rebels, none of whom seemed disposed to molest him on his mission. These are the last advices received from Capt. MIDDLETON through Surgeon MCDERMOTT, who states that there is but little doubt that the body of Gen. WADSWORTH is now in Fredericksburgh or en route for Washington.

abstract: Comptroller BRENNAN yesterday opened proposals from forty-five different individuals and firms, embodying eighty-six bids for a new issue of "Central Park Improvement Fund stock," to bear 6 per cent. interest, and to be payable in 1876. The sum to be issued is $300,000. The bids for it aggregated $1,702,300.
lead_paragraph: Comptroller BRENNAN yesterday opened proposals from forty-five different individuals and firms, embodying eighty-six bids for a new issue of "Central Park Improvement Fund stock," to bear 6 per cent. interest, and to be payable in 1876. The sum to be issued is $300,000. The bids for it aggregated $1,702,300. The stock was awarded to 15 individuals and firms, 22 bids being accepted, at premium rates of from four to ten per cent. $50,000 was awarded at five, and $35,000 at six per cent. premium. Only one par bid was made. The rejected premium bids were chiefly at three per cent. and above. The bidding, it will be observed, ran up to unprecedented high rates, and shows the value of City stocks. The bidder, who secured $50,000 worth of the stock at 5 cent. premium was present at the opening, and deemed himself fortunate, although $16,000 was awarded at 4 cent. There were so many offers at this rate that, after accepting all the higher bids, the balance to be accepted necessary to make up $300,000 was apportioned to them, according to the amount of the bids. One party bid for $50,000 at 4 cent., and got but $16,700, and another, who bid for $25,000 at the same rate, got only $7,500.

abstract: on Grant and the Automaton Chess Player
snippet: on Grant and the Automaton Chess Player
lead_paragraph: -- The confidence reposed in Lieut.-Gen. GRANT by president LINCOLN, and the cordiality which exists between these distinguished men, were happily illustrated by a characteristic anecdote related recently by the President in the course of a familiar conversation with a personal friend. In reply to a question in regard to the present military prospect, Mr. LINCOLN, with that peculiar smile which he always puts on when about to tell a good story, said: "Well, sir, your question reminds me of a little anecdote about the automaton chess-player, which many years ago astonished the world by its skill in that game. After a while the automaton was challenged by a celebrated player, who, to his great chagrin, was beaten twice by the machine. At the end of the second name, the player, significantly pointing his finger at the automaton, exclaimed in a very decided tone. 'There's a man in it!' And this, sir, is just the secret of our present success."

abstract: -- The statement is pregnant that of the vast body of rebel prisoners -- some 8,000 -- captured in the late battles, not one made his escape in the long journey toward the rear, through districts of more than doubtful loyalty, and affording abundant means of escape and concealment. The fact is unprecedented in the history of the war, and can barely be accounted for on the ground of the preeminent vigilance of the guard placed over the captives.

abstract: Seventy-ninth Regiment; Return and History
snippet: Seventy-ninth Regiment; Return and History
lead_paragraph: As the son was going down, one Sunday evening, three years since, the Seventy-ninth New-York (Highland) Regiment, clad in the ancient and picturesque costume of the Scottish Highlanders, passed down Broadway amid the plaudits and farewells of a loyal multitude. They were over a thousand bayonets strong; and there never marched to the field a thousand men braver, prouder, more intelligent and patriotic. Since that 2d of June, 1861, the Seventy-ninth Regiment have done an amount of soldierly service in varied and distant fields and campaigns that seem almost incredible. In Virginia, in South Carolina, in Maryland, in Mississippi, in Tennessee, in Kentucky, and again in Virginia, it has campaigned. It has served under MCDOWELL, MCCLELLAN, POPE and HUNTER; under BURNSIDE in Virginia, and under BURNSIDE in Tennessee. It has served under Brig.-Gen. GRANT, while he commanded at Vicksburgh; under Major-Gen. GRANT while he commanded in Tennessee; and under Lieut.-Gen. GRANT in his late operations in Virginia. It fought at the first Bull Run, at the second Bull Run, at the bloody battles of James Island, at South Mountain and Antietam, at Fredericksburgh, at Vicksburgh and Jackson, at Knoxville and at the Wilderness. These are the great actions in which it has taken part, but the minor though no less perilous fights in which it has been engaged are numerous as the men who at first filled its populous ranks.

abstract: -- It must have been consoling to the famous firm of LAIRD, in Liverpool, to learn from the Foreign Secretary's speech in the House of Lords, that they are not to be believed when they give evidence, no matter how loudly they protest. Earl RUSSELL says they are not so innocent of illegal transactions of the sort now charged to them, as to be credible witnesses, and accepting their testimony as truthful, would have been to open the road direct to war with the United States. Quoting textually, his most emphatic words are: "They (the LAIRDS) have done everything in their power by fitting out ships, by engaging in contracts for supplying vessels of war to the other belligerent, to give the United States a just cause of war against this country."

abstract: -- In a Lynchburgh newspaper we find the Union prisoners recently captured and sent to that place, described as "a decidedly genteel set of Yankees, who conducted themselves with more propriety than usual." It is some satisfaction to know that gentility finds an exponent in a community which openly boasts of the cold-blooded massacre of the captured garrison of Fort Pillow. A critical taste in matters of social propriety ought, probably, to pass for high breeding, even in a select circle of cut-throats. There is nothing like style.

abstract: Fanatical Agitation on, District of Columbia
snippet: Fanatical Agitation on, District of Columbia
lead_paragraph: Slavery died by over-doing itself. Anti-Slavery, if left to some of its friends, would perish in the same manner. Slavery was not content with its own sure constitutional ground, but crusaded on needless and false issues. It bludgeoned free parliamentary debate, it struck away the Missouri Compromise line, it sought to drive freedom from every Territory, it raised the flag of rebellion against the Government. It not only made war upon its enemies, but set up a procrustean bed for its friends, and smote without mercy every one of them who did not touch its extremist mark. There is a set of Anti-Slavery men who exhibit too much of this same spirit, and are doing quite as much in their way to hurt the cause they mean to support. They are not content to let alone the causes that are fast securing the entire abolition of Slavery, but insist upon clogging them with other questions which have no legitimate connection with them. Thus, a while ago, it was undertaken to identify the abolition of Slavery with the abolition of the States containing it. Now the effort is to carry universal black suffrage with emancipation, and to make the adoption of that an absolute test of Anti-Slavery principle.

abstract: The news of the situation in Virginia does not disclose any remarkably new features. Gen. GRANT has been receiving and disposing of large reinforcements, and on Friday evening last there seems to have been a very material change in the position of the two armies.
lead_paragraph: The news of the situation in Virginia does not disclose any remarkably new features. Gen. GRANT has been receiving and disposing of large reinforcements, and on Friday evening last there seems to have been a very material change in the position of the two armies. LEE's present position is represented as being a very strong one, and the fortifications of recent construction. The roads have been so bad as to preclude any movement by the flank, which had been contemplated.

abstract: Major CUTTING, of Gen. AUGER'S Staff, arrived here this morning with the body of Gen. WADSWIRTH. He was shot by a rebel sharpshooter who was concealed in a tree, the ball striking him on the top of the head and coming out back of the neck. Gen.
lead_paragraph: Major CUTTING, of Gen. AUGER's Staff, arrived here this morning with the body of Gen. WADSWORTH. He was shot by a rebel sharpshooter who was concealed in a tree, the ball striking him on the top of the head and coming out back of the neck. Gen. SPRAGUE, Adjutant-General of New-York, having received a dispatch from Gov. SEYMOUR to receive the remains on the part of the State, and to take such steps as he may think proper, has just called a meeting of the New-York delegation. His remains will leave to-night, accompanied by a committee of five members of Congress.

abstract: THEODORE ALLEN, against whom a large number of complaints have been made within the last few months, was taken into custody yesterday by Officer S. BURNS, detective in Gen. HAY's office. The arrest was made pursuant to instructions from Gen. DIX, in command of this Department. The charges against him are, that he, in connection with others, is guilty of swindling soldiers who were recruited at Lafayette Hall, in Broadway, out of large portions of their bounty money. Gen. DIX issued orders for his apprehension some time since. ALLEN, in some way learned the fact that officials were in search of him, left the City, went to Philadelphia and thence to Wilmington, where he remained several weeks. Recently he returned and yesterday, it was ascertained that he was stopping with his wife at a house on the corner of Mercer and Spring streets. Officer BURNS went there accompanied of Officer CARROLL of the Twenty-seventh Precinct Police. When BURNS went up to him and told him he was a prisoner by order of Gen. DIX, ALLEN drew a pistol with his left hand, and attempted to shoot. Fortunately the pistol missed fire. Fearing another shot, Officer CARROLL caught the pistol, and the prisoner was taken across Broadway. There a rescue was attempted by some of ALLEN's friends who are well known to the police. When near the corner of Broadway and West Houston-street, they were compelled to put hand-cuffs on the prisoner. While doing so some of ALLEN'S friends stood on the opposite side of the way, with pistols cocked and pointed ready to shoot Officers BURNS and DEPUE, United States Detectives, and Policeman CARROLL. But for the timely appearance of Police Detectives KELSOE and RADFORD, who, seeing the condition of things, drew their own revolvers, and pointed them at ALLEN's friends, thereby holding them at bay until the handcuffs were on, and the prisoner placed in a Broadway omnibus which was chartered for the purpose of conveying him to his destination, the affair might have termination seriously for the officers. He was taken to the office of Gen. DIX, where an investigation of the case will, doubtless, be made to-day.

abstract: We have important advices from our special correspondent at headquarters of the Army of the Potomac, dated 5 o'clock yesterday morning, at which time the battle was being renewed, skirmishing having just commenced.
lead_paragraph: We have important advices from our special correspondent at headquarters of the Army of the Potomac, dated 5 o'clock yesterday morning, at which time the battle was being renewed, skirmishing having just commenced. Dispatches received at the War Department yesterday from Gen. GRANT state that the roads had improved, reinforcements had arrived, and that he should move against the enemy without delay. To-day, therefore, will probably bring news of another great battle.

abstract: Shakespeare Tercentenary in London; A Political Meeting Stopped by Police
snippet: Shakespeare Tercentenary in London; A Political Meeting Stopped by Police
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, a very feeble, and under almost all its aspects, a most ridiculous attempt was made to celebrate the birthday of our great poet, by what was called in the handbills a "Working Men's Shakespeare Jubilee and Great National Festival." To say that it was not a "jubilee" nor a "great national festival" would not only be to tell the public exactly what they expect, for their recent experiences of SHAKESPEARE Committees has led to a most judicious distrust of their plans over turning out anything but the reverse of what their concocters originally wished or intended. It was not a Working Men's Jubilee, for the precession, all told, did not include 500 members, who were of the usual idle stock of banner-bearers, or the harmless idiots who, in green velvet and feathers and point, will insist -- as on the occasion of GARIBALDI's entry -- on exhibiting their lunacy before the gaze of hundreds. So far from being a national festival, it was not even a local one, and the pathetic entreaties of the handbills inviting the cooperation of "benefit and trade societies, brass bands, corporate bodies, foreign workmen, and the poet's admirers," fell on reluctant and unsympathetic ears, as far as compliance with these adjurations was concerned. So also did the request "that householders along the line of route would give effect to the scene by the display of flags and by the ringing of the bells in the various parish churches in order that the day might be made as it ought," &c. Not a flag was shown except the time-worn and now rather illegible banners brought by the few processionists themselves; not a bell was rung, and the procession was constantly reminded that it was not a national holiday by having to open its thin ranks for the passage of prosaic carts and 'busses, in fact it was a dull and tame affair throughout, and nothing so much redeemed its dullness as its general tone of absurdity. The demonstration "fell through," as our American cousins say, for want of some living principle, some motive power, greater than the mere accident of a tercentenary. Notwithstanding this 200th anniversary, SHAKESPEARE is not a whit more admired this year than he was last year, or will be next year, and though nations may go to war for an idea, and do so, if the truth were known, much more often than is generally admitted, yet a jubilee for an idea, or a procession for an idea, seems, after Saturday's experience, to be out of the question.

abstract: The Citizens' Association is a permanent organization, having, as is known, but the one purpose of advancing the interests of the City and County; improving their government, lessening their expenses, increasing their health, adding to their coffers, and contributing in many ways to the comfort of the people. A system has been adopted by the Central Association, having its headquarters at No. 813 Broadway, which will unfailingly secure the objects desired. Boards and Councils are to be organized, so that every department of the City Government and all public interested will have especial care, each Board and Council being composed of citizens possessing the best qualifications for the special duties they may have in hand. Already the following are organized: The Legal Board of Advisers; the Council of Hygiene and Public Health; the Board of Engineers for Professional Consultation; the Board of Public Instruction. Messrs. DANIEL LORD, WILLIAM CURTIS NOYES, JAMES R. WHITING, FRANCIS B. CUTTING and other eminent lawyers, in all twelve, who give their aid gratuitously, compose the Legal Board. Beside these, there are two able lawyers, under salary, whose entire time is devoted to an examination if the divers acts affecting the public to which doubts of legality are attached, and to the many matters arising which require legal scrutiny. All these are reported to the Legal Board. Consultation will be had with the authorities in all cases where wrong is known to exist, but if the remedy is not applied, then suits to enforce it will be commenced and prosecuted, not nominally, but in earnest. The other boards and councils to which reference will be made, have equally as important duties as the legal to perform. All, though unofficial, will prove most valuable.

abstract: its Lesson
snippet: its Lesson
lead_paragraph: We have one more victim of "superior forces" to add to the long list which already adorns our military annals. Gen. SIGEL on Sunday last, "fought the forces of ECHOLS and IMBODEN under BRECKINRIDGE, at New-Market," and in consequence of the enemy's forces being superior in number, "he gradually withdrew from the battle-field, having lost five pieces of artillery and six hundred killed and wounded." Translated into simpler English, this means that he was well beaten, though not routed.

abstract: The
snippet: The
lead_paragraph: A month ago there was a general and clamorous demand, on the part of a certain school of politicians, for the postponement of the Baltimore Convention. It was too soon to nominate a Presidential candidate. The country would not tolerate so early an opening of the Presidential canvass. Public sentiment ought to be harmonized, united, consolidated, before anything should be said about candidates, and this could not be done before the 7th of June.

abstract: Our forces still hold the long line of earthworks, which were captured last Thursday from the enemy. There was no general engagement yesterday, but all along our lines the skirmishers were firing briskly. The second line of rebel works is ...
lead_paragraph: Our forces still hold the long line of earthworks, which were captured last Thursday from the enemy. There was no general engagement yesterday, but all along our lines the skirmishers were firing briskly. The second line of rebel works is about three-quarters of a mile in advance of our position, and the belief is that there the enemy will make a firm stand. Whether Gen. BUTLER will attack these fortifications, or content himself with holding, for the present, the large tract of country from which we have driven the rebels, I am unable to say. We now have the district between City Point and Bermuda Landing to within three miles of Petersburgh on the south, and to within nine miles of Richmond on the north side. Drury's Bluff, whereon the guns of Fort Darling frown, is scarcely two miles and a half beyond our pickets.

abstract: About 5 o'clock, yesterday morning, while Officer ROBERT THOMPSON, of the Eighteenth Precinct, was patroling his beat, near the corner of Third-avenue and Twenty-second-street, he was accosted by a stranger, who stated to the officer that his hat had just been stolen by a gang of roughs on the next block. The officer went with the stranger, at his request, and on the corner below, they found a party of rowdies, who nightly infest that neighborhood. The stranger at once pointed out to the officer the person who stole his hat. Officer THOMPSON politely requested them to return the hat, which they refused to do, and while he was endeavoring to effect the arrest of one of the gang who struck the owner of the hat in his presence, the entire party made a dastardly attack on the officer. They knocked him down several times, and beat, kicked, and otherwise bruised him in a shocking manner. In this way they succeeded in rescuing their man. During the affray, five pistol shots were fired by the ruffians at Officer THOMPSON. One of them passed entirely through his coat-sleeve, inflicting a flesh wound on his arm above the elbow. The rowdies then fled. As soon as the officer could regain his feet, he pursued them, and fired four shots at his assailants, none of which took effect, so far as is known. Capt. CAMERON, of the Eighteenth, was patroling his Precinct at the time; he heard the shots, and pursued the offenders as far as Third-avenue and Twenty-fourth-street, where they suddenly disappeared in the dark alleys of a long row of tenement houses. So far as is known, no arrests have yet been made.

abstract: The following letter from the United States Medical Director of the District of North Carolina is communicated by the lady to whom it was addressed, in hopes that the appeal may meet a ready and generous response from the public. All the blacks from Washington, N.C. -- 3,000 in number -- have been thrown on the hands of those who have been caring for this class of poor in Newbern, and their wants are draining the stores of the Freedmen's Associations. But the whites are entirely unprovided for, and their case should excite the sympathies of all, particularly those who have taken no special interest in the "contrabands." Donations sent to Surgeon HAND or Rev. HORACE JAMES, Newbern, N.C., will be gladly distributed to these poor whites, who have given proof of their loyalty in "leaving all to follow us:"

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The gratitude and admiration of theatrical people move in mysterious ways. Several prominent actors give to-night a testimonial enteriainment to Mr. DAN BRYANT, a gentleman who receives a testimonial benefit every night ...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The gratitude and admiration of theatrical people move in mysterious ways. Several prominent actors give to-night a testimonial enteriainment to Mr. DAN BRYANT, a gentleman who receives a testimonial benefit every night in the shape of a crowded audience to his negro minstrel hall. Mr. BRYANT's ambition extends beyond the sphere of an "[???]nd man." He is said to be an excellent actor; and peculiarly felicitous in the delineation of Irishmen. Hence he plays Handy Andy in the piece of that name, being supported by first-rate talent. Mr. DAN BRYANT has so many admirers that the Academy is sure to be crowded to its greatest capacity. Two small pieces will precede the drama.

abstract: The Seventy-ninth Regiment New-York State Volunteers, after three years of faithful service, returned to this City yesterday morning, their term of enlistment having expired. They were received by the members of the Caledonian Club, and escorted up Broadway amidst the cheering of numerous spectators. The gallant Col. MORRISON, though suffering from a wound received in the battle at Spottsylvania Court-house, rode at the head of his regiment. The Seventy-ninth was reviewed about noon, in front of the City Hall, by Mayor GUNTHER and the Common Council, after which it was escorted by the Sixty-ninth Regiment to the Jefferson Market drill rooms, where the officers and men sat down to a sumptuous dinner. In deference to the wishes of the returning veterans, who were anxious, after so long an absence, to greet their families and their friends, but few speeches -- and those short and fitting -- were made during the dinner.

abstract: the Publication of a
snippet: the Publication of a
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, at about 3 1/2 o'clock, a boy left in the business office of the TIMES three pages of thin paper, upon which was written what purported to be a proclamation, signed by President LINCOLN, and countersigned by the Secretary of State. It was at once sent to the editorial rooms, and put into the hands of the night Editor. It resembled somewhat the copy usually sent from the office of the Associated Press, though its handwriting was not that which usually comes from that office -- and a perusal of the document led the editor to doubt its authenticity. On inquiry he learned that it was not inclosed in the envelope bearing the stamp of the Associated Press, or in any other, and that the boy who left it had, after throwing it upon the counter, instantly left the office. The editor then sent the manuscript to the office of the Associated Press, with an inquiry as to its origin, and received from the person in attendance the following perfectly satisfactory reply:

abstract: We have a special dispatch from our correspondent at Lieut.-Gen. GRANT's headquarters, under date of yesterday morning, 5 o'clock, in these words: "The struggle has this moment begun with skirmishing on our extreme right. We fully expect a great, a bloody, and, we trust, a decisive battle to-day." The progress and result of the day's work -- whether the skirmishing swelled into a general battle -- whether the two Commanders spent the hours in a game of strategy -- whether the issue was for or against the Union arms -- we do not yet know.

abstract: Denmark Question, The, in, and the Queen
snippet: Denmark Question, The, in, and the Queen
lead_paragraph: The news from Europe by the Persia is of deep significance. Following close in the track of the Austro-Prussian squadron, which was making its way toward the Baltic, a British frigate, under command of Sir L. MCCLINTOCK, had set sail, it is said, as the first of a British fleet which will oppose the entrance of the German men-of-war into the Sound. The English press, almost without exception, is agreed that consideration, not only for the honor, but for the material interests of England, now require that her naval power shall be exerted to bar the entrance of the Baltic to the Austrian force, and to prevent any additional pressure being brought to bear upon Denmark.

abstract: 'Tis not our intention to preach a reform against the growing and sociable use of the weed, for it is a luxurious comfort. What gentleman, we ask, old or young, who is addicted to this habit of enjoying himself behind a good Havana, particularly after a hearty meal, will dispute us. We speak from experience, for we often indulge in a good cigar ourselves; but what we wish to suggest is, try that justly-popular, fragrant, convenient and efficacious dentrifice, SOZODONT. Just the thing after smoking; removes instantly the unpleasant taste and odors attendant on the use of tobacco; 'tis refreshingly agreeable, and leaves the mouth cool and sweet.
lead_paragraph: 'Tis not our intention to preach a reform against the growing and sociable use of the weed, for it is a luxurious comfort. What gentleman, we ask, old or young, who is addicted to this habit of enjoying himself behind a good Havana, particularly after a hearty meal, will dispute us. We speak from experience, for we often indulge in a good cigar ourselves; but what we wish to suggest is, try that justly-popular, fragrant, convenient and efficacious dentrifice, SOZODONT. Just the thing after smoking; removes instantly the unpleasant taste and odors attendant on the use of tobacco; 'tis refreshingly agreeable, and leaves the mouth cool and sweet.

abstract: M. E. Gen. Conference Deputation and Reply to
snippet: M. E. Gen. Conference Deputation and Reply to
lead_paragraph: The Senate Finance Committee is working from four to six hours daily on the Tax Bill. It will probably not be ready to report before Monday. Commissioner LEWIS was before them to-day for several hours. It is understood that they have decided to increase the tax on whisky. Also, that they have decided to adhere to their former action, and not tax stock on hand.

abstract: Its Text; World Office Seized by Military for Publishing Bogus Proc.; Journal of Commerce Seized by Military for Publishing Bogus Proc.
snippet: Its Text; World Office Seized by Military for Publishing Bogus Proc.; Journal of Commerce Seized by Military for Publishing Bogus Proc.
lead_paragraph: By the publication of the following atrocious forgery in the World and Journal of Commerce, yesterday morning, great excitment was created among our citizens until the fact that it was utterly false, concocted by enemies of the Union and of the Administration, became patent. Their indignation was aroused, and was neither reserved nor unstinted in its expression. But meantime it had operated in Wall-street, had found its way on the steamer to Europe, and had secured against the Administration an unusual amount of declamation and condemnation.

abstract: Notwithstanding the counter attractions at the Union Course, Monday, there was quite a large attendance at the Fashion, the match between the gray gelding Dutchman, and the bay gelding Dr. Thomas, exciting a considerable amount of interest between the contestants. The match was originally a play or pay one for $100 -- but prior to the start the stakes were increased to $1,000 on either side -- and the partizans of both of these notorious roadsters mustered in force. Prior to this event coming off there was another little affair decided, which may briefly be dismissed as follows:

abstract: A special dispatch of the Commercial, dated Gauly Bridge 17th, says a courier arrived this morning direct from Gen. CROOK. He has fought three battles near Newbern with the forces under Gens. MORGAN, SAM JONES and A.G. JENKINS, gaining a complete victory over the enemy. The enemy lost six hundred killed and wounded and three hundred prisoners. Gen. A.G. JENKINS fell into our hands mortally wounded. Our loss was four hundred killed and wounded. A large railroad bridge over New River at Newbern, with several miles of track, was completely destroyed. Gen. CROOK was at Newbern on the 13th inst.

abstract: LAW SCHOOL. -- A large audience assembled last evening at the Historical Society Building, corner of Eleventh-street and Second-avenue, on the occasion of the fifty annual commencement of Columbia College Law School. Among the distinguished guests present on the stage were Hon. H.B. Ruggles, Horrace Webster, Esq., Profs. Dwight, McVickar and Leiber. The proceedings were opened with prayer by Rev. R.C. DUFFIE, Chaplain of the College, after which Prof. THEODORE W. DWIGHT, LL.D., delivered an eloquent address; subject. The History and True Theory of Legal Education. The valedictory by EDWARD WHITMORE, and the awarding of prizes closed the proceedings.
lead_paragraph: LAW SCHOOL. -- A large audience assembled last evening at the Historical Society Building, corner of Eleventh-street and Second-avenue, on the occasion of the fifty annual commencement of Columbia College Law School. Among the distinguished guests present on the stage were Hon. H.B. Ruggles, Horrace Webster, Esq., Profs. Dwight, McVickar and Leiber. The proceedings were opened with prayer by Rev. R.C. DUFFIE, Chaplain of the College, after which Prof. THEODORE W. DWIGHT, LL.D., delivered an eloquent address; subject. The History and True Theory of Legal Education. The valedictory by EDWARD WHITMORE, and the awarding of prizes closed the proceedings.

abstract: Blackguardism in House
snippet: Blackguardism in House
lead_paragraph: While our soldiers are bareing their breasts to the storm of war, with a heroism that makes all true men proud to be their countrymen, the representatives of the people are besliming the American name with their unclean tongues. No decent man can read the scurrility bandied in the sitting of yesterday without shame. Though but a meagre outline of it is reported, it excites absolute disgust. It passes comprehension how gentlemen -- and we know there are some in the body -- could sit so quietly, and endure the exhibition in all its foul reality. Talk of purging the House by the expulsion of ALEXANDER LONG! ALEXANDER LONG is Hyperion himself in comparison with the members who, at such a time as this, can indulge in such mutual abuse. Fallacious as were his arguments, disloyal as were his sentiments, LONG in no wise infringed upon the dignity of the House. His words were the words of a gentleman. They were words that could be neutralized by sober reason, and leave no stain. The feeling they aroused was pure and generous indignation, which is a feeling essentially healthful and invigorating. They sickened no man with disgust. Men could listen to what he said and breathe freely -- could sternly rejoice even that it gave truth one more chance to grapple with error. But no such sensation is possible in such a commingling of filthy spite as that of yesterday -- Yahoo with Yahoo. The only effect is unmixed, overpowering loathing. The House ought to have purged itself on the spot. No silencing could have been too summary, no rebuke too severe. If the House has no care for its own dignity, it at least has no moral right to allow such ribaldry to be thrust upon the people, who have a sense of the requirements of civilized society, and whose hearts are now less than ever in a frame to abide the outrage patiently. Black-guards are never so intolerable as when solemnity should rule the hour.
headline: {'main': 'Blackguardism in the House.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Blackguardism in the House.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Journals on President Lincoln and Gen. Grant's Successes; Grant's Successes, Copperheads say, will Defeat President Lincoln; Grant's Campaign, the, and Sherman's Successes
snippet: Journals on President Lincoln and Gen. Grant's Successes; Grant's Successes, Copperheads say, will Defeat President Lincoln; Grant's Campaign, the, and Sherman's Successes
lead_paragraph: The Copperhead journals have at last found how to extract some comfort from GRANT's success. They are discovering that this success is just the thing to defeat the renomination of President LINCOLN! They feel quite certain that the Baltimore Convention, in view of these victories, will adjourn until September, and then select a more available candidate.

abstract: Independent Telegraph Operators Seized and Released
snippet: Independent Telegraph Operators Seized and Released
lead_paragraph: During yesterday, the offices of the World, Journal of Commerce, and Independent Line of Telegraph, were in charge of the military guard, and no business was allowed to be transacted. There was no excitement among the citizens in consequence of the suppressions, and the only feeling was of curiosity as parties passed the several offices at the novel sight of "military occupation." There was a very general impression that both the papers and the Telegraph Company would be permitted to resume business, but up to a late hour last evening no orders to that effect had been made public.

abstract: The fast and famous paddle-wheel steamer Kin Kiang, Capt. TAYLOR, from New-York on the 10th of February, arrived at Table Bay (Cape of Good Hope) on the 26th of March, making the voyage in five weeks. Some interesting incidents of her arrival we gather from the African Advertiser and Mail, of the 26th of March. She came into the anchorage ground in Table Bay and was passing Monille Point with the American flag flying at her mast-head, while the rebel privateer Alabama was starting out. Capt. TAYLOR and his officers at first thought the Alabama was an English gunboat. But they soon found out their mistake when they saw the rebel colors at her peak. The Kin Kiang, however, passed into the anchorage while the Alabama steamed away to sea. It will thus be seen that the Kin Kiang had a narrow escape; for although she would have easily distanced the Alabama in a straight race, she would have had no chance for taking to her heels had the two vessels, on their opposite courses, met a few miles out of the Bay, beyond the boundary-line of British maritime territory. A gentleman who was a passenger in the Kin Kiang from New-York, has written an account of the affair to a friend here, and from this letter we make the following extracts:

abstract: The draft in the Second District was commenced yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock. The officials present were Capt. MADDOX, Commissioner CHAS. W. CHESHIRE, Surgeon G.S. WOODWARD, and Col. abstract: Rumors continue rife that SIGEL is to be superseded for his conduct in the recent engagement in the Valley of Virginia. It is believed that the force opposing him only numbered about four thousand, and some express doubts as to whether BRECKINRIDGE was there at all. CROOKS was in the rear of the rebel force, and there are no apprehensions of their making any effort to pursue their advantage over SIGEL.

abstract: The operations of Wednesday, which our special dispatch of yesterday, from headquarters, announced as having opened with skirmishing at daylight, settled into a heavy engagement, lasting through the forenoon. It culminated in a brilliant charge by Gen. HANCOCK, in which he drove the enemy and carried their first line of intrenchments on the Po. The position thus gained was held by our forces up to the latest advices, and so far the result of the day's work was favorable. It is further said that GRANT in the course of the day turned nearly the whole of LEE's left. The rebels, however, maintained tenaciously the greater part of their line, and officers from headquarters describe their fortifications as exceedingly formidable. The dispatches lead to the opinion that the Lieutenant-General has not paused, and will not pause, in his labor of advancing upon them.
lead_paragraph: The operations of Wednesday, which our special dispatch of yesterday, from headquarters, announced as having opened with skirmishing at daylight, settled into a heavy engagement, lasting through the forenoon. It culminated in a brilliant charge by Gen. HANCOCK, in which he drove the enemy and carried their first line of intrenchments on the Po. The rebels, however, maintained tenaciously the greater part of their line, and officers from headquarters describe their fortifications as exceedingly formidable. The dispatches lead to the opinion that the Lieutenant-General has not paused, and will not pause, in his labor of advancing upon them.

abstract: The Senate yesterday passed the bill in relation to donations to settlers upon public lands in California. A report recommending that the Senate insist on the amendments to the Army Appropriation Bill, and ask for another committee of conference, was agreed to. The report of the Committee of Conference on the Territory of Montana was agreed to by the following vote: Yeas, 26; Nays, 13. The Pacific Railroad Bill was debated at length on its minor amendments.

abstract: The remains of Gen. WADSWORTH arrived here last evening, on the half-past six o'clock train from Washington, accompanied by Gen. SPRAGUE, Dr. FITZHUGH and the Congressional Committee, Hons. Messrs. Fenton, Odell, Morris, Ganson, Frank and Winfield. The body was escorted by eight of the Veteran Reserves. The remains were received at the foot of Cortlandt-street by a detachment of the Third Regular Infantry, under command of Lieut. POMEROY, and Company C, Seventh Regiment, Capt. HAWS commanding. At 7 o'clock the precession was formed under direction of Gen. HALL, and proceeded to the City Hall. The coffin, inclosed in a rough box, was taken to the Governor's room, where the body will remain until 3 o'clock to-day, when it will be escorted to the Erie Railroad Depot by the Seventh Regiment. It will be taken at once to Geneseo. The friends of the deceased are requested to meet at the City Hall to-day, at the above hour, to join in the military and municipal procession.
lead_paragraph: The remains of Gen. WADSWORTH arrived here last evening, on the half-past six o'clock train from Washington, accompanied by Gen.
