At 7 o'clock the precession was formed under direction of Gen. HALL, and proceeded to the City Hall. The coffin, inclosed in a rough box, was taken to the Governor's room, where the body will remain until 3 o'clock to-day, when it will be escorted to the Erie Railroad Depot by the Seventh Regiment. It will be taken at once to Geneseo. The friends of the deceased are requested to meet at the City Hall to-day, at the above hour, to join in the military and municipal procession.

abstract: The important intelligence that the great struggle in Virginia was renewed on Wednesday, which was announced exclusively in the TIMES of yesterday, is fully confirmed this morning by later dispatches, which state that the battle was quite general, and that HANCOCK's gallant corps had made another famous charge, capturing the first line of the enemy's works on our right, and turning the left flank of the enemy. Along the other portions of the line the results were encouraging, as our line had steadily pushed the enemy back. Up to 10 o'clock yesterday morning the battle had not been renewed, the day having been spent in manoeuvering by both armies.
lead_paragraph: The important intelligence that the great struggle in Virginia was renewed on Wednesday, which was announced exclusively in the TIMES of yesterday, is fully confirmed this morning by later dispatches, which state that the battle was quite general, and that HANCOCK's gallant corps had made another famous charge, capturing the first line of the enemy's works on our right, and turning the left flank of the enemy. Along the other portions of the line the results were encouraging, as our line had steadily pushed the enemy back. Up to 10 o'clock yesterday morning the battle had not been renewed, the day having been spent in manoeuvering by both armies.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen yesterday adopted a resolution that the pork and oyster stands in Washington Market be closed after 1 P.M., from June 1 to Sept. 1. A resolution appropriating $10,000 for the celebration of the Fourth of July, was laid over. The Mayor transmitted a communication from the Kings County Supervisors, asking that some reciprocal arrangement may be made whereby the families of volunteers from New-York residing in Brooklyn, and the families of volunteers from Brooklyn, residing in New-York, may be benefitted by the relief funds of the respective counties from which they are now enlisted. The ordinance of the Aldermen, appropriating $500,000 additional for the relief of families of volunteers was concurred in, as also the resolution to lease the upper floors of Nos. 115 and 117 Nassau-street for the accommodation of the First District Court. Adjourned to Monday next.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen yesterday adopted a resolution that the pork and oyster stands in Washington Market be closed after 1 P.M., from June 1 to Sept. 1. The ordinance of the Aldermen, appropriating $500,000 additional for the relief of families of volunteers was concurred in, as also the resolution to lease the upper floors of Nos. 115 and 117 Nassau-street for the accommodation of the First District Court. Adjourned to Monday next.

abstract: -- This delightful toilet preparation, which is exciting a furore among the most beautiful and fashionable women, exercises the charm of the ancient May-dew in whitening the skin and imparting to it delicacy and clearness. It is free from all injurious ingredients; is perfectly innocent, delicious and refreshing, and renders the skin beautifully clear, soft and smooth. It is sold by all druggists, and at the principal depot, No. 718 Broadway. -- Illustrated News.

abstract: -- On Tuesday Justice DOWLING decided the evidence in the old arson case against Mr. JOHN D. VERMEULE, who had been arrested for setting fire to his crockery-store No. 282 Greenwich-street, on the 8th of December last, to be quite insufficient to sustain the charge, and dismissed the complaint. Mr. VERMEULE stands, therefore, fully acquitted. The arrest of Mr. VERMEULE was the result of a difficulty between himself and his former partner, FRANCIS HULL, the latter preferring the complaint against Mr. V.

abstract: In pursuance of instructions received from the War Department, the Provost-Marshals of this City are preparing to make out a new enrollment of persons liable to a draft, -- a labor which will require the services of about forty clerks in each office for a month or longer. All persons not liable to draft, will save themselves much trouble by immediately securing their exemptions at the offices where they may be enrolled. Persons liable to duty, can secure exemptions for three years, if drafted, by furnishing an alien as a substitute.
lead_paragraph: In pursuance of instructions received from the War Department, the Provost-Marshals of this City are preparing to make out a new enrollment of persons liable to a draft, -- a labor which will require the services of about forty clerks in each office for a month or longer. abstract: The hardest fighting of the campaign on the south side of the James River occurred yesterday. In the early morning, under cover of a fog so dense as to limit vision to the distance of a few yards, the enemy fell upon the right of our line of battle with the force of an avalanche, completely crushing it backward, and turning our flank, as two days before we had turned theirs.

abstract: The news from Gen. GRANT is up to 8  o'clock yesterday morning, at which time Gen. GRANT  dated a dispatch to Secretary STANTON, announcing the failure of an attempt of the enemy to turn our right flank, they being severely repulsed by Gen. TYLER'S division, just from Washington. Yesterday there was no fighting, and up to latest accounts no change in the position. Gen. GRANT had received 25,000 veteran reinforcements.

abstract: M. ROUBER, in the Corps Legislatif, had been defending the Government from the recent attacks in the speeches of IRIS and BEERYER. He fully acquiesced in the policy of peace. He said peace was in the hands of France, and France would only open that hand when compelled to defend her honor and the inviolability of her frontiers. He hoped now for a pacific solution of the conflict of North Europe. He considered that the Mexican question had a very reassuring aspect, and was fruitful in results.

abstract: And Kentucky Neutrality; Tribune's Second Article on; Reiteration on the Buckner-McClellan Agreement; Gen. Buckner's Agreement with McClellan, Tribune on
snippet: And Kentucky Neutrality; Tribune's Second Article on; Reiteration on the Buckner-McClellan Agreement; Gen. Buckner's Agreement with McClellan, Tribune on
lead_paragraph: The Tribune repeats its conviction that Gen. MCCLELLAN never had any understanding with Gen. BUCKNER by which the substantial neutrality of the State of Kentucky was recognized and respected, as is stated by Mr. RAYMOND in his History of President Lincoln's Administration. It is of opinion that the letter of Gen. BUCKNER to Gov. MAGOFFIN, asserting that there was such an understanding, and purporting to give its substance, was essentially false.

MALESPINE to whose pen this country is indebted for the clear and able espose published in the Opinion on the 28th of March, and given to the American public through the columns of the TIMES, has found the occasion pressing enough to induce a resumption of his labors in that direction, and we append a translation in brief of the result, omitting, here and there, such documents as have already appeared in our columns, or in the diplomatic correspondence published by our Department of State:

lead_paragraph: The Evening Post invokes the constitutional principle of the freedom of the press in behalf of the suspended Journal of Commerce and the World. This is not reasonable. Indeed, it seems to us little less than mockery -- much like pleading the freedom of trade for the receiver of stolen goods, or the inviolability of your house for the assassin who shoots from your window.

abstract: Federalist, The, Edited by John C. Hamilton
snippet: Federalist, The, Edited by John C. Hamilton
lead_paragraph: The primary aim of this new edition, as stated by the editor himself, was to disclose all the evidence known to exist to designate the respective contributions of its authors. The result is that a great deal more than the lion's share is allotted to HAMILTON, and for insufficient reasons, as it seems to us. It is a matter of the more consequence, for it involves the question whether JAMES MADISON did or did not write a deliberate falsehood, in laying claim to some dozen or fifteen numbers which the present editor argues were not his. We believe that Mr. MADISON told the truth, and also that there was no intentional misrepresentation on the part of Mr. HAMILTON. The grounds of this belief we shall take an early occasion to present in detail.

abstract: Vermont Convention; Indorsement and Anti-Slavery Men
snippet: Vermont Convention; Indorsement and Anti-Slavery Men
lead_paragraph: The Union Convention of Vermont, which has just adjourned, unanimously adopted a resolution declaring ABRAHAM LINCOLN the first choice of the people of that State for the next Presidential term. This is another proof of the falsity of the pretense that Mr. LINCOLN has not the confidence of the earnest Anti-Slavery men of the country. No State in the Union has so steadily and so emphatically testified its abhorrence of human chattelism as Vermont. In its very earliest history, one of its judges refused to recognize an affidavit of the ownership of a fugitive slave, saying that he "would take no evidence short of a bill of sale from the Almighty;" and that has ever been the spirit of the State in every line of its public action. Its mountains have not been firmer than its Anti-Slavery principles.
headline: {'main': 'Anti-Slavery Principles and President Lincoln.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Anti-Slavery Principles and President Lincoln.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. HALE presented a bill from JOHN ERICSSON for relief, which was granted. The bill for the relief of Mrs. AMES, wife of a Sergeant of the Sixth Massachusetts Infantry, was passed. A joint resolution was introduced by Mr. WILSON to authorize the President to call out men by draft for one year. The bill authorizing a mail steamship, service between the United States and Brazil was brought up, and after some discussion laid over; the amendment offered by Mr. WILKINSON was rejected. The Pacific Railroad Bill was brought up for consideration.

abstract: Wadsworth, Gen., His Character, the National Loss; Another Ministerial Crisis
snippet: Wadsworth, Gen., His Character, the National Loss; Another Ministerial Crisis
lead_paragraph: The more the public mind dwells upon the death of Gen. WADSWORTH, the more profound is the feeling that it was a great national loss. The truth is, that of all classes of men which American democracy has produced, the rarest and the most needed is just that of which the lamented General was the representative. Of scholars and clergymen, politicians and lawyers, sailors and soldiers, rich men and skillful mercantile men, we have a plenty; but of men of the peculiar position, influence and personal character of Gen. WADSWORTH, we have by far too few.

abstract: The quota of New-York County, under the call for 200,000 men -- being 7,400 men -- has been filled at last. Inspector BLUNT has, by letter and personal application to the proper authority, secured in getting credits for several hundred men raised before the last call, and never before allowed, and this morning it is calculated that the County is about 750 men ahead of all demands up to this time. It is not yet definitely determined whether the Supervisors Committee will continue to raise men in anticipation of a new call, or whether they will await the new call before making further attempt to raise men.

abstract: Howard, J., Jr., Arrested
snippet: Howard, J., Jr., Arrested
lead_paragraph: It turns out that J. HOWARD, Jr., City Editor of the Brooklyn Eagle, is the person who forged the Proclamation, and procured its insertion in as many of the City newspapers as he succeeded in duping. He has acknowledged the fact, and was sent down last evening to Fort Lafayette. He says he had no other motive except to make a little money on the Stock Exchange, and that it never occurred to him that his performance could produce any more important or serious effect.

abstract: Meyerbeer, Giacomo, the Composer
snippet: Meyerbeer, Giacomo, the Composer
lead_paragraph: A telegram from Paris, dated May 2, brings the announcement of the death of MEYERBEER, the eminent German composer. The deceased was born in Berlin on the 5th of September, 1794, and consequently at the time of his death was nearly 70 years of age. As a child, he was extremely precocious' and his musical talent came to him so early that when only seven years old he was celebrated; and at nine, a German critic spoke of him as one of the best pianists of Berlin. Under less favorable circumstances, the lad would doubtless have been prematurely brought before the public as a prodigy, to contradict, perhaps, in manhood, the promises of his youth. But his father, JAMES BEER, a Jew banker, was very wealthy, and GIACOMO MEYERBEER, as the composer afterward called himself, italianizing his name, only appeared occasionally, principally at amateur concerts, and had plenty of opportunities afforded him for study. With what result he availed himself of them, is known throughout the world. MEYERBEER did not however, at once obtain a high position in music. His first opera, "Jeptha's Daughter," was represented at Munich, in 1812, with but indifferent success, but the numerous works he afterward produced, and which extended over nearly the whole range of musical composition, secured for him a wide reputation, and proved that his talents were of no common order. Of these productions the "Crociato in Egitto," produced in Venice, in 1825, may be said to have laid the foundation of his European fame. In 1831 be produced his grand work, "Robert the Devil," and henceforth MEYERBEER was recognized as a master. The "Huguenots" followed in 1836, and the "Prophete" in 1849, both operas at once taking that commanding position on the lyric stage which they have ever since maintained. "L'Etoile du Nord," a work in a different style, but distinguished by the same charm of genius, followed in 1854, and the "Pardon de Ploermel" still more recently. It has long been known that the deceased composer had finished another work, "I'Africaine," and that his scrupulous and perhaps fastidious anxiety to secure for it a satisfactory interpretation has alone kept it from the public. Its production may now, it is to be presumed, he looked for at no distant date.

abstract: THE SHOOTING OF PATRICK McGEE. An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner WILDEY, at the New-York Hospital, on the body of PATRICK McGEE, who was shot and fatally wounded on the 2d inst., near...
lead_paragraph: THE SHOOTING OF PATRICK MCGEE. -- An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner WILDEY, at the New-York Hospital, on the body of PATRICK MCGEE, who was shot and fatally wounded on the 2d inst., near Sheeps Head Bay, L.I., by Lieut.-Col. RUGG, of the Fifty-ninth Regiment N.Y.V., as previously reported in the TIMES. Several witnesses were examined, and the testimony all went to show that Col. RUGG was first assaulted by the deceased, and his friend named CARMAN, and that in resorting to the use of the pistol the Colonel only acted in self-defence. The jury rendered the following verdict: "That PATRICK MCGEE come to his death from injuries received by a pistol shot wound at the hands of Col. HORACE P. RUGG, on the 2d of May inst., under circumstances which we think render the shooting justifiable." Un this verdict the Coroner discharged Col. RUGG from custody. Deceased was 23 years of age, and a native of Ireland.

abstract: force of workmen engaged on the frigate Neshamony, at our Navy-yard, will, it is believed, be able to get her ready for launching in thirty days. Her planking is nearly completed, and her deck will be at once put on. The machinery is being made in New-York and she will be towed there to receive it. As this frigate is one of a class intended for special service, requiring great speed and heavy guns, the Navy Department has ordered her completion and equipment as early as possible. It is not a secret that she is designed to aid in ridding the ocean of the privateers, which are doing so much damage, and this is sufficient to account for the desire to get her afloat without delay.

lead_paragraph: At 11 A.M. yesterday, funeral services were held at the residence of WILLIAM A. RICE, Esq., State-street, over the remains of the lamented Gen. JAMES C. Rice. The family, relatives and friends were present. Rev. Dr. PALMER, in an eloquent address, recited the incidents in the life of the deceased, and traced his patriotism, his self-sacrifice and heroism, as well as his influence on others to their source, in religious faith, and an elevated moral sense.

abstract: Pope Pius, His Gift to the Sanitary Commission
snippet: Pope Pius, His Gift to the Sanitary Commission
lead_paragraph: the Pope, through His Eminence, Cardinal BARNABO, has given from his private purse the sum of five hundred dollars to alleviate the sufferings of our gallant wounded soldiers. The Bishop of Buffalo, to whom the money was forwarded, has sent it to Mrs. HORATIO SEYMOUR, to be by her given to the Sanitary Commission; and this lady, in acknowledging the gift of the Sovereign Pontiff, thanks him warmly, and adds: "We are deeply touched by such evidences of interest in our present struggle for national life, and the indorsement of this national channel for our charities, which we believe to be the most direct, humane and efficient one through which the good will of a Christian people can be conveyed to the wounded patriots in field or hospital."

abstract: A Paris letter writer says: "The world to Paris is gone mad after the Japanese. This embassy, regardless of the 'happy dispatch' which may await them on their return, are enjoying themselves in the most reckless manner.
lead_paragraph: -- A Paris letter writer says: "The world to Paris is gone mad after the Japanese. This embassy, regardless of the 'happy dispatch' which may await them on their return, are enjoying themselves in the most reckless manner. Only last night I found several secretaries of legation -- where, do you think? Why, actually behind the scenes of the Grand Opera, surrounded with ballet girls! European secretaries of legation know better than that, at any rate, though they do not know much as a rule. As for 'Mablile,' and the Chateau des Fleurs, they are there every night. On Wednesday they 'entertained at dinner.' I saw the menu, but it contained nothing worth recording; judging, however, from the list of wines selected, I should say that the very best of everything is nearly good enough for the dusky diplomacy of Japan."

abstract: Rebel Ram Attack and Repulse
snippet: Rebel Ram Attack and Repulse
lead_paragraph: We have just passed through the second engagement with that ugly little ram, the Roanoke. Yesterday afternoon, at 2 o'clock, the ram, consorted by the steamer Cotton Planter and the Bombshell, which last they sunk at the attack on Plymouth, and afterwards raised, made its appearance at the mouth of the river. We retreated slowly and they followed, Capt. FRENCH sent the Massasoit ahead to inform the remainder of the fleet.

abstract: The Conference Concerning; Conviction of
snippet: The Conference Concerning; Conviction of
lead_paragraph: We have just received intelligence that an armistice has been concluded between the Danes and the Allies. The nature of its conditions is not mentioned -- we are not told whether the blockade of the German ports is to be raised, or whether Jutland is to be evacuated, but if the main fact is correct, the belligerents have removed one great stumbling-block out of the way of the diplomats. This assistance was rendered most seasonably, for at its second sitting the Conference accomplished, as little as at its first, and the general impression in London was that it could effect nothing, and would soon come to an untimely end.

abstract: We are authorized by Mr. CYRUS W. FIELD to state that the announcement which has appeared in print, that the steamship Great Eastern has been sold to the French Government, is untrue. The Great Eastern was sold by auction for £25,000, her purchasers being Messrs. GOOCH, BARBER, BRASSEY and others, who have formed a company under the title of the "Great Ship Company." This Company have chartered her to lay the Atlantic cable before the 31st of December, 1865, and if the cable is successfully laid, they are to receive £50,000 in shares of the Atlantic Telegraph Company.

abstract: Fever, The; Buzfuz and His Friends
snippet: Fever, The; Buzfuz and His Friends
lead_paragraph: The performances of the persons who are affected with the monomania about Gen. MCCLELLAN have, during the last fortnight, been very curious subjects of contemplation. Before Lieut.-Gen. GRANT had begun his movements, they got up a report that he had solemnly applied to the President to give Gen. MCCLELLAN a command, and upon this little fiction -- for we need hardly say it is pure fiction -- their organ in this City based an elaborate article, showing the necessity of giving the said Gen. MCCLELLAN what he wanted, in order that in case GRANT was defeated, MCCLELLAN might be able "to certify" that it was not GRANT's fault, but that of the mud, the rivers, or something. GRANT was to fight the battles, and MCCLELLAN was to invent the excuses. The writer gravely assured us that nothing short of a manifesto, under Little Mac's sign manual, would satisfy the Copperhead public that if GRANT were defeated, he was defeated en regle. Now, we have no doubt whatever, that it would have been very agreeable to Maj.-Gen. GEORGE B. MCCLELLAN to be in a position in which he could again get up a wrangle with Mr. STANTON, and lecture Mr. LINCOLN upon his policy; but we believe Gen. GRANT considers himself as well able to concoct his own excuses as to fight his own battles; so this superb suggestion never bore fruit.
headline: {'main': 'Buzfuz and His Friends.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Buzfuz and His Friends.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: the Insurrection in
snippet: the Insurrection in
lead_paragraph: The Arabs of the Sahara are again in rebellion against France, and threaten to give NAPOLEON something else to do than setting up thrones for scions of the House of Hapsburg. This unexpected uprising of the native tribes is accounted for in two ways. Those who would not have it ascribed to French insolence, or oppression, maintain that it is a mere outburst of religious fanaticism, the effect of an old prediction which assured the Faithful that, in the year 1864, they were destined to expel the Glaours, and to recover their independence. Others, who are less prejudiced against the Arabs, less disposed to veil French misdeeds, and more entitled to credit, affirm that the original cause of the insurrection was an insult offered by a French official to one of the most venerated of the native chiefs.
headline: {'main': 'The Insurrection in Algeria.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Insurrection in Algeria.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Outrages by Spain
snippet: The Outrages by Spain
lead_paragraph: The more one reflects on the circumstances attending the outrage perpetrated upon Peru by the agents of Spain, the more reason is there to regard the proceeding, not as an unauthorized act of reprisal on the part of the Spanish Admiral and M. SALAZAR, but as part of a deliberate plan of invasion and subjugation. It was barely six months from the date of the attack on Fort Sumter, and the regular opening of the civil war in this country, when the tripartite treaty of London was signed, by which the Mexican Republic was overthrown and its Government turned into that of an hermaphrodite monarchy, partially self-sustained, but in part also a dependency of a European Power.

abstract: You have already been furnished with a voluminous account of the operations under Gen. SHERMAN, up to the date of the battles at Resaca, and your readers have had an opportunity to become thoroughly posted with the important details of the first fortnight of Gen. SHERMAN's campaign, down to the eventful moment when he launched the bulk of his army at the rebel flank through Snake Gap, which movement was fully initiated Thursday, May 12. As predicted in that letter, the enemy immediately evacuated Dalton, having no alternative but a speedy retreat, or a full concentration at Resaca to deliver battle. On Saturday the battle was joined, JOHNSTON being compelled to fight to gain time, and thereby lessen the immediate perils of retreat.

abstract: erally will hear with great satisfaction, as the nickel-hoarders will doubtless hear with dismay, that there is a probability of the early issue of a three-cent postage currency. This relief, so simple, inexpensive and effectual, has been advocated by us so repeatedly, that it is no little gratification to find that the appeal is to be attended with practical results. The new provision for fractional exchanges will be an unspeakable benefit to the large class of small householders, who are now subjected to every sort of inconvenience, imposition and loss by the unconscionable greed of the traders they have to deal with. Many of these traders are known to be regular and persistent speculators in nickel; hoarding what they get for sale to petty brokers, and issuing to their customers, in place of lawful change, their dirty pasteboard cards -- alike in defiance of common honesty and the laws of the country.

abstract: The latest advices from the Army of the Potomac represent everything quiet on Friday, though it was not improbable that the movements in progress on Friday and Saturday would soon produce very important results. Our loss during the rebel attack on our communications on Thursday amounts to about eleven hundred. Rebel dead and wounded to the number of twelve hundred and fifty fell into our hands, beside four hundred and fifty prisoners, who have been brought to Washington.

lead_paragraph: The trial of Solomon Kohnstaum was concluded yesterday. James T. Brady, Esq., summed up the case for the defence. He contended that the wording of the statute required that the prisoner should have actually presented the bill or claim in person to the disbursing office and have obtained the money for it himself, and that no evidence had been produced by which Kohnstaum could be connected with the presentation of this claim. He was followed by Mr. Pierrepont, who closed the case for the prosecution. At the conclusion of his remarks Wm.M. Evarts, Esq., one of the counsel for the prisoner, said that he desired to present some views of the counsel for the defence in regard to the indictment and the Act of Congress upon which it was based. His Honor said that these points might better be used in arrest of judgment, and they were submitted to the court in writing. Justice NELSON then rose and charged the jury as follows:

lead_paragraph: There are, we hope, but few people in any part of the country who are not stirred to the inmost depths of their souls by what is now passing in Virginia. Whether we consider the number of the men engaged, or the obstinacy of the fighting, or the magnitude and importance of the stake, there has been nothing in the history of modern war to equal it, and there has been nothing except the campaign which resulted in the abdication at Fontainbleau that at all approaches it.

abstract: Arrest of F. A. Malleson
snippet: Arrest of F. A. Malleson
lead_paragraph: FRANCIS A. MALLISON, a reporter for the Brooklyn Eagle and a manifold copyist for several New-York papers, was arrested yesterday morning at 9 1/2 o'clock, while on his way to the Forty-fifth Precinct Station-house, Williamsburgh, where he was to attend to the draft, by detectives YOUNG, RADFORD and MCDOUGAL, on suspicion of being implicated with J. HOWARD, Jr., in the preparation and publication of the forged proclamation. MALLISON was immediately taken before Col. LUDLOW, at Gen. DIX's headquarters, by whom he was subjected to a searching examination. Perceiving that he was hopelessly implicated, and that the evidences of his guilt already in the possession of Col. LUDLOW were clear and overwhelming, MALLISON at length made a full confession of his complicity in the matter, corroborating in every point the previous confession of Mr. HOWARD.

abstract: Union State Convention, The City Convention
snippet: Union State Convention, The City Convention
lead_paragraph: CONVENTION. -- We have been hoping that we might live to see the day when a delegation could go from this City to a State Convention, without requiring that body to devote a large portion of its time to settling questions of disputed seats. We begin to despair of ever witnessing that consummation. The Union Convention, which meets at Syracuse on Wednesday next, is to have its full share of this annoyance. Every district in this City, is to send two delegations -- and the Convention must decide which is "regular."

abstract: Secretary STANTON'S official dispatch of last evening conveys, in distinct terms, the very important intelligence that on Friday Gen. GRANT commenced a flank movement for the purpose of compelling LEE to abandon his position at Spottsylvania Court...
lead_paragraph: Secretary STANTON's official dispatch of last evening conveys, in distinct terms, the very important intelligence that on Friday Gen. GRANT commenced a flank movement for the purpose of compelling LEE to abandon his position at Spottsylvania Court-house; that, although all the details cannot yet be given, the movement is thus far a success; that the gallant HANCOCK is once again in the vanguard -- an hour and a half ahead of LONG-STREET, on the march to Richmond, and probably twenty-four hours ahead of EWELL; that the rebels are making for the south bank of the North Anna River; that, although LEE has received reinforcements, GRANT, in effecting his movement, has thus far suffered no severe losses; and that the advance of the national army is now at Guinney's and Milford Stations, south of the River Mattapony.

lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN CITY MORTALITY. -- The total number of deaths in this city last week was 104, of which 21 were men, 17 women, 43 boys and 23 girls. The principal diseases were -- consumption, 14; convulsions, marasmus, inflammation of the lungs, 7 each; dropsy, debility, scarlet fever, 5 each; disease of heart, congestion of brain, croup, diphtheria, inflammation of brain, 4 each; drowned, premature birth, 3 each; hooping cough, cholera infantum, disease of kidneys, apoplexy, typhus fever, palsy, 2 each, &c., &c. Under 1 year of age, 24. Natives of the United States, 78; Ireland, 17; England, 3; Germany, 2; British America, 1; unknown, 3.

abstract: THE SANITARY FAIR THE KNICKERBOCKER KITCHEN. lead_paragraph: THE SANITARY FAIR -- THE KNICKERBOCKER KITCHEN. -- The ladies of the Committee for the Knickerbocker Kitchen, Metropolitan Fair, take this method of acknowledging their obligations to all those whose ready kindness and prompt liberality assisted them to successfully sustain their undertaking, by donations in money, the amount of $875; by supplies of the various articles of food, by the loan of antique furniture, valuable portraits and pictures, and choice plants and by the gift of several relics, as well as by other and equally efficient services. The committee gratefully report that through these influences and the favor of the public, they have been enabled to pay over to the Treasurer of the fair the net sum of $12,518. Mrs. J.J. Roosevelt, Mrs. Alfred Schermerhorn, Mrs. A.T. Clayton, Miss Susan Benson, Mrs. James Beekman, Mrs. Theodore Timpson, Mrs. Edward Willis, Mrs. T.E. Garson, Mrs. Wm. Binns, Miss M.J. Cornell, Mrs. Dr. A. Brown, Mrs. Andrew Leggat, Mrs. E.L. Veile, Mrs. Joel Wolfe, Mrs. Thomas Ronalds, Mrs. M.M. Caleb, Committee.

abstract: Government and the Press; Responsibility of Editors
snippet: Government and the Press; Responsibility of Editors
lead_paragraph: We expressed, on Saturday, in terms sufficiently clear, our dissent from the doctrine of the Evening Post, that the right to publish forged State papers forms any part of "the liberty of the press," more especially when their publication may be attended with great damage to the National interests, and when there exists a fair warrant for the presumption that it has been dictated by malignant hostility to the Government. When a document, such as the late bogus proclamation, finds its way into a public journal, no matter by what means, somebody must be made to answer for it, whether it occurs through accident, or oversight, or design. In matters in which such gigantic mischief may be wrought, through neglect or mistake, though not as criminal as malice, is still criminal. If editors go home at three in the morning, leaving power in the hands of printers or other incompetent persons, to insert whatever comes into the office after that hour, they willfully incur a great risk; and if their incurring it results in the momentary conversion of the journal into a machine for attacks on the national credit and the public tranquillity, they must shoulder the responsibility.

abstract: The season draws slowly but steadily to a close. It lingers somewhat longer this year than last, but the signs are distinct, and any augur may read them. In a few weeks the theatres will be handed over to such "stars" as have a provincial reputation, and whose patrons, coming into the City by every train.
lead_paragraph: The season draws slowly but steadily to a close. It lingers somewhat longer this year than last, but the signs are distinct, and any augur may read them. In a few weeks the theatres will be handed over to such "stars" as have a provincial reputation, and whose patrons, coming into the City by every train, may be expected to patronize them. Then will it be impossible for the critic who knows his regular audience, to recognize a single face. He will leave the place of amusement with a feeling that is not far from being akin to pain. Precisely what is to be done at the various theatrical establishments of the City is so far unknown. It seems probable, however, that two or three of the principal establishments will, with shortened sail, endeavor to weather the storm. Judging from present indications the danger is great, but "hope springs eternal" in the managerial breast.

abstract: The Havre and Bremen steamer America, via Southampton, with dates to Wednesday, the 11th inst., arrived here yesterday. The news is only in part anticipated in the intelligence received by the Peruvian via Port au Basque. It is of much interest and importance. The London Conference, as was briefly reported by the Peru.
lead_paragraph: The Havre and Bremen steamer America, via Southampton, with dates to Wednesday, the 11th inst., arrived here yesterday. The news is only in part anticipated in the intelligence received by the Peruvian via Port au Basque. It is of much interest and importance. The London Conference, as was briefly reported by the Peruvian, had succeeded in obtaining an armistice, or rather a suspension of hostilities, to commence from the 12th of May, and to continue for one month. Previous to this arrangement, however, a collision had taken place between the naval squadrons of Austria and Denmark in the North Sea. The Austrians had two frigates and three gunboats engaged, and the Danes two frigates and a corvette. While the House of Commons was in session on the 9th, a telegram was received from the Governor of Heligoland, which reported that the Danes had defeated the Austrians; that one of the frigates of that Power was in flames, and the rest of the Austrian squadron was making for Heligoland. The announcement was received with loud cheers from all parts of the House, the occupants of the Strangers' Gallery joining heartily in the applause. The Daily News says: "Government officials have been at Southampton inspecting some of the mail packets, to ascertain their fitness for war transports. A deputation of the GARIBALDI Committee had waited on Mr. GLADSTONE to get a statement of the facts connected with the sudden departure of GARIBALDI. The result does not appear to have been entirely satisfactory to the committee, although Mr. GLADSTONE reaffirmed, in the most positive terms, that he acted solely on his own responsibility, as solely from a consideration for Gen. GARIBALDI's health.

abstract: Their Lesson
snippet: Their Lesson
lead_paragraph: The case of SALOMON KOHNSTAMM, convicted on Saturday, in the Circuit Court of the United States, of having defrauded the Government, is an important one. There has been so much fraud in connection with the operations of the Government here, that it was full time that some one should be made an example of, and we consider this conviction as an important success for the Government, which we hope will be speedily followed up. The case excited great interest, from the standing which KOHNSTAMM has had in the community, and the court-room was crowded every day of the week during which the trial lasted.

abstract: GRANT's BATTLE MARCH. -- The official news from the Army of the Potomac this morning, though not news of battle, is news of success. Secretary STANTON telegraphed at the hour of ten last night, that GRANT commenced, on Friday evening, his movement to force LEE from Spottsylvania; and almost immediately after HANCOCK had begun his flank movement, LONGSTREET's corps started South, and was followed by the corps of EWELL on Saturday night. The movement of Gen. GRANT, says Secretary STANTON, has thus far been accomplished without any severe engagement or serious interruption. We now occupy Guinney's Station, Milford Station, and are south of the Mattapony on that line. Both of these stations are on the Richmond and Fredericksburgh Railroad, and LEE must either have retreated very rapidly, or GRANT must be well in his rear. If LEE does not show fight before he reaches, he will almost certainly fight at, Hanover Junction, the point of crossing of the Virginia Central and Fredericksburgh railroads, and situated on the North Anna River. There will probably be as sanguinary scenes in the closing days of May as there were in its opening fortnight.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: This gallant officer died yesterday morning at the Metropolitan Hotel in this City, of a wound received at the battle or the Wilderness. Col. TYLER enlisted in his regiment as a private at the beginning of the war, and rose to the rank he held before he was twenty-one years old. He was brave almost to a fault, and actuated by the noblest patriotism in the performance of his duty. He leaves a large number of warm friends to mourn his loss. His body was yesterday taken to Brattleboro', Vt., where the last tribute of respect to the gallant soldier's remains will be paid.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. MORGAN introduced a bill to prohibit the release of drafted men from the draft by the payment of money.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. MORGAN introduced a bill to prohibit the release of drafted men from the draft by the payment of money. The bill relative to the naval supplies was taken up, and Mr. GRIMES addressed the House for over two hours, in answer to the adverse report made thereon by the Naval Committee. Mr. HALE and Mr. DAVIS also spoke at length on the same subject. The Pacific Railroad Bill was passed as amended, by a vote of 23 ayes against 5 nays.

abstract: Under date of spottsylvania, May 17, Gen. O. B. WILLCOX, of Gen. BURNSIDE'S Corps, telegraphed to Gov. BLAIR, of Michigan: "The Michigan' regiments of this Division have been engaged in ...
lead_paragraph: Under date of Spottsylvania, May 17, Gen. O.B. WILLCOX, of Gen. BURNSIDE's Corps, telegraphed to Gov. BLAIR, of Michigan: "The Michigan regiments of this Division have been engaged in several skirmishes and three general engagements. They have all done well, some of them splendidly. Their losses, since crossing the Rapidan to this date, have been: Killed, 161; wounded, 722; missing, 540; total loss, 1,423, Will you please use every measure in your power to hurry up all reinforcements to these regiments. I think we are on the high road to success."

abstract: THE LATE SUICIDE BY SHOOTING. An Inquest was held by Coroner NAUMANN on the body of WM. NEWMANN, who, on Saturday afternoon last, committed suicide by shooting himself through the head in ...
lead_paragraph: THE LATE SUICIDE BY SHOOTING. -- An inquest was held by Coroner NAUMANN on the body of WM. NEWMANN, who, on Saturday afternoon last, committed suicide by shooting himself through the head in the Jewish Cemetery, in Eighty-eighth-street. He was standing over the grave of a young sister at the time he committed the fatal act. For the last six years he has been connected with the Fourteenth United States Infantry Regiment. He was honorably discharged recently, and reenlisted for three years more. He had been in a depressed state of mind for several days, and became more so upon learning that several of his late associates in the army had been killed in one of the late battles under Gen. BUTLER. He placed the muzzle of a small revolver to his forehead and discharged it. The bullet was found deeply imbedded in his brain. Death ensued in a short time after. Deceased was 37 years of age and a native of Germany.

abstract: Arguelles Case, Diplomatic Cor. on the
snippet: Arguelles Case, Diplomatic Cor. on the
lead_paragraph: The official correspondence in the case of the absconding Cuban official, Don JOSE AUGUSTIN ARQUELLES, has been made public in connection with the indictment found against Marshal MURRAY for aiding in ARQUELLE's abduction. The first note of the batch is from the United States Vice-Consul at Havana, intimating that a cargo of negro slaves had been brought to Havana for sale, having been landed secretly from a steamship on some other part of the coast. In the transaction several wealthy persons were implicated. This note is dated Nov. 20, 1863. The next letter is from Mr. SEWARD, informing Lord LYONS of the contents of the Consul's note. This Lord LYONS acknowledges, and promises to inform his Government of the facts. On receiving his Government's reply, Lord LYONS again writes (Feb. 4, 1864,) conveying the thanks of Lord RUSSELL, and urging representations from the United States Government to that of Spain. Following these preliminary notes is a memoradum of the State Department, showing how faithfully the Captain-General of Cuba has executed the treaty agreements with the United States and England for the suppression of the slave trade. Two subsequent notes from Lord LYONS and Mr. SEWARD, respectively show that the Ministers of the two countries at Madrid were instructed to make representations to the Queen's Government as to the slave-trading practices at Cuba: and these instructions were promptly fulfilled. The United States Vice-Consul at Havanna, again writes to the State Department giving fuller particulars of the slaver described in his first note, and these particulars were handed to Lord LYONS. This was in the beginning of March last. On the 27th of March the Vice-Consul again writes to say, that he had an interview with the Captain-General of the island, who wished to ascertain if the United States authorities can return to this island the person of an officer of the Spanish army named Don JOSE AUGUSTIN ARGUELLES, who was believed to be in New-York."

abstract: Campaign in Georgia
snippet: Campaign in Georgia
lead_paragraph: In the absorbing interest of the campaign in Virginia, the public are almost overlooking a brilliant advance of the Union armies toward a point which last year we should have considered equal in importance to Richmond itself -- Atlanta. It is well understood that Gen. SHERMAN began his movement from Chattanooga with a force so imposing and of such excellent fighting quality that nothing in the Southwestern rebel States could be expected to withstand it for a week. The positions held by the different portions of JOHNSTON's army were exceedingly strong, being often mountain passes where every advantage of nature was on their side. But the great superiority of number with SHERMAN enabled him to make flank movements with as heavy force as he kept in front of the enemy, and he has thus succeeded in turning all their positions in the mountains, and has now reached that part of the uplands of Georgia, where the country is open and rolling, and not so easily defended by small bodies of men.

abstract: It was very well for the French philosopher to say that "there is no mischance which a clever man may not turn to his advantage;" but there are mischances which no man, with a ...
lead_paragraph: It was very well for the French philosopher to say that "there is no mischance which a clever man may not turn to his advantage;" but there are mischances which no man, with a sense of justice and propriety, would attempt so to convert. If the predicament came from carelessness, and had inflicted injury upon others, only an ignoble nature could seek to make capital of it. A true man will always feel cheap over a blunder that has cost others dear, and, in no circumstances, will make an ado about it for his own profit.

abstract: Concedes an "Understanding" between McClellan and Buckner
snippet: Concedes an "Understanding" between McClellan and Buckner
lead_paragraph: The Tribune concedes that there was an "understanding" come to between Gen. MCCLELLAN and Gen. BUCKNER, as to the neutrality of Kentucky, in June, 1861; but it objects, with what seems to us superfluous and slightly absurd tenacity, to having it styled, as Mr. RAYMOND styles it in his book, an "agreement." Very well. This is a matter of very small importance; and we presume that Mr. RAYMOND would have no special objection to substituting the one word for the other in that paragraph, which has developed in the Tribune so much new-born zeal on behalf of Gen. MCCLELLAN. The Tribune says it would have "felt constrained to protest, promptly and peremptorily, [against] any such 'agreement,' had it come to our knowledge at the time." We do not doubt it.

abstract: Blockade-runners, Grievances of
snippet: Blockade-runners, Grievances of
lead_paragraph: -- In the British Foreign Office the number of "claims" registered against the United States, from the commencement of the war to the 31st of March last, is four hundred and fifty-one. Of these, the cases of personal injury number seventy-one -- the majority of complaints being registered by discomfited blockade runners. In going over the list we find that the latter class of injured innocents have steadily increased in each successive year. Thus in nine months of 1861 they numbered thirty-one; in 1862, sixty-three; in 1863, ninety-seven; and in the first quarter of 1864, ninety-six -- making in all, within three years, an aggregate loss to the British "neutrality" interest of two hundred and eighty-seven vessels, with their entire rig, machinery and cargoes. It is something awful to contemplate the combined and consolidated indignation of the blockade-running community represented in the grievance shelves of the British Foreign Office. And the most painful part of it, as we gather from the official report, before us is, that in nearly all the cases cited, redress is unattainable in the present unsatisfactory state of public opinion throughout the world.

abstract: From the several armies this morning, we have hardly any news whatever. From Gen.GRANT there are no advices, either official or otherwise.  We have private information that on Monday his army was not far from Hanover Junction, near the South Anna River, and that a battle was expected that day.
lead_paragraph: From the several armies this morning, we have hardly any news whatever. From Gen. GRANT there are no advices, either official or otherwise. We have private information that on Monday his army was not far from Hanover Junction, near the South Anna River, and that a battle was expected that day. Frederickburgh and Belle Plain, as bases of supplies, will probably be abandoned, and others nearer and more accessible be substituted. Everything was quiet with Gen. BUTLER up to Monday. The rebels had been severely punished in their last night's assault upon our lines, and had not renewed the fight. In the recent battles at that point the rebels have lost two general officers, viz.: Brig.-Gen. CORSE, of Virginia, killed, and Brig.-Gen. WALKER, of South Carolina, severely wounded and captured. From Gen. SHERMAN there is no later news than published yesterday.

abstract: The one thousand tons of gas coal, presented to the Metropolitan Fair by Mr. GEORGE ELLIOTT, of London, was sold at auction at noon yesterday at the Merchants' Exchange Rooms, in Pine-street, by Mr. E.H. LUDLOW. The auctioneer stated the amount of coal would probably run to nearly 1,100 tons. abstract: Arguelles Case; Copperhead Press and the Slave Trade
snippet: Arguelles Case; Copperhead Press and the Slave Trade
lead_paragraph: The Copperhead press, true to their instincts, have done their best to make party capital from the arrest of ARGUELLES in this City, and his deportation to Cuba to take his trial as a slave-trader. Their point is, that there is no extradition treaty between the United States and Spain, and that, therefore, the giving up of ARGUELLES was neither necessary nor legal. They are perfectly welcome to this issue with the Administration, and we hope they will continue to press it with all their natural virulence.

abstract: -- This gallant regiment, 463 men, Col. MCLAUGHLIN commanding, which arrived here from the Army of the Potomac last Monday (their term of three years' service having expired) departed yesterterday for Boston. At 4 P.M. there was a dress parade of the regiment in the City Hall Park, after which, escorted by the Sons of New-England, they marched to the Fall River boat, lying at Pier No. 3, North River, and embarked for home. There were no ceremonies, and everything passed off in a quiet way. During their stay here the men were furnished with refreshments by the New-England Soldiers' Relief Association, and the officers were entertained by Mr. STETSON at the Astor House.

abstract: The Mayor, Comptroller, and City Inspector advertise for proposals, to be opened at noon on Thursday, June 2, for contracting to clean the streets for a term of five years, in accordance with the requirements of the City Tax Law for 1864. The amount of surety required for the fulfillment of the agreement is $500,000. All the information desirable to parties wishing to compete for the contract is also advertised.
lead_paragraph: The Mayor, Comptroller, and City Inspector advertise for proposals, to be opened at noon on Thursday, June 2, for contracting to clean the streets for a term of five years, in accordance with the requirements of the City Tax Law for 1864. The amount of surety required for the fulfillment of the agreement is $500,000. All the information desirable to parties wishing to compete for the contract is also advertised. By the specifications, it appears, that Broadway, from the Battery to Twenty sixth-street, and all the principal streets below Canal-street, except those about the markets, where the market wagons stand, are to be swept at night. City Inspector BOOLE expresses himself very desirous of having the streets cleaned by contract, as the change will relieve him of a burdensome duty and responsibility, but he is firmly of the opinion that no contractor can, at the present high prices, do the work at all fairly for $300,000 per year, which is the specific sum allotted for the purpose by law. By the days work system, now in vogue, it costs upward of $500,000 a year.

abstract: OLYMPIC THEATRE. If Mr. WATTS PHILLIPS' new drama of "Paul's Return" does not deal absolutely with new material, it possesses the merit, at all events, of using old material in a thoroughly workmanlike manner. The workmanship, in fact, is sometimes too apparent, and particularly so in the matter of construction.
lead_paragraph: OLYMPIC THEATRE. -- If Mr. WATTS PHILLIPS' new drama of "Paul's Return" does not deal absolutely with new material, it possesses the merit, at all events, of using old material in a thoroughly workmanlike manner. The workmanship, in fact, is sometimes too apparent, and particularly so in the matter of construction. An ancient vulgar device -- listening -- is resorted to on every possible opportunity, and in this example taxes the ingenuity of the stage carpenter to provide the proper screens for performing the ungracious act. Still the elements of life being simple, and variety not being one of the charms of Mr. PHILLIPS' literary style, there is a direct earnestness about "Paul's Return" which will commend it to the public, and provide a suitable compensation for incidents that are commonplace and hackneyed. There is obviously no novelty in a guardian who, to preserve his own name and reputation, appropriates the fortune of his ward, end little freshness in the handsome adventurer, whether from California or elsewhere, who returns in time to see that justice is done to the injured damsel, and to save the family reputation. The characters are, however, deftly contrasted, and the language, although copious, is generally respectable. More than this cannot well be said.

snippet: Letter to District Attorney on Bogus Proclamation Newspaper Seizures
lead_paragraph: -- If Gov. SEYMOUR had left out all of his letter to the District-Attorney, excepting the opening paragraph and the closing one, it would have subserved his professed purpose equally well as in its present shape, and would have been far more creditable to his common sense. He has, it seems, been advised of the seizure of the two newspaper offices which published the forged proclamation -- has seen it charged that this was done without due legal process; and he calls upon the District-Attorney to look into the facts -- informs him that "if the acts were illegal, the offenders must be punished" -- authorizes him to call upon the Sheriff or police for any needed assistance in making inquiries and in prosecuting the parties implicated, and says that the failure to give this by any official under his (the Governor's) control, will be deemed a sufficient cause for removal.
headline: {'main': "SEYMOUR'S NONSENSE.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "SEYMOUR'S NONSENSE.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate yesterday Mr. JOHNSON introduced a bill to aid in the construction of a railroad and telegraph line from Lake Superior to Puget Sound, which was referred to the Committee on Public Lands. The Committee on Finance reported favorably on the House bill to punish and prevent the counterfeiting of coin in the United States. The Brazil Mail Steamship Bill was passed by a vote of 21 yeas, against 14 nays. The bill to appoint additional Inspectors of Steamboats was taken up. After an amendment had been offered by Mr. CHANDLER, the bill was passed. The Internal Revenue Bill was taken up and argued at length.

abstract: Iron-clad Navy, Our
snippet: Iron-clad Navy, Our
lead_paragraph: While England and France are expending their resources upon a variety of iron-clad vessels, and are producing such ships as the Solferino, which is officially reported to have gone fourteen knots an hour at sea, fully armed and equipped for service, the United States is building only one class of vessels, familiarly known as "Monitors," excepting only the Ironsides, which seems to be the best iron-clad at Charleston, and the Dunderberg, not yet launched. The distinction between the English and French plans and ours, consists in this, that their vessels are generally similar to ordinary ships, and are, therefore, habitable by men as ordinary ships, whereas our iron-clads rise above water only about two feet or less, and confine their crews in a closed box, which is not very agreeable at any time, and from which, when the vessel sinks, as one did at Charleston, riding at anchor, but few can escape out of the contracted openings allowable through their decks.
headline: {'main': 'Our Iron-Clad Navy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Iron-Clad Navy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- One of our cotemporaries the other day censured the press for publishing so many particulars about the battles and army movements, saying that the Government was greatly embarrassed and the success of our cause put in serious jeopardy thereby. It suggested that the press should abstain wholly from giving details of tactical movements on the field, even after the battle was over, and content itself with reporting incidents, of which thousand are constantly occurring, of great interest, but of no public military importance.

abstract: -- Mayor A.M. WOOD received a telegraphic dispatch from Washington, yesterday afternoon, stating that the Fourteenth Regiment, whose three years' term had expired on the 21d instant, had arrived from the front, and took the cars for home. They will arrive in Jersey City, this morning, where they will be provided with breakfast by the Brooklyn authorities, after which they will be escorted to this City. The Board of Aldermen, the military authorities and firemen, held meetings last evening, and resolved to turn out in force, and give the veterans a reception worthy of the name and fame they gained on many a hard-fought battle-field. They will probably arrive in Brooklyn, about 10 o'clock A.M.
lead_paragraph: -- Mayor A.M. abstract: the Rioter, Conviction of
snippet: the Rioter, Conviction of
lead_paragraph: -- The case of JOHN W. ANDREWS was yesterday tried in the United States Circuit Court before Judge NELSON, and resulted in the conviction of the accused, and his sentence to three years imprisonment in the State Penitentiary, exclusive of the term he has already undergone since his arrest. From the report of the trial it will be seen that the District-Attorney waived the count in the indictment charging ANDREWS with treason, and took up the charge of "conspiring to levy war against the United States, and resisting the execution of the United States laws." Of the six witnesses called to establish this charge, two (the Provost-Marshals of the Eighth and Ninth Districts,) gave no evidence whatever respecting ANDREWS; one witness was unable to identify the prisoner, and the remaining three testify exclusively to the fact of having seen and heard ANDREWS inciting the mob to resist the draft, to burn Government property, and to sack certain obnoxious newspaper offices. There is nothing whatever in the evidence relating to conspiracy. He appears on the scene, so far as the witnesses can tell us, while the crime was in course of perpetration, and not while it was being hatched. On the latter part of the count, therefore, the conviction must have been made to turn; and as the law determines that, "when a felony has been committed in pursuance of a conspiracy, the latter merged in the former," we presume that the conviction would be found in any case to bear the strictest judicial revision, as being sufficiently in harmony with the evidence offered. The sentence of the court is lenient; but, we presume it is severe enough to mark the sense of the community on the nature of the crime, and to offer a warning to the heedless or the designing, who, in times of peril like these, venture to resist the laws or defy the Government.

abstract: -- The death of Mr. JOHN ELLIOT, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, was reported yesterday by Capt. SPEIGHT at Police Headquarters. During the July riots deceased was so seriously injured that he has since been unable to do patrol duty. He had been connected with the Department for the last three years, during which time he has been an efficient officer.

abstract: French Government from the beginning; that I had always represented to the Government here, that any action upon their part interfering with the form of government in Mexico, would be looked upon with dissatisfaction in our country, and they could not expect us to be in haste to acknowledge a Monarchical Government built upon the foundation of a Republic which was our next neighbor; that I had reason to believe you had held the name language to the French Minister in the United States. This allegation he did not deny, but obviously received the resolutions in question as a serious step on our part; and I am told that the leading Secessionists here build largely upon these resolutions as a means of fomenting ill feeling between this country and some others and ourselves. Mr. MASON and his Secretary have gone to Brussels, to confer with Mr. DUDLEY MANN, who is their Commissioner at that place. Mr. SLIDELL, it is said, was to have gone to Austria, although he has not yet got off.

abstract: Thirty-fifth Anniversary
snippet: Thirty-fifth Anniversary
lead_paragraph: The thirty-fifth anniversary of the Brooklyn Sunday-schools was celebrated Tuesday, with exercises at the different churches, processions and feasting. The morning was unfavorable, and a portion of the proceedings were on the point of being abandoned, but toward noon the rain ceased, and the children repaired to their different school-houses, where they were joined in line and marched to the churches designated. The exercises were similar everywhere. The children commenced by singing:

abstract: Failures of Civilian Generals; Failure of Civilian Generals; West Point Education Vindicated
snippet: Failures of Civilian Generals; Failure of Civilian Generals; West Point Education Vindicated
lead_paragraph: In our recent exposition of the almost universal failure of civilian Commanders in this war, we reserved judgment upon Major-Gen. SIGEL and Major-Gen. BUTLER, preferring to await the issues of the important enterprises in which they were then engaged. The results have now been developed. They are of a character to round off completely a demonstration that all of our Commanders, without a regular military education, are incapable.

abstract: Grant's Army, Strength of
snippet: Grant's Army, Strength of
lead_paragraph: The latest intelligence from Gen. GRANT is up to one o'clock on Tuesday afternoon, at which time his headquarters were at Mount Carmel Church, and he says in his dispatch to Secretary STANTON that although his troops are much fatigued, he "will reach the South Anna by nightfall." This is very remarkable as well as important progress. It shows that the rebels have made a precipitate retreat, and Gen. GRANT is already in possession of both the Richmond and Fredericksburg and the Virginia Central Railroads, for if our army is on the South Anna, it is certainly in possession of Sexton's Junction, which is five miles north of that river. In the operations of Monday, Gen. GRANT captured one thousand prisoners, with slight loss on our side.

abstract: WORTH AT GENESEO.--The remains of Brig.-Gen. J.S. WADSWORTH arrived at his native town, via the Erie and A.G. and Mt. Morris Railroads, at 11 A.M., on Saturday morning last. They were wrapped in the American flag, and accompanied by Messrs. FENTON, FRANK, MORRIS and WINFIELD, of the Congressional delegation, Major J.T. SPRAGUE, State Adjutant-Gen- ...
lead_paragraph: WORTH AT GENESEO. -- The remains of Brig.-Gen. J.S. WADSWORTH arrived at his native town, via the Erie and A.G. and Mt. Morris Railroads, at 11 A.M., on Saturday morning last. They were wrapped in the American flag, and accompanied by Messrs. FENTON, FRANK, MORRIS and WINFIELD, of the Congressional delegation, Major J.T. SPRAGUE, State Adjutant-General, and one orderly and six soldiers detailed by Major-Gen. AUGUR, Capt. M. RITCHIE, D.H. FITZHUGH, Jr., of New-York, and others. The remains were immediately conveyed to his late residence in the north part of the village. At 1 P.M. a special train arrived, bringing a detachment of seventy-five veterans of the Twenty-first Regiment New-York State Volunteers, Col. RODGERS, who fought at the first battle at Bull Run, and the fine regimental cornet band from Buffalo, a few gentlemen from that city and a large and respectable delegation from Rochester. The funeral was held at St. Michael's Church, at 2 P.M., when the beautiful and impressive funeral service of the Episcopal Church was eloquently read by the Rector, Rev. WM. IRISH. The remains were deposited in the family burial ground of Temple Hill Cemetery, with the graves of his ancestors and relatives, where repose his grandmother, father, mother, uncle, brother and one sister.

abstract: Piracy; Georgia, the, Admission to the Mersey, and British Govt.
snippet: Piracy; Georgia, the, Admission to the Mersey, and British Govt.
lead_paragraph: -- The opposition offered by the Palmerston Government to Mr. BARING's motion in the House of Commons, relative to the admission of the pirate Georgia into the Mersey, presents no new principle in the policy heretofore pursued by Lord RUSSELL. The bona fides of Mr. BARING in bringing forward the case for Parliamentary discussion, is probably not open to question. But there have been numerous occasions, in the earlier stages of the war, when such a motion might have been offered with more practical effect. The Alabama, for instance, not only provisioning and refitting at the Cape, but actually taking a captured prize there for outfit as a pirate, offered a far more flagrant case for protest than the reappearance of the Georgia in the Mersey. And we must also remind our readers that on all party questions proper in the House of Commons, Mr. BARING's vote goes to sustain those political leaders who defend and applaud the LAIRDS -- the very head and front of the pirate interest in England. It will be cheerfully admitted that Mr. BARING, as a private member of Parliament, has been careful not to follow his party into the slough of rebel intrigue which surrounds the Carleton Club. But were Mr. BARING's party leaders in power, the "neutrality" of England, dubious and uncertain as it may sometimes be called now, would be shortly found to relax in favor of the rebels to an extent that would render war with this country all but an assured result. Mr. COBDEN naturally takes ground with Mr. BARING on the side of international equity; but Mr. COBDEN would barely venture to give a vote, however much in accordance with his conviction of what is due to this country, that might lead to an immediate overthrow of the men now in power. Low as may be his estimate of Lord RUSSELL's neutrality views, Mr. COBDEN knows too much to invite a party coup d'etat which would restore MALMESBURY to the Foreign Office and DERBY, to the Treasury. The position, then, as far as American interests are concerned, seems to give no immediate token of a change either in national policy or party leadership.

abstract: We conversed a day or two since with a gentleman who is connected with the Refugee Commission of Louisville, Ky., from whom we learned that this organization is in pressing need of assistance in the prosecution of its labors.
lead_paragraph: We conversed a day or two since with a gentleman who is connected with the Refugee Commission of Louisville, Ky., from whom we learned that this organization is in pressing need of assistance in the prosecution of its labors. The object of the commission, as its name indicates, is to extend aid and comfort to those persons who seek refuge within our lines from the tyranny and distress prevailing in the rebel States. These refugees are counted by hundreds and thousands, and are generally in a condition of pitiable destitution. Many of them were prosperous and even wealthy before their noble and unswerving fidelity to the old flag drew down upon them the merciless vengeance of their rebel neighbors. Stripped of their property, driven from their homes, subjected to every species of persecution which rebel hatred could invent, they have made their way, as best they might, to seek the protection of the flag for which they have sacrificed everything but honor. Many who have been assisted by the Refugee Commission have had an experience of rebel cruelty, the mere recital of which sends a cold shudder to the heart. A lady, who, with her daughter, escaped from Southern Kentucky, said that her little boy, only 14 years old, was tied to a tree by a guerrilla band and shot at as a target, while his mother and sister were compelled to look on. An old man, of more than eighty years, who fought bravely during the last war with England, was taken by rebels, his hands tied behind his back and his feet tied together. He was then placed in a chair in front of the fire-place, with his feet resting on hot embers, which had been raked out upon the hearth. In this position he was left, utterly unable to move; and when, after a lapse of time, he was discovered by a neighbor, the bottoms of his feet were already burned to the bone!

abstract: Last hours of
snippet: Last hours of
lead_paragraph: From a long obituary of STUART -- whom the rebels call the "flower of Cavaliers" -- in the Richmond Examiner, we clip as follows: "No incident of mortality, since the fall of the great JACKSON, has occasioned more painful regret than this. Major-Gen. J.E.B. STUART, the model of Virginian cavaliers and dashing chieftain, whose name was a terror to the enemy, and familiar as a household word in two continents, is dead, struck down by a bullet from the dastardly foe, and the whole Confederacy mourns him. He breathed out his gallant spirit resignedly, and in the full possession of all his remarkable faculties of mind and body, at twenty-two minutes to 8 o'clock, Thursday night, at the residence of Dr. BREWER, a relative, on Green-street, in the presence of Drs. BREWER, GARNETT, GIBSON and FONTAINE, of the General's staff, Rev. Messrs. PETERKIN and KEPPLER, and a circle of sorrow-stricken comrades and friends.

abstract: The Conference met again in London on the 12th inst.  The Daily News says that the Conference approached the question of the political future of the Duchies. The discussion which took place, however, did scarcely more than make evident the immense divergence of the views of the several Powers, and the difficulties which would attend the arrangement of acceptable terms of peace.  After sitting three hours the Conference adjourned till the 10th day of May.

abstract: The battle near Drury's Bluff was imperfectly appreciated in Richmond till yesterday. It was, during the time it lasted, one of the most terrific combats that has been known. Confederate valor never had a more splendid illustration. The nerve of SMITH of BUTLER'S large army was concentrated on the hills, behind heavy fortifications, which they had strengthened with all the appliances of unlimited labor and inexhaustible ingenuity.
lead_paragraph: The battle near Drury's Bluff was imperfectly appreciated in Richmond till yesterday. It was, during the time it lasted, one of the most terrific combats that has been known. Confederate valor never had a more splendid illustration. The nerve of SMITH of BUTLER's large army was concentrated on the hills, behind heavy fortifications, which they had strengthened with all the appliances of unlimited labor and inexhaustible ingenuity. A world in arms would not have moved BEAUREGARD from such a place. The vast army of GRANT has been lately broken on some hasty breastworks, thrown up in a night by LEE's troops, with their bayonets and tin cans. But a small force of brave Southern men moved on those forts, not in a drunken rush, but with the steady, Spartan step of true discipline and inflexible resolution, and went, through the blaze of ten thousand guns, straight to their mark.

abstract: Speech at Charlottesville
snippet: Speech at Charlottesville
lead_paragraph: No more preposterous exhibition has been seen in the course of this war than the town of Charlottesville beheld the other day on the arrival of those two Yankee Brigadier-Generals who had been captured in the night attack by GORDON's brigade in the Wilderness. The two worthies are named SHALER and SEYMOUR; the former has visited Richmond before, in his capacity of captain of a company in the New-York "Seventh," when that dandy regiment of Gotham cockneys was entertained here on the occasion of the MONROE funeral obsequies. At that time, coming as a friend and (in some sense) compatriot, he and his comrades were received with all the cordial, unsuspicious hospitality of Virginia. Now, advancing with his crew of cut-throats and fire-raisers, to burn and sack the city in which he had been an honored though unworthy guest, he experienced Virginia's of other style of receiving visitors, and will have the opportunity of comparing the Libby with the Ballard. This SHALER, however, has at least kept himself quiet, and has in silence laid up all these things in his mind and pondered them in his heart.

abstract: As a French Dependency; M. Dallozz's Speech; Dalloz, M., Speech on French Protectorate of Mexico
snippet: As a French Dependency; M. Dallozz's Speech; Dalloz, M., Speech on French Protectorate of Mexico
lead_paragraph: The spokesmen of the Imperial Government in the French Legislative body, do not even attempt to conceal the fact that Mexico is hereafter to be regarded as a permanent appanage or dependency of France. During the debate on the budget on the 10th inst., this view of the situation was brought out with a directness and force which is really instructive. M. DALLOZ, for instance, speaking for the Emperor's Government, elaborates a lengthy statement of the commercial advantages which will accrue to Europe from the substitution of French influence in Mexico for that of the United States. The effect of the partiality shown for this country by the Liberal party of the Mexican Republic is, he thinks, partly seen in the fact that for eighty French merchant ships touching at the chief Mexican ports, there have been five hundred vessels of the United States. From this day forth, however, he says, "France will protect European commerce," which probably means -- if it means anything -- that the reactionary party, under French direction, will foster commercial intercourse with France, as against the Anti-European commercial policy of the late Juarez Government. M. DALLOZ, too, sees an ample justification for the French protectorate thus far, in the fact that there are in Mexico over 200,000 Frenchmen -- which includes, he might have added, the French army of occupation, and the army of functionaries sent over by the Emperor -- and he finds a recompense for the pecuniary burdens consequent on that protectorate, in the apocryphal statement that "while California is sending, on an average, 160,000,000 francs in bullion yearly to New-York, and while double this amount may be obtained from Mexico, France and England have allowed the United States to appropriate to themselves that inexhaustible bank."
headline: {'main': 'Mexico as a Dependency.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Mexico as a Dependency.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Grant's Campaign
snippet: Grant's Campaign
lead_paragraph: GRANT's campaign the past week has been, to the attentive observer, of the most fascinating and all-absorbing interest. There has been but little of the coarser work of war, and the fighting that has occurred has been but incidental. The operations have been in the very highest ranges of intellect and strategy. We have seen those two great masters of the art of war -- GRANT and LEE -- these two soldiers, each of whom has been, in other days, the victor in half a dozen great fields, combating with each other after a style which, though not accompanied by thunder and smoke, and the flash of steel and the flow of blood, has yet displayed no less valor, and has certainly been great in achievement. The immense masses of men which each of them has moved have been handled as great mechanical forces, out of which genius evolves mighty results, and by means of which it will solve the greatest national problems.

abstract: By the steamship Eagle, which arrived at this port yesterday, we have a summary of the latest Mexican news, which includes a record of alleged atrocities by the Juarez guerrillas, of the progress of railway enterprise, the preparation for the reception of the new Emperor, the resistance still offered to French rule, the conversions ...
lead_paragraph: By the steamship Eagle, which arrived at this port yesterday, we have a summary of the latest Mexican news, which includes a record of alleged atrocities by the Juarez guerrillas, of the progress of railway enterprise, the preparation for the reception of the new Emperor, the resistance still offered to French rule, the conversions made to the Franco-Mexican cause; besides rumors of the surrender of VIDAURRI's private Secretary, by United States troops in Texas, to the Mexican authorities, and the conviction and condemnation of a Vice-Consul of the United States. The latter story is given in a very indefinite form, and probably has no foundation. We have also news from San Domingo, which says that Spain is preparing to send 30,000 troops to the island, to quell the insurrection at once and forever. ARGUELLES had arrived at Havana.
