abstract: We hope that if there is any likelihood that large reinforcements will be required for GRANT's army, either before the campaign is over or when it is about to close, measures will be taken to raise them now, and not next August or September. It must not be forgotten that we have entered on this campaign just as we have entered on all the others, without any reserve. Our whole army is in the field, actively engaged with the enemy, and we have no body of trained men to draw on to fill up the gaps made by battle or disease. As we have often said before, no nation in the world has ever carried on war in this way before. It is in the highest degree reckless and wasteful, and exposes us, every time a battle is fought, to the most terrible risks; and we certainly should long ere this have paid the penalty of our rashness, but for the fact that the nature of the country renders all our actions indecisive.

abstract: Message on the House Resolution on Mexico; The U. S. House Resolution and the President
snippet: Message on the House Resolution on Mexico; The U. S. House Resolution and the President
lead_paragraph: The Message which the President has sent to the House, (published by us yesterday,) communicating the representations made to the French Government touching the joint resolution passed last month by the House, on the French-Mexican question, demands the calmest attention of all men who have at heart the avoidance of foreign war, and the conquest of the rebellion. The course of the Government has been preeminently wise; yet factionists throughout the land, doubtless, will seek to take advantage of it precisely as they did of the settlement of the Trent difficulty. But in this instance, as in every other, faction is impotent before the sober sense of the people.

abstract: The  proportion of the new National Bank Notes to the general currency of the country, thus far issued, is small; but it is known that already a select few of our City Banks are disposed to give their own dealers annoyance by refusing them on current deposit.
lead_paragraph: -- The proportion of the new National Bank Notes to the general currency of the country, thus far issued, is small; but it is known that already a select few of our City Banks are disposed to give their own dealers annoyance by refusing them on current deposit. This feeling is indulged more in antagonism to the Government that has established, as part and parcel of its own financial machinery as well as to secure a uniform Bank currency for the People, the National Banking Law, than from any hope of seriously damaging the system itself.

abstract: Fiske, Rev. S., author of Dunn Browne Papers
snippet: Fiske, Rev. S., author of Dunn Browne Papers
lead_paragraph: Some years ago there appeared in the Springfield Republican a series of letters from Europe, signed by "Dunn Browne," which were widely copied and much admired for their sprightly vivacity. They ware from the pen of Mr. SAMUEL FISKE, a graduate of Amherst College, in the class of 1848, and the author of a well-known college text-book, a translation of ESCHENBERG's Manual of Greek and Roman Antiquities. Mr. FISKE was a clergyman, settled at Madison, Conn., when the war broke out; but he left the pulpit for the field, and dropped the "reverend" for a Lieutenant's title. After fighting bravely in the several battles, he was taken prisoner by the rebels, and detained for some time in Richmond. During the battle of the Wilderness, Captain -- for he was promoted from a Lieutenancy -- FISKE was mortally wounded. He was conveyed to Fredericksburgh, where, in a private house, he received the attention of personal friends, and of his wife and other members of his family. His death has taken from the Union ranks a brave, intelligent officer; from literary circles, a lively, versatile writer, and from the newspaper world, an admirable "war correspondent."

abstract: The new  conscription bill is reported in the Senate minus the $300 exemption clause. The proposed amendment, however, does not interfere with the right heretofore extended to drafted persons to furnish substitutes.
lead_paragraph: -- The new conscription bill is reported in the Senate minus the $300 exemption clause. The proposed amendment, however, does not interfere with the right heretofore extended to drafted persons to furnish substitutes. Viewed from the stand-point of military exigency, the new provision is justified on the theory that the commutation fee is altogether disproportionate to the value of a recruit ready found; and chiefly so, in taking into account the great element of time. For, those who do not choose to serve personally in the field become active and interested recruiting agents; and if the draft fails to bring the required number of men instantaneously into the field, it will bring at once to the aid of the War Department an army of recruiting agents bound (for good and sufficient personal reasons) to make the work go through.
headline: {'main': 'THE NEW CONSCRIPTION BILL.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE NEW CONSCRIPTION BILL.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Fourteenth was expected to arrive in Brooklyn Wednesday morning about 10 o'olock, but in consequence of delay at Baltimore in procuring transportation, they did not leave that City before 5  o'clock the same morning.
lead_paragraph: The Fourteenth was expected to arrive in Brooklyn Wednesday morning about 10 o'clock, but in consequence of delay at Baltimore in procuring transportation, they did not leave that City before 5 1/2 o'clock the same morning. Having expected to start the night previous, every preparation had been made to receive them, and from an early hour, thousands of persons thronged Fulton-street from the City Hall to the ferry. After waiting until nearly noon, a dispatch was made public to the effect that they would not reach Jersey City, before 8 o'clock P.M. The crowd then gradually dispersed. Toward evening the streets along the line of march as designated by the Common Council Committee, again became thronged. The City Hall Park, Fulton Ferry, and Washington Park, were the points of greatest interest, it having been announced that the regiment would be dismissed at the latter place.

abstract: The latest intelligence from Gen. GRANT is embodied in a dispatch from Gen. GRANT, dated Wednesday morning, in which he says the rebels appear to be concentrated in a strong position between the North and South Anna Rivers.
lead_paragraph: The latest intelligence from Gen. GRANT is embodied in a dispatch from Gen. GRANT, dated Wednesday morning, in which he says the rebels appear to be concentrated in a strong position between the North and South Anna Rivers. The previous intelligence from Gen. GRANT indicated that LEE had crossed the South Anna, as Gen. GRANT said on Tuesday that his army "would probably reach that river by nightfall." But it appears that the rebels were discovered in their new and strong position, which undoubtedly covers Sexton's Junction, with their right resting on Little Swamp, and their left on Little River, a rapid rugged stream. Thus situated they can again make a strong resistance to GRANT's advance, though there is no reason why the position cannot be readily flanked. The Secretary of War says Gen. GRANT was prosecuting operations for the development of the enemy's intentions. Fredericksburgh and Aquia Greek are by this time abandoned as bases of supplies.

abstract: Retreat Toward Richmond
snippet: Retreat Toward Richmond
lead_paragraph: There is, as usual with our excitable public on such occasions, the highest exultation over the retreat of Gen. LEE, and the feeling is somewhat shared by the Secretary of War, if we might judge from yesterday's dispatches. A calm observation of the campaign will, we believe, somewhat modify these high hopes, and yet give us ground to believe in a successful result, at a later period.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen met yesterday. Mr. OPDYKE introduced a resolution, which was referred to the Committee on Railroads, to change the grant to the Harlem Railroad Company to run short cars from Thirty-second to Forty-second-street, by providing that they shall pass through the tunnel, instead of going over the surface of the street.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen met yesterday. Mr. OPDYKE introduced a resolution, which was referred to the Committee on Railroads, to change the grant to the Harlem Railroad Company to run short cars from Thirty-second to Forty-second-street, by providing that they shall pass through the tunnel, instead of going over the surface of the street. Resolutions were adopted increasing the pay of all Inspectors of Pavement, paying in the Croton Department, and the Inspectors of Lamps in the Street Department, from $2 to $2 50 per day. The Street Commissioner replied to a resolution of inquiry that he is at a loss to make suggestions for the improvement of travel in Broadway, between Pine-street and Maiden-lane, but gives the plans heretofore discussed, such as dismissing the omnibuses from and establishing a railway in Broadway, widening Nassau-street, widening Church-street, &c., for information in the matter. He also reported to the board that the Erie Railroad Company have no authority for constructing sheds on the piers between Chambers and Rea[???] streets, North River. Both communications were referred. The Comptroller reported a balance of $1,767,369 06 in the City Treasury on the 21st inst. Adjourned to 2 o'clock P.M. next Monday.

abstract: and the Washington Newsboys
snippet: and the Washington Newsboys
lead_paragraph: Mr. JAMES BROOKS proposes to have the Washington newsboys taught the Magna Charta, "not only in English, but in the original Latin," and proposes to have it posted on the Capitol walls in "Latin, Saxon, English and all other languages." In addition to this, he desires to have the newsboys "educated under the Petition of Right, and the principles of the common law affecting human liberty." We have no objection in the world to having the newsboys taught the Magna Charta, and having it posted on the Capitol in "Latin, Saxon, English," and as many other languages as Mr. BROOKS and his confederates may think desirable, provided it is not done at the expense of the public. If it is considered by the Democratic party desirable that a knowledge of the Magna Charta should be more widely diffused, we would suggest that a ready way of attaining the object would be to circulate copies of it this Summer as a campaign document. This would, doubtless, be very damaging to the Administration, particularly the Latin and Saxon versions of it. Nor would we, were we in the place of the Democratic leaders, stop here. There are a variety of other documents which would, if judiciously distributed, cause Mr. LINCOLN's knees to shake with apprehension. The Saxon Chronicle, the Annals of the Four Masters, the Proclamation of Henry III., the Year Books, the State Trials, the Pragmatic Sanction, and the Edict of Nantes, are not half as well known, either to the newsboys or the rest of the community, as they ought to be; and the Democratic party will render the public an immense service by striking off a million copies or thereabouts of each of them, and selling them cheap or distributing them gratuitously this Summer.
headline: {'main': 'News for the Newsboys.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'News for the Newsboys.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A BOUNTY BROKER SHOT. -- MALCOLM WALLACE and MICHAEL HANORAN, bounty brokers, doing business at No. 14 State-street, became involved in a quarrel, yesterday, at their place of business, during which HANORAN drew a revolver and shot WALLACE in the arm, inflicting a serious wound. The latter was taken to the New-York Hospital, and the other was arrested and committed to the Tombs to await the result of the wounded man's injuries.

lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Douglass' Letter on Cleveland Convention
snippet: Douglass' Letter on Cleveland Convention
lead_paragraph: SIR: I mean the complete abolition of every vestige, form and modification of Slavery in every part of the United States, perfect equality for the black man in every State before the law, in the jury-box, at the ballot-box and on the battle-field; ample and salutary retaliation for every instance of enslavement or slaughter of prisoners of any color. I mean that in the distribution of offices and honors under this Government no discrimination shall be made in favor of or against any class of citizens, whether black or white, of native or foreign birth. And supposing that the convention which is to meet at Cleveland means the same thing, I cheerfully give my name as one of the signers of the call.

abstract: Giddings, Hon. J. R.
snippet: Giddings, Hon. J. R.
lead_paragraph: Hon. JOSHUA R. GIDDINGS, Consul-General of the United States at Montreal, died suddenly at that city, at 10 o'clock yeterday evening. He was born at Athens, Penn., Oct. 6, 1795, but removed to Ohio when ten years of age. He served as a soldier in the war of 1812, when but 17 years of age. After the close of the war he studied law with Hon. ELISHA WHITTLESEY, and was admitted to the bar in 1820. He was a member of the Legislature of the State of Ohio in 1826, and in 1838 was elected to Congress as the successor of Mr. WHITTLESEY; here he was distinguished for his steady and determined opposition to Slavery and the Slave-trade. In 1841 an American vessel, the Creole, sailed from Virginia for New-Orleans with a cargo of 130 slaves; during the passage a revolt occurred, in which the slaves killed one man, took possession of the vessel, and entered the British port of Nassau. On the 21st of March, 1843, Mr. GIDDINGS offered in Congress a series of resolutions, declaring that Slavery was an abridgment of natural right, that the slaves in the Creole had violated no law of the United States in regaining their personal liberty, and that they were not legally liable to punishment. These resolutions brought down upon him the displeasure of the House, who, by a vote, severely condemned his conduct. Mr. GIDDINGS then instantly resigned his seat, but was immediately reelected, and resumed his seat, after an absence of only six weeks. His whole period of service in Congress was twenty-one years. He was a strong supporter of Gen. HARRISON and HENRY CLAY, but on Anti-Slavery grounds refused to support Gen. TAYLOR. In 1850 he was conspicuous for his opposition to the enactment of the "compromise measures," especially the Fugitive Slave Law. In 1843 he wrote a series of political essays, signed "Pacificus," and in 1858 ho compiled The Exiles of Florida. A volume of his speeches in Congress has also been published.
headline: {'main': 'OBITUARY.; Death of Hon. Joshua R. Giddings.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'OBITUARY.; Death of Hon. Joshua R. Giddings.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We print Admiral PORTER's official, as well as spirited and enthusiastic report, of the means by which his large and powerful fleet of iron-clads and gunboats, was safely brought from out of the tribulations of Red River. The report will be found very instructive; and it is striking evidence of what one energetic, practical man can do, when not hampered by official red-tape and etiquette. Lieut.-Col. BAILEY, the engineer to whom Admiral PORTER feelingly ascribes the chief praise of the successful extrication of the fleet, is a Wisconsin man, attached to the Fourth Wisconsin Cavalry, (late infantry,) and before the war was a Wisconsin lumberman. In this capacity he gained that practical knowledge of navigating shallow, crooked and difficult streams which has proved of such great importance in this case. He went into the war as captain of a company of lumbermen, whose athletic forms were the attraction of the regiment and whose reliability has never failed. The regiment was commanded at first by Col. HALBERT E. PAINE, now Brigadier-General, who lost a leg at Port Hudson, then by Col. S.A. BEAN, who was killed at Port Hudson, and latterly by Col. F.A. BOARDMAN, who was recently killed in a skirmish near Baton Rouge, and Lieut.-Col. BAILEY will now succeed to its command. Admiral PORTER truly says that the highest honors the Government could confer would not be too great for the services he has rendered his country.

lead_paragraph: Some of our cotemporaries, both in this City, in Cincinnati, and elsewhere, have been greatly exercised about a few remarks that lately appeared in this journal concerning the armature, armament, draft, and sailing qualities of the American-built iron-plated frigate Re d'Italia. They said that her remarkable voyage from New-York to Naples was no test of her speed -- that she carried the bulk of her iron-plating in her hold instead of on her sides -- and that if she had had the weight of her guns aboard, it would have made a very great difference.

abstract: Substitutes, the Law on; New-York, Hunter Murder Trial Commenced
snippet: Substitutes, the Law on; New-York, Hunter Murder Trial Commenced
lead_paragraph: As the enrollment in this City in anticipation of a new call is now being made, it is well that all liable to be drafted should understand what is for their interest. The disposition evinced by some to give the names of only a part of those residing in their dwellings tends to increase the liability of the others to draft, for the fewer the number to draft from, the less the chances of escape. It is also for the interest of all concerned to see that errors in names and addresses are corrected. A misapprehension seems to exist in the minds of some persons that by misrepresentation regarding their places of residence, they can avoid the vigilance of the officers. This is a mistake. The strictest measures have been adopted to ascertain the true address of every person enrolled; and in order to do this a system of correspondence has been perfected by means of which the residence of every man can be ascertained.

abstract: Allen's, John, Engravings, Books,>amp;c.
snippet: Allen's, John, Engravings, Books,>amp;c.
lead_paragraph: -- The auction sale of Mr. JOHN ALLAN's library and collection of engravings, coins, &c., has occupied the evenings of the last two weeks, commencing with May 2, at the auction rooms of Messrs. BANGS, MERWIN & CO., Broadway. In respect to the curiosity of the collection, and the prices realized by many of the important articles, it is by far the most noticeable event in the annals of bibliomania that has ever occurred on this continent. So extraordinary was the demand for many of the rarer books, that all the old ideas of value seemed completely subverted, and a perfect recklessness appeared to reign among the buyers as to the sums they might have to expend in securing some cherished memento of this famous sale. We write while yet there are three more evenings' work to be done, so that it is impossible to give the precise amount; but it is certain that the sum total of the sale will be more than forty thousand dollars, a result quite unparalleled as the produce of any private literary collection in America. As was betiting, in this great City, the two highest lots were connected with New-York. One of them -- a letter of Gen. WASHINGTON, in answer to the notification that the Freedom of the City had been presented to him by the Common Council of New-York, in 1785 -- sold for the astounding sum of two thousand two hundred and fifty dollars, after a brisk competition, mostly between two parties, who acted as agents for the real buyers. It was written on a single foolscap sheet of paper, in good preservation, and, a few years since, would have been thought well sold at $50. The other, and next highest lot, was a copy of "Knickerbocker's History of New-York," extended to folio size, and illustrated by the insertion of nearly three hundred plates, mostly of the Dutch and Flemish schools. This sold for twelve hundred and fifty dollars. The odd $250 would be a liberal estimate of its cost and ordinary commercial value. A copy of ELIOT's Indian version of the Bible, printed at Cambridge, Massachusetts, brought $825. It had been so long in the late owner's possession that he had no recollection of its original cost, but it probably was not over $5. The last copy sold here was in Mr. CORWIN's library, 1858; it brought $210. The first edition of ROBERT BURNS' Poems, published at Kilmarnock, in Scotland, and usually worth in England about three guineas, sold for $120. A small vellum manuscript missal, bought from PAYNE & FOSS, the famous London booksellers for fifteen guineas, sold for $400 to one of our most distinguished and enthusiastic young book collectors. A copy of DIBGINS' "Bibliomania," extended to quarto size, bound in two volumes and illustrated with portraits, and prints inserted, brought $700. It came from the library of the late ITHIEL TOWN, the architect, and had cost him thirty pounds sterling. These are only a few samples of the prices realized. Most of the illustrated books, indeed, went in a similar proportion. As is the case in every large sale, many books sold considerably below their cost, and bargains were to be obtained by those familiar with the real value of books; but anything that attracted the untempered zeal without knowledge of our wealthy book buyers, and provoked competition among them, ran up immediately to sums that would formerly have been considered perfectly fabulous.

abstract: Hare vs. Steamships Maryland and New World; Collision; Laing vs. Brigantine G. L. Buckman; Collision
snippet: Hare vs. Steamships Maryland and New World; Collision; Laing vs. Brigantine G. L. Buckman; Collision
lead_paragraph: Joseph Laing vs. The Brigantine G.L.Buckman. -- This was libel filed by the owner of the British bark Water Lilly to recover the damages occasioned to her by being run into by the brigantine on the night of Jan. 21, 1864. The bark had come in over the bar at Sandy Hook in charge of a pilot and anchored in the channel. The brigantine came in during the night without a pilot, and ran into the bark while lying at anchor. The bark had lights set and burning in her rigging, and an anchor-watch on deck. The evidence for the libelant was, that the night was clear and bright moonlight, and that vessels could be seen at anchor three miles off. The evidence for the brigantine was directly contradictory on these points. The master and mate of each vessel were examined. The master of the brigantine was also part owner.

abstract: Citizens of the United States, who mean to uphold the Union, who believe that the rebellion can be suppressed without infringing the rights of individual or State, who regard the extinction of Slavery as among the practical effects of the war for the Union, and favor an amendment of the Federal Constitution for the exclusion of Slavery, and who demand integrity and economy in the administration of Government, are respectfully invited to meet in Mass Convention, at Cleveland, on Tuesday, the 31st day of May inst., for consultation and concert of action in respect to the approaching Presidential election.

abstract: Movements for President Lincoln; And Support by Union State Conventions
snippet: Movements for President Lincoln; And Support by Union State Conventions
lead_paragraph: The great States of New-York, Ohio, and Illinois have just held their Union State Conventions, and have all unanimously declared for the renomination of President LINCOLN. This action completes the committal of the Union party through all the loyal States, save Missouri, to the policy of making no change in the Executive chair. It is now made certain that the National Convention will be substantially a unit on this momentous question. ABRAHAM LINCOLN will be renominated by acclamation.

abstract: Advices from New-Orleans to the 21st inst., via Cairo, mention the arrival of the steamer St. Mary's from Mexico, with 150 refugees, and reports that a heavy battle had taken place between the French and Mexicans, in which the French were thoroughly defeated.
lead_paragraph: Advices from New-Orleans to the 21st inst., via Cairo, mention the arrival of the steamer St. Mary's from Mexico, with 150 refugees, and reports that a heavy battle had taken place between the French and Mexicans, in which the French were thoroughly defeated. The Mexican Consul has, however, received no intelligence of the victory, and it is, probably, like all the other stories of the same kind emanating from Mexican sources -- untrue.

abstract: The latest intelligence from Gen. GRANT is that published yesterday morning, which was up to 8 A.M. of Thursday, at which time Gen. GRANT was making important movements, the results of which, Secretary STANTON said, would be developed in twenty-four hours.
lead_paragraph: The latest intelligence from Gen. GRANT is that published yesterday morning, which was up to 8 A.M. of Thursday, at which time Gen. GRANT was making important movements, the results of which, Secretary STANTON said, would be developed in twenty-four hours. But they are still in abeyance. We publish this morning a very full and clear account of the movement up to the repulse of the rebels on the North Anna. From the best information obtainable, the rebels appear to be in position south of Saxton's Junction, as our correspondent describes their line as being but a short distance north of the South Anna, and our forces have crossed and thoroughly destroyed the Virginia Central Railroad for several miles west of the Junction.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. WADE reported the bill to regulate the vote power in Washington Territory with a substitute. A motion to take up...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. WADE reported the bill to regulate the vote power in Washington Territory with a substitute. A motion to take up the resolution as to the imprisonment of WILLIAM YOCUM, was rejected. An index to the Internal Revenue Bill was ordered to be printed. Mr. FESSENDEN reported a resolution amendatory of the House resolution, to increase the duty on imports. Mr. SUMNER submitted a resolution, that a State pretending to secede from the Union and battling against the Government was not entitled to a representative in the Senate, until it had been readmitted by a vote of both houses of Congress. The resolution he desired to lie upon the table until it could be referred to the Committee to be appointed on the credentials of Mr. FISHBANK. Mr. SHERMAN reported a bill to encourage navigation. Mr. WADE's bill to enable the people of Colorado to form a Constitution and State Government was passed. The consideration of the Tax Bill was then resumed by the Senate in the Committee of the Whole.

abstract: Grant's Advance, Progress of
snippet: Grant's Advance, Progress of
lead_paragraph: The news we print this morning, announces very important results of Gen. GRANT's latest operations. It seems that on Thursday night he withdrew his army from the south side of the North Anna, and commenced another flank movement down the Pamunky, about twenty miles in a southeasterly direction, and placing his whole army across that river at Hanovertown, by Friday noon, within twelve miles of Richmond, and again threatening LEE's right flank. The movement was bold and hazardous, but it seems to have been quickly executed, and to have been a complete surprise to the enemy. Gen. LEE is reported to have abandoned his strong position on the South Anna, and to be falling back directly upon Richmond. This is probably in consequence of the operations of Gen. GRANT. Richmond will at last be defended by the entire rebel army in Virginia behind its intrenchments, but with equal strength, numbers, guns and ability, which GRANT undoubtedly possesses, we fully believe the destruction of the rebel army, and the fall of the rebel capital, can only be a question of time.

abstract: Comptroller BRENNAN, yesterday, opened thirty proposals, covering seventy-five bids, for an issue of "soldiers' Substitute Bounty Redemption Fund Bonds," at 6 per cent interest, and redeemable in successive annual installments of $500,000 each, from Nov. 1873. The bids footed up $3,784,200. Only two were at par; the others were at
lead_paragraph: Comptroller BRENNAN, yesterday, opened thirty proposals, covering seventy-five bids, for an issue of "soldiers' Substitute Bounty Redemption Fund Bonds," at 6 per cent. interest, and redeemable in successive annual installments of $500,000 each, from Nov. 1873. The bids footed up $3,784,200. Only two were at par; the others were at premium rates of from one-half of one to four and a half per cent. Mr. ETHAN A. ALLEN bid for the whole sum, ($2,000,000,) and nothing less than the whole, at 1 1/4 per cent. This is the largest bid from a private individual ever before made for any City or County stock of New-York. The making of the awards was deferred till to-morrow. The list of the bids may be found elsewhere.

abstract: Garibaldi and the Prince of Wales' Visit to; Marquis de Boissy on; Street Cleaning--Suggestions
snippet: Garibaldi and the Prince of Wales' Visit to; Marquis de Boissy on; Street Cleaning--Suggestions
lead_paragraph: Every one knows our perpetual difficulties with regard to the cleaning of the streets. Under all the various administrations of the City which have taken charge of this important work, no essential progress has been made. Heaps of garbage still fill the gutters in front of the tenement-houses; the refuse left by thousands of families still cumbers the streets and poisons the air; some quarters of the City are noxious with the pestilential stenches and foul odors arising from these heaps of decaying matter. If the lower wards be left long in their present condition, a more fatal pestilence than the typhoid which is now raging, will be inevitable. It will be observed that the more respectable the street, the fewer of these festering piles appear, and the cleaner the drains and alley-ways. Indeed, often in a single street, there will be a distinct boundary-line between filth and cleanliness, where private houses end and tenement houses begin -- so that one part of the City will be comparatively clean and pure and healthy, while the other is fetid with foul odors and desolated with the ravages of disease. The cleanly and respectable part of New-York is probably the healthiest city locality in the world, and were it not for the pestilential winds which sweep over from the neglected portions, it would probably show a higher ratio of births to deaths than any other great city of modern times.
headline: {'main': 'Street-Cleaning--Some Practical Suggestions.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Street-Cleaning--Some Practical Suggestions.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Springbok Case; Memorial Diplomatique on Judge Betts' Decision; Memorial Diplomatique on the Springbok Case
snippet: Springbok Case; Memorial Diplomatique on Judge Betts' Decision; Memorial Diplomatique on the Springbok Case
lead_paragraph: We called attention some time since to an article in the Memorial Diplomatique, of Paris upon Judge BETTS' decision in the case of the prize Springbok, and pointed out what we thought were errors in its statements of fact and in its reasoning. The former were so glaring that we were sure that the writer could never have seen the decision of the court, and such proves to have been the case, for another article has recently made its appearance in that paper, an extract from which we published a few mornings since, in which the writer returns to the charge, having now before him, as he says, "the entire printed text of that judgment."

abstract: The schooner Flash, GRAY, from St. Martin's April 23 and Baracoa 13th inst. with fruit to B.J. WENBURG, arrived yesterday morning. She left there schooner Nathaniel Chase from New-York in six
lead_paragraph: The schooner Flash, GRAY, from St. Martin's April 23 and Baracoa 13th inst. with fruit to B.J. WENBURG, arrived yesterday morning. She left there schooner Nathaniel Chase from New-York in six days. May 22, latitude 31° 17′, longitude 74° 25′, spoke bark Ocean Home, hence 7 days out. April 26, at 7:45 P.M., while on the passage from St. Martin to Baracoa, off Isabella Bay, a vessel hove in sight astern and fired two guns, blank, when we immediately hove to. The sail came up, and proved to be a Spanish man-of-war. While nearing us she commenced shortening sail and never hailed us. They then fired four musket shots at us, the ball of one whistled close to Capt. GRAY's ears and went through the mainsail, near the deck. Was then boarded from the steamer by an officer and six marines, who examined the papers, when they were sent on board the man-of-war, to be examined by her Commander. They were then sent back and the vessel allowed to proceed.
headline: {'main': 'A STRANGE PROCEEDING.; Unwarrantable Conduct of a Spanish Vessel of War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A STRANGE PROCEEDING.; Unwarrantable Conduct of a Spanish Vessel of War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill amending the Charter of Washington, so as to provide for the registration of voters, was passed. Mr. DOOLITTLE introduced a joint resolution of thanks to Col. BAILEY, who saved Admiral PORTER's fleet in the Red River, and authorizing the President to have a gold medal struck and presented to him in the name of the people of the United States. The Senate then considered the Internal Revenue Bill, and after discussion, by a vote of 25 to 15, struck out the clause taxing spirits on hand. After an executive session, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: The effect of the concession to public opinion which was made by the War Department when it undertook, at the opening of the present campaign, to give a succcinct diary of each day's military movements,is beneficially
lead_paragraph: The effect of the concession to public opinion which was made by the War Department when it undertook, at the opening of the present campaign, to give a succcinct diary of each day's military movements,is beneficially apparent in numerous ways. Indeed, we have yet had barely time to estimate the full value of an explicit statement, at brief intervals, of the progress of the campaign -- of the actual advantages gained, of the possible reverses endured, of important changes in the position of the contesting armies, of the estimated number of the wounded, and of measurably accurate records of the lost. To find a just appreciation of the worth of this new provision in our military administration, we should probably have to make personal inquest among the thousands of bereaved households around us, or wait for the judgment of those of our faithful, anxious, eager countrymen abroad, who have had to bear, for many and many a weary week, during all these years of war, the jibes, the contumely, and the leering insolence of open enemies or faithless friends -- when the reckless newsman carried abroad the story of victory to-day, which to-morrow was ruthlessly to turn into defeat.

abstract: Annexed is a transcript of the bids opened by Comptroller BRENNAN, yesterday, for an issue of " Soldiers' Substitute Bounty Redemption Fund Bonds," at six per cent. interest, and redeemable in
lead_paragraph: Annexed is a transcript of the bids opened by Comptroller BRENNAN, yesterday, for an issue of " Soldiers' Substitute Bounty Redemption Fund Bonds," at six per cent. interest, and redeemable in 1873, '74, '75 and '76. The disposition of the bids -- the decision as to their acceptance -- was deferred till to-morrow. Mr. E.A. ALLEN bid for the whole loan $2,000,000 -- and nothing less than the whole -- at 1 1/2 per cent.; without his bid, the loan cannot be awarded entire. Unless he should consent to take half of it, that proportion may be readvertised. Mr. ALLEN's bid is the largest ever before made by one party for any City or County stock of New-York.

abstract: Independence of Labor
snippet: Independence of Labor
lead_paragraph: The system of cooperative manufacturing associations, into which the operatives both in France and England have been entering so largely of late years, in order to secure the capitalist's profits and wages free of superintendence, for division among the workers themselves, has made an important step in advance within the last few weeks, by its extension to the iron trade in England. The master puddlers in the North have sought to put down the Trades' Unions, by dismissing all men who refused to sign a pledge not to belong to them, or in other words, by forming a combination of their own. Both parties are now standing gazing defiantly at each other, but a number of the men have begun work for themselves on the cooperative system, and bid fair to succeed.

abstract: The news this morning from Gen. GRANT is of a very interesting nature. The intelligence is  up to 7 o'clock yesterday morning, at which time he was in the successful execution
lead_paragraph: The news this morning from Gen. GRANT is of a very interesting nature. The intelligence is up to 7 o'clock yesterday morning, at which time he was in the successful execution of another of his remarkable movements upon LEE's flank. On Thursday night our army was all withdrawn from the south bank of the North Anna, and immediately put on the march for Hanover Ferry, on the Pamunkey River, at least twenty miles southeast of his former position, below the confluence of the North and the South Anna, and within twelve miles of Richmond. Our cavalry secured the ferry, capturing seventy-five prisoners, and advancing at once, occupied Hanovertown, a small village, only a short distance from the ferry. Gen. GRANT says the whole army moved with great rapidity and in the highest spirits. The movement was a complete surprise to the enemy, as only a small force of rebels was met. Hanovertown must not be mistaken for Hanover Court-house, which is fully eight miles northwest of the former, and which was, yesterday morning, occupied by BRECKENRIDGE with a force of from three to five thousand infantry and two brigades of cavalry. Hanovertown is about fourteen miles above White House, on the Pamunkey, and not to exceed twelve or fourteen miles from Richmond. By this movement Gen. GRANT has reduced his former distance from Richmond one half, and mast certainly be as near the rebel capital as LEE himself. Our special dispatch announces that LEE has retreated from his strong position at Sexton's Junction which is probably true in view of GRANT's movements. GRANT's supplies must now come to him either by way of Urbanna on the Rappahannock, or by way of West Point on the York.

abstract: Just here, two miles west of the railway bridge across the North Anna, the river is seventyfive yards wide and three or four feet deep at the ford, with a rocky bottom. A steep descent of twenty-five or thirty feet leads down to the ford, across which the southern bank rises precipitously about two hundred feet. This bank is heavily wooded, and has been intrenched by the rebels.

abstract: Gladstone, Mr., Speech of, and Liberalism in England
snippet: Gladstone, Mr., Speech of, and Liberalism in England
lead_paragraph: The open avowal made by Mr. GLADSTONE -- in the recent debate in the House of Commons, on the bill conferring the franchise in boroughs on six-pound householders, instead of ten-pound as at present -- of broadly democratic opinions, disposing him even to favor "manhood suffrage," promises to rouse the English liberals into fresh activity. The course of events, both on the continent and in this country since 1848 has had the effect of almost completelysilencing the agitation for parliamentary reform. Ten years ago it was still so powerful that both Whigs and Tories were compelled to bow to it, by making an extension of the franchise part of their programme. DISRAELI acknowledged its necessity as well as Lord RUSSELL; the only difference between them was about details. But ever since then the movement has been gradually declining, and the apparent break up of our Republic gave it its death-blow. The liberal leaders were all frightened out of their wits by it, and the alacrity with which most of them abandoned both their party and their principles and joined the high Tories in denouncing popular government, will always remain one of the most discreditable incidents in English political history. During the years 1861-62 it would have been hard to find an intelligent man of the middle or upper classes in England who, however warmly he sympathized with the North on general grounds, did not admit that democracy was a failure. There was a complete panic about it amongst all the classes who own any property.
headline: {'main': 'Liberalism in England.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Liberalism in England.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Sir EDWARD GRAHAM, of Esk, County Cumberland, England, whose death in this city is noticed elsewhere, was the ninth Baronet, and succeeded his father, Sir ROBERT GRAHAM, in January, 1852. The first Baronet was created in 1629 by King JAMES I., but the family claim descent from the renowned GRAEME, who, anno 404, commanded the army of FERGUS II., and was Governor of Scotland in the minority of his grandchild, EUGENE second. From the time of this eminent man, the GRAEMES are to be found in the record of Scotland, enjoying the very highest influence. There are at present three baronetcies in the family -- the GRAHAMS of Eskr; the GRAHAMS of Morton Conyers, County of York; the GRAHAMS of Netherby, County Cumberland. The eighth baronet of Esk, father of the baronet just deceased, was one of the claimants to the earldom of Annandale and Hartfill, as descendants of Sir JOHN GRAHAM (second Bart) and Lady MARY JOHNSTON. The title descends to ROBERT JAMES STUART, eldest son of deceased, now Sir ROBERT GRAHAM, tenth baronet, who was born in 1845. -- Montreal Gazette.

abstract: The schooner Flash, from St. Martin's, arrived at this port on Saturday morning. She reports that on the 26th of April, while on the passage from St. Martin to Baracoa, a vessel, which afterward proved to be a Spanish man-of-war, hove in sight and fired two guns, blank, when the Flash hove to. She was then boarded by an officer and six marines, who examined her papers, and then sent them on board the man-of-war to be examined by her commander. They were afterward returned and the vessel allowed to proceed. While nearing the Flash four musket shots were fired from the schooner, one of which passed close to the Captain's head and went through the mainsail, near the deck.

abstract: Between 1 and 2 o'clock yesterday morning flames were discovered issuing from the two-story frame building, No. 75 Division-street, owned by Mr. BERNARD HELLER, and occupied by him as a dwelling and second-hand furniture store. The damage to HELLER's stock and fixtures will amount to about $2,000. He is fully insured in the Rutgers Insurance Company. A portion of the store floor was occupied by MARY KELLY as a fruit-store. Her loss will amount to over $300. She was not insured. The loss on the building is about $1,500; supposed to be insured.

abstract: Military Organization by
snippet: Military Organization by
lead_paragraph: Secretary STANTON has been the best abused man of the war. Many of the disasters have been fathered upon him, and very few of the victories have been put to his credit by the public estimation. Without discussing the exact value of his services to the country, it is worth while to consider occasionally one grand fact which is almost forgotten by the public, and yet which must redound in history especially to the credit of his administration. We mean the wonderful organization by which our immense armies are kept constantly supplied with food, clothing, ammunition and weapons.

abstract: Grant's Flanking Operations
snippet: Grant's Flanking Operations
lead_paragraph: The official dispatches from the War Office, as well as our own dispatches from army headquarters, furnish accounts of the new flanking operation which the Lieutenant-General has under way. Ten days ago, GRANT having previously tried hard to force the lines of Spottsylynia, began his march on their right flank, and instantly LEE was compelled to retreat. He fell back, however, but a few miles, and again assumed battle-front on the north side of the South Anna, a line which they had long been preparing, and meant to defend to the last. To compel a retreat from this position it is, that the new flanking movement was begun on Thursday night last. The army recrossed the North Anna, whose lines it had forced a few days before, struck a short distance east, and then south for the Pamunky, at the Hanovertown crossing of which it arrived on Friday. The full effect of this march on the army of LEE yet remains to be developed. But that development cannot be long delayed. From GRANT's position on the Pamunky, it is only about fifteen miles to the immediate defences of Richmond, which is a shorter distance than LEE has to travel from the South Anna to reach them.
headline: {'main': "Grant's Flanking Operations.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Grant's Flanking Operations.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. WALLACK is determined to end the season gallantly. Although it is far advanced, and the public begins to show an indifference to indoor amusements, Mr. WALLACK keeps up the interest of his programmes, and to-night produces a new play of unusual promise. It is from the pen of Mr. G.H. LEWES -- an English writer, of universal culture, whose labors have graced almost every branch of letters -- and is called "Capt. Bland." A singular feature about this piece is that it has not yet been played in England. Mr. LEWES will receive his first verdict from New-YorK. The caste at Mr. WALLACK's is excellent, and sufficient to insure the best of introduction for "Capt. Bland." The "Wife's Secret" was given last week, and Miss COOMBS appealed to her friends from the vantage ground of a thoroughly melo-dramatic role. We cannot compliment the lady on her success. The manner of the Provinces clings to her yet, and will take long to eradicate. Nothing but the beauty of Miss JANE COOMBS, and her easy, graceful and well-bred presence excuse the common-place outbreaks and positive storminess of her last scene in this play. The male characters were well played, and Miss IONE BURKE did excellently in the most important part she has yet essayed.
lead_paragraph: Mr. WALLACK is determined to end the season gallantly. Although it is far advanced, and the public begins to show an indifference to indoor amusements, Mr. WALLACK keeps up the interest of his programmes, and to-night produces a new play of unusual promise. It is from the pen of Mr. G.H. LEWES -- an English writer, of universal culture, whose labors have graced almost every branch of letters -- and is called "Capt. Bland." A singular feature about this piece is that it has not yet been played in England. Mr. LEWES will receive his first verdict from New-YorK. The caste at Mr. WALLACK's is excellent, and sufficient to insure the best of introduction for "Capt. Bland." The "Wife's Secret" was given last week, and Miss COOMBS appealed to her friends from the vantage ground of a thoroughly melo-dramatic role. We cannot compliment the lady on her success. The manner of the Provinces clings to her yet, and will take long to eradicate. Nothing but the beauty of Miss JANE COOMBS, and her easy, graceful and well-bred presence excuse the common-place outbreaks and positive storminess of her last scene in this play. The male characters were well played, and Miss IONE BURKE did excellently in the most important part she has yet essayed.

abstract: London Economist on U. S. Ability to Bear Taxation; London Saturday Review on U. S. Ability to Bear Taxation; Our Ability to Bear
snippet: London Economist on U. S. Ability to Bear Taxation; London Saturday Review on U. S. Ability to Bear Taxation; Our Ability to Bear
lead_paragraph: The London Economist and the Saturday Review -- neither of them at all partial to this country -- have taken occasion lately to call attention to an important economical fact, developed by this war -- the immense wealth of the population of the Free States. The Economist, in a recent able article on the subject of our "ability to bear taxation," demonstrates, as if against the popular opinion of England, our capacity to bear easily $600,000,000 annual taxation. The writer states that the great peculiarity of American society has not been understood in Europe, -- that is, the large number of people with an income say of $500f. There are not, he admits, a body of men, representing, for instance, such an amount of property as is represented by the British Parliament, but there are a far larger number of small property-holders with taxable incomes than in England. Reckoning the average wage of the American laborers and small farmers at $1 50 a day, which he believes to be a low estimate, and the number of families in the Union at five and a half millions, he thinks the wage-income of America would be equal to the property-income of Great Britain. The income of our middle class he estimates as equal to that of thef British middle class, though the former possesses less accumulated property. Suppose a tax laid corresponding to the English, of three shillings on the pound, he concludes that £120,000,000 could be raised here from direct taxes, without counting the indirect taxes on luxuries. With respect to the willingness of our people to pay, he entertains little doubt that where a debt is so universally held and where a population is so well off, the tax would be paid with but little grumbling. He does not see why an American "farmer" or artisan should not be willing to pay for the American nationality or dignity, or safety, or whatever we consider it, as much as the British banker's clerk for the British -- namely, three shillings on the pound. Grumblings there would be, but there are grumblings also from English rate-payers, and yet the poorest pay with little opposition. There might be many difficulties in collecting, but experience and ingenuity would gradually perfect modes of raising the taxes which would be the most effective and the least annoying. And, as he justly argues, it is hard to fix a limit to the amount of indirect taxes on luxuries which might be raised from so rich a people. His final candid conclusion is that the European public have not at all estimated correctly the American ability to bear taxation.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad. is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

lead_paragraph: The news from Gen. GRANT is up to two o'clock P.M. of Sunday, at which time headquarters were at Hanovertown, and the army was all well across the Pamunky, and then occupied a front about three miles south of that river. On Saturday two divisions of our cavalry had a fight with the rebels, and drove them back upon what Gen. GRANT says appears to be their new line, but he expected to find out all about it that day. Important movements of the several corps were in progress when Gen. GRANT's dispatch left, but no engagement had been fought.

abstract: Kohnstamm, Sentence of
snippet: Kohnstamm, Sentence of
lead_paragraph: SALOMON KOHNSTAMM was yesterday sentenced to an imprisonment of ten years in the State Prison for fraud upon the Government. It was the severest sentence affixed by law to the crime of which he had been convicted; and certainly it would be difficult to find a case, the circumstances of which would warrant a severer punishment, than those of this one, as depicted by Judge NELSON in passing sentence upon the culprit. A long continued course of deliberate crime, whose successful prosecution made necessary the careful planning of fraud and the continual employment of perjury, on the part of a man whose intelligence and standing in the community precluded the idea of his being a tool of others, and who was not led away by the stress of sudden temptation, but was rather the tempter of others, -- the leader in an immense series of frauds upon the Government, such as everywhere have helped to make its wheels drive heavily during all the past three laborious years, -- has thus found its fit end at last.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday the bill to expedite the title to land claims in California was brought up, and, after a long discussion, was laid over. Mr. CONNESS offered an amendment to the Tax Bi11, in lieu of the tax of five per cent, on gold and silver produced from quartz mines and the...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday the bill to expedite the title to land claims in California was brought up, and, after a long discussion, was laid over. Mr. CONNESS offered an amendment to the Tax Bill, in lieu of the tax of five per cent. on gold and silver produced from quartz mines and the beds of rivers, which was adopted. An amendment to the clause in the Tax Bill relative to banking, was offered by Mr. SHERMAN. Several other amendments were also offered but not acted upon.

abstract: ARRIVAL OF THE LOUISIANA DELEGATES TO THE BALTIMORE CONVENTION. Among the passengers who arrived yesterday morning on the steamship Merrimac were the delegates elected by the Union men of Louisiana, to represent that State in the National Union Convention to be held at Baltimore on the 7th prox. In addition to the political powers delegated...
lead_paragraph: ARRIVAL OF THE LOUISIANA DELEGATES TO THE BALTIMORE CONVENTION. -- Among the passengers who arrived yesterday morning on the steamship Merrimac were the delegates elected by the Union men of Louisiana, to represent that State in the National Union Convention to be held at Baltimore on the 7th prox. In addition to the political powers delegated to them, they are charged with the responsible duty of making some arrangement with the Government by which the embarrassments now retarding the commercial prosperity of New-Orleans maybe effectually removed, and trade regulations rendered less stringent. On Sunday, when off the Delaware Coast, the delegation were handsomely entertained by Capt. SAMPSON, of the Merrimac, whose health was proposed by Hon. CUTHBERT BULLITT. Capt. SAMPSON responded, and in turn toasted the Delegation, on whose behalf J.W. THOMAS, Esq., replied at length, pledging the members to an unqualified support of ABRAHAM LINCOLN for the next Presidency. The following is a list of the delegates: Cuthbert Bullitt, Edward H. Durell, M.F. Bonzano, W.R. Fish, R.W. Tallaferro, T.M. Wells, B. Rush Plumley, Alexander A. Atocha, C.A. Weed, J.W. Thomas, H. Millspaugh, A. Cazabat, J.P. Sullivan, and R.V. Montague.

abstract: The Inman steamer City of Baltimore, from Liverpool on the 18th, and Queenstown 19th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning. The conference on the Dano-German war held a meeting on the 17th, at which all the members were ...
lead_paragraph: The Inman steamer City of Baltimore, from Liverpool on the 18th, and Queenstown 19th inst., arrived at this port yesterday morning. The conference on the Dano-German war held a meeting on the 17th, at which all the members were present; but little was done, however, and the conference were to meet again on the 28th. The belief in an approaching fatal termination of the Pope's malady had greatly increased. The London Times of the 14th is quite gloomy over the large emigration from Ireland, by which the Queen loses many subjects. A letter has been written on the same subject by the Roman Catholic Bishop of Toronto to the Roman Catholic Bishops of Ireland. A memorial had been received by the House of Commons from the ship-owners of Liverpool, expressing their regret at the action the Government had taken with regard to the construction of ships for the use of belligerents, and praying them to prevent it for the future.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met yesterday. A preamble and resolutions by Mr. OTTIWELL, paying a high tribute of respect to the character and memory of Gen. WADSWORTH, were unanimously adopted. The Committee on Public Health presented a lengthy report in regard to fat-boiling. They conclude, from the testimony which they took upon the subject, that the business is an...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met yesterday. A preamble and resolutions by Mr. OTTIWELL, paying a high tribute of respect to the character and memory of Gen. WADSWORTH, were unanimously adopted. The Committee on Public Health presented a lengthy report in regard to fat-boiling. They conclude, from the testimony which they took upon the subject, that the business is an absolute nuisance, which ought to be driven beyond the City. To do this, however, they think it necessary to invoke the power of the Board of Health. The report was directed to be published entire in the official papers. The Mayor sent in a message proposing the purchase of the "Field Notes" of a surveyor made under the auspices of the Commissioners for laying out the City, and while he was engaged in preparing a map of it, in 1818, with a view of embodying them in a new and enlarged map. The Mayor vetoed a grant to keep a stand on the sidewalk in Wall-street, because it would interfere with public travel. He expresses willingness, however, to approve similar grants to poor and worthy persons, at points where public convenience may not be infringed. An application from the Police Commissioners for funds (provided in the City Tax Law, but not yet appropriated) for rebuilding Station-houses for the Eighteenth, Twenty-third and Twenty-seventh Precincts, was referred to the Finance Committee. The board adjourned to 2 o'clock P.M. to-morrow.

abstract: Retreat Before Sherman
snippet: Retreat Before Sherman
lead_paragraph: -- A rebel letter from Atlanta, dated the 17th inst., says that "JOHNSTON is falling back gradually, drawing the enemy (SHERMAN) along, waiting for _____, and trying to get a good battle-ground." The blank for whom JOHNSTON was waiting was, most probably, Bishop LEONIDAS POLK and his forces, who, for the last year, have been flitting around Alabama and Mississippi, ready for any work that might turn up -- ready to defend Mobile, to threaten Vicksburgh, to enter Tennessee in the wake of FORREST -- ready for everything, but never accomplishing anything. There is evidence that shortly after the date of the above letter, Blank POLK did actually succeed in joining JOHNSTON, who, however, even after this reinforcement, still continues to "fall back gradually, drawing SHERMAN along," and who, up to the close of last week, was still in search of a "good battle-ground." We would like to know what old JOHNSTON considers a good battle-ground. Was he not satisfied with his position on the heights of Ringgold? What could he find equal to Tunnel Hill, Rocky-faced Ridge, and Buzzard Roost? What could be superior to Resaca, or the mountain fastness of Altoona? What better than the line of the Coosa, or the Etowah? He has, in turn, left all these and other equally tremendous and all but impregnable natural strongholds, and our army has now chased him to within a few miles of Atlanta, which, being in a level country, will furnish a "good battle-ground" for us, but a very bad one for him. "Beware of LEE on the advance, and of JOHNSTON on the retreat," it has been said; but certainly, so far, there has been nothing to be frightened at in this retreat of JOHNSTON. Even the holy blank has not helped him.

abstract: The elements of a half-dozen conventions are manifesting themselves here; one, and probably by far the largest in numbers, favors the nomination of Gen. FREMONT. This, with these, is a foregone conclusion. The Teutonic strata entirely controls this wing.
